Chase has released three studio albums, 2000's ''In the Middle of Something'', 2004's ''The Ride'' and 2009's ''Gettin' There''. Her debut album produced two charting singles on the ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' Country Tracks chart in Canada, of which the highest was the No.&nbsp;11-peaking title track.<ref name=\"RPM Country Singles\">{{cite web|url=http://www.bac-lac.gc.ca/eng/discover/films-videos-sound-recordings/rpm/Pages/list.aspx?OCRText=Diane+Chase&ChartEn=Country+Singles&|title=Diane Chase - Country Singles|work=RPM|accessdate=February 27, 2023}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Chad_Klinger","to":"Chad Klinger"}],"pages":{"26161811":{"pageid":26161811,"ns":0,"title":"Chad Klinger","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Chad Klinger\n| image           =\n| caption         =\n| image_size      =\n| origin          = [[Lashburn, Saskatchewan]], Canada\n| instrument      =\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 1998\u20132013\n| label           = CK\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = {{official website|http://www.chadklinger.com/}}\n}}\n'''Chad Klinger''' is a Canadian [[country music]] artist. Klinger recorded his self-titled debut CD in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] in 1998, produced by Dean Sams of [[Lonestar]].<ref name=\"jam\">{{cite web |last=Griwkowsky |first=Fish |title=From swinging to singing |url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/K/Klinger_Chad/2000/09/22/746647.html |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130115064217/http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/K/Klinger_Chad/2000/09/22/746647.html |url-status=usurped |archive-date=January 15, 2013 |work=[[Edmonton Sun]] |date=September 2, 2000|accessdate=February 11, 2010}}</ref> Two singles released from the project, \"Who Needs the Moon\" and \"Bring It On,\" reached the Top 30 of the ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' Country Tracks chart.<ref name=\"rpm1\">{{cite web |title=Country Singles |url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-119.01-e.php?&file_num=nlc008388.8377&volume=69&issue=15&issue_dt=August%2002%201999&type=1&interval=24&PHPSESSID=0csnhpv20m1hqesodipjde7ca1 |work=[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]] |date=August 2, 1999 |accessdate=February 11, 2010 |work=[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]] |date=January 1, 2000|accessdate=February 11, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013030130/http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-119.01-e.php?&file_num=nlc008388.10030&volume=70&issue=11&issue_dt=January%2017%202000&type=1&interval=24&PHPSESSID=0csnhpv20m1hqesodipjde7ca1 |archive-date=October 13, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref> He took a break from his recording career in 2000 to enroll in the [[University of Alberta]].<ref name=\"ualberta\">{{cite web |last=Capello |first=Laura |title=Country star puts 'class' in his act |url=http://www.folio.ualberta.ca/38/01/08.html |work=Folio |date=September 8, 2000 |accessdate=February 11, 2010 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706210200/http://www.folio.ualberta.ca/38/01/08.html |archivedate=July 6, 2011 }}</ref>\n\nKlinger returned to the music business in November 2009 with the single \"Minivan Man,\" which has reached the Top 50 of the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Canadian Country Singles chart.<ref name=\"bbiz\">{{cite magazine |title=Canadian Update |url=http://www.billboard.biz/billboardbiz/photos/pdf/canadian_update_021010.pdf |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=February 1, 2010 |accessdate=February 11, 2010 |archive-date=May 12, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200512001118/https://www.billboard.com/business |url-status=dead }}</ref> His second album, ''The Man I Am Inside'', was released in April 2010.\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:16em;\"| Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"65\"| [[RPM (magazine)|CAN Country]]\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1999\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[Who Needs the Moon]]\"\n| 12\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"2\"| ''Chad Klinger''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Bring It On\"\n| 23\n|-\n| 2009\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Minivan Man\"\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"5\"| ''The Man I Am Inside''\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 2010\n! scope=\"row\"| \"The Night Ain't Over Yet\" <small>(with [[Gord Bamford]])</small>\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I'm Gonna Be There\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Three Words Aren't Enough\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2011\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Beer Cans and Bonfires\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*{{official website|http://www.chadklinger.com/}}\n\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Klinger, Chad}}\n[[Category:Canadian country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Canadian male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]\n[[Category:University of Alberta alumni]]\n[[Category:Singers from Saskatchewan]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Gil_Grand","to":"Gil Grand"}],"pages":{"4220537":{"pageid":4220537,"ns":0,"title":"Gil Grand","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Canadian country music singer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2023}}\n{{BLP sources|date=August 2018}}\n{{Infobox musical artist | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n|image=\n| name            = Gil Grand |\n| background      = solo_singer |\n| birth_name      = Gilles Lagrandeur |\n| alias           = |\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1968|01|08}} |\n| death_date      = |\n| origin          = [[Greater Sudbury|Sudbury]], Ontario, Canada |\n| instruments     = Vocals, guitar |\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]] |\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter |\n| years_active    = 1998\u2013present |\n| label           = [[Monument Records|Monument]]<br />[[Royalty Records|Royalty]]\n| website         = [http://www.gilgrand.com/ www.gilgrand.com] |\n}}\n\n'''Gil Grand''' (born '''Gilles Lagrandeur''', January 8, 1968) is a Canadian [[country music]] singer. Since 1998, he has released three studio albums: ''[[Famous First Words (Gil Grand album)|Famous First Words]]'' (1998), ''Burnin{{'}}'' (2002) and ''Somebody's Someone'' (2006).<ref>{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p380511|pure_url=yes}}|title=Biography: Gil Grand|last=Seida|first=Linda|publisher=[[All Media Guide|AMG]]|accessdate=May 13, 2010}}</ref> He has charted several singles on the Canadian country singles charts as well, including the ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' top ten single \"[[Famous First Words (song)|Famous First Words]]\" in 1998.\n\n==Career==\nIn 1998, Grand signed a record deal with [[Monument Records]]' Nashville division. His debut album, ''[[Famous First Words (Gil Grand album)|Famous First Words]]'', helped him receive three [[Canadian Country Music Awards]] nominations including Male Vocalist of the Year, Album of the Year and [[Wrangler Jeans|Wrangler]] Rising Star.\n\n''Burnin{{'}}'' was released in December 2002. \"Cry A Little,\" \"Break It to Them Gently,\" \"Run\" and the title track were all released as singles. Grand earned five CCMA nominations in 2003 including Single of the Year, [[SOCAN]] Song of the Year, Video of the Year, and Best Album Graphics, and won Independent Male Artist of the Year.\n\nHe released his third album, ''Somebody's Someone'', in March 2006. In 2006, Grand and his younger brother [[Jake Mathews|Jake]] joined forces for Raise the Roof, a tour that took them from British Columbia to Ontario, raising awareness of Ronald McDonald House Charities. Grand now lives in Nashville where he is co-owner and president of Grand & Gee Music Group.\n\n==Discography==\n'''Studio albums'''\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:14em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:20em;\"| Details\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Lisa_Hewitt","to":"Lisa Hewitt"}],"pages":{"24916834":{"pageid":24916834,"ns":0,"title":"Lisa Hewitt","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Canadian country music singer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Lisa Hewitt\n| image           = Lisa_Hewitt.jpg\n| caption         = Lisa Hewitt, November 2005\n| image_size      = \n| background      = solo_singer\n| origin          = Canada\n| instrument      = \n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer\n| years_active    = 1999\u2013present\n| label           = Socan, [[Royalty Records|Royalty]], 306\n| associated_acts = \n| website             = {{official website|http://www.lisahewitt.com}}\n}}\n'''Lisa Hewitt''' is a Canadian [[country music]] singer. Hewitt released her self-titled debut album on the independent Socan Records in 1999. Her second album, ''The Road I Chose'', was released in 2004 by [[Royalty Records]]. Its first single, \"One of These Goodbyes,\" reached the Top 25 on the ''[[Radio & Records]]'' Canadian country singles chart. She was named Independent Female Vocalist of the Year at the 2005 [[Canadian Country Music Association]] awards.<ref name=\"cmn\">{{cite web|url=http://secure4.worldsites.net/countrymusicnews-ca/news.ihtml?step=2&article_id=953 |title=2005 CCMA Award Winners |publisher=[[Country Music News]] |accessdate=October 31, 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20110721214751/http://secure4.worldsites.net/countrymusicnews-ca/news.ihtml?step=2&article_id=953 |archivedate=July 21, 2011 }}</ref> Hewitt was featured in 2006 on the [[CMT (Canada)|CMT]] series ''Plucked'', a documentary about six country music stars in training.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channelcanada.com/Article1517.html |title=CMT Premieres New Original Production Plucked this october |publisher=Channel Canada |accessdate=October 31, 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100104142711/http://channelcanada.com/Article1517.html |archivedate=January 4, 2010 }}</ref> In 2009, Hewitt was signed to 306 Records.<ref>[http://www.306records.com/news.cfm?JournalID=16723&UserID=22 306 Records] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090302032447/http://www.306records.com/news.cfm?JournalID=16723&UserID=22 |date=March 2, 2009 }}</ref> Her third album, ''Fearless'', was released in March 2009.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:19em;\"| Album details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Lisa Hewitt''\n| \n* Release date: September 1, 1999\n* Label: Socan Records\n* Formats: CD, [[Compact cassette|cassette]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''The Road I Chose''\n| \n* Release date: October 19, 2004\n* Label: [[Royalty Records]]\n* Formats: CD, [[music download]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Fearless''\n| \n* Release date: March 31, 2009\n* Label: 306 Records\n* Formats: CD, music download\n|-\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"65\"| [[Radio & Records|CAN Country]]<br><ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-RandR/2000s/2004/RR-2004-12-17.pdf|title=Canada Country Top 30|journal=[[Radio & Records]]|date=December 17, 2004}}</ref>\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2000\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Midnight in the Garden of Love\"\n| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"3\"| ''Lisa Hewitt''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I Just Want to Hold You\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2001\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Slide Over I'm Driving\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2004\n! scope=\"row\"| \"One of These Goodbyes\"\n| 21\n| rowspan=\"4\"| ''The Road I Chose''\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2005\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Say It's Gone\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Take Me There\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2006\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Somebody\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2009\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Better in Texas\"\n| \u2014\n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''Fearless''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Too Used to Loving You\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2014\n! scope=\"row\"| \"If I Could\"\n| \u2014\n| {{n/a}}\n|-\n| colspan=\"4\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| 2006\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Somebody\"\n| [[Stephano Barberis]]\n|}\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! Year\n! Association\n! Category\n! Result\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2005\n| rowspan=\"4\"| [[Canadian Country Music Association]]\n| Chevy Trucks Rising Star Award\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Independent Female Artist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2006\n| Independent Female Artist of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| 2007\n| Independent Female Artist of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*{{official website|http://www.lisahewitt.com}}\n*[http://www.cmt.ca/Artist/LisaHewitt Lisa Hewitt] at [[CMT (Canada)|CMT]]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Hewitt, Lisa}}\n[[Category:Canadian women country singers]]\n[[Category:Canadian country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:306 Records artists]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"The_Wolfe_Brothers","to":"The Wolfe Brothers"}],"pages":{"42980017":{"pageid":42980017,"ns":0,"title":"The Wolfe Brothers","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Australian country duo}}\n{{For|the street gang of the same name|Indian Posse}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=July 2014}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = The Wolfe Brothers\n| image           = Wolfe Brothers.jpg\n| alt             = \n| caption         = The Wolfe Brothers in 2016\n| origin          = [[Longley, Tasmania]], Australia\n| years_active    = 2010\u2013present\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[country rock]]}}\n| label           = [[Bertelsmann Music Group|BMG]]\n| current_members =\n* Tom Wolfe\n* Nick Wolfe\n| past_members    =\n* Casey Kostuik\n* Brodie Rainbird\n| website         = {{URL|http://www.thewolfebrothers.com}}\n}}\n'''The Wolfe Brothers''' are an Australian [[country music]] duo consisting of brothers Tom and Nick Wolfe. The group formerly included childhood friends Brodie Rainbird and Casey Kostiuk. The Wolfe Brothers rose to prominence after placing second in [[Australia's Got Talent (season 6)|season six]] of ''[[Australia's Got Talent]]''.\n\n==Career==\n===Early years to 2012: Formation and ''Australia's Got Talent''===\nTom and Nick Wolfe grew up on a small berry farm outside [[Hobart, Tasmania]]. Their father Malcolm and uncle Tony played in a band with their parents, called ''The Wolfe Family Orchestra''.<ref name=\"ABC Emily\">{{cite web|url= https://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-07-21/wolfe-brothers-berry-farming-country-music-in-a-days-work/8726552 |title= The Wolfe Brothers take on second family legacy to combine berry farming with country music|website=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=21 July 2017|access-date=23 February 2023 |author= Emilie Gramenz}}</ref>\n\nNick Wolfe says, \"We come from four generations of farmers and musicians.\" Their father guided Nick to the guitar and Tom to the piano, perhaps with \"the intention of starting a band with us\". Their mother filled the family home with music, exposing her children to 1990s country staples like [[Garth Brooks]] and [[Billy Ray Cyrus]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://musictasmania.org/connect/artists/wolfe-brothers |title= The Wolfe Brothers |website=Music Tasmania| access-date=23 February 2023}}</ref>\n\nThe Wolfe Brothers were formed by brothers Nick (guitar and vocals) and Tom Wolfe (bass and vocals), Brodie Rainbird (guitar) and Casey Kostiuk (drums).<ref>{{cite web|url= https://tinselandtapshoes.com/2017/05/08/thoughts-on-lee-kernaghan-25th-anniversary-tour/|title= THOUGHTS ON LEE KERNAGHAN \u2013 25TH ANNIVERSARY TOUR |website=Tinsel and Tap Shoes|date=May 2017|access-date=23 February 2023}}</ref><ref name=\"ABC Emily\"/> During their high school years all four played in different bands, covering songs by their glam rock and heavy metal music heroes. After leaving school they formed ''The Wolfe Brothers'', and for six years played covers in pubs and clubs across Tasmania.<ref name=\"ICCMM\">{{cite web|url=https://www.lccmm.com.au/the-wolfe-bros/|website=ICCMM| title=The Wolfe Bros.|date=19 November 2018|access-date=23 February 2023}}</ref>\n\nIn May 2010, The Wolfe Brothers self-released a self-titled debut EP.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/au/album/the-wolfe-brothers-ep/1440862650|title= The Wolfe Brothers EP|website=Apple Music|date=May 2010|access-date=18 April 2020}}</ref>\n\nIn 2012, The Wolfe Brothers auditioned for the [[Australia's Got Talent (season 6)|sixth season]] of [[Australia's Got Talent]], where they placed second behind [[Andrew De Silva]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kixcountry.com.au/hottest-country-news/44377-the-wolfe-brothers-perform-in-studio|title=The Wolfe Brothers dropped by the studios for a chat.|website=Kix Country|date=2013|access-date=23 February 2023}}</ref>\n\n===2013\u20132019: ''It's On'' to ''Country Heart''===\n[[File:The Wolfe Brothers with Big Stu & MJ.jpg|alt=The Wolfe Brothers pose for a photo with radio hosts Big Stu & MJ|thumb|The Wolfe Brothers posing for a photo with radio hosts [[Planet Country with Big Stu & MJ|Big Stu and MJ]] during the 2018 [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]].]]\n\nIn January 2013, The Wolfe Brothers released their debut studio album ''It's On'', which peaked at number 18 on the [[ARIA Charts]]. The album spawned three county top 10 singles, including their first #1 song and #1 video \"The Girl, The Bottle, The Memory\".<ref name=\"ICCMM\"/>\n\nThe Wolfe Brothers were special guests on [[Lee Kernaghan]]'s 2013\u20132014 ''Beautiful Noise Tour''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=James|title=Wolfe Brothers to support \"real gentleman\" Kernaghan for Bunbury gig|url=http://www.bunburymail.com.au/story/2266317/wolfe-brothers-to-support-real-gentleman-kernaghan-for-bunbury-gig/|access-date=6 June 2014|publisher=Bunbury Mail|date=7 May 2014}}</ref>\n\nAt the 2014 [[Country Music Awards of Australia]], The Wolfe Brothers were nominated for four awards and won the New Australian Artist of the Year at the [[CMC Music Awards]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Martain|first1=Tim|title=Tassie band Wolfe Brothers win major Country Music Channel award|url=http://www.themercury.com.au/news/tasmania/tassie-band-wolfe-brothers-win-major-country-music-channel-award/story-fnj4f7k1-1226855612710|access-date=6 June 2014|publisher=The Mercury|date=16 March 2014}}</ref><ref name=\"DM Mar14\"/>\n\nIn September 2014, The Wolfe Brothers released their second studio album, ''Nothin' But Trouble'', which peaked at number 13 on the ARIA Charts. The album spawned the single \"That Kinda Night\", which reached number 1 on the country singles chart.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://countrytrackschart.com.au/index.php?chartid=24|title=Country Songs Top 40 Australian Airplay Chart|website=countrytrackschart.com.au|access-date=15 July 2019}}</ref> The album's second and third singles, \"You Got to Me\" and \"Born and Bred\" became the group's third and fourth number 1 on the country charts and the CMC video chart.<ref name=\"ICCMM\"/>\n\nIn September 2015, a live album titled ''Live at CMC Rocks QLD 2015'' was released.<ref name=\"ICCMM\"/>\n\nThe group supported Kernaghan on his 2015 ''The Songs and the Stories Tour''. Tom Wolfe later saying, \"Touring with Lee has been a dream come true for us. He has taught us so much and it is still a little surreal to look across the stage and realise we are actually performing with one of our childhood heroes \u2013 the great Lee Kernaghan\".<ref name=\"ICCMM\"/>\n\nIn June 2016, the group released their third studio album, ''This Crazy Life'' album, which peaked at number 10 on the ARIA charts. The album was recorded in Nashville, USA over three months between November 2015 and February 2016 under the guidance of producer Luke Wooten.<ref name=\"ICCMM\"/>\n\nIn 2016, The Wolfe Brothers were nominated in three categories in the CMC Music Awards, winning the CMC Group of the Year Award; their second CMC Award.<ref name=\"ICCMM\"/><ref name=\"Knox\"/>\n\nLate in 2016, Nick and Tom's father, Malcolm died of cancer.<ref name=\"ABC Emily\"/>\n\nIn 2017 they recorded the single \"Damn Good Mates\" with Lee Kernaghan for Kernaghan's ''[[The 25th Anniversary Album (Lee Kernaghan album)|25th Anniversary Album]]''. In 2017 The Wolfe Brothers won Australian Group/Duo of the Year at the [[Planet Country with Big Stu & MJ|Planet Country's]] Music for a New Generation Awards.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.planetcountryradio.com.au/mfang-awards-2017|title=Planet Country Radio Show|website=Planet Country Radio Show|access-date=30 October 2018}}</ref>\n\nIn April 2018, the group released their fourth studio album ''Country Heart'', which peaked at number 9 on the ARIA Charts. The singles \"Ain't Seen It Yet\" and \"Country Heart\" both reaching number 1 on the country singles chart.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://countrytrackschart.com.au/index.php?chartid=208|title=Country Songs Top 40 Australian Airplay Chart|website=countrytrackschart.com.au|access-date=15 July 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://countrytrackschart.com.au/index.php?chartid=270|title=Country Songs Top 40 Australian Airplay Chart|website=countrytrackschart.com.au|access-date=15 July 2019}}</ref>\n\nAt the 2019 [[Country Music Awards of Australia]], the group won including Album of the Year, Contemporary Country Album of the Year, Group or Duo of the Year and  Song of the Year with \"Ain't Seen It Yet\".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/here-are-all-the-winners-from-the-2019-golden-guitar-awards|title=Here Are All The Winners From The 2019 Golden Guitar Awards {{!}} Country Music Channel on Foxtel|date=28 July 2019|website=Country Music Channel|language=en-AU|access-date=15 July 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2019-01-27/golden-guitars-wolfe-brothers-win-top-country-music-awards/10753724|title= Wolfe Brothers, Andrew Swift, Beccy Cole and Travis Collins win Golden Guitars|publisher=ABC|date=27 January 2019|access-date=27 January 2019 }}</ref>\n\n===2020\u2013present: ''Kids on Cassette'' to ''Livin' the Dream''===\nIn March 2020, Brodie Rainbird announced he is leaving the group as Casey Kostiuk had done some years earlier. However, both continue to play with the duo on tour.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/thewolfebrothers/videos/223840938754887/?t=1|title= Hey everyone, we have a bit of an announcement. Brodie has decided to step back as an official member of The Wolfe Brothers. |website=[[Facebook]]|date=2 March 2020| access-date=23 February 2023}}</ref>\n\nIn April 2020 the band worldwide deal with global independent label, BMG, in partnership with the [[BBR Music Group]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://themusicnetwork.com/the-wolfe-brothers-bmg/|title=Country rockers The Wolfe Brothers sign global record deal with BMG|date=2020-04-14|website=The Music Network|access-date=2020-04-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2020/04/bmg-signs-australian-duo-the-wolfe-brothers-to-global-label-deal/ |title =BMG Signs Australian Duo The Wolfe Brothers To Global Label Deal|website=Music Row|date=April 2020| access-date=23 February 2023}}</ref>\n\nOn 17 April 2020, the group released their first single on the label entitled \"No Breaks\".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/au/album/no-brakes-single/1502092204|title=No Brakes - single|website=Apple Music|access-date=18 April 2020}}</ref>\n\nThe Wolfe Brothers' fifth studio album, ''Kids on Cassette'' was released in July 2021, the same day they celebrated their 15th consecutive #1 single on the Country Airplay Charts with \"Startin' Something\"<ref>{{cite web|url= https://amnplify.com.au/the-wolfe-brothers-celebrate-their-15th-consecutive-country-1-single-on-the-day-they-release-their-fifth-studio-album/|title= THE WOLFE BROTHERS celebrate their 15th consecutive country #1 single on the day they release their fifth studio album|website= amnplify|date=July 2021|access-date=24 February 2023}}</ref> The album debuted at number 6 on the [[ARIA Charts]].\n\nIn November 2021, they joined Australian-born, Canadian country artist [[Gord Bamford]] for the Australian version of his single \"[[Drink Along Song]]\" in 2021.<ref>{{cite web|title=Drink Along Song by Gord Bamford and The Wolfe Brothers \u2013 Song of the Day|url=https://countrytown.com.au/reviews/drink-along-song-by-gord-bamford-and-the-wolfe-brothers-song-of-the-day/YP14cnV0d3Y/19-11-21|date=18 November 2021|first=Mallory|last=Arbour|work=Countrytown}}</ref>\n\nThe Wolfe Brothers were nominated for seven awards at the 2022 CMAAs, winning two.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://themusic.com.au/news/2021-golden-guitar-award-nominations/iSyRnZyfnoE/23-11-21 | title=Troy Cassar-Daley, The Wolfe Brothers Top Golden Guitar Award Nominations |website=[[The Music (magazine)|The Music]]|date= 23 November 2021|access-date=23 February 2023}}</ref>\n\nIn April 2022, the Wolfe Brothers commenced their ''Startin' Something'' tour across Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hotoffthepress.com.au/news/2022/04/the-wolfe-brothers-kick-off-their-startin-something-national-tour-with-two-wins-at-the-golden-guitars.html|website=hot off the press|title=The Wolfe Brothers Kick Off Their Startin' Something Tour|date=27 April 2022| access-date=23 February 2023}}</ref>\n\nThe Wolfe Brothers' sixth studio album ''Livin' the Dream'' was released on 14 April 2023.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jbhifi.com.au/products/cd-wolfe-brothers-the-livin-the-dream-cd|title=Livin' the Dream|website=[[JB Hi-Fi]]|access-date=21 February 2023}}</ref> The album was written during the pandemic over Zoom writing sessions with writers all over the world. Nick Wolfe produced the album with Rod McCormack and Matt Fell. Nick said \"Sonically, ''Livin' the Dream'' is a conscious decision by us to get back to our country roots. We explored a lot of pop and rock territory on our last record but we want to come out of the gate swinging country style and give everyone a taste of what's to come for the rest of this record that we're really proud of.\"\n\nThe Wolfe Brothers were nominated for six awards at the 2024 CMAAs.<ref name=\"CMAA23noms1\">{{cite web|url=https://www.tcmf.com.au/gga-nominees|title=Toyota 52nd Golden Guitar Awards|website=TCMF|date=20 November 2023|access-date=23 November 2023}}</ref><ref name=\"CMAA23noms2\">{{cite web|url=https://www.tcmf.com.au/nominees-announced-for-the-52nd-country-music-awards-of-australia-the-toyota-golden-guitar-awards#:~:text=Tamworth%20Regional%20Council%20will%20present,livestreamed%20via%20the%20Festival%20website.|title=Nominees Announced for the 52nd Country Music Awards |website=TCMF|date=20 November 2023|access-date=23 November 2023}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n====Studio albums====\n{|class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n!rowspan=\"2\"| Title\n!rowspan=\"2\"| Details\n!colspan=\"1\"| Peak chart positions\n|-\n!style=\"width:3em;font-size:90%\"|[[ARIA Charts|AUS]]<br><ref>{{cite web|url=https://australian-charts.com/search.asp?search=The+Wolfe+brothers&cat=a|title=The Wolfe Brothers at Australian Charts|website=Australian Charts|access-date=18 April 2020}}</ref>\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"|''It's On''\n|\n*Released: 18 January 2013\n*Label: ABC Music/Universal Music Australia (3724819)\n| 18\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"|''Nothin' But Trouble''\n|\n*Released: 5 September 2014\n*Label: ABC Music/Universal Music Australia (3791761)\n| 13\n|-\n! Title \n! Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"|''Live at CMC Rocks QLD 2015''\n|\n*Released: 18 September 2015<ref name=\"Live\">{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/au/album/live-at-cmc-rocks-qld-2015/1440862696|title=Live at CMC Rocks QLD 2015|website=Apple Music|access-date=18 April 2020}}</ref>\n*Label: The Wolfe Brothers/ ABC\n|}\n\n===Extended plays===\n{|class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n! Title \n! Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"|''The Wolfe Brothers''\n|\n*Released: May 2010<ref>{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/au/album/the-wolfe-brothers-ep/1440862650|title=The Wolfe Brothers (EP)|website=Apple Music|access-date=18 April 2020}}</ref>\n*Label: Wolfe Brothers\n|}\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n===AIR Awards===\nThe Australian Independent Record Awards (commonly known informally as [[AIR Awards]]) is an annual awards night to recognise, promote and celebrate the success of Australia's Independent Music sector.\n{{awards table}}\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| [[AIR Awards of 2019|2019]]\n| ''Country Heart''\n| Best Independent Country Album\n| {{nom}}\n| <ref name=\"2019nom\">{{cite web|url=https://scenestr.com.au/music/2019-air-awards-nominees-20190328|title=2019 AIR Awards Nominees|date=28 March 2019 |access-date=20 August 2020}}</ref>\n|-\n| [[AIR Awards of 2022|2022]]\n| ''Kids on Cassette''\n| Best Independent Country Album or EP\n| {{nom}}\n| <ref>{{cite web|url=https://musicfeeds.com.au/news/nominees-announced-for-air-independent-music-awards-2022/|title=Nominees Announced For AIR Independent Music Awards 2022|website=musicfeeds|date=1 June 2022|access-date=1 June 2022}}</ref><ref name=\"AIRwins2022\">{{Cite web|url=https://musicfeeds.com.au/news/genesis-owusu-wins-big-at-the-2022-air-awards/|title=Genesis Owusu Wins Big At The 2022 AIR Awards|website=[[MusicFeeds]]|date=5 August 2022|access-date=6 August 2022|author=Tyler Jenke}}</ref>\n|-\n| [[AIR Awards of 2024|2024]]\n| ''Livin' the Dream''\n| Best Independent Country Album or EP\n| {{nom}}\n| <ref name=\"AIR 2024 noms\">{{cite web|url=https://themusic.com.au/industry/2024-air-awards-nominees-genesis-owusu-cub-sport-rvg-teen-jesus-more/3f1j8fDz8vU/14-05-24|title=2024 AIR Awards Nominees: Genesis Owusu, Cub Sport, RVG, Teen Jesus & More| website= [[The Music (magazine)|The Music]]|date=14 May 2024|access-date=16 May 2024}}</ref>\n{{end}}\n\n===APRA Awards===\nThe [[APRA Awards (Australia)|APRA Awards]] are presented annually from 1982 by the [[Australasian Performing Right Association]] (APRA), \"honouring composers and songwriters\". They commenced in 1982.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apra-amcos.com.au/APRAAwards/MusicAwards/History.aspx |title=APRA History |publisher=[[Australasian Performing Right Association]] (APRA) &#124; [[Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners Society]] (AMCOS) |access-date=25 April 2022 }}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| [[APRA Music Awards of 2014|2014]] \n| \"The Girl, the Bottle, the Memory\" (Nicholas Wolfe)\n| Country Work of the Year\n| {{nominated}}\n| <ref name=\"CWotYNom\">{{cite web | url = http://apraamcos.com.au/awards/2014-awards/apra-music-awards/country-work-of-the-year/ | title = Country Work of the Year | publisher = Australasian Performing Right Association (APRA) &#124; Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners Society (AMCOS) | year = 2014 | access-date = 2 January 2016 }}</ref>\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===ARIA Music Awards===\nThe [[ARIA Music Awards]] is an annual awards ceremony that recognises excellence, innovation, and achievement across all genres of [[Australian music]].The Wolfe Brothers have been nominated thrice.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.ariaawards.com.au/history/search/?text=Wolfe%20brothers|title = ARIA Awards Search Results \u2013 Wolfe Brothers|website =ARIA|access-date = 26 April 2020}}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n! The Wolfe Brothers have won nine awards.<ref name=\"CMAAwins\">{{cite web|url=https://www.country.com.au/awards/past-award-winners|title=Past Award Winners|website=Country|access-date=26 April 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"CMAA2014noms\">{{cite web|url=https://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/finalists-for-the-2014-cmaa-golden-guitars-announced|title=The finalists for the 42nd Annual CMAA Country (CMA) are and annual American awards show which honours country music artists and broadcasters and recognizes outstanding achievement in the country music industry. The Wolfe Brothers have one nomination.\n\n{{awards table}}\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| [[56th Annual Country Music Association Awards|2022]]\n| The Wolfe Brothers\n| Global Country Artist Award\n| {{nom}}\n| <ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.billboard.com/music/awards/2022-cma-international-award-nominees-ashley-mcbryde-brothers-osborne-1235137577/ | title=Ashley McBryde & Brothers Osborne Among 2022 CMA International Awards Nominees | magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] }}</ref>\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===CMC Awards===\n[[CMC Music Awards|The CMC Awards]] are awarded annually by [[Country Music Channel]] Australia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2014/03/cmc-music-awards-winners.html|title=CMC Music Awards: winners|publisher=TV Tonight|date=15 March 2014|access-date=24 February 2023}}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| 2014|| The Wolfe Brothers || New Australian Artist of the Year|| {{won}} || <ref name=\"DM Mar14\">{{cite news | url = https://www.dailymercury.com.au/news/morgan-evans-fans-choice-cmc-country-music-awards/2199901/ | title = Morgan Evans Is Fans' Choice in CMC Country Music Awards | work = [[Daily Mercury]] | publisher = News Corp Australia | date = 15 March 2014 | access-date = 23 February 2023 }}</ref>\n|-\n| 2016|| The Wolfe Brothers ||  CMC Group Of The Year || {{won}} || <ref name=\"Knox\">{{cite news | url = https://tvtonight.com.au/2016/03/cmc-music-awards-2016-winners.html | title = CMC Music Awards 2016: Winners | last = Knox | first = David | work = TV Tonight | date = 11 March 2016 | access-date = 23 February 2023 }}</ref>\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===National Live Music Awards===\nThe [[National Live Music Awards]] (NLMAs) are a broad recognition of Australia's diverse live industry, celebrating the success of the Australian live scene. The awards commenced in 2016.\n{{awards table}}\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| [[National Live Music Awards of 2019|2019]]\n| The Wolfe Brothers\n| Live Country Act of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n| <ref name=\"2019noms\">{{cite web|url=https://www.nlmas.com.au/2019/10/22/here-are-your-2019-national-live-music-awards-nominees/|title=HERE ARE YOUR 2019 NATIONAL LIVE MUSIC AWARDS NOMINEES!|website=NLMA|date=22 October 2020|access-date=5 September 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"2019wins\">{{cite web|url=https://www.nlmas.com.au/2019/12/05/and-the-winners-of-the-2019-national-live-music-awards-are/|title=AND THE WINNERS OF THE 2019 NATIONAL LIVE MUSIC AWARDS ARE\u2026|website=NLMA|date=5 December 2020|access-date=5 September 2020}}</ref>\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n{{Australia's Got Talent}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Wolfe Brothers, The}}\n[[Category:2010 establishments in Australia]]\n[[Category:Australian country music groups]]\n[[Category:Australian country rock groups]]\n[[Category:Australian musical groups]]\n[[Category:Tasmanian musical groups]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Tasmania]]\n[[Category:Australia's Got Talent contestants]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Tania_Kernaghan","to":"Tania Kernaghan"}],"pages":{"7721679":{"pageid":7721679,"ns":0,"title":"Tania Kernaghan","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Australian country music singer (born 1968)}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2020}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=July 2017}}\n{{Infobox musical artist|<!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name             = Tania Kernaghan\n| image            = Tania Kernaghan.jpg\n| background       = solo_singer <!-- mandatory format: this cannot be changed -->\n| birth_date       = {{Birth date and age|df=y|1968|7|18}}\n| birth_place      = [[Albury]], [[New South Wales]], Australia\n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation       = Singer\n| years_active     = 1992\u2013present\n| label            = [[ABC Records]] KCR\n| associated_acts  = [[Lee Kernaghan]], [[Ray Kernaghan]] Fiona Kernaghan Greg Kernaghan\n| website          = [http://www.taniakernaghan.com Tania Kernaghan Official Site]\n}}\n\n'''Tania Maree Kernaghan''' (born 18 July 1968) is an Australian country music singer.\n\nDuring her career, Tania has earned fifteen number one radio hits singles, numerous awards, sell out concerts and record sales in the hundreds of thousands. She has also performed at the [[Grand Ole Opry]] in Nashville.\n\nTania is Vice Patron for ''Riding for the Disabled Association'' Australia (RDA). <ref name=About>{{cite web|title=Biography|url=http://www.taniakernaghan.com/biography.html|website=Tania Kernaghan official website|accessdate=1 July 2017}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nIn 1992, Kernaghan released her first single, \"I'll Be Gone\".<ref name=About />\n\nHer first album, ''December Moon'', was released in January 1996. It was nominated for Best Country Album at the [[ARIA Music Awards of 1996]]. The album was certified Gold by [[Australian Recording Industry Association|ARIA]] in 1997<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/aria-charts-accreditations-albums-1997.htm|title=ARIA Charts \u2013 Accreditations \u2013 1997 Albums|website=aria.com.au|access-date=7 April 2016}}</ref> and Platinum in 1998.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/aria-charts-accreditations-albums-1998.htm|title=ARIA Charts \u2013 Accreditations \u2013 1998 Albums|website=aria.com.au|access-date=7 April 2016}}</ref>\n\nAt the time of releasing her fourth album ''Higher Ground'' in 2005, Tania started her own record label, KCR.<ref name=\"sanity1\">[http://www.sanity.com.au/product/product.asp?sku=1198265 KERNAGHAN, TANIA / HIGHER GROUND \u2013 Sanity.com.au \u2013 More Movies \u2013 More Music<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>\n\nTania is an accomplished and well-known horsewoman and an acclaimed keynote speaker which she presents at various functions across Australia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.taniakernaghan.com/news.html|title=NEWS|website=Official Tania Kernaghan|access-date=7 April 2016}}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n===Studio albums===\n{|class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n!rowspan=\"2\"| Title\n!rowspan=\"2\"| Details\n!colspan=\"2\"| Peak chart name=\"Shop\"/>\n*Label: KCR / Shock\n*First greatest hits album (CD/DVD)\n|}\n\n== Awards and nominations==\n===AIR Awards===\nThe Australian Independent Record Awards (commonly known informally as [[AIR Awards]]) is an annual awards night to recognise, promote and celebrate the success of Australia's Independent Music sector.\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| [[AIR Awards of 2009|2009]]<ref name=\"09noms\">{{cite web|url=https://www.auspop.com.au/2009/10/air-nominees/|title=AIR Nominees|date=19 October 2009|accessdate=19 August 2020|archive-date=18 September 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200918230557/https://www.auspop.com.au/2009/10/air-nominees/|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=\"AIRwins\">{{cite web|url=https://www.air.org.au/awards/history|title=History Wins|website=[[Australian Independent Record Labels Association]]|accessdate=18 August 2020}}</ref>\n|''Livin' the Dream'' \n| Best Independent Country Album\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===ARIA Music Awards===\nThe [[ARIA Music Awards]] are a set of annual ceremonies presented by [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA), which recognise excellence, innovation, and achievement across all genres of the [[music of Australia]]. They commenced in 1987. \n\n{{awards table}}\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 1996|1996]] || ''December Moon'' || [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]] || {{nom}} || <ref>ARIA Award previous winners. {{cite web|url=http://www.ariaawards.com.au/history/award/Best-Country-Album|title=ARIA Awards Best Country Album|publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA)|access-date=9 April 2022}}</ref>\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 1999|1999]] || ''Dancing on Water'' || Best Country Album || {{nom}} || <ref>ARIA Award previous winners. {{cite web|url=http://www.ariaawards.com.au/history/award/Best-Country-Album|title=ARIA Awards Best Country Album|publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA)|access-date=9 April 2022}}</ref>\n{{end}}\n\n===Country Music Awards of Australia===\nThe [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] (CMAA) (also known as the Golden Guitar Awards) is an annual awards night held in January during the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]], celebrating recording excellence in the Australian country music industry. They have been held annually since 1973.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.country.com.au/awards/past-award-winners|title=Past Award Winners|accessdate=2 November 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.historyofcountrymusic.com.au/cmhands.html|title=Country Music Hands of Fame|website=historyofcountrymusic.com.au|access-date=7 April 2016}}</ref>\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n|-\n|rowspan=3| 1997\n| ''December Moon''\n| Album of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| Tania Kernaghan for \"Where the Murray Meets the Darling\"\n| Female Vocalist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| \"A Bushman Can't Survive\" with Lee Kernaghan\n| Vocal Collaboration of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 1998\n| Tania Kernaghan for \"Dunroamin' Station\"\n| Female Vocalist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 1999\n| Tania Kernaghan\n| Hands of Fame\n| {{yes2|imprinted}}\n{{end}}\n\n===Tamworth Songwriters Awards===\nThe Tamworth Songwriters Association (TSA) is an annual songwriting contest for original country songs, awarded in January at the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]]. They commenced in 1986.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsaonline.com.au/song-competition/|title=Tamworth Songwriters Association|website=Tamworth Songwriters Association Online|access-date=23 March 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsaonline.com.au/past-winners/|title=Tamworth Songwriters Association Past Winners|website=Tamworth Songwriters Association Online|access-date=23 March 2022}}</ref>\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n|-\n| 1997\n| \"Where the Murray Meets the Darling\" by Tania Kernaghan\n| Songmaker Award\n| {{won}}\n{{end}}\n\n== Other projects ==\nTania is a presenter for Lifestyle TV Program What's Up Downunder which currently airs on Channel 10, One Digital, Southern Cross and numerous regional affiliates .<ref name=\"WUD1\">[http://www.whatsupdownunder.com.au/touring-with-tania What's Up Downunder]</ref>\n\nShe also had a part in the film 'Shadows of the Past' playing the role of Sally Robson.<ref name=SOP1>[http://www.shadowsofthepast.com.au/ Shadows of the Past Official Movie Site]</ref> And in 2019 appeared in Australian Indie Movie, An Unconventional Love\n\nTania is Ambassador for Outback Queensland Tourism Association and Board Member\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://www.taniakernaghan.com/ Official Homepage]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Kernaghan, Tania}}\n[[Category:1968 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:APRA Award winners]]\n[[Category:Australian country singers]]\n[[Category:Australian women singers]]\n[[Category:People from Albury, New South Wales]]\n[[Category:20th-century Australian women singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century Australian singers]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Slim_Dusty","to":"Slim Dusty"}],"pages":{"321623":{"pageid":321623,"ns":0,"title":"Slim Dusty","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Australian country music singer-songwriter (1927\u20132003)}}\n{{other people|David Kirkpatrick}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2023}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Slim Dusty\n| honorific_suffix  = [[Order of Australia|AO]] [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]]\n| background        = solo_singer\n| image             = Slim Dusty with Golden Guitar.jpeg\n| image_size        = \n| caption           = At the Golden Guitar awards in Tamworth\n| birth_name        = David Gordon Kirkpatrick\n| birth_date        = {{birth date|1927|6|13|df=y}}\n| birth_place       = Nulla Nulla Creek, [[New South Wales]], Australia\n| death_date        = {{death date and age|2003|9|19|1927|6|13|df=y}}\n| death_place       = [[Sydney]], New South Wales, Australia\n| genre             = {{hlist|[[Australian country music|Country]]|[[bush ballad]]|[[Australiana]]}}\n| occupation        = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter|guitarist|music producer}}\n| instrument        = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar}}\n| years_active      = 1945\u20132003\n| label             = {{hlist|[[Regal Zonophone Records|Regal Zonophone]]|[[EMI]]}}\n| past_member_of   = {{unbulleted list|Joy McKean|Anne Kirkpatrick|Smoky Dawson|Buddy Williams|The Wiggles|South Kempsey Boys|Shorty Ranger}}\n| website           = [http://www.slimdustymusic.com.au/ slimdustymusic.com.au]\n| spouse            = [[Joy McKean]]\n}}\n'''Slim Dusty''', [[Order of Australia|AO]] [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]] (born '''David Gordon Kirkpatrick'''; 13 June 1927 \u2013 19 September 2003) was an [[Australian country music]] singer-songwriter, guitarist and producer. He was an [[Culture of Australia|Australian cultural icon]], referred to universally as [[Honorific nicknames in popular music|Australia's King of Country Music]]<ref name=\"TM\">{{cite web|url=https://triplem.com.au/story/the-very-best-of-slim-dusty-reaches-1000-weeks-in-the-aria-country-albums-chart-101427|title=The Very Best of Slim Dusty Reaches 1000 weeks in the Aria Country Album Charts}}</ref> and one of the country's most awarded stars, with a career spanning nearly seven decades and producing numerous recordings. He was known to record songs in the [[Australian patriotism|legacy of Australia]] genre, particularly of bush life, including works by renowned Australian [[bush poet]]s [[Henry Lawson]] and [[Banjo Paterson]], who represented the lifestyle. The music genre was coined the \"bush ballad\", a style first made popular by [[Buddy Williams (country musician)|Buddy Williams]]. Dusty was also known for his many trucking songs.\n\nSlim Dusty \"released more than a hundred albums, selling more than seven million records and earning over 70 gold and platinum album certifications\". He was the first Australian to have a No.&nbsp;1 international hit song, with a version of [[Gordon Parsons (singer-songwriter)|Gordon Parsons]]' \"[[A Pub with No Beer]]\".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://aso.gov.au/titles/music/a-pub-with-no-beer/notes/|title=Curator's notes A Pub With No Beer (1957) on ASO - Australia's audio and visual heritage online|website=Aso.gov.au|access-date=28 October 2019}}</ref> He received 38 [[Golden Guitar]]s and an [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA) award. He was inducted into the [[ARIA Hall of Fame]] and [[Australian Roll of Renown]]. At the time of his death, age 76, Dusty had been working on his 106th album for [[EMI Records]]. In 2007, his domestic record sales in Australia surpassed seven million. During his lifetime, Dusty was considered an [[Australian National Living Treasure|Australian National Treasure]]. He performed \"[[Waltzing Matilda]]\", a very famous song in Australia, at the [[2000 Summer Olympics closing ceremony|closing ceremony]] of the [[2000 Summer Olympics|Sydney 2000 Olympic Games]].\n\n==Family and career==\n===Childhood and early career===\nDavid Gordon Kirkpatrick was born on 13 June 1927 in Nulla Nulla Creek west of [[Kempsey, New South Wales]], the son of a cattle farmer. His childhood home, \"[[Homewood, Bellbrook|Homewood]]\", survives and is now heritage-listed. He was known by his middle name, Gordon. He wrote his first song, \"The Way the Cowboy Dies\", in 1937 and adopted the stage name \"Slim Dusty\" in 1938 at age 11.<ref>\"Senior Australian of the Year\", 1999 award by the Australian government. Retrieved 10 March 2008.</ref> His earliest musical influences included American [[Jimmie Rodgers (country singer)|Jimmie Rodgers]], New Zealander [[Tex Morton]], and Australia's [[Buddy Williams (country musician)|Buddy Williams]]. In 1945, Dusty wrote \"[[When the Rain Tumbles Down in July]]\" and released his first record that year at age 18. In 1946, he signed his first recording contract with Columbia Graphophone for the Regal Zonophone label.<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/09/21/1063625259334.html \"Slim Dusty: The boy who lived his dream\"], ''The Age'' (Australia), 21 September 2003</ref>\n\n===Influential wife, and children===\n[[File:Cunnamulla Fella.JPG|thumb|Statue of the \"[[Cunnamulla Fella]]\" erected as a tribute to songwriter [[Stan Coster]] and Slim Dusty]]\nIn 1951, Dusty married singer-songwriter [[Joy McKean]] and, with her help, achieved great success around Australia. In 1954, the two launched a full-time business career, including the Slim Dusty Travelling Show. McKean was Dusty's wife and manager for over 50 years. \n\nMcKean's sister Heather, half of the McKean Sisters music duo that preceded Joy's association with Dusty, was married to Australian country singer [[Reg Lindsay]], before separating and later divorcing in the 1980s, whereupon the McKean sisters re-started their music duo.\n\nTogether Dusty and Joy McKean had two children, [[Anne Kirkpatrick]] and David Kirkpatrick, who are also accomplished singer-songwriters.<ref name=\"slimdusty.com.au\">{{cite web |url=http://www.slimdusty.com.au/news.html#joytributeconcert |title=News |publisher=Slim Dusty |access-date=10 April 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120430142753/http://www.slimdusty.com.au/news.html#joytributeconcert |archive-date=30 April 2012}}</ref>\n\n===Dusty hits written by Joy McKean===\nMcKean wrote several of Dusty's most popular songs, including \"[[Lights On The Hill]]\", \"Walk a Country Mile\", \"Indian Pacific\", \"Kelly's Offsider\", \"The Angel of Goulburn Hill\" and \"[[The Biggest Disappointment]]\".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://store.countrymusic.com.au/store/item.inetstore?id=343 |title=The Country Music Store \u2013 Slim Dusty Sings Joy McKean |publisher=Store.countrymusic.com.au |access-date=10 April 2012 |archive-date=30 August 2002 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020830034755/http://store.countrymusic.com.au/store/item.inetstore?id=343 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n===Other songwriters' contributions===\nAlthough himself an accomplished writer of songs, Dusty had a number of other songwriters, including Mack Cormack, [[Gordon Parsons (singer-songwriter)|Gordon Parsons]], [[Stan Coster]], and Kelly Dixon, who were typically short on formal education but big on personal experience of the [[Australian bush]]. Drawing on his travels and such writers over a span of decades, Dusty chronicled the story of a rapidly changing postwar Australian nation.\n\n===First megahit===\nDusty's 1957 hit \"[[A Pub with No Beer]]\" was the biggest-selling record by an Australian to that time, the first Australian single to go gold and the first and only 78 rpm record to be awarded a gold disc.<ref name=\"Guardian-obit\">Dave Laing, [https://www.theguardian.com/news/2003/sep/20/guardianobituaries.artsobituaries \"Slim Dusty: Country singer famous for A Pub With No Beer\"], ''The Guardian (UK)'', 20 September 2003</ref> (The \"Pub with No Beer\" is a real place, in [[Taylors Arm, New South Wales|Taylors Arm]], not far from Kempsey, where Slim was born.)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mynrma.com.au/cps/rde/xchg/mynrma/hs.xsl/north_coast_pub.htm|title=North Coast: The Pub With No Beer|publisher=[[NRMA]]|access-date=13 June 2008}}</ref> In 1959 and 1960, Dutch and German cover versions of the song became number one hits (even evergreens) in Belgium, Austria and Germany, brought by the Flemish country singer-guitarist and amusement park founder [[Bobbejaan Schoepen]].\nIn 1964 the annual Slim Dusty Australia-round tour, a {{Convert|48280|km|mi|0}} journey that went on for ten months, was started. This regular event was the subject of a feature film, ''[[The Slim Dusty Movie]]'', in 1984.\n\n===Contributions of other songwriters===\nDusty recorded not only songs written by himself and other fellow Australian performers but also classic Australian poems by [[Henry Lawson]] and [[Banjo Paterson]], with new tunes to call attention to the old \"bush ballads\". An example is \"[[The Man from Snowy River (poem)|The Man from Snowy River]]\" by Paterson. The 1980 album and songs ''The Man Who Steadies the Lead'' and ''The Pearl of Them All'' were the works of Paterson's rival for the title of Australia's bush balladeer, Scottish-Australian poet [[William Henry Ogilvie|Will H. Ogilvie]] (1869\u20131963). In 1970, Dusty was made a member of the [[Order of the British Empire]] for services to music.<ref>[https://honours.pmc.gov.au/honours/awards/1084733 It's an Honour] \u2013 Member of the Order of the British Empire</ref>\n\n==Awards and honors==\nIn 1973, Dusty won Best Single at the inaugural [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] at the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]] (McKean won Song of the Year as writer of \"[[Lights on the Hill (song)|Lights on the Hill]]\"). By March 1976, Dusty had achieved 37 gold and two platinum records, more than any other Australian artist.<ref name=\"aus76\">{{cite magazine|url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-All-Music/Cash-Box/70s/1976/Cash-Box-1976-03-13.pdf|title=Slim Dusty Inks Huge EMI Deal |magazine=[[Cash Box magazine|Cash Box]]|via=World Radio History|page=55|date=13 March 1976|access-date=21 November 2021}}</ref>\n\nDusty and his wife were patrons of the National Truck Drivers' Memorial, located in [[Tarcutta]], New South Wales.\n\nThe general manager of the [[Grand Ole Opry]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], Bob Whitaker, invited Dusty and his wife to perform in 1997, recognising 50 years of contributing to country music. \n\nThe following January, Dusty was appointed an Officer of the [[Order of Australia]] for his service to the entertainment industry.<ref>[https://honours.pmc.gov.au/honours/awards/870179 It's an Honour] \u2013 Officer of the Order of Australia</ref>\n\nDusty recorded and released his 100th album, ''Looking Forward, Looking Back'', in 2000 and became the first artist in worldwide commercial recording history to do so; second was [[Cliff Richard]]. All 100 albums were recorded with the same record label, EMI, making Dusty the first music artist in the world to record 100 albums with the same label.<ref name=\"nla.gov.au\">{{cite web |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.cs-ma-destra+Media~76AE0801-0FCD-4334-A8D0-86AA829BE178 |title=Music Australia \u2013 Slim Dusty |publisher=Nla.gov.au |date=3 April 2007 |access-date=10 April 2012 |archive-date=29 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629165046/http://nla.gov.au/nla.cs-ma-destra+Media~76AE0801-0FCD-4334-A8D0-86AA829BE178 |url-status=dead }}</ref> \n\nDusty was appointed to sing \"[[Waltzing Matilda]]\" at the closing ceremony of the 2000 Summer Olympics; the whole stadium (officially 114,714 in attendance, the largest in Olympic history) sang along with him.<ref>{{cite web|title=2000 Sydney Closing Ceremony Music List|url=https://olympicceremonies.wordpress.com/2000-sydney-closing-ceremony-music-list/|website=Olympic ceremonies|date=30 August 2008 |access-date=8 June 2015|ref=olym2000}}</ref><ref>Archived at [https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211211/UORKwBTKWqw Ghostarchive]{{cbignore}} and the [https://web.archive.org/web/20120430114540/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UORKwBTKWqw Wayback Machine]{{cbignore}}: {{cite web|title=Slim Dusty performing|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UORKwBTKWqw|website=YouTube| date=17 December 2009 |access-date=8 June 2015|ref=performance2000}}{{cbignore}}</ref>\n\n===ARIA Music Awards (ARIA)===\nThe Australian Recording Industry Association Music Awards (commonly known informally as ARIA Music Awards or ARIA Awards) is an annual series of awards nights celebrating the Australian music industry, put on by the Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA).\nSlim Dusty has won one award from 10 nominations. \nAdditionally, Dusty was awarded two achievement awards and inducted into the Hall of Fame.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ariaawards.com.au/history/award/Best-Country-Album|title=ARIA Awards Best Country Album|publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA)|access-date=29 March 2020}}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}} \n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 1987|1987]] || ''Stories I Wanted to Tell'' || [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]] || Album || {{won}} \n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2001|2001]] || ''Looking Forward Looking Back'' || Highest Selling Album || {{nom}} \n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2004|2004]] || ''[[Columbia Lane - the Last Sessions]]'' || Best Country Album || {{nom}} \n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Country Music Awards (CMAA)===\nThe Country Music Awards (CMAA) are an annual awards ceremondy celebrating recording excellence in the Australian country music industry. It first commenced in 1973 at the [[Tamworth, New South Wales|Tamworth]] [[Country Music Awards of Australia]].\n\nAccording the Country Music Association of Australia, Slim Dusty won 44 [[Golden Guitar|Golden guitar]] plus, an induction into the [[Australian Roll of Renown]]. (listed below). This is more than any other artist.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.country.com.au/awards/golden-guitar-award-winners|title=CMAA Award Winners|date=October 2019|access-date=29 March 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://country.com.au/golden-guitars/award-winners/1970s |website=CMAA|title=Award Winners 1970s |access-date=29 March 2020 }}</ref>\n<ref>{{cite web |url=http://country.com.au/golden-guitars/award-winners/1980s |website=CMAA|title=Award Winners 1980s |access-date=29 March 2020 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://country.com.au/golden-guitars/award-winners/1990s |website=CMAA|title=Award Winners 1990s |access-date=29 March 2020 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://country.com.au/golden-guitars/award-winners/2000s |website=CMAA|title=Award Winners 2000s |access-date=29 March 2020 }}</ref>\n\nAccording to Australian Broadcasting Corporation in 2022, [[Troy Cassar-Daley]] won his 40th, surpassing Slim Dusty's record of 38 awards.<ref name=\"CMAA2022\">{{cite web|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2022-04-20/golden-guitar-winners-2022-country-music-tamworth/101002818|title=2022 Golden Guitar Awards see Cassar-Daley take out Slim Dusty record, Shane Nicholson and Ashleigh Dallas collect top gongs|website=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=20 April 2022|access-date=21 April 2022|author= Maguire, Kemii}}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}} <small>(wins \"Just an Old Cattle Dog\" || Bush Ballad of the Year || {{won}}\n|-\n| 2005|| \"Get Along\" || Video Clip of the Year || {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===King of Pop Awards===\n[[Australian pop music awards#1967\u20131978: King of Pop Awards|The King of Pop Awards]] were voted by the readers of [[TV Week]]. The King of Pop award started in 1967 and ran through to 1978.<ref name=\"Top40TV\">{{Cite web | url = http://users.ncable.net.au/~ronjeff/top40/oz_king.htm | title = Australian Music Awards | publisher = Ron Jeff | access-date = 16 December 2010 | archive-date = 30 June 2012 | archive-url = https://archive.today/20120630220831/http://users.ncable.net.au/~ronjeff/top40/oz_king.htm | url-status = dead }}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| 1977\n| himself\n| Most Popular Australian Country Musician\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 1978\n| himself\n| Most Popular Australian Country Musician\n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n* Note: the Most Popular Australian Country Musician award was only presented in 1977 and 1978.\n\n===Mo Awards===\nThe Australian Entertainment Mo Awards (commonly known informally as the [[Mo Awards]]), were annual Australian entertainment industry awards. They recognise achievements in live entertainment in Australia from 1975 to 2016. Slim Dusty won two awards in that time. From 2006, the \"best country entertainer\" award was named in his honour.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.moawards.com.au/awardwinners|title=MO Award Winners|website=Mo Awards|access-date=16 March 2022}}</ref>\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n|-\n| 1985\n| Slim Dusty\n| Male Country Entertainer of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2015\n| Slim Dusty\n| Special Lifetime Achievement Award\n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Tamworth Songwriters Awards===\nThe Tamworth Songwriters Association (TSA) is an annual songwriting contest for original country songs, awarded in January at the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]]. They commenced in 1986.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsaonline.com.au/song-competition/|title=Tamworth Songwriters Association|website=Tamworth Songwriters Association Online|access-date=23 March 2022}}</ref> Slim Dusty won two awards in that time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsaonline.com.au/past-winners/|title=Tamworth Songwriters Association Past Winners|website=Tamworth Songwriters Association Online|access-date=23 March 2022}}</ref>\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n|-\n| 1993\n| \"Bucking Horse Called Time\" by Slim Dusty and Keith Garvey\n| Traditional Bush Ballad of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 1996\n| \"Fifteen Hundred Head\" by Slim Dusty and K&M Dixon\n| Traditional Bush Ballad of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n==Country gospel music interest==\n[[Slim Dusty discography|Dusty's repertoire]] included [[country gospel]] music, with which he liked to finish his shows.<ref>Per narration by Slim Dusty, ''Slim Dusty Live at Wagga Wagga''; Track 12, 1972</ref> His live albums usually carried the theme, and in 1971 he released the Gospel album ''Glory Bound Train'' featuring the eponymous hit ''Glory Bound Train'' and other songs of a Christian theme. ''Glory Bound Train'' was in turn the song selected to conclude the tribute concert held at Tamworth after his death. The \"Concert for Slim\" was recorded live on 20 January 2004, at the Tamworth Regional Entertainment Centre, and an all-star cast of Australian musicians sang out the show with Slim's ''Glory Bound Train''. The DVD was certified 3\u00d7 Platinum in Australia.<ref name=ARIACert05>{{cite certification|region=Australia|artist=Various Artists|type=video|certyear=2005|access-date=17 December 2021}}</ref>\n\n==Death==\nDusty died at his home in [[St Ives, New South Wales]], on 19 September 2003 at the age of 76 after a protracted battle with [[lung cancer|lung]] and [[kidney cancer]].<ref>[http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/09/19/1063625203882.html \"Slim Dusty dies\"], ''Sydney Morning Herald'', 19 September 2003</ref>\n\nEminent figures, including the [[Prime Minister of Australia]], [[John Howard]], and the federal opposition leader, [[Simon Crean]], attended a [[state funeral]] at [[St Andrew's Cathedral, Sydney]] on 26 September 2003, where thousands had gathered. In the funeral, the Anglican Dean of Sydney, [[Phillip Jensen]] paid tribute by leading the congregation of family, statesmen, fans and musicians in the singing of \"A Pub With No Beer\". Several tributes were featured from Dusty's children as well as words from other national musicians ([[Peter Garrett]] and [[John Williamson (singer)|John Williamson]]) and music from [[Graeme Connors]], [[Kasey Chambers]] and [[Troy Cassar-Daley]]. Around Australia, thousands of fans gathered to stand outside the cathedral; Dusty was later cremated.\n\nDusty had been working on his 106th album for EMI at the time of his death. On 8 March 2004 the album, ''[[Columbia Lane \u2013 the Last Sessions]]'', debuted at number five in the Australian album charts and number one on the country charts. Gold status was achieved after being on sale for less than two weeks.\n\n''Columbia Lane'' is a tribute to the laneway juxtaposed to [[Parramatta Road]] in [[Strathfield]] (near the railway bridge link), where the EMI studios once stood (now a [[Kennards Self Storage]] store), and where he began his music career.\n\nIn 2004, Tamworth hosted the \"Concert for Slim\" as a memorial tribute featuring more than 30 Australian musical artists including [[Joy McKean]], [[Paul Kelly (Australian musician)|Paul Kelly]], [[Keith Urban]], [[Lee Kernaghan]] and [[Kasey Chambers]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://chaos.com/product/concert-for-slim-slim-dusty/571478-192588.html |title=Concert for Slim (Slim Dusty): DVDs |publisher=Chaos.com |access-date=10 April 2012 |archive-date=4 March 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304023057/http://chaos.com/product/concert-for-slim-slim-dusty/571478-192588.html |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nIn 2005, in tribute to the iconic song \"[[Cunnamulla Fella]]\" performed by Dusty with lyrics by [[Stan Coster]], an eponymous statue was unveiled in the Queensland town of [[Cunnamulla]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.queenslandholidays.com.au/things-to-see-and-do/cunnamulla-fella/index.cfm |title=Cunnamulla Fella \u2013 Things To See and Do |publisher=Queensland Holidays |date=18 November 2005 |access-date=10 April 2012}}</ref>\n\n[[EMI Records]]' Australian sales of Dusty's records surpassed seven million in 2007.<ref name=\"sdc\">{{cite web |url=http://www.slimdusty.com.au/milestones.html |title=Milestones |publisher=Slim Dusty |access-date=10 April 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110920214044/http://www.slimdusty.com.au/milestones.html |archive-date=20 September 2011}}</ref>\n\n==Milestones==\nSlim Dusty was Australia's most successful and prolific musical artist, with more [[Gold album|Gold]] and [[Platinum albums]] than any other Australian artist.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cultureandrecreation.gov.au/articles/music/country/ |title=Australian country music \u2013 australia.gov.au |publisher=Cultureandrecreation.gov.au |date=31 October 2007 |access-date=10 April 2012 |archive-date=17 February 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110217020802/http://www.cultureandrecreation.gov.au/articles/music/country/ |url-status=dead }}</ref> He was also:<ref name=\"nla.gov.au\"/>\n\n* The first Australian to receive a [[Gold Record]]. \n* Made a [[Member of the Order of the British Empire]] and an [[Officer of the Order of Australia]] for services to entertainment.\n* On 14 April 1981, on [[Space Shuttle Columbia|Space Shuttle ''Columbia'']]'s [[STS-1|first mission]], Dusty's rendition of \"[[Waltzing Matilda]]\" was broadcast to Earth.<ref>[https://www.honeysucklecreek.net/other_stations/orroral/Orroral_STS-1_audio.html STS-1 audio (Orbit 16)]. 14 April 1981. Recorded at [[Orroral Valley Tracking Station]]. Retrieved 30 January 2019.</ref><ref>[https://www.upi.com/Archives/1981/04/14/Country-singer-Slim-Dusty-whose-recording-of-the-song/1845356072400/ Country singer Slim Dusty, whose recording of the song...]. 14 April 1981. From [[United Press International|UPI]] archives. Retrieved 30 January 2019.</ref>\n* The Royal Australian Mint issued a coin celebrating his life.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.allnumis.com/royal-australian-mint-celebrates-the-life-of-slim-dusty-with-a-1-dollar-coin.html |title=Royal Australian Mint celebrates the life of Slim Dusty with a 1 Dollar coin |publisher=News Allnumis |date=13 June 2013 |access-date=13 June 2013}}</ref>\n* Dusty's image was featured on an [[Australia Post]] postage stamp.\n* In December 2020, Slim Dusty was listed at number 40 in ''Rolling Stone Australia''{{'}}s \"50 Greatest Australian Artists of All Time\" issue.<ref>[https://au.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/50-greatest-australian-artists-of-all-time-king-gizzard-the-lizard-wizard-22575/ 50 Greatest Australian Artists of All Time \u2013 #40: Slim Dusty]. Troy Cassar-Daley, ''Rolling Stone Australia'', 4 February 2021. Retrieved 4 February 2021.</ref>\n\n==Legacy==\n* Dusty's life was the subject of a 1984 feature film: ''[[The Slim Dusty Movie]]''.\n* \"Pub With No Beer\" was added to the [[National Film and Sound Archive]]'s [[Sounds of Australia]] registry in 2008.\n* The 2010 book ''[[100 Best Australian Albums]]'' by Toby Creswell, Craig Mathieson and John O'Donnell ranked ''[[The Very Best of Slim Dusty]]'' as the 24th best Australian album of the previous 50 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/musicnews/s3050375.htm |title=The 100 Best Australian Albums &#124; music news &#124; triple j |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=28 October 2010 |access-date=10 April 2012}}</ref>\n* The Slim Dusty Centre was built in Kempsey, NSW, Dusty's home town, and opened in October 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slimdustycentre.com.au/default.htm |title=The Slim Dusty Centre Project. Kempsey, New South Wales, Australia. Slim Dusty Paver Program. Slim Dusty Tyrrells Wines. Slim Dusty Music Memories Week |publisher=Slimdustycentre.com.au |date=30 October 2011 |access-date=10 April 2012}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Slim Dusty discography}}\n[[EMI Records]]' Australian sales of Slim Dusty records surpassed 7 million in 2007.<ref name=\"sdc\"/>\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist|30em}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://www.slimdusty.com.au/ Official website] Dusty}}\n*[http://colsearch.nfsa.afc.gov.au/nfsa/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;group=;groupequals=;holdingType=;page=0;parentid=;query=Number%3A357298;querytype=;rec=0;resCount=10 Slim Dusty at the National Film and Sound Archive] more about it on australianscreen online.\n* {{IMDb name|0244730}}\n\n{{Slim Dusty}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Dusty, Slim}}\n[[Category:1927 births]]\n[[Category:2003
