<https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Cyndi_Thomson","to":"Cyndi Thomson"}],"pages":{"4583878":{"pageid":4583878,"ns":0,"title":"Cyndi Thomson","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Cyndi Thomson\n| image           =\n| caption         =\n| image_size      =\n| birth_name      =\n| alias           = Cyndi Goodman\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1976|10|19}}\n| death_date      =\n| origin          = [[Tifton, Georgia|Tifton]], Georgia, United States<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p478481/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Cyndi Thomson biography |accessdate=January 29, 2008 |last=Loftus |first=Johnny |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref>\n| instrument      = Vocals\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 2000\u20132002, 2006\u2013present\n| label           = [[Capitol Records|Capitol Nashville]]\n| associated_acts = [[Gary Allan]]\n| website         = \n}}\n\n'''Cyndi Thomson''' (born October 19, 1976) is an American [[country music]] artist. Thomson wrote songs with songwriter [[Tommy Lee James]] and in 2000, she signed with [[Capitol Records Nashville]] as a recording artist. She released her first album, ''[[My World (Cyndi Thomson album)|My World]]'', in 2001 and her debut single, \"[[What I Really Meant to Say]]\", became a number one hit on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]) charts. She later abandoned her recording career in 2002, but resumed recording in 2006.\n\n==Biography==\n\n===Early life===\nCyndi Thomson was born and raised in [[Tifton, Georgia|Tifton]], Georgia, the youngest of four daughters of Pat and Russ Thomson.  As a child, she was exposed to many different types of music.  Her parents listened to the [[oldies]] while her sisters listened to music by [[The Manhattan Transfer|Manhattan Transfer]] and [[Janet Jackson]] among others.<ref name=\"musicohio\">{{cite web\n| author = Perlman, Jason\n| date = July 24, 2001\n| url = http://www.musicohio.com/interviews/archive/cyndithomson.html\n| title = Cyndi Thomson\n| publisher = MusicOhio\n| accessdate = July 18, 2007\n| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160303172414/http://www.musicohio.com/interviews/archive/cyndithomson.html\n| archive-date = March 3, 2016\n| url-status = dead\n}}</ref> As Thomson got older, she began singing in church like her sisters did. At the age of twelve, she knew that she wanted to be a singer and at thirteen, after listening to [[Trisha Yearwood]]'s \"[[She's in Love with the Boy]]\", she knew that she wanted to be a country singer.<ref name=\"cmt010802\">{{cite web\n| author = Gray, Michael\n| date = August 2, 2001\n| url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1445919/20010801/thomson_cyndi.jhtml\n| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930045803/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1445919/20010801/thomson_cyndi.jhtml\n| url-status = dead\n| archive-date = September 30, 2007\n| title = Cyndi Thomson's \"World\" Shaped by Trisha Yearwood\n| publisher = [[Country Music Television]]\n| accessdate = July 18, 2007\n}}</ref>\n\nAfter graduating high school and winning a Georgia Music Hall of Fame scholarship,<ref name=\"cmt000407\">{{cite web\n| date = April 7, 2000\n| url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1476883/20030813/thomson_cyndi.jhtml\n| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930044429/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1476883/20030813/thomson_cyndi.jhtml\n| url-status = dead\n| archive-date = September 30, 2007\n| title = Thomson Joins Capitol Nashville Roster\n| publisher = [[Country Music Television]]\n| accessdate = July 18, 2007\n}}</ref> Thomson attended [[Kennesaw State University]] in [[Kennesaw, Georgia|Kennesaw]].<ref name=\"topeka\">{{cite web\n| author = Blankenship, Bill\n| date = October 26, 2001\n| url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4179/is_20011026/ai_n11771994\n| title = Sweet young twang\n| publisher = [[The Topeka Capital-Journal]]\n| accessdate = July 26, 2007\n}}</ref> Feeling that her dream of being a country singer was not going to be realized staying in Atlanta, she moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], Tennessee.  There, she attended [[Belmont University]] and enrolled in its music business program,<ref name=\"cmt010802\"/> but dropped out after a year and a half realizing that school was not necessary for her to do what she wanted to do.<ref name=\"musicohio\"/> Thomson did various jobs while pursuing the recording career that she wanted, one of which was a modelling job at a party for [[Deana Carter]]'s album ''[[Did I Shave My Legs for This?]]'' going platinum.<ref name=\"cmt010802\"/> One of the other models there later introduced Thomson to songwriter [[Tommy Lee James]],<ref name=\"usatoday\">{{cite web\n| author = Mansfield, Brian\n| date = August 9, 2001\n| url = https://www.usatoday.com/life/music/2001-08-09-cyndi-thomson.htm\n| title = Everything is just peachy for Thomson\n| publisher = [[USA Today]]\n| accessdate = July 25, 2007\n}}</ref> who wrote for [[Brooks & Dunn]] and [[Martina McBride]].\n\n===Music career===\nEven though Thomson had never written a song before, James agreed to work with her and within a year of writing their first song, Thomson signed with [[Sony-ATV Music Publishing]] as a songwriter.<ref name=\"musicohio\"/><ref name=\"cmt010802\"/> In 2000, James introduced Thomson to [[Capitol Records Nashville]] which signed her to a record deal immediately after hearing her sing three songs.<ref name=\"usatoday\"/> Thomson co-wrote eight of the eleven songs on her debut album ''My World'', released on July 31, 2001. Co-produced by James and producer [[Paul Worley]], it became the best-selling debut album by a female country singer since [[LeAnn Rimes]]' album ''[[Blue (LeAnn Rimes album)|Blue]]'' was released in 1996.<ref name=\"ew011019\">{{cite web\n| author = Nash, Alanna\n| date = October 19, 2001\n| url = http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,253970,00.html\n| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20071016144402/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,253970,00.html\n| url-status = dead\n| archive-date = October 16, 2007\n| title = Georgia Peach\n| publisher = [[Entertainment Weekly]]\n| accessdate = July 18, 2007\n}}</ref> The album was certified gold, for selling more than 500,000 copies, by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] ten months after the album's release.<ref name=\"businesswire\">{{cite web\n| date = June 2, 2002\n| url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_2002_June_6/ai_86855490/pg_1\n| title = Cyndi Thomson Goes GOLD! Capitol Recording Artist's Debut Album Sells Over 500,000 Units\n| publisher = [[Business Wire]]\n| accessdate = July 17, 2007\n}}</ref><ref name=\"cmt020607\">{{cite web\n| date = June 7, 2002\n| url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1455078/20020607/thomson_cyndi.jhtml\n| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930040857/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1455078/20020607/thomson_cyndi.jhtml\n| url-status = dead\n| archive-date = September 30, 2007\n| title = Thomson Hits Gold Standard\n| publisher = [[Country Music Television]]\n| accessdate = July 18, 2007\n}}</ref>\n\nLead-off single \"[[What I Really Meant to Say]],\" written after an encounter with an older boy at a party one night,<ref name=\"cmt010802\"/> spent three weeks at the top of the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]) charts.<ref name=\"businesswire\"/> It also became the only debut single by a female country singer to spend more than one week at the top of the [[Radio & Records]] country chart.<ref name=\"ew011019\"/> Her next two singles, \"I Always Liked That Best\" and \"I'm Gone\", failed to reach the top 20, with the former peaking at No.&nbsp;21 and the latter peaking at No.&nbsp;31 on the ''Billboard'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart.\n\nIn late 2002, Thomson, in a letter written to her record label, fans and friends, announced that she was walking away from her recording career.<ref name=\"cmt021015\">{{cite web\n| date = October 15, 2002\n| url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1458104/20021012/thomson_cyndi.jhtml\n| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930030847/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1458104/20021012/thomson_cyndi.jhtml\n| url-status = dead\n| archive-date = September 30, 2007\n| title = Thomson to Give Up Recording Career\n| publisher = [[Country Music Television]]\n| accessdate = July 18, 2007\n}}</ref> Thomson, who married musician and producer Daniel Goodman earlier that year, stated that being a recording artist was an \"overwhelming life changing experience\" and that she \"cannot commit to [the] obligations\" of making a new album.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/><ref name=\"cmt021015\"/> She did, however, contribute to the 2004 album ''Amazing Grace 3: A Country Salute to Gospel'', on which she sang \"'Tis So Sweet to Trust in Jesus\".<ref name=\"deseret\">{{cite web\n| author = Wadley, Carma\n| date = August 7, 2004\n| url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4188/is_20040807/ai_n11467751\n| title = Singer's life takes a sharp turn\n| publisher = Deseret News Publishing Co.\n| accessdate = July 18, 2007\n}}</ref> She also sang \"Have Yourself A Merry Little Christmas\" for the album ''Christmas Angels'' released by Capitol Nashville in 2005.<ref name=\"cmt051108\">{{cite web\n| date = November 8, 2005\n| url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1513280/20051108/thomson_cyndi.jhtml\n| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930011141/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1513280/20051108/thomson_cyndi.jhtml\n| url-status = dead\n| archive-date = September 30, 2007\n| title = Country Christmas Albums Released\n| publisher = [[Country Music Television]]\n| accessdate = July 18, 2007\n}}</ref><ref name=\"amazon\">{{cite web\n| url = https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/B000BM6AO2/musiccityusa-20\n| title = Christmas Angels\n| publisher = [[Amazon.com|Amazon]]\n| accessdate = July 18, 2007\n}}</ref>  \"[[Life Ain't Always Beautiful]]\", co-written by Thomson and credited to her as Cyndi Goodman, became a top five hit for [[Gary Allan]] in 2006. That year, she also returned to Capitol Nashville after leaving the label for four years and started recording for her second album with James.<ref name=\"cmt060112\">{{cite web\n| date = January 12, 2006\n| url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1520615/20060112/thomson_cyndi.jhtml\n| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930044356/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1520615/20060112/thomson_cyndi.jhtml\n| url-status = dead\n| archive-date = September 30, 2007\n| title = Cyndi Thomson Returns to Capitol Nashville\n| publisher = [[Country Music Television]]\n| accessdate = July 18, 2007\n}}</ref> \n\nOn October 29, 2009, Thomson released her first new music album in eight years, ''This Time'', a digital-only EP featuring five original songs.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:10em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Details\n! colspan=\"2\"| Peak chart<br>positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| [[Music recording sales certification|Certifications]]<br><small>and sales</small>\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"40\"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]<br>\n! width=\"40\"| [[Billboard 200|US]]<br>\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[My World (Cyndi Thomson album)|My World]]''\n| \n* Release date: July 31, 2001\n* Label: [[Capitol Nashville Records|Capitol Nashville]]\n* Formats: CD, [[compact Cassette|cassette]]\n| 7\n| 81\n| align=\"left\"| \n* [[Recording Industry Association of America|US]]: Gold<ref>{{cite web|url=http://riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?resultpage=1&table=SEARCH_RESULTS&action=&title=&artist=Cyndi%20Thomson&format=&debutLP=&category=&sex=&releaseDate=&requestNo=&type=&level=&label=&company=&certificationDate=&awardDescription=&catalogNo=&aSex=&rec_id=&charField=&gold=&platinum=&multiPlat=&level2=&certDate=&album=&id=&after=&before=&startMonth=1&endMonth=1&startYear=1958&endYear=2009&sort=Artist&perPage=25|title=RIAA Gold & Platinum \u2013 Cundi Thomson|publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]]|accessdate=June 7, 2009}}</ref>\n|-\n|}\n\n===EPs===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Bill_Chambers_(musician)","to":"Bill Chambers (musician)"}],"pages":{"52369385":{"pageid":52369385,"ns":0,"title":"Bill Chambers (musician)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2020}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=November 2016}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name        = Bill Chambers\n| image       =\n| image_size  =\n| landscape   = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank -->\n| alt         =\n| caption     =\n| birth_name  =\n| alias       =\n| birth_date  =\n| birth_place = [[Southend, South Australia]], Australia\n| occupation = Singer, musician\n| death_date  =\n| death_place =\n| genre       = Country\n| associated_acts = [[Kasey Chambers]]\n}}\n'''Bill Chambers''' is an Australian country musician and former member of the [[Dead Ringer Band]].<ref name=\"theage2002\">{{Citation | last = Best | first = Sophie | date = 13 October 2002 | title = The man behind Kasey Chambers | periodical = The Age | url = http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2002/10/12/1034222636357.html }}</ref><ref name=\"allmusic\">{{Citation | last = Campbell | first = Al | title = Bill Chambers | periodical = Allmusic | url = http://www.allmusic.com/artist/bill-chambers-mn0000067555/biography }}</ref> Chambers's albums ''Sleeping with the Blues'' and ''Cold Trail'' were nominated for the [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album]].<ref>{{Citation | last = Zuel | first = Bernard | date = 5 October 2016 | title = ARIA Award nominations have a hairy surprise among the Flumes and Avalanches | periodical = The Sydney Morning Herald| url = http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/aria-award-nominations-have-a-hairy-surprise-among-the-flumes-and-avalanches-20161004-grv17p.html}}</ref> He is best known as being the father of [[Nash Chambers]] and [[Kasey Chambers]]. \n\n==Career==\nBill Chambers was born in [[Southend, South Australia]] and married his wife Diane at age 20. Together they had two children, [[Nash Chambers|Nash]] in 1974 and [[Kasey Chambers|Kasey]] in 1976. Shortly after the birth of [[Kasey Chambers|Kasey]] in 1976, Chambers moved his family to central Australia's [[Nullarbor Plain]] and earned a living by hunting and trapping rabbits and foxes that raided Nullarbor poultry farms, then selling the pelts. Bill home schooled Nash and Kasey, and taught them American folk and country music by the [[Carter Family]], [[Jimmy Rogers|Jimmie Rogers]], [[Hank Williams]], [[Townes Van Zandt]] and [[Gram Parsons]], as well as Australian country artists [[Slim Dusty]], [[Buddy Williams (country musician)|Buddy Williams]] and [[Tex Morton]]. In 1986, Bill moved the family to [[Southend]], located on the southern coast of Australia, and began playing as a band at local public houses.<ref name=\"KCSS\"/>\n\nAs a family quartet, billed under Bill's name, they released ''Sea Eagle'' in 1987 and ''Kindred Spirit'' in 1991, before changing their name to ''[[Dead Ringer Band]]''.<ref name=\"KCSS\">{{cite web|url=https://www.encyclopedia.com/education/news-wires-white-papers-and-books/chambers-kasey|title= Kasey Chambers Singer, songwriter |website=encyclopedia|access-date=30 March 2020}}</ref>\n\nIn 1998, Bill and Diane separated and were divorced and ended Dead Ringer Band after four studio album. Bill moved to Sydney, started producing records, started a record label, Reckless Records. Late in 1998, the label's first album ''Looking Back to See'' with [[Audrey Auld]] (as Bill & Audrey) was released. By 1999, Chambers began focussing on supporting Kasey's fledgling solo career.<ref name=\"theage2002\"/>\n\nIn 2002 Chambers released a solo album called ''Sleeping with the Blues'', which was nominated for [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]] at the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2003]]. He contributed to the various artists album ''Reckless Records Garage Sale 1997-2003''.\n\nIn 2006, Chambers released ''Frozen Ground''. In 2009, Chambers released ''Drifting South''. \n\nIn July 2013, Chambers released ''Live at the Pub Tamworth'', which featured special guests [[Kasey Chambers]], [[Shane Nicholson (singer)|Shane Nicholson]] and Kevin Bennett.\n\nIn January 2016, Chambers released ''Cold Trail''. The album was nominated for Best Country Album at the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2016]].\n\nIn January 2019, Chambers released ''1952'', an album inspired by [[Hank Williams]].\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|+ List of album, with selected details\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"1\" style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"1\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Album details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Sea Eagle''\n|\n* Released: 1987\n* Label: Dead Ringer Band\n* Formats: CD\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Drifting South'' \n|\n* Released: September 2009\n* Label: Whitewater <small>(001)</small>\n* Formats: CD\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Live at the Pub Tamworth'' \n|\n* Released: July 2013\n* Note: Live album\n* Label: Whitewater <small>(004)</small>\n* Formats: CD, [[Music download|digital download]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Cold Trail'' \n|\n* Released: 22 January 2016<ref>{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/au/album/cold-trail/1073206183|title=Cold Trail album|website=Apple Music|access-date=30 March 2020}}</ref>\n* Label: Whitewater <small>( 004)</small>\n* Formats: CD, digital download\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''1952'' \n|\n* Released: 18 January 2019<ref>{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/au/album/1952/1448364399|title=1952 album|website=Apple Music|access-date=30 March 2020}}</ref>\n* Label: Bill Chambers\n* Formats: digital download\n|}\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n===AIR Awards===\nThe Australian Independent Record Awards (commonly known informally as [[AIR Awards]]) is an annual awards night to recognise, promote and celebrate the success of Australia's Independent Music sector.\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| [[AIR Awards of 2017|2017]]<ref name=\"17nom\">{{cite web|url=https://theindustryobserver.thebrag.com/a-b-original-dominates-2017-air-awards-nominations/|title=A.B Original dominates 2017 AIR Awards nominations|website=theindustryobserver|date=31 May 2017|access-date=20 August 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"AIRwins\">{{cite web|url=https://www.air.org.au/awards/history|title=History Wins|website=[[Australian Independent Record Labels Association]]|access-date=18 August 2020}}</ref>\n| ''Cold Trail''\n| Best Independent Country Album\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===ARIA Music Awards===\nThe [[ARIA Music Awards]] is an annual awards ceremony that recognises excellence, innovation, and achievement across all genres of [[Australian music]]. Bill Chambers has been nominated twice.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.ariaawards.com.au/search?term=Bill%20Chambers|title = ARIA Awards Search Results \u2013 Bill Chambers|publisher=ARIA Awards|access-date = 30 March 2020}}</ref>\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2003|2003]]\n| ''Sleeping with the Blues''\n| [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]]\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2016|2016]]\n| ''Cold Trail''\n| Best Country Album\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Country Music Awards of Australia===\nThe [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] (CMAA) (also known as the Golden Guitar Awards) is an annual awards night held in January during the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]], celebrating recording excellence in the Australian country music industry. They have been held annually since 1973.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.country.com.au/awards/past-award-winners|title=Past Award Winners|access-date=2 November 2020|archive-date=25 October 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201025171148/https://country.com.au/awards/past-award-winners|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n|-\n| 1992\n| \"Things Are Not The Same on the Land\" (written by Bill Chambers and recorded by Slim Dusty)\n| Smoky Dawson Award\n| {{won}}\n{{end}}\n\n===Tamworth Songwriters Awards===\nThe Tamworth Songwriters Association (TSA) is an annual songwriting contest for original country songs, awarded in January at the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]]. They commenced in 1986.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsaonline.com.au/song-competition/|title=Tamworth Songwriters Association|website=Tamworth Songwriters Association Online|access-date=23 March 2022}}</ref> Bill Chambers won one award in that time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsaonline.com.au/past-winners/|title=Tamworth Songwriters Association Past Winners|website=Tamworth Songwriters Association Online|access-date=23 March 2022}}</ref>\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n|-\n| 1992\n| \"Things Are Not The Same on the Land\" by Bill Chambers\n| Traditional Bush Ballad of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.billchambersmusic.com/ Bill Chambers: Home]\n\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Chambers, Bill}}\n[[Category:Australian male singers]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Musicians from South Australia]]\n[[Category:Australian country singers]]\n[[Category:Dead Ringer Band members]]\n[[Category:Former Seventh-day Adventists]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jetty_Road_(band)","to":"Jetty Road (band)"}],"pages":{"38449423":{"pageid":38449423,"ns":0,"title":"Jetty Road (band)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Australian country music trio}}\n{{COI|date=January 2014}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=September 2017}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Jetty Road\n| image           = Jetty Road concert.jpg\n| image_size      =\n| image_upright   =\n| landscape       = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank -->\n| alt             =\n| caption         = L to R: Julian Sammut, Paula Bowman, Lee Bowman, Simon Ross<br>[[Tamworth Country Music Festival]], January 2010\n| alias           =\n| origin          = Melbourne, Victoria, Australia\n| genre           = Country\n| years_active    = {{start date|2005}}\u2013present\n| label           = {{flatlist|\n* One Stop Entertainment\n* Compass Bros\n* WJO/[[Shock Records|Shock]]\n* [[Sony Music Australia|Sony]]\n}}\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = {{URL|jettyroad.band/}}\n| current_members = * Lee Bowman\n* Paula Bowman\n* Julian Sammut\n| past_members    = * Alexander Ross\n* Ben Cant\n* Russell Cochrane\n}}\n\n'''Jetty Road''' are an Australian country music trio comprising identical twin sisters Lee Bowman and Paula Bowman, both on vocals, with Julian Sammut on lead guitar. Founding multi-instrumentalist member, Simon Ross left in 2012. They have released five albums, ''Full Circle'' (2005), ''Dirt Roads City Lights'' (2007), ''Life at a Million Miles'' (2009), ''Far Away Places'' (2011) and ''Hearts on Fire'' (2015). The group have won two [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] Golden Guitar trophies. ''Hearts on Fire'' peaked in the top&nbsp;40 on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Albums Chart]].\n\n== History ==\n\nJetty Road's founding members are identical twin sisters Lee Bowman, on vocals and acoustic guitar, and Paula Bowman (both born on 30 April 1976) on vocals, with Julian Sammut (born 7 June 1973) on lead guitar and Simon Ross (born 16 June 1976) on guitar, harmonica, mandolin and accordion.<ref name=\"Andrews\">{{cite web | url = http://www.nashvillemusicguide.com/aussie-band-jetty-road-looks-to-conquer-canada/ | title = Aussie Band, Jetty Road, Looks to Conquer Canada | last = Andrews | first = Amanda K | date = 13 May 2011 | work = Nashville Music Guide | accessdate = 2 September 2017 }}</ref><ref name=\"CounRage\">{{cite web | url = http://www.countryragepage.com/jettyrd.htm | title = Jetty Road  | work = Country Rage Page | accessdate = 2 September 2017 }}</ref> The four met during their tertiary educational studies at [[Box Hill Institute|Box Hill Institute of Music]] (1995\u201397).<ref name=\"BVJ\">{{cite web | url = https://www.bigvalleyjamboree.com/performers/jetty-road | title = Jetty Road | publisher = [[Big Valley Jamboree]] | accessdate = 2 September 2017 }}</ref> Several years after graduating the quartet began writing and recording music.<ref name=\"BVJ\"/> They were named after the Bowman's childhood home on Nungurner Jetty Road, Nungurner (see [[Shire of Tambo (Victoria)|Shire of Tambo]]) and made their debut by busking at the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]] in January 2005. They placed second in the Tamworth Busking Championships.\n\nJetty Road released their debut album ''Full Circle'' on One Stop Entertainment in January 2005. A single, \"Run to You\", was released in that year, which peaked at #21 on the national Country Tracks Top 30 Chart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countrymusicradio.com.au/CT30/chart.cfm |title=Country Tracks : Top 30 |publisher=Countrymusicradio.com.au |accessdate=2014-02-18 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222014744/http://www.countrymusicradio.com.au/CT30/chart.cfm |archivedate=2014-02-22 }}</ref><ref name=\"Music com\">{{cite web | url = http://mmusic.com.au/index.php?route=product/product&product_id=150 | title = Jetty Road \u2013 ''Full Circle'' | work = Meteor Music | publisher = | accessdate = 2 September 2017 }}</ref> The song was selected as the opening track on [[John Nutting (radio presenter)|John Nutting]]'s ''ABC Saturday Night Country Hottest Hits, Vol. 2''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/saturday-night-country-hottest-hits-vol-2-mw0001087983 |title = Saturday Night Country Hottest Hits, Vol. 2 \u2013 Various Artists &#124; Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher = AllMusic |date = 13 January 2006 |accessdate=2014-02-18}}</ref> By 2006 the group had added Ben Cant on drums and Russell Cochrane on bass guitar.<ref name=\"CounRage\"/><ref name=\"Music com\"/>\n\nAt the beginning of 2007 Jetty Road met Australian country musician, [[James Blundell (singer)|James Blundell]] and spent the next 18 months touring together. Their second album, ''Dirt Roads City Lights'' was released in that year.\n\n'''2008'''\n\nJetty Road received their first finalist nomination in the 36th [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] (Best Group or Duo). They won the TIARA Award for Best Group; the following month their ''Dirt Roads City Lights'' album won Victorian Album of the Year at the Victorian & National Country Music Awards. June 2008 saw the band undertake their first international tour, performing in Nashville, Canada and the UK.\n\n'''2009'''\n\nIn January 2009 they won ''Best Group'' at the Australian Country Music People's Choice Awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.peopleschoiceawards.com.au/ |title=Australian Country Music People's Choice Awards |publisher=Peopleschoiceawards.com.au |date= |accessdate=2014-02-18}}</ref> They also won their second consecutive TIARA Award. In March 2009 Jetty Road's third album ''Life at a Million Miles'' was released (Compass Bros), produced by band member Julian Sammut and co produced by Nashville-based Australian expat Mark Moffatt. The band undertook their second international tour (June \u2013 September) to Canada, the United States, France, Switzerland, Germany, Denmark, Austria and Norway. Upon returning to Australia, they won ''Group/Duo of the Year'', ''Album of the Year'' and ''Artist of the Year'' at the Australian Independent Country Music Awards in October.\n\n'''2010'''\n\nIn January 2010, at the 38th Country Music Awards of Australia, the band won their first CMAA (Golden Guitar) Award in the category, Best Group or Duo, for their track, \"Million Miles\".<ref name=\"CMAA 2010\">{{cite web | archiveurl = https://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20100927143200/http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/21044/20100928-0032/www.apra-amcos.com.au/news/industrynews/cmmacountrymusicawardstroycassardaleywinsaprasongoftheyear.html | url = http://www.apra-amcos.com.au/news/industrynews/cmmacountrymusicawardstroycassardaleywinsaprasongoftheyear.html | title = CMMA Country Music Awards \u2013 Troy Cassar-Daley wins APRA Song of the Year | publisher = [[Australasian Performing Right Association]] (APRA) &#124; [[Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners Society]] (AMCOS) | archivedate = 27 September 2010 | date = 25 January 2010 | accessdate = 6 November 2014 }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> They scored an additional two finalist nominations that year,<ref name=\"CMAA 2010\"/> for Album of the Year (''Life at a Million Miles'') and Single of the Year (\"Million Miles\").\n\nJetty Road won ''Best Group'' and ''Best Song'' (Million Miles) awards at the Australian Country Music People's Choice Awards,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.peopleschoiceawards.com.au/gallery10.html |title=Australian Country Music People's Choice Awards, Gallery 2010 |publisher=Peopleschoiceawards.com.au |date= |accessdate=2014-02-18}}</ref> as well as ''Best Group'' (National), ''Victorian Album of the Year'' and ''Victorian Entertainer of the Year'' at the Victorian & National Country Music Awards.  A few months later they won the National Music Oz Award for ''Best Country Act''. \n<br>\nMid 2011 saw Jetty Road touring extensively throughout Canada and Europe and song writing with Canadian writers/artists including The Road Hammer's Jason McCoy (I'm A Dreamer/Welcome to the Party), The Higgins (Let It Out/Look At Me) and write and sing a duet with George Canyon (Wrong). In October Jetty Road recorded their fourth album ''Far Away Places'' in Vancouver at The Factory Studios with Canadian producer Paul Shatto and David Wills.\n\n'''2011'''\n\n''Far Away Places'' was released on 6 May 2012 in Australia (WJO). It peaked at number 12 on the [https://web.archive.org/web/20130216065957/http://country.com.au/news/cmaa-charts ARIA Top 20 Australian Artist Country Albums Chart] and remained there for 30 weeks. The debut single release \u201cServes You Right\u201d achieved #1 on the CMC Top 30 Chart<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://vimeo.com/20393665 |title=Jetty Road \"Serves You Right\" on Vimeo |publisher=Vimeo.com |date=2011-02-25 |accessdate=2014-02-18}}</ref> and also radio's national Country Tracks Chart<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cmronline.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1025&news_display_year_5298=2011&display_news_id_5298=1174 |title=Country Music Radio: Archive |publisher=Cmronline.com.au |accessdate=2014-02-18 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222052256/http://cmronline.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1025&news_display_year_5298=2011&display_news_id_5298=1174 |archivedate=2014-02-22 }}</ref> ( #1 for 4 weeks). The album was also signed to Canada's OnRamp Records<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onramprecords.com/releases.cfm?NameFilter=J |title=On Ramp Records Releases |publisher=Onramprecords.com |accessdate=2014-02-18 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222223159/http://www.onramprecords.com/releases.cfm?NameFilter=J |archivedate=2014-02-22 }}</ref> (EMI).  \u201cLet It Out\u201d was released to Canadian Country radio and charted at #49 on the Media Base airplay chart.<br />\nMidyear saw their fourth consecutive international tour to Canada and Europe. They returned in October to win the major Professional Development Award ($20,000 prize) at the inaugural Australian Independent Artist Development Awards (AIADA).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://countrymusicbulletin.com.au/newsarchive_Oct11.html |title=Australian Country Music News, October 2011 |publisher=Countrymusicbulletin.com.au |date= |accessdate=2014-02-18}}</ref>  They were finalists in all three categories (including People's Choice and Video of the Year Awards). A week later Jetty Road went on to win Group/Duo of the Year at the Australian Independent Country Music Awards.\n\n'''2012'''\n\nIn January 2012 the band won their second CMAA (Golden Guitar) Award at the 40th Country Music Awards of Australia for Best Group or Duo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://countrymusicbulletin.com.au/newsarchive_Jan12.html |title=Australian Country Music News \u2013 January 2012 |publisher=Countrymusicbulletin.com.au |date= |accessdate=2014-02-18}}</ref> In February Jetty Road won Best Group (National), Best Independent Release (National), Best Group (VIC), Victorian Album of the Year (VIC) and Victorian Entertainer of the Year at the 2012 Victorian & National Country Music Awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://countrymusicbulletin.com.au/newsarchive_Feb12.html |title=Australian Country Music News \u2013 February 2012 |publisher=Countrymusicbulletin.com.au |date= |accessdate=2014-02-18}}</ref> The same month saw their single I'm A Dreamer reach #1 on the CMC Top 30 Chart<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fAJMCIt4Q5g&list=PL6827FC2EF1DA4801&index=2 |title=Jetty Road \u2013 \"I'm A Dreamer\" official video clip |publisher=YouTube |date=2011-09-25 |accessdate=2014-02-18}}</ref> and also the national radio Country Tracks Chart (#1 for 7 weeks).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cmronline.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1025&news_display_year_5298=2012&display_news_id_5298=1197 |title=Country Music Radio: Archive |publisher=Cmronline.com.au |accessdate=2014-02-18 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222051241/http://cmronline.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1025&news_display_year_5298=2012&display_news_id_5298=1197 |archivedate=2014-02-22 }}</ref>\nIn May, Jetty Road was recognized nationally when their song \u2018Serves You Right\u2019 was nominated for the APRA 'Country Work of the Year' Award<ref>{{cite web|url=http://countrymusicbulletin.com.au/newsarchive_May12.html |title=Australian Country Music News \u2013 May, 2012 |publisher=Countrymusicbulletin.com.au |date= |accessdate=2014-02-18}}</ref> alongside Kasey Chambers, Shane Nicholson and O\u2019Shea.\nTheir third single Sweet Goodbye was released from their Far Away Places album in September, achieving #1 on the CMC Top 30 Chart<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pc-97DKNGU8 |title=Jetty Road \u2013 Sweet Goodbye |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2014-02-18}}</ref> and the national radio Country Tracks Chart<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cmronline.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1025&news_display_year_5298=2012&display_news_id_5298=1219 |title=Country Music Radio: Archive |publisher=Cmronline.com.au |accessdate=2014-02-18 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222051958/http://cmronline.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1025&news_display_year_5298=2012&display_news_id_5298=1219 |archivedate=2014-02-22 }}</ref> (#1 x 3 weeks).\n\nIn October 2012, Jetty Road won their third consecutive Group/Duo of the Year Award at the Australian Independent Country Music Awards. Ross left the group due to \"family commitments\", the band issued a statement \"Simon has expressed the need to devote more time to his 4 yr old son Nico, who lives in Germany and will therefore pursue other projects. This has been a difficult decision for Simon, something he has not taken lightly.\"<ref name=\"CMC\">{{cite web | url = http://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/news/jetty-road-lose-member.aspx | title = Jetty Road lose member | publisher = Country Music Channel (CMC) | accessdate = 2 September 2017 | url-status = bot: unknown | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160304025732/http://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/news/jetty-road-lose-member.aspx | archivedate = 4 March 2016 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Title\n! Details\n! Peak positions<br />[[ARIA Charts|AUS]]<ref name=\"AUS Charts\">{{cite web | url = http://australian-charts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Jetty+Road | title = Discography Jetty Road | website=australian-charts.com | accessdate = 2 September 2017 }}</ref>\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Full Circle''\n| \n* Released: January 2005 (Australia)\n* Label: One Stop Entertainment\n| style=\"text-align:center\"| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Dirt Roads City Lights''\n| \n* Release date: 26 February 2007 (Australia)\n* Label: One Stop Entertainment\n| style=\"text-align:center\"| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Life at a Million Miles''\n| \n* Release date: 20 April 2009 (Australia)\n* Label: Compass Bros Distribution\n| style=\"text-align:center\"| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Far Away Places''\n| \n* Release date: 6 May 2011 (Australia), 28 June 2011 (Canada)\n* Label: WJO Distribution (Australia), OnRamp (Canada)\n| style=\"text-align:center\"| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Hearts on Fire''\n|\n* Release date: 29 May 2015 (Australia)\n* Label: Sony\n| style=\"text-align:center\"| 38\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Because We Can''\n|\n* Release date: 20 September 2019\n* Label: Social Family\n| style=\"text-align:center\"| 25\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! Year !! Video !! Director\n|-\n| 2005 || Be With You || Gary Hedegus\n|-\n| 2006 || Run To You<br />Till The Day I Die ||  Steve Hadley\n|-\n| 2007 || Real Smooth Cowboy<br />I Wanna Go Home || Ross Wood\n|-\n| 2008 || City Lights<br />Good Times || Ross Wood\n|-\n| 2009 || Million Miles<br />World Keeps Turning || Ross Wood\n|-\n| 2010 || Road To Nowhere<br />I Have Been || [[Duncan Toombs]]\n|-\n| 2011 || Serves You Right<br />I'm A Dreamer || Mick Jones<br />Glenn Wilson\n|-\n| 2012 || Sweet Goodbye<br />Wrong || Robb Cox<br />Duncan Toombs\n|-\n| 2015 || What We Did Last Night<br />Hearts On Fire<br />I Turn To You || Josh Favaloro<br />Josh Favaloro<br />Peter John\n|-\n| 2017 || Shakedown<br />You Need To Run || Jesse Anderson\n|}\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n===Country Music Awards of Australia===\nThe [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] (CMAA) (also known as the Golden Guitar Awards) is an annual awards night held in January during the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]], celebrating recording excellence in the Australian country music industry. They have been held annually since 1973.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.country.com.au/awards/past-award-winners|title=Past Award Winners|accessdate=2 November 2020|archive-date=25 October 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201025171148/https://country.com.au/awards/past-award-winners|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! Year !! Award !! Detail !! Result  \n|-\n| 2008 || Group or Duo of the Year || Real Smooth Cowboy || {{nom}} \n|-\n| 2010 || Group or Duo of the Year|| Million Miles|| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2012 || Group or Duo of the Year || Serves You Right || {{won}}\n|-\n| 2020<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.country.com.au/news/and-the-2020-toyota-golden-guitar-awards-finalists-are|title=And the 2020 Toyota Golden Guitar Awards Finalists Are...|website=TCMF|date=November 2019|access-date=2 December 2022}}</ref> || Group or Duo of the Year || ''Because We Can'' || {{nom}} \n|}\n\n===APRA Awards===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! Year !! Award !! Work !! Result\n|-\n| [[APRA Music Awards of 2012|2012]] || Country Work of the Year || \"Serves You Right\"<ref name=\"CWotYNom\">{{cite web | url = http://www.apraamcos.com.au/awards/2012-awards/apra-music-awards/country-work-of-the-year/ | title = 2012 APRA Music Awards \u2013 Country Work of the Year | publisher = Australasian Performing Right Association (APRA) &#124; Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners Society (AMCOS) | year = 2012 | accessdate = 6 November 2014 }}</ref> || {{nom}}\n|}\n\n==References==\n\n{{Reflist}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n[[Category:Australian country music groups]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 2005]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Gord_Bamford","to":"Gord Bamford"}],"pages":{"12987734":{"pageid":12987734,"ns":0,"title":"Gord Bamford","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Australian-Canadian country music singer|bot=PearBOT 5}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image           =\n| name            = Gord Bamford\n| caption         = Gord Bamford, September 2012\n| birth_name      =\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1976|04|17}}\n| birth_place     = [[Traralgon]], Victoria, Australia\n| death_date      =\n| origin          = [[Lacombe, Alberta]], Canada\n| instrument      = {{hlist|Guitar|vocals}}\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter}}\n| years_active    = 1995\u2013present\n| label           = {{hlist|Cache|[[Anthem Records|Anthem]]|[[Royalty Records|Royalty]]|[[Sony Music Canada]]|[[ABC Music]]}}\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = {{URL|http://www.gordbamford.com}}\n| current_members =\n| past_members    = \n}}\n\n'''Gordon Bamford''' (born April 17, 1976) is an Australian-Canadian [[country music]] singer.<ref name=\"bamford\">{{cite web|url=http://www.gordbamford.com/about.php |title=Gord Bamford: About Gord |access-date=August 17, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041012214141/http://www.gordbamford.com/about.php |archive-date=October 12, 2004 }}</ref> He has released ten studio albums. Alberta-raised Bamford stands as one of the most decorated artists in Canadian country music with 26 Canadian Country Music Association (CCMA) awards, along with multiple JUNO nominations. Additionally, Bamford is one of two multi-time winners of Nashville's Country Music Association (CMA) Global Country Artist of the Year award, along with [[the Shires (duo)|the Shires]].\n{{TOC limit}}\n\n==Biography==\n\n===Early years===\nBamford was born in [[Traralgon]], Victoria, Australia. When Bamford was five years old, he moved with his mother, Marilyn, from Australia to [[Lacombe, Alberta|Lacombe]], Alberta, Canada after his parents' divorce.<ref name=\"cmn\">[http://www.countrymusicnews.ca/news.ihtml?step=2&article_id=783 Country Music News Canadian country Music Artists CD's CDs CD Nashville report<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> A singer who toured with an Australian country band, Bamford's mother encouraged him to pursue a career in music.<ref name=\"cmn\" /> In 1995, Bamford entered and won the Nornet Radio Network's \"Search for the Stars.\"<ref name=\"bamford\" /> With Rob Bartlett from Sundae Sound producing, Bamford went to [[Calgary]] to record his debut single, \"Forever Starts Today,\" written by [[Dean McTaggart]].<ref name=\"bamford\" /><ref name=\"cmn\" /> The song received a positive response from Canadian country radio the following year.\n\n===2000\u20132002: ''God's Green Earth'' and hiatus===\nIn January 2001, Bamford released his debut album, ''[[God's Green Earth]]'', on his own GWB Records. The album was produced by Bart McKay at Sound Edge Productions in [[Saskatoon]], Saskatchewan.<ref name=\"cmn\" /> Bamford wrote two songs on the album.<ref name=\"bamford\" /> Five songs were released from the project \u2013 \"God's Green Earth,\" \"24 x 24,\" \"Where a Cowboy Likes to Roam,\" \"Man of the House\" and \"Classic Country Song.\" The album didn't do as well as Bamford had expected and he left the business discouraged.<ref>{{usurped|1=[https://archive.today/20120729093629/http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/B/Bamford_Gord/2008/01/18/4779380-sun.html Gord Bamford a smalltown storyteller]}}</ref>\n\n===2003\u20132006: ''Life Is Good'' and nominations===\nIn 2003, Bamford began spending time in [[Nashville, Tennessee]] writing with [[Steve Fox (musician)|Steve Fox]], Tim Taylor, and [[Byron Hill]] who went on to co-produce his second album.<ref name=\"bamford\" /> The album, ''[[Life Is Good (Gord Bamford album)|Life Is Good]]'', was released on October 19, 2004.<ref name=\"news\">{{cite web |url=http://www.gordbamford.com/news.php |title=Gord Bamford: News and Tour Dates |access-date=August 28, 2007 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070810171203/http://www.gordbamford.com/news.php |archive-date=August 10, 2007 }}</ref> Bamford wrote or co-wrote 10 of the 11 songs on the project.<ref name=\"cmn\" /> Six singles were released from the album, including the top 20 singles \"Heroes,\" \"My Heart's a Genius,\" \"All About Her,\" \"Life Is Good\" and \"I Would for You.\" A music video was shot for \"All About Her,\" and reached No.&nbsp;8 on [[CMT (Canada)|CMT Canada]]'s Chevy Top 20.\n\nOver the next few years, Bamford opened shows for [[Tim McGraw]], [[Kenny Rogers]], [[Carolyn Dawn Johnson]], [[Don Williams]] and [[Terri Clark]].<ref name=\"bamford\" /> In both 2005 and 2006, he was nominated at the [[Canadian Country Music Awards]] for Independent Male Vocalist of the Year, Independent Song of the Year, and the Chevy Trucks Rising Star Award.<ref name=\"stockey\">[http://www.charleswstockeycentre.com/cwsc/newsrelease.php?story=116 Charles W. Stockey Centre for the Performing Arts and the Bobby Orr Hall of Fame (Festival Performance Hall \u2013 Events Calendar)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> On June 4, 2007, Bamford was one of only two Canadian artists invited to perform at the Global Artist Party at the [[CMA Music Festival]] in Nashville.<ref name=\"stockey\" />\n\n===2007\u20132009: ''Honkytonks and Heartaches''===\nBamford's third album, ''[[Honkytonks and Heartaches]]'', co-produced by Nashville producer [[Byron Hill]], was released on September 25, 2007.<ref name=\"stockey\" /> The first single, \"Blame It On That Red Dress,\" was Gord's first top 10 hit on the Canadian country singles chart and the music video, directed by award-winning director Stephano Barberis, reached No.&nbsp;1 on CMT Canada's Chevy Top 20 for one week.\n\n===2010\u20132011: ''Day Job''===\nGord Bamford's fourth album, ''[[Day Job (album)|Day Job]]'', co-produced by Nashville producer [[Byron Hill]], was released in April 2010. Four singles were released from the album: \"Day Job\", \"Put Some Alcohol On It\", \"My Daughter's Father\" and \"Hank Williams Lonesome\".\n\n===2012\u20132013: ''Is It Friday Yet?''===\nBamford's fifth album, ''[[Is It Friday Yet?]]'', co-produced by Nashville producer [[Byron Hill]], was released in March 2012. Five singles were released from the album: \"Is It Friday Yet?\", \"Leaning on a Lonesome Song\", \"Disappearing Tail Lights\", \"Farm Girl Strong\" and \"Must Be a Woman\".\n\n===2013\u20132019: ''Country Junkie'', ''Tin Roof'', and ''Neon Smoke''===\nBamford's sixth album, ''[[Country Junkie]]'', co-produced by Nashville producer [[Byron Hill]], was released in October 2013. The album earned Bamford's first No. 1 single \"When Your Lips Are So Close\" (2013), a CRIA Gold Digital Single certification for \"When Your Lips Are So Close\" (2013), CCMA Single of the Year for \"When Your Lips Are So Close\" (2014), a Top-10 Country single \u2018Unreal\u2019 (2014), a Top-10 Country single \u2018Where A Farm Used To Be\u2019 (2014), a JUNO nomination for Country Album of the Year (2014), a fourth chart single \"Groovin With You\" (2015), CCMA Single of the Year for \"Where A Farm Used To Be\" (2015), and CCMA Song of the Year for \"Where A Farm Used To Be\" (2015).\n\nIn January 2018, Bamford released his eighth studio album ''Neon Smoke''. It includes his second #1 [[Canada Country]] hit \"[[Dive Bar (Gord Bamford song)|Dive Bar]]\",<ref>{{Cite web|first=Nanci|last=Dagg|url=https://canadianbeats.ca/2018/09/19/gord-bamford-accomplishes-what-many-hope-to-do-with-two-1-hits-now-under-his-belt-and-a-1-hit-in-australia/|title=Gord Bamford accomplishes what many hope to do with two #1 hits now under his belt and a #1 hit in Australia|work=Canadian Beats Media|date=September 19, 2018}}</ref> as well as collaborations with [[Jim Cuddy]] and [[Tracy Lawrence]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://frontporchmusic.ca/music/gord-bamford-neon-smoke-album/|title=Gord Bamford's New Album: Neon Smoke|work=Front Porch Music|date=January 7, 2018}}</ref> He also performed at Casino Nova Scotia with Aaron Goodvin and [[Clay Walker]].<ref>[https://www.thechronicleherald.ca/living/the-best-nova-scotia-concerts-of-2018-270134/ \"The best Nova Scotia concerts of 2018\"]. ''Chronicle Herald'', Stephen Cooke, December 20, 2018</ref>\n\n===2020\u2013present: ''Diamonds in a Whiskey Glass'' and ''Fire It Up''===\nIn June 2021, Bamford released his ninth studio album ''Diamonds in a Whiskey Glass'' on [[Anthem Records]] and Cache Entertainment. It includes the singles \"Diamonds in a Whiskey Glass\" and \"[[Heaven on Dirt]]\".<ref>{{cite web |title=Award-Winning Country Star Gord Bamford|url=https://patch.com/michigan/farmington-mi/award-winning-country-star-gord-bamford|first=Deb|last=Nicolson|website=Patch|date=May 26, 2021}}</ref> In November 2021, Bamford released the new single \"[[Drink Along Song]]\".<ref>{{cite web|title=Drink Along Song by Gord Bamford and The Wolfe Brothers \u2013 Song of the Day|url=https://countrytown.com.au/reviews/drink-along-song-by-gord-bamford-and-the-wolfe-brothers-song-of-the-day/YP14cnV0d3Y/19-11-21|date=November 18, 2021|first=Mallory|last=Arbour|work=Countrytown}}</ref>\n\nIn January 2023, Bamford released the single \"One Heartbeat From Heaven\". It is the lead single off his tenth studio album ''Fire It Up'', which was released in April 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://canadianbeats.ca/2023/01/20/gord-bamford-releases-his-new-single-one-heartbeat-from-heaven/|title=Bamford releases his new single, \"One Heartbeat From Heaven\"|first=Nanci|last=Dagg|work=Canadian Beats Media|date=January 20, 2023|access-date=January 26, 2023}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nOn August 30, 2004, Gord and his wife Kendra welcomed a boy, Nash David weighing in at 6 pounds, 7 ounces. They had a daughter, Paisley in 2006  and on July 31, 2009, they welcomed another daughter, Memphis Quinn.\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Gord Bamford discography}}\n*''[[God's Green Earth]]'' (2001)\n*''[[Life Is Good (Gord Bamford album)|Life Is Good]]'' (2004)\n*''[[Honkytonks and Heartaches]]'' (2007)\n*''[[Day Job]]'' (2010)\n*''[[Is It Friday Yet?]]'' (2012)\n*''[[Country Junkie]]'' (2013)\n*''[[Tin Roof]]'' (2016)\n*''Neon Smoke'' (2018)\n*''Diamonds in a Whiskey Glass'' (2021)\n*''Fire It Up'' (2023)\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! Year winners]]\n[[Category:21st-century Canadian singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century Australian singer-songwriters]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Chris_Buck_Band","to":"Chris Buck Band"}],"pages":{"49487084":{"pageid":49487084,"ns":0,"title":"Chris Buck Band","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Canadian country music group}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Chris Buck Band\n| image             = \n| caption           = \n| image_size        = \n| alias             = \n| origin            = [[British Columbia]], Canada\n| genre             = [[Country music|Country]]\n| years_active      = \n| label             = {{flatlist|\n* Bailey Way\n* [[Royalty Records|Royalty]]\n* Sakamoto Music\n}}\n| website           = {{URL|http://chrisbuckband.com/}}\n| current_members   = Chris Buck\n| past_members      =\n* Phillip Puxley\n* Michael Vanderlans\n* Paul Kinman\n* Taylor Allum\n* Ryan Stead\n* Matt Genereux\n}}\n\n'''Chris Buck Band''' is a Canadian [[country music]] group from [[British Columbia]], Canada composed of Chris Buck, and various band members.<ref name=\"whistler\">{{cite news|last1=Thompson|first1=Eric|title=Chris Buck Band makes its Pemberton debut|url=http://www.whistlerquestion.com/entertainment/music/chris-buck-band-makes-its-pemberton-debut-1.2065051|accessdate=February 19, 2016|work=Whistler Question|date=September 21, 2015}}</ref> Buck formed the band when he lost his best friend to cancer at age 13.<ref name=\"whistler\" /><ref name=\"cmt\">{{cite web|title=Chris Buck Band Biography|url=http://www.cmt.ca/artist/chris-buck-band|website=[[CMT (Canadian TV channel)|CMT]]|accessdate=February 19, 2016}}</ref> Their first single, \"Caribbean Dream\", was released in 2013.<ref name=\"summerland\">{{cite web|title=Summerland Festival of Lights presents: Chris Buck Band|url=http://summerlandlightup.com/events/main-stage/chris-buck-band/|website=Summerland Festival of Lights|accessdate=February 19, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160206222841/http://summerlandlightup.com/events/main-stage/chris-buck-band/|archive-date=February 6, 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref> It was included on their debut album, ''Buck Wild'', released in June 2014.<ref name=\"summerland\" /> Chris Buck Band won the 2014 British Columbia Country Music Association Award for Country Club Act of the Year.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Landreville|first1=Troy|title=Langley country artists scoop up awards|url=http://www.langleyadvance.com/entertainment/300174631.html|accessdate=February 19, 2016|work=Langley Advance|date=October 22, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303202109/http://www.langleyadvance.com/entertainment/300174631.html|archive-date=March 3, 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref> At the 2015 BCCMA Awards, they won Country Club Act of the Year and Group/Duo of the Year.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Marchand|first1=Francois|title=Dallas Smith ropes in the wins at 2015 B.C. Country Music Awards|url=http://blogs.vancouversun.com/2015/10/27/dallas-smith-ropes-in-the-wins-at-2015-b-c-country-music-awards/|accessdate=February 19, 2016|work=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|date=October 27, 2015}}</ref> \n\nTheir second single, \"Leave Your Light On\", was released in 2015.<ref name=\"summerland\" /> It peaked at number 44 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Canada Country]] chart.<ref name=\"Canada Country\" /> They signed to Bailey Way Entertainment for the release of their next single, \"Giddy Up\".<ref name=\"cmt\" /> It debuted on the Canada Country chart in February 2016.<ref name=\"Canada Country\" /> In 2017 Chris Buck Band signed with Royalty Records and released their third single \"That's When You Know\" (Featuring Kira Isabella), which climbed the charts to number 19. In 2022, this song earned them a certified Canadian Gold Record. Chris Buck has been writing his own music since his first album, which earned him the Songwriter of the Year Award at the 2019 BCCMA Awards. In 2021 he signed a publishing deal in Nashville, Tennessee with Anthem Entertainment which took his creativity to new heights. Chris Buck Band signed with Sakamoto Music in 2021 and started writing and recoding his next studio album \"Answers\" with producer [[Jeremy Stover]] and RED Creative Group. In 2022, Chris Buck released four singles from \"Answers\"; \"Can't Beat The View\", \"Thank God for Good Friends\", \"She Gone\" and \"Wild and Free\". The album won 2023 BCCMA Country Music \u201cAlbum of the Year\u201d.\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|+List of studio albums, with selected details\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Troy_Cassar-Daley","to":"Troy Cassar-Daley"}],"pages":{"2443227":{"pageid":2443227,"ns":0,"title":"Troy Cassar-Daley","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Australian musician}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name             = Troy Cassar-Daley\n| image            = TroyCassar.jpg\n| image_size       = \n| landscape        = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank -->\n| alt              = \n| caption          = \n| background       = solo_singer\n| alias            = \n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1969|05|18|df=y}}\n| birth_place      = [[Surry Hills, New South Wales]], Australia\n| instruments      = Vocals, guitar, harmonica\n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation       = Songwriter, singer, author\n| years_active     = 1990\u2013present\n| label            = [[Sony Music]], [[Liberation Music]]\n| website          = {{URL|http://www.troycassardaley.com.au/}}\n}}\n\n'''Troy Cassar-Daley''' (born 18 May 1969) is an Australian [[Australian country music|country music]] songwriter and entertainer.\n\nCassar-Daley has released thirteen studio albums, two live albums and five compilation albums over 30 years, including the platinum-selling ''[[The Great Country Songbook]]'' with [[Adam Harvey]]. Throughout this time he has received awards including five [[ARIA Music Awards]], forty [[Country Music Awards of Australia|Golden Guitar]]s,<ref name=\"CMAA2022\"/> nine [[Deadly Awards]] (Australian Indigenous Artist Awards), four [[Country Music Association of Australia]] Entertainer of the Year awards and two [[National Indigenous Music Awards]].<ref name=\"Sony2020\">{{cite web|url=https://themusicnetwork.com/troy-cassar-daley-sony-music/|title=Troy Cassar-Daley returns home to Sony Music under new global deal|website=The Music Network|date=24 June 2020|access-date=25 June 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"abc2021arias\">{{cite news|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-11-24/aria-awards-winners-genesis-owusu-the-kid-laroi/100647266|title=You could dub this year's awards the Hip Hop and R'n'B ARIAs|publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|date=24 November 2021|first=Mawunyo|last=Gbogbo|access-date=25 November 2021}}</ref>\n\n==Early life and career==\nCassar-Daley was born on 18 May 1969<ref name=\"allmusicbio\"/> in the Sydney suburb of [[Surry Hills, New South Wales|Surry Hills]] to a Maltese-Australian father and an [[Indigenous Australians|Aboriginal]] mother from the [[Gumbaynggirr]] and [[Bundjalung people|Bundjalung]] people.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/tv/talkingheads/txt/s2554373.htm|title=Troy Cassar-Daley|work=[[Talking Heads (Australian TV series)|Talking Heads]]|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=4 May 2009|access-date=12 July 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090524000641/http://www.abc.net.au/tv/talkingheads/txt/s2554373.htm|archive-date=24 May 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://troycassardaley.com.au/about/|title=About|publisher=Troy Cassar-Daley|access-date=21 November 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211121103946/https://troycassardaley.com.au/about/|archive-date=21 November 2021}}</ref> At a very young age, he moved with his mother to [[Grafton, New South Wales|Grafton]] in north-eastern [[New South Wales]]. At eleven, Troy went to the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]] and returned the next year to busk on the streets.<ref>[http://au.yahoo.com/it-takes-two/couples/bio/troy-cassar-daley/ Troy Cassar-Daley \u2013 It Takes Two<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070704061433/http://au.yahoo.com/it-takes-two/couples/bio/troy-cassar-daley/ |date=4 July 2007 }}</ref> At 16, he and his band, Little Eagle, were touring the [[North Coast (New South Wales)|North Coast of New South Wales]] and he made the top 10 in [[Tamworth, New South Wales|Tamworth]]'s Toyota Star Maker Quest. He won the 1986 \"Search for a Star\" competition and then toured with Brian Young for seven months in which he began to develop his songwriting skills. After returning home he replaced [[James Blundell (singer)|James Blundell]] as leader of country music band The Blue Heeler Band.<ref name=\"allmusicbio\">{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/troy-cassar-daley-mn0000393685/biography|title=Troy Cassar-Daley Biography|publisher=AllMusic|access-date=1 August 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Solo career==\nBy late 1993 Cassar-Daley had enough original songs for a debut EP. The first single \"Dream Out Loud\" was released on 24 October 1994<ref>{{cite web|url=http://i.imgur.com/T3ZokDY.png|title=New Release Summary \u2013 Product Available from: 24/10/94 (from The ARIA Report Issue No. 245)|publisher=Imgur.com|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> by Sony Music and reached number-one on the Australian country music charts. His first album, ''[[Beyond the Dancing]]'', was released in January 1995 and won the [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album]] at the [[ARIA Music Awards of 1995]]. At the 1996 Country Music Awards, in Tamworth, Cassar-Daley won Best Male Vocalist. He also made a cameo appearance in the motion picture ''[[Race the Sun (film)|Race the Sun]]'' in which he performed a song in a bar scene.\n\nIn June 1996, Cassar-Daley was part of the Australian Country Music Showcase in Nashville. The Showcase included [[Lee Kernaghan]], [[Gina Jeffreys]] and [[Tommy Emmanuel]]. As a result, Cassar-Daley returned to the US to record his new album ''[[True Believer (Troy Cassar-Daley album)|True Believer]]'' (1998) with Steve Dorff.{{cn|date=November 2021}} His follow-up, ''[[Big River (album)|Big River]]'' (1999),won another best country album ARIA Award at the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2000]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aria.com.au/awards/past-winners/2000|title=2000 ARIA Awards winners|publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association|access-date=21 November 2021}}</ref> His next four studio albums were ''[[Long Way Home (Troy Cassar-Daley album)|Long Way Home]]'' (2002), ''[[Borrowed & Blue]]'' (2004), ''[[Brighter Day (album)|Brighter Day]]'' (2005), and ''[[I Love This Place]]'' (2009), the latter two also winning best country album ARIA Awards.<ref name=\"allmusicbio\"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aria.com.au/awards/past-winners/2006|title=2006 ARIA Awards winners|publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association|access-date=21 November 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aria.com.au/awards/past-winners/2010|title=2010 ARIA Awards winners|publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association|access-date=21 November 2021}}</ref>\n\nCassar-Daley performed the national anthem at the [[2003 NRL grand final]]. He partnered up with [[Kate Ritchie]] for the singing competition ''[[It Takes Two (Australian television)|It Takes Two]]'' aired on [[Seven Network]] in 2006. In May 2007 he re-appeared on the same show,<ref>[http://au.yahoo.com/it-takes-two/ It Takes Two official website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060615163216/http://au.yahoo.com/it-takes-two/ |date=15 June 2006 }}</ref> this time partnered with Krystal Forscutt,<ref>[http://au.yahoo.com/it-takes-two/couples/bio/krystal-forscutt/ Krystal Forscutt \u2013 It Takes Two<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070715141610/http://au.yahoo.com/it-takes-two/couples/bio/krystal-forscutt/ |date=15 July 2007 }}</ref> a former contestant on [[Network Ten]]'s [[Big Brother (Australia)|''Big Brother'' program]]. The same year, Cassar-Daley was featured in [[The Wiggles|Wiggles]] music videos for the songs \"[[Old Dan Tucker]]\" and \"[[Turkey in the Straw]]\". Cassar-Daley with [[Kasey Chambers]] and Shane Nicholson played together at the [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] on 14 March 2009 for [[Sound Relief]] which was a multi-venue rock music concert in support of relief for the [[February 2009 Victorian bushfires|Victorian Bushfire Crisis]].<ref name=\"Brumby\">{{cite web|url=http://www.premier.vic.gov.au/premier/artists-unite-for-sound-relief-bushfire-benefit.html|title=Artists Unite For 'Sound Relief' Bushfire Benefit \u2013 Premier of Victoria, Australia|last=Brumby|first=John|authorlink=John Brumby|publisher=Premier of Victoria|date=24 February 2009|accessdate=25 February 2009}}</ref><ref name=\"Mitchell\">{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,25099180-661,00.html |title=Coldplay, Kings of Leon to headline bushfire relief concerts |last=Mitchell |first=Geraldine |work=[[Herald Sun]] |publisher=[[The Herald and Weekly Times Ltd]] |date=24 February 2009 |accessdate=25 February 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090225040650/http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,25099180-661,00.html |archivedate=25 February 2009 }}</ref> The event was held simultaneously with another concert taking place at the [[Sydney Cricket Ground]].<ref name=\"Brumby\"/> All the proceeds from the Melbourne Concert went to the [[Red Cross]] Victorian Bushfire Relief Appeal.<ref name=\"Brumby\"/><ref name=\"Mitchell\"/><ref name=\"Official\">{{cite web|url=http://www.soundrelief.com.au/melb/index.php |title=Latest News |publisher=Sound Relief |accessdate=25 February 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090227073309/http://www.soundrelief.com.au/melb/index.php |archivedate=27 February 2009 }}</ref>\n\nCassar-Daley went on to release the albums ''[[Home (Troy Cassar-Daley album)|Home]]'' (2012), ''[[The Great Country Songbook]]'' with [[Adam Harvey]] (2013), and ''[[Freedom Ride (album)|Freedom Ride]]'' (2015).<ref name=\"allmusicbio\"/> In August 2016, Cassar-Daley released his first book, an autobiography of his early life and music career titled ''[[Things I Carry Around]]'' with an accompanying album of the same title.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://australianmusician.com.au/troy-cassar-daley-new-album-book-interview/|title=Troy Cassar-Daley: New Book & Album \u2013 Interview |access-date=1 June 2016}}</ref> In 2017 Cassar-Daley was the 50th inductee into the prestigious [[Australian Roll of Renown]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tcmf.com.au/What-s-On/Roll-of-Renown/|title=Roll of Renown |publisher=TCMF|access-date=21 August 2018}}</ref> In October 2018, Cassar-Daley released his 42-track double album [[Greatest Hits (Troy Cassar-Daley album)|Greatest Hits]], along with a new single called \"Wouldn't Change A Thing\" on the Bloodlines label, part of [[Mushroom Group]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.triplem.com.au/story/troy-cassar-daley-set-to-deliver-42-of-his-greatest-hits-109467|title=Troy Cassar-Daley Set To Deliver 42 of his Greatest Hits|publisher=TripleM|access-date=1 August 2020}}</ref> The extensive album was also released on vinyl.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sanity.com.au/products/2393214/Greatest-Hits|title=Troy Cassar-Daley Vinyl|publisher=Sanity|access-date=1 August 2020}}</ref>\n\nIn June 2020, Cassar-Daley signed a worldwide label deal with [[Sony Music Australia|Sony Music Entertainment Australia]]; he had first signed to the label in 1995.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://themusicnetwork.com/troy-cassar-daley-sony-music/|title=Troy Cassar-Daley 'returns home' to Sony Music under new global deal|date=24 June 2020 |publisher=The Music Network|access-date=1 August 2020}}</ref> He released the albums ''[[Christmas for Cowboys]]'' in 2020 and ''[[The World Today (album)|The World Today]]'' in 2021, which won the best country album award at [[2021 ARIA Music Awards|that year's ARIA Music Awards]].<ref name=\"abc2021arias\"/><ref name=\"stack\">{{cite web|url=https://stack.com.au/music/album-review/troy-cassar-daley-christmas-for-cowboys-review/|title=Troy Cassar-Daley, ''Christmas for Cowboys'' review|website=Stack Magazine|date=25 November 2020|access-date=21 November 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2021/mar/19/troy-cassar-daley-i-looked-in-the-mirror-and-thought-stop-it-you-are-destroying-everything-you-love|title=Troy Cassar-Daley: 'I looked in the mirror and thought, stop it. You are destroying everything you love'|work=The Guardian|date=19 March 2021|first=Andrew|last=Stafford|access-date=21 November 2021}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\n[[File:TroyCassar-Daley_Family.jpg|thumb|Cassar-Daley with his wife and children]]\nCassar-Daley is married to radio and television presenter [[Laurel Edwards]] with whom he has two children.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/tv/enoughrope/transcripts/s1669506.htm Enough Rope with Andrew Denton \u2013 episode 109: Troy Cassar-Daley (26/06/2006)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060628202449/http://www.abc.net.au/tv/enoughrope/transcripts/s1669506.htm|date=28 June 2006}}</ref><ref>[http://www.laureledwards.com/bio.htm Welcome to LaurelEdwards.com]</ref> One of their children is singer-songwriter [[Jem Cassar-Daley]].<ref >{{cite web | last=Knowles | first=Rachael | title=Continuing the family legacy, Jem Cassar-Daley is making her mark with music | website=[[NITV]]| date=8 April 2022 | url=https://www.sbs.com.au/nitv/article/continuing-the-family-legacy-jem-cassar-daley-is-making-her-mark-with-music/oqbckpk7p | access-date=12 December 2022}}</ref>\n\nIn 2020, Cassar-Daley's participation in Australia's ''[[Who Do You Think You Are? (Australian TV series)|Who Do You Think You Are?]]'' was broadcast on [[SBS (Australian TV channel)|SBS]], where he traced both his ancestral roots on his father's side in [[Malta]], and his mother's [[Aboriginal Australians|Aboriginal Australian]] ancestry.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tvtonight.com.au/2020/07/who-do-you-think-you-are-july-7.html|title= Who Do You Think You Are?: July 7|date= 6 July 2020|publisher=TV Tonight|access-date=21 November 2021}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:17em;\"| Details\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:10em;\"| [[Music recording sales certification|Certifications]]<br /><small>([[List of music recording sales certifications|sales thresholds]])</small>\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! They commenced in 2006.\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| [[AIR Awards of 2011|2011]]<ref name=\"11nom\">{{cite web|url=https://tonedeaf.thebrag.com/independent-music-awards-nominees-announced/|title=Independent Music Awards Nominees Announced|website=tonedeaf|date=13 September 2011|access-date=19 August 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"AIRwins\">{{cite web|url=https://www.air.org.au/awards/history|title=History Wins|website=[[Australian Independent Record Labels Association]]|access-date=18 August 2020}}</ref>\n|''Troy Cassar-Daley Live'' \n| Best Independent Artist\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[AIR Awards of 2015|2015]]<ref name=\"15nom\">{{cite web|url=https://musicfeeds.com.au/news/1-dads-courtney-barnett-lead-this-years-independent-music-award-nominations/#/slide/1|title=1 Dads, Courtney Barnett Lead This Year's Independent Music Award Nominations|website=MusicFeeds|date=7 September 2015|access-date=20 August 2020}}</ref>\n|''Freedom Ride'' \n| Best Independent Country Album\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===APRA Awards===\nCassar-Daley |access-date=24 October 2021 |author=Kelly, Vivienne |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211020000045/https://themusicnetwork.com/2021-aria-awards-nominees/ |archive-date=20 October 2021 |url-status=live}}</ref>\n| ''[[The World Today (album)|The World Today]]'' || Best Country Album || {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===CMAA Awards===\nThe [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] is an annual awards night held in January during the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]], celebrating recording excellence in the [[Australian country music]] industry. Cassar-Daley has won forty awards, the most of any artist.<ref name=\"CMAA2022\"/> Cassar-Daley was inducted into the [[Australian Roll of Renown]] in 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tcmf.com.au/roll-of-renown |title=Roll of Renown |publisher=Tamworth Country Music Festival|access-date=29 October 2020}}</ref> \n\n{{awards table}} <small>(wins
