Awards===\n[[The Deadly Awards]], (commonly known simply as The Deadlys), was an annual celebration of Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander achievement in music, sport, entertainment and community. They ran from 1996 to 2013.\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| [[Deadly Awards 1997|1997]]\n| ''True Believer''\n| Album of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| [[Deadly Awards 2001|2001]]\n| himself\n| Country Artist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| [[Deadly Awards 2003|2003]]\n| himself\n| Male Artist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| [[Deadly Awards 2004|2004]]\n| himself\n| Male Artist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| [[Deadly Awards 2006|2006]]\n| himself\n| Male Artist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| \"Lonesome But Free\"\n| Single of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| [[Deadly Awards 2007|2007]]\n| \"Going Back Home\"\n| Song of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| [[Deadly Awards 2012|2012]]\n| ''Home''\n| Album of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| [[Deadly Awards 2013|2013]]\n| himself\n| Male Artist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Environmental Music Prize===\nThe [[Environmental Music Prize]] is a quest to find a theme song to inspire action on climate and conservation. It commenced in 2022.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://themusicnetwork.com/environmental-music-prize-search/|title=Environmental Music Prize Searches for Green Theme Song|website=The Music Network|date=May 2022|access-date=22 June 2022}}</ref>\n{{awards table}}\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| 2023\n| Back On Country\"\n| Environmental Music Prize\n| {{nom}}\n| <ref name=\"EMP 2023 noms\">{{cite web|url=https://musicfeeds.com.au/news/flume-tash-sultana-and-moju-among-finalists-for-the-2023-environmental-music-prize/|title= Environmental Music Prize 2023 Finalists|website=[[Music Feeds]]|date=26 April 2023|access-date=4 May 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://musicfeeds.com.au/news/xavier-rudd-environmental-music-prize/ |title= Xavier Rudd Wins 2023's Environmental Music Prize|website=[[Music Feeds]]|date=13 June 2023|access-date=13 June 2023}}</ref>\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Mo Awards===\nThe Australian Entertainment Mo Awards (commonly known informally as the [[Mo Awards]]), were annual Australian entertainment industry awards. They recognise achievements in live entertainment in Australia from 1975 to 2016. Troy Cassar-Daley won six awards in that time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.moawards.com.au/awardwinners|title=MO Award Winners|website=Mo Awards|access-date=16 March 2022}}</ref>\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n|-\n| 1997\n| Troy Cassar-Daley\n| Male Country Entertainer of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 1998\n| Troy Cassar-Daley\n| Male Country Entertainer of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 1999\n| Troy Cassar-Daley\n| Male Country Entertainer of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2002\n| Troy Cassar-Daley\n| Male Country Entertainer of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2003\n| Troy Cassar-Daley\n| Male Country Entertainer of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2008\n| Troy Cassar-Daley\n| Slim Dusty Male Country Vocal Performer of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===National Indigenous Music Awards===\nThe [[National Indigenous Music Awards]] recognise excellence, innovation and leadership among Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander musicians from throughout Australia. They commenced in 2004.\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| [[National Indigenous Music Awards 2012|2012]]\n| himself\n| Artist of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| ''Home''\n| Album of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| [[National Indigenous Music Awards 2017|2017]]\n| himself\n| Artist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| ''Things I Carry Around''\n| Album of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| \"Things I Carry Around\"\n| Song of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"1\"| [[National Indigenous Music Awards 2021|2021]]\n| \"Back On Country\"\n| Film Clip of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[National Indigenous Music Awards 2024|2024]]\n| ''Between the Fires''\n| Album of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n| rowspan=\"1\"| <ref name=\"NIMA2024noms\">{{cite web|url= https://themusic.com.au/industry/the-kid-laroi-barkaa-lead-national-indigenous-music-awards-nominations/yHR22t3c394/19-07-24 |title= The Kid LAROI & Barkaa Lead National Indigenous Music Awards Nominations |website=[[The Music (magazine)|The Music]]|date= 19 July 2024|access-date= 19 July 2024|author= Mary Varvaris }}</ref>\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Queensland Music Awards===\nThe [[Queensland Music Awards]] (previously known as Q Song Awards) are annual awards celebrating [[Queensland, Australia]]'s brightest emerging artists and established legends. They commenced in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.queenslandmusicawards.com.au/about|title= About the Queensland Music Awards|website=Queensland Music Awards|access-date=21 March 2021}}</ref>\n\n{{Awards table}} <small>(wins only)</small>\n|-\n| [[Queensland_Music_Awards#2009_Q_Song_Awards|2009]]<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.queenslandmusicawards.com.au/past-winners/2009|title=Past Winners 2009|website=Queensland Music Awards|access-date=25 March 2021}}</ref>\n| \"Big Big Love\"\n| Published Song of the Year \n| {{won}}\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://www.troycassardaley.com.au Official website]\n\n{{Troy Cassar-Daley}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Cassar-Daley, Troy}}\n[[Category:1969 births]]\n[[Category:APRA Award winners]]\n[[Category:ARIA Award winners]]\n[[Category:Australian country guitarists]]\n[[Category:Australian country singers]]\n[[Category:Australian male singers]]\n[[Category:Australian people of Maltese descent]]\n[[Category:Indigenous Australian musicians]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Australian male guitarists]]\n[[Category:Musicians from New South Wales]]\n[[Category:People from Grafton, New South Wales]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Hey_Romeo","to":"Hey Romeo"}],"pages":{"24916880":{"pageid":24916880,"ns":0,"title":"Hey Romeo","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Music band}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Hey Romeo\n| image           =\n| caption         =\n| image_size      =\n| alias           = Udder Maddness\n| origin          = [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]], Canada\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| years_active    = 2002\u2013present\n| label           = Icon, [[Royalty Records]]\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = {{Official website|http://www.heyromeo.com}}\n| current_members = Darren Gusnowsky<br />Rob Shapiro\n| past_members    = Stacie Roper\n}}\n'''Hey Romeo''' is a Canadian [[country music]] trio from [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]]. The band's members are Stacie Roper (vocals), Darren Gusnowsky (guitar) and Rob Shapiro (keyboard). Their 2007 single \"Second Hand News\", a cover of the 1977 [[Fleetwood Mac]] song, reached the Top 50 on the ''[[Radio & Records]]'' Canadian country-singles chart.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://secure4.worldsites.net/countrymusicnews-ca/news.ihtml?step=2&article_id=1356 |title=CD Review - ''Hey Romeo'' |publisher=[[Country Music News]] |accessdate=2009-10-31 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20110721214820/https://secure4.worldsites.net/countrymusicnews-ca/news.ihtml?step=2&article_id=1356 |archivedate=2011-07-21 }}</ref> Hey Romeo was named Top New Talent of the Year - Group or Duo at the 2008 [[Canadian Country Music Association]] awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jos.thatscountry.com/index.php/associations/ccma/397-2008-ccma-award-winners-announced |title=2008 CCMA Award Winners Announced |author=Marti Clayton |date=2008-09-09 |publisher=That's Country |accessdate=2009-10-31 }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Stacie Roper, the lead singer, died on May 8, 2023.\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Beverley_Mahood","to":"Beverley Mahood"}],"pages":{"1159441":{"pageid":1159441,"ns":0,"title":"Beverley Mahood","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Canadian singer and television host}}\n{{Multiple issues|\n{{BLP sources|date=July 2011}}\n{{like resume|date=February 2020}}\n}}\n{{EngvarB|date=April 2013}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2022}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image           = Beverley_Mahood_and_Giselle_Brohman.jpg\n| caption         = Beverley Mahood (left) with Giselle Brohman\n| name            = Beverley Mahood\n| birth_name      =\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1974|11|02}} <br /> [[Belfast]], [[Northern Ireland]], United Kingdom\n| death_date      =\n| origin          = [[London, Ontario|London]], [[Ontario]], Canada\n| Instruments     =\n| genre           = [[Canadian country music|Country]], [[Pop music|pop]]\n| occupation      = Singer, songwriter\n| years_active    = 1996\u2013present\n| label           = Spin Records<br />BPM Entertainment Corp.\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = [http://www.beverleymahood.com/ beverleymahood.com]\n| current_members =\n| past_members    = \n}}\n\n'''Beverley Mahood''' (born 2 November 1974) is a in Irish born Canadian [[country music]] singer-songwriter and television host based in [[Ontario]], Canada. Beverley emigrated from [[Belfast]] to Canada<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/24/arts/the-pop-life-seeking-models-who-can-sing.html?pagewanted=2&src=pm|title=THE POP LIFE; Seeking Models Who Can Sing|last=Strauss|first=Neil|date=24 December 1998|work=The New York Times|page=3|access-date=7 July 2011}}</ref> as a child. She is also formerly part of the all-female trio [[Lace (band)|Lace]], produced by [[David Foster]]. From 2004 to 2005, she co-hosted the [[CKVU|Citytv Vancouver]] morning show, ''[[Breakfast Television]]''. Mahood was then named to co-host [[CMT (Canada)|CMT Canada]]'s flagship show, ''CMT Central''. She starred as the anchor judge on the series \"CMT Chevy Karaoke Star.\"  Other hosting duties have included the reality series ''Project Mom/Project Dad'' and ''Pick a Puppy'' (2010\u20132013) and the countdown program ''Ultimate''.\n\nMahood established a business partnership in 2005 with Canadian entrepreneur [[W. Brett Wilson]] in forming BPM Entertainment Corp. to pursue creative investment opportunities in the entertainment world. She bought out his interest in BPMEC in 2012 and has continued to grow her entertainment business.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Beverley Mahood \u2013 New Songs, Playlists & Latest News \u2013 BBC Music|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/artists/85fba360-ac44-4135-a610-03f008a708bd|access-date=2020-07-28|publisher=BBC|language=en-GB}}</ref> Mahood attended Saunders High School in London.\n\n==Biography==\n\n===Music career===\nMahood has been building her profile in the music scene throughout Canada and the United States since her debut album, ''[[Girl Out of the Ordinary]]'', was released in 1998. The album garnered multiple radio singles and music videos. She signed with [[143 Records]], a record label owned by record producer David Foster. With Foster, she was part of the female trio, [[Lace (band)|Lace]], releasing an album, ''[[Lace (album)|Lace]]'', in 1999. The first single, \"I Want a Man\", went to number 7 on the charts in Canada and was a number one video on CMT's ''Chevy Top 20''. A second solo CD, ''Moody Blue'', was released in 2004, receiving recognition with another number one CMT video for the single \"The First Day You Wake Up Alone.\"\n\nIn addition to her own recorded material, Mahood co-wrote the hit single \"Come to Me,\" recorded by [[Celine Dion]] on her 2005 ''[[Miracle (Celine Dion album)|Miracle]]'' album. She also wrote \"Good to Be Alive,\" the theme for the CMT reality series' ''Project Mother'' and ''Project Dad'', which was released to radio in 2007 with an accompanying music video airing on CMT. In May 2008, Mahood marked her return as a recording artist with the release of the song, \"This Girl.\" A second single, \"Rewrite History,\" was released in October 2008. Mahood's new album, ''Unmistakable'', was released on 18 November 2008. Her most recent Christmas album, ''This Christmas Celebrate Me Home'', was released on 4 November 2008. In May 2013, Mahood released a new single, \"Hope & Gasoline,\" to Canadian country radio.  Mahood's fourth album was released on 12 November 2013. The album was re-released in 2017 as \"New Religion\" with extra tracks.\n\n===Acting career===\nIn 2006, Mahood contributed her name and image to the Bootlegger Jean print campaign with her image appearing in stores across North America. As an actress, she has performed in ''[[The Vagina Monologues]]'' (2004), the stage production ''Heartthrobs'' (2003) and ''Castle Rocks'' ([[Lorraine Kimsa Theatre for Young People|Young People's Theatre]], 1998).\n\nShe performed in the 2004 television film ''[[Chicks with Sticks]]''.<ref name=\"NStars\">{{cite web |author=<!--staff writers--> |title=Chicks with Sticks |website=Northernstars |date=30 June 2016 |publisher=Canadian Independent Visual and Digital Media Association |location=Toronto, Ontario |url=https://www.northernstars.ca/chicks_with_sticks/ |access-date=15 April 2021 |archive-date=15 April 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210415223322/https://www.northernstars.ca/chicks_with_sticks/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Mahood was cast to be the singing superheroine [[Dazzler (Marvel Comics)|Dazzler]] in ''[[X-Men: The Last Stand]]'' (2006). However, she did not shoot any scenes as her character (and many others) were cut from the film.\n\n===Charity work===\nMahood has and continues to host the Kinsmen [[Telemiracle]] in [[Saskatchewan]] annually each March, with 2024 being the 27th year that she has done so. As the host of the Saskatchewan-based telethon, Mahood performs and sings, as well as introducing talent and speaking with various people who have raised funds.  Mahood also sings the Telemiracle theme song \"Thank You\", which has been that telethon's theme since 2021.\n\nShe also performed at The Bohemian Ball in [[Toronto]] on 20 February 2009. The 2009 Bohemian Ball, organised by the Canada Czech Republic Chamber of Commerce, was held in support of the SickKids Foundation and the Hospital for Sick Children.\n\nMahood is a supporter of the following initiatives: the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, the Alberta's Children's Hospital, the David Foster Foundation and the CIBC Run for the Cure. She is also the spokesperson for the Pink Mitten Campaign, which raises money for breast cancer research, education and awareness programs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pinkmitten.com/|title=Pink Mitten \u2013 Geek Chic for the Win!|website=Pinkmitten.com|access-date=29 October 2021}}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n=== Albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[Girl Out of the Ordinary]]''\n| \n* Release date: 3 February 1998\n* Label: Spin Records\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Moody Blue''\n| \n* Release date: 23 March 2004\n* Label: Spin Records\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Have a Little Faith''\n| \n* Release date: 2006\n* Label: Spin Records\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''This Christmas Celebrate Me Home''\n| \n* Release date: 4 November 2008\n* Label: BPM Entertainment\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Unmistakable''\n| \n* Release date: 4 November 2008\n* Label: BPM Entertainment\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Hope and Gasoline''\n|\n*Release date: 12 November 2013\n*Label: Spin Music\n|}\n\n=== Singles ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:22em;\"| Single\n! This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Audrey_Auld-Mezera","to":"Audrey Auld-Mezera"}],"pages":{"24790296":{"pageid":24790296,"ns":0,"title":"Audrey Auld-Mezera","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2022}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Audrey Auld-Mezera\n| image            = Audrey Auld at Threadgill's in Austin, TX. Photo by Ron Baker..jpg\n| image_size       =\n| landscape        = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank -->\n| alt              = Audrey Auld at Threadgill's in Austin, TX. Photo by Ron Baker\n| caption          = Audrey Auld at Threadgill's in Austin, TX (2010)\n| birth_name       = Audrey Auld\n| native_name      =\n| native_name_lang =\n| alias            =\n| birth_date       = 14 January 1964\n| birth_place      =\n| origin           = Hobart, Tasmania, Australia\n| death_date       = {{Death date and age|2015|8|9|1964|1|14|df=y}}\n| death_place      = Stinson Beach, California, USA\n| genre            = [[country music|Country]]\n| occupation       = Singer-Songwriter\n| instrument       = Guitar\n| years_active     = <!-- YYYY\u2013YYYY (or \u2013present) -->\n| label            = [http://www.recklessrecords.com Reckless Records]\n| past_member_of  = [[Bill Chambers (musician)|Bill Chambers]], [[Kieran Kane]], [[Fred Eaglesmith]], [[Mary Gauthier]], [[Dale Watson (singer)|Dale Watson]], [[Kasey Chambers]], and [[Carrie Rodriguez]]\n| website          = {{URL|http://www.audreyauld.com/}}<!-- {{URL|example.com}} -->\n}}\n\n'''Audrey Auld-Mezera''' (''[[n\u00e9e]]'' '''Audrey Auld''';<ref name=\"amg\"/> 14 January 1964 \u2013 9 August 2015) was an [[Australian American]] [[country music]] touring [[singer\u2013songwriter]]. She had released eleven albums and three EPs on her own Reckless Records label,<ref name=\"amg\"/> and had recorded with numerous musicians including [[Bill Chambers (musician)|Bill Chambers]], [[Kieran Kane]], [[Fred Eaglesmith]], [[Mary Gauthier]], [[Dale Watson (singer)|Dale Watson]], [[Kasey Chambers]], and [[Carrie Rodriguez]].<ref name=\"reckless\"/> She had songs recorded by various artists and songs placed on the FX TV shows \"Justified\", \"Longmire\", \"NCIS: New Orleans\" and \"The Good Guys\". She hosted songwriting workshops with inmates in San Quentin Prison in California from 2007 till 2013.<ref name=\"reckless\"/>\n\nAuld-Mezera died of [[cancer]] on 9 August 2015, aged 51.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/2015/08/10/singer-songwriter-audrey-auld-dies-51/31421879/|title=Singer-songwriter Audrey Auld dies at 51|newspaper=[[The Tennessean]]|date=August 10, 2015|accessdate=August 10, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://obituaries.themercury.com.au/notice/187872002?random=1439253882358/|title=Tributes: Auld, Audrey (Mrs Daniel Mezera)|newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)]]|date=August 11, 2015|accessdate=August 11, 2015}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|+List of albums, with release date and label shown\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Wood''\n| \n* Released: July 2012\n* Format: CD, DD\n* Label: Reckless Records\n\n|}\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n===ARIA Music Awards===\nThe [[ARIA Music Awards]] are a set of annual ceremonies presented by [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA), which recognise excellence, innovation, and achievement across all genres of the [[music of Australia]]. They commenced in 1987.<ref name=\"reckless\"/><ref name=\"CountryAlbum\">ARIA Award previous winners. {{cite web|url=http://www.ariaawards.com.au/history/award/Best-Country-Album|title=ARIA Awards Best Country Album|publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA)|access-date=9 April 2022}}</ref>\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2001|2001]] || ''The Fallen'' || Best Country Album || {{nom}} \n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2005|2005]] || ''Texas'' || Best Country Album || {{nom}} \n|-\n{{end}}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist|1|refs=\n\n<ref name=\"amg\">[{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p792142|pure_url=yes}} Audrey Auld Mezera] at allmusic</ref>\n\n<ref name=\"reckless\">[http://www.recklessrecords.com/aa_bio.html Reckless Records biography]</ref>\n\n}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://audreyauld.com/index.html Official website]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Auld-Mezera, Audrey}}\n[[Category:Australian country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Australian women singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Australian singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Australian women guitarists]]\n[[Category:1964 births]]\n[[Category:2015 deaths]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Kal_Hourd","to":"Kal Hourd"}],"pages":{"24916923":{"pageid":24916923,"ns":0,"title":"Kal Hourd","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Canadian country music singer-songwriter}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Kal Hourd\n| image             = \n| caption        = \n| image_size        = \n| background      = solo_singer\n| origin          = [[Saskatoon, Saskatchewan]], Canada\n| instrument      = \n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer\n| years_active    = 2007\u2013present\n| label           = [[E1 Entertainment|E1]]\n| associated_acts = \n| website             = \n}}\n'''Kal Hourd''' (pronounced Hurd, born May 9) is a Canadian [[country music]] singer-songwriter. Hourd's debut album, ''Haven't Even Met Yet'', was released in August 2009 by [[E1 Entertainment]].<ref name=\"starphoenix\">{{cite web |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/38138897/its_time_to_meet_kal_hourd_review_by/ |title=It's time to meet Kal Hourd |last1=Dedekker |first1=Jeff |last2=French |first2=Janet |date=2009-09-10 |publisher=[[The StarPhoenix]] |accessdate=2019-10-31 |location=Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, Canada }}</ref>\n\n== Career ==\nHourd grew up in [[Stockholm, Saskatchewan]].<ref name=\"MacPherson\"/> He took up music when he was young as, unlike many of his friends, he was not athletic.<ref name=\"MacPherson\"/> He was encouraged to perform by [[Brad Johner]], whom he met and jammed with in 2001, and so he started entering talent quests.<ref name=\"MacPherson\"/> He began writing songs for his first album in 2006.<ref name=\"starphoenix\"/> In 2007, he won a rising star award at the 2007 Saskatchewan Country Music Association (SCMA) Awards.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Stewart |first1=Jeanette |title=Johner big winner at SCMA award show |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/512884111/?terms=%22Kal%2BHourd%22 |work=Star-Phoenix |date=16 April 2007 |location=Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, Canada |page=2}}</ref><ref name=\"Star\"/>\n\nHe released his debut album ''Haven't Even Met Yet'' in August 2009.<ref name=\"starphoenix\"/><ref name=\"MacPherson\">{{cite journal |last1=MacPherson |first1=Alex J. |title=Lucky Break. How a chance meeting changed Kal Hourd's life |journal=Verb |date=December 7, 2012 |volume=R57 |pages=10\u201311 and cover |url=https://issuu.com/verb/docs/r57 |location=Regina, Saskatchewan, Canada}}</ref> It featured 12 songs, eight of which Hourd had co-written.<ref name=\"Dedekker3\">{{cite news |last1=Dedekker |first1=Jeff |title=Hourd formulating a new plan |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/38139013/hourd_formulating_a_new_plan_by_jeff/ |accessdate=31 October 2019 |work=The Leader-Post |date=4 March 2010 |location=Regina, Saskatchewan, Canada |page=9}}</ref> Prior to the release of the album, Canadian astronaut [[Julie Payette]] asked for a copy of ''Haven't Even Met Yet'' to take with her on a mission to the [[International Space Station]], on the [[Space Shuttle Endeavour|Space Shuttle ''Endeavour'']].<ref name=\"MacPherson\"/><ref name=\"Star\">{{cite news |title=music to get weightless by |work=The Toronto Star |date=3 June 2009 |location=Toronto, Ontario, Canada |page=E2 |issn=0319-0781}}</ref><ref name=\"Goodman\">{{cite news |last1=Goodman |first1=Lee-Anne |title=Payette, Thirsk to make history in space |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/technology/payette-thirsk-to-make-history-in-space/article585522/ |accessdate=31 October 2019 |work=The Globe and Mail |date=July 8, 2009 |location=Toronto, Ontario, Canada}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Sask. musician in orbit over astronaut's support |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatchewan/sask-musician-in-orbit-over-astronaut-s-support-1.853007 |accessdate=31 October 2019 |work=CBC News |date=June 12, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Julie Payette emportera avec elle un peu de Saskatchewan dans l'espace |url=https://ici.radio-canada.ca/REGIONS/saskatchewan/Tele/Chroniques/index_1092_6_09.shtml |accessdate=31 October 2019 |work=Le T\u00e9l\u00e9journal Saskatchewan |date=3 June 2009 |language=French}}</ref> The same year, 2009, Hourd's single ''Beautiful Sound'', co-written by Missouri songwriter Deanna Harper,<ref name=\"SCMA2010\"/> reached No 50 on the Canadian Country chart,<ref name=\"Billboard\"/> his song ''When Pink Is Just a Color Again'' was chosen as the [[Pink Ribbon]] International official song,<ref>{{cite web |title=Music - Pink Ribbon Songs |url=http://pinkribbon.org/media-and-events/pink-ribbon-songs/ |website=Pink Ribbon |accessdate=31 October 2019}}</ref> and he won Video of the Year for ''When Pink Is Just a Color Again'' at the SCMA awards.<ref name=\"Star\"/><ref>{{cite web |title=2009 SCMA Award Winners |url=https://scma.sk.ca/past-awards/2009-scma-award-winners/ |website=Saskatchewan Country Music Association |accessdate=31 October 2019}}</ref> At the 2010 SCMA Awards, Hourd received awards for album of the year for ''Haven't Even Met Yet'', as well as single of the year and song of the year for ''Beautiful Sound''.<ref name=\"SCMA2010\">{{cite news |title=Hourd, Prevost win big at SCMA awards |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/498302339/?terms=%22Kal%2BHourd%22 |accessdate=31 October 2019 |work=The Leader-Post |date=20 April 2010 |location=Regina, Saskatchewan, Canada}}</ref> In 2012, ''When Pink Is Just a Color Again'' won him a second SCMA song of the year award.<ref name=\"SCMA2012\">{{cite news |title=Prevost pulls off SCMA hat trick |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/498774882/?terms=%22When%2BPink%2BIs%2BJust%2Ba%2BColor%2BAgain%22 |accessdate=31 October 2019 |work=The Leader-Post |date=24 April 2012 |location=Regina, Saskatchewan, Canada}}</ref> In 2016, he co-wrote the song ''Covered In Dust'' with Darlene Tuleta, who recorded the single and video.<ref name=\"Boz\">{{cite news |last1=Boz |title=Darlene Tuleta Interview & \"Farm Fresh Song\" |url=https://www.620ckrm.com/2016/04/25/boz-darlene-tuleta-interview-farm-fresh-song/ |accessdate=31 October 2019 |work=620 CKRM |date=April 25, 2016 |location=Regina, Saskatchewan, Canada}}</ref> Hourd was also leader of The Kal Hourd Band.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Dedekker |first1=Jeff |title=SCMA award nominees |url=https://leaderpost.com/entertainment/scma-award-nominees |accessdate=31 October 2019 |work=The Leader-Post |date=February 25, 2011 |location=Regina, Saskatchewan, Canada}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Details\n|-\n! Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"65\"| [[Canada Country|CAN Country]]<br /><ref name=\"Billboard\">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/kal-hourd/chart-history/canada-country|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190812061645/https://www.billboard.com/music/kal-hourd/chart-history/canada-country|url-status=dead|archive-date=August 12, 2019|title=Kal Hourd - Canada Country|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=August 12, 2019}}</ref>\n|-\n| 2009\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Beautiful Sound\"<ref name=\"SCMA2010\"/>\n| 50\n| rowspan=\"4\"| ''Haven't Even Met Yet''<ref name=\"starphoenix\"/>\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2010\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Haven't Even Met Yet\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Always Better\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2011\n! scope=\"row\"| \"When Pink Is Just a Color Again\"<ref name=\"SCMA2012\"/>\n| \u2014\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*{{official website|https://web.archive.org/web/20111009110650/http://www.kalhourd.com/Kal_Hourd/Kal.html}}\n*[http://www.cmt.ca/Artist/KalHourd Kal Hourd] at [[CMT (Canada)|CMT]]\n\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Hourd, Kal}}\n[[Category:Canadian country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Canadian male singers]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Saskatoon]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]\n[[Category:Canadian male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Singers from Saskatchewan]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Amber_Lawrence","to":"Amber Lawrence"}],"pages":{"31914357":{"pageid":31914357,"ns":0,"title":"Amber Lawrence","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Australian country music singer-songwriter}}\n{{BLP sources|date=May 2024}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=July 2017}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name         = Amber Lawrence\n| image        = Amber Lawrence 2016.jpg\n| alt          =\n| caption      = Amber Lawrence, [[Penrith, New South Wales|Penrith]], March 2016\n| image_size   =\n| birth_name   = Amber Louise Lawrence\n| birth_date   = {{birth date and age|df=y|1978|4|19}}\n| birth_place  = Sydney, New South Wales, Australia\n| origin       = \n| genre        = {{hlist|[[Australian country music|Australian country]]|children's}}\n| occupation   = Musician\n| instrument   = {{hlist|Guitar|vocals}}\n| years_active = 2003\u2013present\n| label        = {{hlist|[[ABC Commercial|ABC]]|[[Universal Music Australia|Universal]]|Core/[[Sony Music Australia|Sony]]}}\n| website      = {{URL|amberlawrence.com.au}}\n}}\n\n'''Amber Louise Lawrence''' (born 19 April 1978) is an Australian [[Australian country music|country music]] singer-songwriter-guitarist. Five of her studio albums have reached the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Albums Chart]] top&nbsp;50, ''3'' (2012), ''Superheroes'' (2014), ''Happy Ever After'' (2016), ''Our Backyard'' (2017) and ''Spark'' (2019, No.&nbsp;13). At the [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] Lawrence has won six Golden Guitar trophies.<ref name=\"CMAAwins2023\"/>\n\nLawrence has performed and is featured at many of the leading country music festivals, such as Gympie Muster, CMC Rocks The Hunter and QLD, Mildura Music Festival, Deni Ute Muster, Caboolture, Mudbulls & Music and Derwent Valley Muster.<ref name=\"newsnn\">{{cite web|url=http://www.newsnn.net/2015/01/earlybird-offer-on-country-muster.html|title=New Norfolk NEWS: Earlybird offer on country muster|publisher=newsnn.net|accessdate=25 November 2015}}</ref>{{citation needed|date=April 2015}} She has toured with the likes of [[Lee Kernaghan]], [[The McClymonts]],<ref name=ABC/> [[Adam Harvey]], [[Melinda Schneider]], Sunny Cowgirls, and Kaylens Rain, and event tours such as Chic Frontier.<ref name=ABC/>\n\nOver the years, Lawrence has also been a supporter of Australia's military, performing for the troops both abroad and at various events around the country. In 2007, she played in East Timor,<ref>{{cite journal |date=December 2007 |title=From Little Pattie to the Screaming Jets a tradition continues |journal=Platypus Magazine |publisher=[[Australian Federal Police]] |issue=97 |pages=30\u201331 |url=http://www.afp.gov.au/~/media/afp/pdf/3/30-31-from-little-pattie-to-the-screaming-jets.pdf |access-date=27 April 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150404225700/http://www.afp.gov.au/~/media/afp/pdf/3/30-31-from-little-pattie-to-the-screaming-jets.pdf |archive-date=4 April 2015 |url-status=dead |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and in 2013, she was in the Sinai, entertaining Australian and coalition forces.<ref>{{cite news |title=Amber Lawrence is busy with music and mates |newspaper=[[Northern Daily Leader]] |date=22 January 2014 |url=http://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/story/2038544/amber-lawrence-is-busy-with-music-and-mates/}}</ref> Her song \"Man Across The Street\" is about a returned veteran; it resulted in her 2013 Golden Guitar nomination for \"Best Female Artist of the Year\".<ref name=ManAcrossTheStreet/>\n\n==Personal life==\nAmber Louise Lawrence was born on 19 April 1978.<ref name=\"Official Bio\">{{cite web | url=http://www.amberlawrence.com.au/bio.htm | title=Biography \u2013 Country Music Singer Songwriter | last=Lawrence | first=Amber | website=Amber Lawrence Official Website | via=[[National Library of Australia]] | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20070829001226/http://www.amberlawrence.com.au/bio.htm | archive-date=29 August 2007 | access-date=31 December 2021 | url-status=live }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref name=\"NLA \">{{Citation | author1=Lawrence, Amber | title=Happy Ever After | year=2016 | url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/214295699 | access-date=31 December 2021 | quote=Creator: Lawrence, Amber (performer.) (1978-) }}</ref><ref name=\"APRA Backyard\"/> She grew up in the Sydney suburb of [[Mascot, New South Wales|Mascot]] with two siblings.<ref name=\"AAP 1\">{{cite web |title=Interview: Amber Lawrence |url=http://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/pages/main-menu/news/latest-news/interview--amber-lawrence|publisher=[[Country Music Channel]] |access-date=28 December 2021 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130915080239/http://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/pages/main-menu/news/latest-news/interview--amber-lawrence |archive-date=15 September 2013 |url-status=dead |df=dmy-all |agency=[[Australian Associated Press]] (AAP) }}</ref><ref name=\"AusStar 1\">{{cite web | url=http://schools.austar.com.au/events/bios.aspx?id=25 | title=Events > Bios: Amber Lawrence | website=AUSTAR for Schools | date=September 2010 | via=[[National Library of Australia]] | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20110412201246/http://schools.austar.com.au/events/bios.aspx?id=25 | archive-date=12 April 2011 | access-date=28 December 2021 | url-status=live }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Her father, Brian Lawrence, was a surf lifesaver at [[South Maroubra Surf Life Saving Club|South Maroubra club]] until he had a stroke at age 40.<ref name=\"Dawson 1\"/><ref name=\"SMSLSC\">{{cite web | url=http://www.surflifesaving.com.au/news/amber-lawrence-hits-her-stride-for-stroke | title=Amber Lawrence Hits Her Stride for Stroke | website=Surf Life Saving NSW | date=14 November 2014 | via=National Library of Australia | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20150322032733/http://www.surflifesaving.com.au/news/amber-lawrence-hits-her-stride-for-stroke | archive-date=22 March 2015 | access-date=28 December 2021 | url-status=live }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> When a toddler, Lawrence wandered onto the busy road in front of her home and was saved from serious injury by a neighbour.<ref name=\"RSL Defence\">{{cite web | url=http://www.defencecare.org.au/ambassadors/amber-lawrence | title=Amber Lawrence | publisher=RSL Defence Care | via=National Library of Australia | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20190306191222/http://www.defencecare.org.au/ambassadors/amber-lawrence | archive-date=6 March 2019 | access-date=29 December 2021 | url-status=live }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref name=\"PR Core Music\">{{cite press release | author=<!--Not stated--> | url=http://www.hotoffthepress.com.au/news/2011/12/media-release-Amber-Lawrence-3-2012-Tour-Dates.html | title=Amber Lawrence \u2013 2012 Tour Dates | website=Hot off the Press | year=2012 | via=National Library of Australia | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20140204123355/http://www.hotoffthepress.com.au/news/2011/12/media-release-Amber-Lawrence-3-2012-Tour-Dates.html | archive-date=4 February 2014 | access-date=29 December 2021 | url-status=live }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> She attended [[Our Lady of the Sacred Heart College, Sydney]] where she completed the [[Higher School Certificate (New South Wales)|Higher School Certificate]] in 1995, including a place in the Order of Merit List.<ref>{{cite web|title=1995 Higher School Certificate Order of Merit List|url=http://www.boardofstudies.nsw.edu.au/bos_stats/hsc95_5000/hsc95t5k_4.html|publisher=boardofstudies.nsw.edu.au|accessdate=15 September 2013}}</ref> She excelled at athletics and tried out for the state team.<ref name=\"AusStar 1\"/>\n\nAfter graduating from the [[University of New South Wales]] with a commerce degree and working for six years as a chartered accountant for [[Qantas]], Lawrence became a full-time musician.<ref name=ABC>{{cite web |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090616110720/http://www.abc.net.au/profiles/content/s2593350.htm |url=http://www.abc.net.au/profiles/content/s2593350.htm |title=Amber Lawrence |date=9 June 2009 |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] (ABC) |archive-date=16 June 2009 |access-date=28 December 2021 }}</ref><ref name=\"Erlewine 1\"/> She had started guitar lessons from the age of 22.<ref name=\"AAP 1\"/> Brian Lawrence died in September 2008, aged 52, after being diagnosed with [[leukemia|leukaemia]].<ref name=\"Dawson 1\"/>\n\nLawrence met marketer Martin Newman via a dating app in 2016.<ref name=\"Byram\">{{cite news | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20200320215238/https://www.camdencourier.com.au/story/6125361/amber-lawrence-has-new-spark-in-her-step/?cs=2999 | url=https://www.camdencourier.com.au/story/6125361/amber-lawrence-has-new-spark-in-her-step/?cs=2999 | title=Australian Country Music Favourite Amber Lawrence Tours New Album ''Spark'' to Laurieton | last=Byram | first=Vickii | work=[[Australian Community Media#North Coast NSW|Camden Haren Courier]] | archive-date=20 March 2020 | date=13 June 2019 | access-date=9 January 2022 | url-status=live }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> On Christmas Day 2017, Lawrence and Newman were engaged at Coogee Beach,<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/sydney-confidential/country-music-singer-amber-lawrence-is-engaged-to-tinder-boyfriend-martin-newman/news-story/e813b4e9e360dd334a430157411d2bda |title=Country music star engaged to Tinder boyfriend |last=Moran |first=Jonathon |date=16 February 2018 |website=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]] |access-date=9 January 2022 }}</ref> and in August 2018 the couple had a child.<ref name=\"Leeson\">{{Cite news |url=https://www.newcastleherald.com.au/story/5452727/mums-the-word/ |title=Mum's the word |first=Josh |last=Leeson |date=9 June 2018 |website=Newcastle Herald }}</ref> On 2 May 2019 they married in [[Port Douglas]], Queensland.<ref name=\"Byram\"/><ref name=\"Sheridan\">{{cite news | url=https://issuu.com/info-capitalnews.com/docs/2019_country_music_capital_news_-_june_issue_volum | title=Dream Big | work=Country Music Capital News | date=1 June 2019 | volume=44 | issue=6 | last=Sheridan | first=Haley | pages=20\u201321 | access-date=9 January 2022 }}</ref>\n\nAfter a chance encounter at an airport in 2017, a unique opportunity presented itself when Lawrence was invited to perform in New York for an event commemorating the 75th Anniversary Battle of the Coral Sea with the American Association. The audience was made up of surviving war veterans, then-Australian prime minister Malcolm Turnbull, then-President of the United States of America, Barack Obama, and Donald Trump among others. Lawrence performed the poignant \"100 Year Handshake\" which she wrote especially for the event with her now-husband Martin Newman.{{Citation needed|date=May 2024}}\n\nIn 2019, Lawrence was invited to perform as part of Vision Australia's Carols by Candlelight, broadcast live annually on Christmas Eve from the Sidney Myer Music Bowl in Melbourne, Australia.{{Citation needed|date=May 2024}}\n\nLawrence is also a mentor to young artists in the Australian Music industry and has provided free entertainment and mentoring in over 300 schools Australia wide, as part of her 'Be Your Own Superhero' program.{{Citation needed|date=May 2024}}\n\nLawrence is the face of iHeartRadio Australia Country, hosting the show each week, a guest presenter on Channel 9's 'Getaway' and was the co-host of the CMC Music Awards in 2017 \u2013 live on Foxtel, and the 2019 Golden Guitar Awards. Lawrence was also extremely honored to receive an Australia Day Bronze Achievement Award for her contribution to War Veterans and their families, via her work with RSL DefenceCare.{{Citation needed|date=May 2024}}\n\nFrom February 2022 to 23 April 2022, Lawrence hosted ABC Radio's ''[[Saturday Night Country]]'' national show, temporarily replacing regular host [[Beccy Cole]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2024}}\n\n==Music career==\n===2003\u20132006: Career beginnings and ''I've Got the Blues''===\nIn January 2003, Lawrence started busking in [[Tamworth, New South Wales|Tamworth]] ahead of its annual [[Tamworth Country Music Festival|country music festival]] although she has said that \"I had no idea what Tamworth was about.\"<ref name=\"AAP 1\"/> She was still working as an accountant, \"It wasn't really a conscious decision for me to become a country singer.\"<ref name=\"AAP 1\"/> Returning in 2004, she entered the Road to Tamworth competition and finished second behind [[Jessica Mauboy]].<ref name=\"AAP 1\"/> Also that year she attended the College of Country Music, where she met fellow aspiring country singer [[Travis Collins]].<ref name=\"Sollars\">{{cite web | url=https://freetimes.com.au/stories/2017-10-17/golden-guitars-in-our-backyard/ | title=Golden Guitars in 'Our Backyard' | last=Sollars | first=Jeremy | website=Southern Free Times | date=17 October 2017 | via=National Library of Australia | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20180323153956/https://freetimes.com.au/stories/2017-10-17/golden-guitars-in-our-backyard/ | archive-date=23 March 2018 | access-date=31 December 2021 | url-status=live }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> The singer-songwriter was one of nine grand finalists for the Star Maker Quest at the 2005 [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] (CMAA), but lost to [[Samantha McClymont]].<ref name=\"Star Maker 2005\">{{cite web | url=http://www.capitalnews.com.au/custom.asp?page_id=6&y=2002&m=2 | title=Toyota Star Maker 2005 | website=apital News | via=National Library of Australia | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20050615175816/http://www.capitalnews.com.au/custom.asp?page_id=6&y=2002&m=2 | archive-date=15 June 2005 | access-date=28 December 2021 | url-status=live }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>\n\nIn January 2006, Lawrence independently released her debut four-track extended play, ''I've Got the Blues''.<ref name=\"Erlewine 1\"/><ref name=\"ARIA Report 830\"/> It was produced by Matt Fell and reached the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA singles chart]] top&nbsp;100.<ref name=\"ARIA Report 830\">{{cite journal | date=30 January 2006 | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20060219130000/http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/23790/20060220-0000/issue830.pdf | title=Week Commencing ~ 30th January 2006 ~ Issue #830 | last=Wallace | first=Ian | journal=The ARIA Report | publisher=[[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA) | issue=830 | pages=2, 4, 7, 18 | url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/documents/issue830.pdf | archive-date=19 February 2006 | access-date=28 December 2021 | url-status=dead }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>\n\n===2007\u20132011: ''The Mile'' and ''When It All Comes Down''===\nLawrence's debut studio album, ''The Mile'', was released in July 2007 and was again produced by McCormack.<ref name=\"Erlewine 1\"/><ref name=\"NLA Mile\">{{Citation | author1=Amber Lawrence (Performer) | title=The Mile | year=2007 | publisher=MRA (Label)/destra Media (Distributor) | url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/37137040 | access-date=28 December 2021}}</ref> The title track relates to Sam McRae, a \"16-year-old jockey\" who \"died in a racing accident\".<ref name=\"Dawson 1\">{{cite web | url=http://nucountry.com.au/articles/diary/november2014/101114_amberlawrence_cdreview.htm | title=Dave's Diary \u2013 Amber Lawrence CD Review | last=Dawson | first=Dave | website=Nu Country | date=10 November 2014 | via=National Library of Australia | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20190326164955/http://nucountry.com.au/articles/diary/november2014/101114_amberlawrence_cdreview.htm | archive-date=26 March 2019 | access-date=28 December 2021 | url-status=live }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> The album reached No.&nbsp;13 on the ARIA Country Albums chart.<ref name=\"ARIA Report 906\">{{cite journal | date=16 July 2007 | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20070719140034/http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/23790/20070720-0000/issue906.pdf | title=Week Commencing ~ 16th July 2007 ~ Issue #906 | last=Wallace | first=Ian | journal=The ARIA Report | publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA) | issue=906 | page=20 | url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/documents/issue906.pdf | archive-date=19 July 2007 | access-date=28 December 2021 | url-status=dead }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>\n\nAt the 2008 CMAA, she was nominated for \"Female Artist of the Year\" and \"New Talent\",<ref name=ABC/> and in the following year she was nominated for \"Female Artist of the Year\", \"APRA Song of the Year\" and \"Video Clip of the Year\". She received a nomination for \"Country Work of the Year\" for ''The Mile''{{'}}s single, \"Good Girls\" at the [[APRA Music Awards of 2009]].<ref name=\"APRA 2009\">{{cite web |url=http://apraamcos.com.au/awards/2000-2010/2009-awards/music-awards/country-work-of-the-year/ |title=2009 APRA Music Awards |publisher=[[APRA AMCOS]] |accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref> At the [[AIR Awards of 2009]], ''The Mile'' was nominated for Independent Country Album of the Year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/musicnews/s2717560.htm |title=AIR Awards 2009 nominations |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=19 October 2009 |accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref>\n\nHer second studio album, ''When It All Comes Down'', was released in August 2009. It reached No.&nbsp;17 on the ARIA Country Albums chart and No.&nbsp;16 on the related Hitseekers Albums chart.<ref name=\"ARIA Report 1019\">{{cite journal | date=7 September 2009 | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20091004130030/http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/23790/20091005-0000/issue1019.pdf | title=Week Commencing ~ 7th September 2009 ~ Issue #1019 | last=Wallace | first=Ian | journal=The ARIA Report | publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA) | issue=1019 | pages=22\u201323 | url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/documents/issue1019.pdf | archive-date=4 October 2009 | access-date=29 December 2021 | url-status=dead }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Two of its tracks, \"Always Kiss Me Goodnight\" and \"The Good Men\" were in honour of her father, Brian, who had died in the previous year.<ref name=\"Dawson 1\"/> Susan Jarvis of ''Capital News'' observed it was, \"at the same time intensely personal and universally relevant. The songs \u2014 all Amber originals \u2014 are catchy, powerful and full of feeling.\"<ref name=\"Jarvis\">{{cite web | url=http://www.capitalnews.com.au/editorial.asp?editorial_id=1676 | title=Feature Album \u2013 ''When It All Comes Down'' | last=Jarvis | first=Susan | website=Capital News | via=National Library of Australia | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20091007212304/http://www.capitalnews.com.au/editorial.asp?editorial_id=1676 | archive-date=7 October 2009 | access-date=28 December 2021 | url-status=live }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>\n\nIn 2010 she won \"Female Vocalist of the Year\" at the Victorian National Country Music Awards (sponsored by the Whittlesea Country Music Festival),<ref name=\"WCMF 2010\">{{cite web | url=http://www.whittleseacountrymusicfestival.com.au/Awards.html | title=Victorian & National Country Music Awards | publisher=Whittlesea Country Music Festival | year=2011 | via=National Library of Australia | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20110218075011/http://www.whittleseacountrymusicfestival.com.au/Awards.html | archive-date=18 February 2011 | access-date=29 December 2021 | url-status=live }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> and was nominated for \"Best Independent Country Album\" at the Independent Country Music Awards (sponsored by the [[Mildura Country Music Festival]]).<ref name=\"ICMA 2010\">{{cite web | url=http://www.milduracountrymusic.com.au/indexce5b.html | title=2010 The Southern Stars \u2013 The Australian Independent Country Music Awards | publisher=[[Mildura Country Music Festival]] | year=2010 | via=National Library of Australia | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20101025231448/http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/56163/20101022-1342/www.milduracountrymusic.com.au/indexce5b.html | archive-date=25 October 2010 | access-date=29 December 2021 | url-status=live }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> At the 2010 CMAA, ''When It All Comes Down'' was nominated for three categories.<ref name=\"ABC AL on road\">{{cite web |url=http://abccountry.net.au/news/amber-lawrence-on-the-road |title=Amber Lawrence on the Road |publisher=ABC Country. (Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC)) |date=22 February 2010 |access-date=29 December 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141210010047/http://abccountry.net.au/news/amber-lawrence-on-the-road |archive-date=10 December 2014 |url-status=dead |df=dmy-all }}</ref> \n[[File:Amber lawrence performing.jpg|thumb|250px|Lawrence performing in 2011]]\n\n===2012\u20132015: ''3'' and ''Superheroes''===\nThe simply named ''3'', her third studio album, was released in January 2012 via Core Music/[[Sony Music Australia|Sony Music Entertainment]],<ref name=\"NLA 3\">{{Citation | author1=Lawrence, Amber | author2=Harvey, Adam | author-link2=Adam Harvey | author3=Whitehead, Axle | author-link=Axle Whitehead | author4=McCormack, Rod | author-link4=Rod McCormack | title=3 | year=2012 | publisher=Core Music: Distributed by [[Sony Music Australia|Sony Music Entertainment Australia]] | url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/163809589 | access-date=29 December 2021 }}</ref> which peaked in the ARIA Albums top&nbsp;50 and reached No.&nbsp;4 on the Country Albums chart.<ref name=\"ARIA Report 1144\">{{cite journal | date=30 January 2012 | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20120315130016/http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/23790/20120316-0000/Issue1144.pdf | title=Week Commencing ~ 30th January 2012 ~ Issue #1144 | last=Wallace | first=Ian | journal=The ARIA Report | publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA) | issue=1144 | pages=2, 5, 7, 12, 15, 20\u201321 | url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/documents/issue1144.pdf | archive-date=15 March 2012 | access-date=29 December 2021 | url-status=dead }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Its second single, \"The Man Across the Street\", relates to the experiences of her neighbour, Bill and other Vietnam Veterans.<ref name=\"Dawson 1\"/><ref name=\"RSL Defence\"/> On 5 March, ''3'', was named Album of the Week at [[98.9 FM (Brisbane)|98.9 FM]], with their reviewer explaining, \"its mixture of upbeat optimism, personal happiness and resilience along with some references to deeper issues including courage in the face of hardship, is another step upward on a sharply-angled career path that has seen [her] delight audiences all over the country.\"<ref name=\"AotW 98.9\">{{cite web | url=http://www.989fm.com.au/news/album-of-the-week-amber-lawrence/ | title=Album of the Week : Amber Lawrence &#124; 98.9 FM For The Best Country | publisher=[[98.9 FM (Brisbane)|98.9 FM]] | date=5 March 2012 | via=National Library of Australia | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20120419073916/http://www.989fm.com.au/news/album-of-the-week-amber-lawrence/ | archive-date=19 April 2012 | access-date=29 December 2021 | url-status=live }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> In both 2012 and 2013, Lawrence was again nominated for CMAA's \"Female Artist of the Year\".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2013/01/22/3674067.htm |title=Could it be gold for Amber Lawrence? |author=Jennifer Ingall |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=22 January 2013 |accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref><ref name=ManAcrossTheStreet>{{cite web |url=http://abccountry.net.au/news/41st-cmaa-award-finalists-announced |title=41st CMAA Award Finalists Announced |publisher=ABC Country |date=13 November 2012 |accessdate=24 April 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150304100021/http://abccountry.net.au/news/41st-cmaa-award-finalists-announced |archive-date=4 March 2015 |url-status=dead |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In 2014, Lawrence was nominated for \"Female Artist of the Year\" at the Australian Club Entertainment Awards.{{citation needed|date=April 2015}}\n\nIn September 2014, Lawrence released her fourth studio album, ''Superheroes''. It also reached the ARIA top&nbsp;50, while debuting at No.&nbsp;3 on the Country Albums chart.<ref name=\"ARIA Report 1283\">{{cite journal | date=29 September 2014 | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20140930044703/http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/23790/20140930-1447/Issue1283.pdf | title=Week Commencing ~ 29th September 2014 ~ Issue #1283 | last=Wallace | first=Ian | journal=The ARIA Report | publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA) | issue=1283 | pages=2, 5, 7, 13, 16, 22 | url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/documents/issue1283.pdf | archive-date=30 September 2014 | access-date=29 December 2021 | url-status=dead }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> The CD's artwork includes a photo of her parents in their surfing era at Maroubra Beach, where they met.<ref name=\"Dawson 1\"/> Dave Dawson of ''Nu Country'' observes that the album has her, \"reeling from a relationship break-up and depression, sings of being her own superhero in the title track, name checking Wonder Woman, Spider Man and Iron Man.\"<ref name=\"Dawson 1\"/> In 2015, Lawrence was awarded the CMAA's Golden Guitar trophy for Best Female Artist of the Year,<ref name=\"CMAA 2021\">{{cite web | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211116051258/https://www.country.com.au/awards/golden-guitar-award-winners | url=https://www.country.com.au/awards/golden-guitar-award-winners | title=Golden Guitar Award Winners (1973\u20132021) | publisher=[[Country Music Association of Australia]] | archive-date=16 November 2021 | year=2021 | access-date=29 December 2021 }}</ref> the Australian Bush Laureate Award for Contemporary Song Lyric of the Year<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bushlaureate.com.au/winners.html |title=Australian Bush Laureate Awards 2015 winners |publisher=Australian Bush Laureate Awards |accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref> and was nominated for Heritage Song of the Year, both for \"The Lifesaver\".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tcmf.com.au/2015-Golden-Guitar-Finalists!/ |title=2015 Golden Guitar Finalists! |publisher=Toyota Country Music Festival: Tamworth 2015 |date=17 November 2014 |accessdate=23 April 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402142530/http://www.tcmf.com.au/2015-Golden-Guitar-Finalists!/ |archive-date=2 April 2015 |url-status=dead }}</ref> The song details her family's response to Brian's stroke in 1996.<ref name=\"SMSLSC\"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/newslocal/city-east/country-singer-amber-lawrence-to-walk-in-stride-for-stroke-at-south-maroubra-in-honour-of-her-father/story-fngr8h22-1227129848495 |title=Country singer Amber Lawrence to walk in Stride for Stroke at South Maroubra in honour of her father |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=21 November 2014 |accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref> She was also named CMC Music Video Channel's Female Oz Artist of the Year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://themusic.com.au/news/all/2015/03/13/fans-dub-adam-brand-australian-country-artist-of-the-year/ |title=Fans Dub Adam Brand Australian Country Artist of the Year |publisher=themusic.com |date=13 March 2015 |accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref>\n\n===2016\u20132018: ''The Kid's Gone Country'', ''Happy Ever After'' and ''Our Backyard''===\nIn April 2016, Lawrence released her fifth studio album, ''The Kid's Gone Country'', her first children's albums. This was followed in September 2016 with her sixth, \n''Happy Ever After'', which reached the ARIA top&nbsp;50 and Country Albums No.&nbsp;6.<ref name=\"ARIA Report 1389\">{{cite journal | date=10 October 2016 | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20161010130041/http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/23790/20161011-0000/issue1389.pdf | title=Week Commencing ~ 10th October 2016 ~ Issue #1389 | last=Wallace | first=Ian | journal=The ARIA Report | publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA) | issue=1389 | pages=2, 5, 7, 10, 13, 16, 22 | url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/documents/issue1389.pdf | archive-date=10 October 2016 | access-date=30 December 2021 | url-status=dead }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> ''Sunburnt Country Music''{{'}}s Sophie Hamley noticed that \"[it's] full of well-crafted country pop that will delight ... she writes and sings from an authentic place, and she is unabashed about showing sentiment and emotion. You get the sense that in conversation she wouldn't be one for small talk \u2013 she would want to get right to the heart of a matter.\"<ref name=\"Hamley\">{{cite web | url=https://sunburntcountrymusic.com/2016/10/18/album-review-happy-ever-after-by-amber-lawrence/?shared=email&msg=fail | title=Album review: ''Happy Ever After'' by Amber Lawrence | last=Hamley | first=Sophie | website=Sunburnt Country Music | date=18 October 2016 | via=National Library of Australia | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20210615024240/https://sunburntcountrymusic.com/2016/10/18/album-review-happy-ever-after-by-amber-lawrence/?shared=email&msg=fail | archive-date=15 June 2021 | access-date=31 December 2021 | url-status=live }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>\n\nHer collaboration with fellow Australian country artist Travis Collins, the seven-track ''Our Backyard'' EP, was released in August 2017.<ref name=\"Erlewine 1\">{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/amber-lawrence-mn0001434685/biography |title=Amber Lawrence: Biography, Songs & Albums |publisher=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=28 December 2021 }}</ref> It peaked at No.&nbsp;40 on the ARIA Albums chart and No.&nbsp;2 on the Country Albums chart.<ref name=\"ARIA Report 1433\">{{cite journal | date=14 August 2017 | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20161010130041/http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/23790/20161011-0000/issue1389.pdf | title=Week Commencing ~ 14th August 2017 ~ Issue #1433 | last=Wallace | first=Ian | journal=The ARIA Report | publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA) | issue=1433 | pages=2, 5, 7, 10, 13, 16, 22 | url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/documents/issue1433.pdf | archive-date=10 October 2016 | access-date=31 December 2021 | url-status=dead }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> The title track was co-written by Lawrence, Collins and Matt Scullion.<ref name=\"APRA Backyard\">{{cite web | publisher=[[APRA AMCOS]] (Australasian Performing Right Association, Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners Society) | title='Our Backyard' at APRA search engine | url=https://www.apraamcos.com.au/works-search?works=true&title=Our%20Backyard&writer=&performer=Lawrence | accessdate=31 December 2021 }}</ref> The EP was produced by Matt Fell.<ref name=\"Sollars\"/> Jeremy Sollars of ''Southern Free Times'' found it, \"Brimming with classics that tell quintessentially Australian stories, the music and lyrics ... reflect the true Australian experience across life, love and friendship.\"<ref name=\"Sollars\"/> At the 2018 CMAA she won three Golden Guitar trophies: Vocal Collaboration of the Year (shared with Collins), Song of the Year (shared with Collins and Scullion) and Single of the Year (shared with Collins), all for \"Our Backyard\".<ref name=\"CMAA 2021\"/>\n\nIn November 2017, Lawrence released her second children's album, ''Aussie Aussie Christmas''.<ref name=\"ARIA Report 1448\">{{cite journal | date=27 November 2017 | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20171127130210/http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/23790/20171128-0002/Issue1448.pdf | title=Week Commencing ~ 27th November 2017 ~ Issue #1448 | last=Wallace | first=Ian | journal=The ARIA Report | publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA) | issue=1448 | pages=8, 22 | url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/documents/issue1448.pdf | archive-date=27 November 2017 | access-date=31 December 2021 | url-status=dead }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>\n\n===2019\u2013present: ''Spark'' and ''Living for the Highlights''===\nIn June 2019, Lawrence's released her eighth studio album, ''Spark'', which peaked at No.&nbsp;13 on the ARIA Albums chart and No.&nbsp;&nbsp;1 on the Country Albums chart.<ref name=\"ARIA Report 1529\">{{cite journal | date=24 June 2019 | archive-url=http://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20190625140000/http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/23790/20190626-0000/Issue1529.pdf | title=Week Commencing ~ 24th June 2019 ~ Issue #1529 | last=Wallace | first=Ian | journal=The ARIA Report | publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA) | issue=1529 | pages=2, 5, 7, 10, 13, 16, 22 | url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/documents/issue1529.pdf | archive-date=25 June 2019 | access-date=31 December 2021 | url-status=dead }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> It was produced by Stuart Stuart.<ref name=\"NLA Spark\">{{Citation | author1=Lawrence, Amber | title=Spark | year=2019 | publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation | url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/236395021 | access-date=31 December 2021 }}</ref>\n\nIn July 2022, Lawrence released her tenth studio album, ''Living for the Highlights'', which peaked at number 5 on the ARIA Charts. Living for the Highlights received an ARIA nomination for Best Country Album in 2022.{{Citation needed|date=May 2024}}\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" scope=\"row\"| \"Making Up for Lost Wine\"\n|}\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n===AIR Awards===\nThe Australian Independent Record Awards (known colloquially as the [[AIR Awards]]) is an annual awards night to recognise, promote and celebrate the success of Australia's Independent Music sector.\n\n{{Awards table}}\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| [[AIR Awards of 2009|2009]]\n| ''The Mile''\n| rowspan=\"3\"| Best Independent Country Album\n| {{nom}}\n| <ref name=\"noms09\">{{cite web|url=https://www.auspop.com.au/2009/10/air-nominees/|title=AIR Nominees|date=19 October 2009|accessdate=19 August 2020|archive-date=18 September 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200918230557/https://www.auspop.com.au/2009/10/air-nominees/|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n|-\n| [[AIR Awards of Sport, RVG, Teen Jesus & More| website= [[The Music (magazine)|The Music]]|date=14 May 2024|access-date=16 May 2024}}</ref>\n|}\n\n===ARIA Music Awards===\nThe [[ARIA Music Awards]] is an annual ceremony presented by [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA), which recognise excellence, innovation, and achievement across all genres of the [[music of Australia]]. They commenced in 1987.\n{{Awards table}}\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| [[2021 ARIA Music Awards|2021]]|| ''The Kid's Gone Country 2: Fun for All the Family'' || [[ARIA Award for Best Children's Album|Best Children's Album]] || {{nom}}\n| <ref>{{cite web |url=https://themusicnetwork.com/2021-aria-awards-nominees/ |title=ARIA Awards nominees revealed: Amy Shark & Genesis Owusu lead the charge |work=[[The Music Network]] |date=20 October 2021 |access-date=24 October 2021 |author=Kelly, Vivienne |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211020000045/https://themusicnetwork.com/2021-aria-awards-nominees/ |archive-date=20 October 2021 |url-status=live}}</ref>\n|-\n| [[2022 ARIA Music Awards|2022]] || ''Living for the Highlights'' || [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]] || {{nominated}} || <ref name=\"2022ARIAnoms\">{{cite web|url=https://themusicnetwork.com/2022-aria-awards-nominees/|title=R\u00fcf\u00fcs Du Sol Leads 2022 ARIA Awards Nominees (Full List)|website=The Music Network|date=12 October 2022|access-date=12 October 2022|author=Lars Brandle}}</ref>\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Country Music Awards of Australia===\nThe [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] (CMAA) (also known as the Golden Guitar Awards) is an annual awards night held in January during the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]], celebrating recording excellence in the Australian country music industry. They have been held annually since 1973.<ref name=\"CMAA 2021\"/><ref name=\"CMAA2021\">{{cite web|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-01-23/golden-guitars-awards-fanny-lumsden-sweeps-awards-in-tamworth/13081696|title=Fanny Lumsden wins five Golden Guitar Awards despite cancelled Tamworth Country Music Festival|publisher=ABC|date=23 January 2021|access-date=24 January 2021}}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n|-\n| 2015\n| Amber Lawrence\n| Female Artist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 2018\n| rowspan=\"3\"| \"Our Backyard\" (Travis Collins & Amber Lawrence)\n| Vocal Collaboration of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| APRA AMCOS Song of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| Single of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2021\n| \"True Blue\" (Amber Lawrence, [[Aleyce Simmonds]], [[Kirsty Lee Akers]] and [[Dianna Corcoran]])\n| Vocal Collaboration of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2023<ref name=\"CMAAwins2023\">{{cite web|url=https://www.miragenews.com/2023-toyota-golden-guitar-winners-announced-932947/|title=2023 Toyota Golden Guitar Winners Announced|website=Mirage News|date=22 January 2023|access-date=22 January 2023}}</ref>\n| Amber Lawrence\n| Female Vocalist of the Year\n| This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Aleyce_Simmonds","to":"Aleyce Simmonds"}],"pages":{"38863479":{"pageid":38863479,"ns":0,"title":"Aleyce Simmonds","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2020}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=March 2019}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Aleyce Simmonds\n| image           = Aleyce.jpg\n| caption         = Aleyce Simmonds in 2016\n| birth_name      =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|df=y|1986|12|6}}\n| birth_place     = [[Port Macquarie, New South Wales]], Australia\n| origin          = [[Tamworth, New South Wales]], Australia<ref name=\"travelin1\">{{cite news|title=Aleyce-Simmonds-from-Tamwort|newspaper=Traveling In|url=https://www.travelin.com.au/articles/Aleyce-Simmonds-from-Tamworth-03210|accessdate=26 June 2016}}</ref>\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[Country pop]], [[Country rock]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 2001\u2013present\n| label           = [[Capitol Records Nashville]], [[Sony BMG]], [[Universal Music Australia]]\n| associated_acts = [[Amber Lawrence]]<br />Christie Lamb<br />[[Dianna Corcoran]]<br />Paul Costa<br />[[The Wildes|Lachlan Bryan & The Wildes]]<br />[[Dean Perrett]]<br />[[Ryan Sampson (singer)|Ryan Sampson]]<br />[[Tommy Emmanuel]]<br />[[Graeme Connors]]\n| website         = {{URL|www.aleyce.com/}}\n}}\n'''Aleyce Simmonds''' (born 6 December 1986 in [[Port Macquarie, New South Wales]]) is an Australian country music recording artist and singer-songwriter. Simmonds' accolades include the [[Telstra]] Road to Tamworth Winner in 2004. As a part of her prize Aleyce visited [[Nashville]] and recorded a successful single, \"Mighty, Mighty Love\". Simmonds also won an [[APRA Award]], in 2017 for Country Work of the Year, with her song \"Greatest Companion\".<ref>{{cite news|title=Young dance and pop songwriters dominate the APRA Music Awards\n|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/young-dance-and-pop-songwriters-dominate-the-apra-music-awards-led-by-flume-and-troye-sivan/news-story/d8a383e134df3841023d338ed0e920fd/|accessdate=4 April 2017}}</ref>\n\nShe won Australian and National Duet of the year winner with Paul Costa for \"The Way You Make Me Feel\" in 2007.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tamworth's sweetheart \u2013 Aleyce Simmonds|newspaper=Tamworth Country Life|url=http://www.tamworthcountrylife.com.au/tamworths-sweetheart-aleyce-simmonds/|accessdate=22 March 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140330195646/http://tamworthcountrylife.com.au/tamworths-sweetheart-aleyce-simmonds/|archive-date=30 March 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nSimmonds received her 7th [[Country Music Awards of Australia|Golden Guitar]] (Country Music Awards of Australia) nomination in 2017.<ref>{{cite news|title=ALEYCE SIMMONDS NOMINATED FOR SIXTH GOLDEN GUITAR\n|url=http://www.nbnnews.com.au/2015/12/08/aleyce-simmonds-nominated-for-sixth-golden-guitar/|accessdate=30 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Toyota Golden Guitar Awards Finalists|url=http://www.tcmf.com.au/2018-Toyota-Golden-Guitar-Awards-Finalists/|accessdate=20 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171124120549/http://www.tcmf.com.au/2018-Toyota-Golden-Guitar-Awards-Finalists|archive-date=24 November 2017|url-status=dead}}</ref> In 2014, Simmonds won Female Artist of the Year at the Australian Independent Country Music Awards for 2014. In October 2015, Simmonds was named Australian Independent Artist of the Year, Female Vocalist of the Year and awarded Best Country Single of the Year.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aleyce Simmonds|newspaper=Tamworth Country Music Festival|url=http://www.tcmf.com.au/Home/Media-Portal/Artists/Aleyce-Simmonds/|accessdate=26 June 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160813021726/http://www.tcmf.com.au/Home/Media-Portal/Artists/Aleyce-Simmonds/|archive-date=13 August 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n==Music career==\nSimmonds released her debut album in 2011 and 4 subsequent radio singles and music videos for \"The Keeper\", \"When I Say Too Much\", \"The Healing Hands of Time\" and \"Bondwood Boat\". All singles except \"Bondwood Boat\" achieved chart positions inside top 20.\n\nSimmonds was nominated for three [[Country Music Awards of Australia|Golden Guitar]] awards at the Country Music awards of Australia, The Healing Hands of Time, written with the album's producer [[Rod McCormack]] ([[Beccy Cole]], [[Adam Harvey]], [[Amber Lawrence]], [[Paul Kelly (Australian musician)|Paul Kelly]]) being nominated for Female Artist of the Year and New Talent of the Year and \"Bondwood Boat\" written with [[Graeme Connors]] being nominated for Heritage Song of the year. She performed the song with Connors at the Golden Guitars.<ref name=\"autogenerated1\"/>\n\nSimmonds was a finalist at the 2016 [[Country Music Awards of Australia|Golden Guitar]] Awards for APRA AMCOS Song of the Year with her song \"Joshua\", about her stillborn baby brother.<ref>{{cite web|title=APRA-AMCOS-Song-of-the-Yea|url=http://www.tcmf.com.au/APRA-AMCOS-Song-of-the-Year-/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160229160347/http://www.tcmf.com.au/APRA-AMCOS-Song-of-the-Year-/|url-status=dead|archive-date=29 February 2016|accessdate=26 June 2016}}</ref><ref name=\"travelin1\"/> \"Joshua\" was awarded the No. 1 spot on the [[2YOU|88.9FM Tamworth]] Country Music Top 20 charts for 2015. Aleyce also secured No. 12 with \"It Finds Us Anyway\" and No. 14 with \"The Greatest Companion\" on the local station's countdown.<ref>{{cite web|title=Being Awarded #1 on Yearly Countdown| website=[[Facebook]] |url=https://www.facebook.com/509474795861709/photos/a.564366963705825.1073741829.509474795861709/644971785645342/?type=3&theater|accessdate=26 June 2016}}</ref>\n\nAt the [[APRA Music Awards of 2017]] Simmonds won the category, Country Work of the Year, with her song, \"Greatest Companion\";<ref name=\"CWotYNom17\">{{cite web | url = http://apraamcos.com.au/awards/2017-awards/apra-music-awards/country/ | title = Country Work of the Year | publisher = [[Australasian Performing Right Association]] (APRA) &#124; [[Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners Society]] (AMCOS) | year = 2017 | accessdate = 5 April 2017 | archive-date = 5 April 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170405173405/http://apraamcos.com.au/awards/2017-awards/apra-music-awards/country/ | url-status = dead }}</ref> it was inspired by being in the studio with Luke Bona on [[2UE]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Tamworth's Aleyce Simmonds named 2017 APRA Country Work of the Year recipient|url=http://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/story/4574397/our-golden-girl-aleyce-simmonds-takes-home-apra-honour/|accessdate=4 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Aleyce Simmonds nominated for APRA honour|url=https://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/story/4532776/our-aleyce-has-eyes-on-apra-nod/|date=17 March 2017|newspaper=The Northern Daily Leader|first=Haley|last=Craig|accessdate=20 March 2019}}</ref> \nIt's about how important overnight radio is to so many people. Aleyce was blown away by the amazing callers Bona receives throughout the night and how important the radio is to them.<ref>{{cite web|title=Aleyce Simmonds Inspiration for Greatest Companion|url=http://www.2ue.com.au/news/aleyce-simmonds-new-song-inspired-by-luke-bonas-overnight-show-20150827-gj9ka7.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160812064316/http://www.2ue.com.au/news/aleyce-simmonds-new-song-inspired-by-luke-bonas-overnight-show-20150827-gj9ka7.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=12 August 2016|accessdate=26 June 2016}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nAleyce Simmonds was born on 6 December 1986 in [[Port Macquarie, New South Wales]] and moved when she was age 12 to [[Tamworth, New South Wales|Tamworth]]. At age 13, Aleyce entered her first talent quest but did not win. Then at the age of 16 she entered the Country Capital Music Association's (CCMA) Talent Quest. She was voted the best overall artist under the age of 16 and won $1,000, with which she brought her first guitar.<ref>{{cite video|url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=H59SqoRER78&feature=youtu.be|title=\nLee Kernaghan: The Stories, Aleyce Simmonds Part 1|publisher=YouTube|date=31 May 2011|accessdate=26 June 2016}}</ref><ref name=\"autogenerated1\">{{cite news|title=The Journey: Aleyce Simmonds|newspaper=ABC New England North West|url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/audio/2012/10/29/3620717.htm|accessdate=22 March 2013}}</ref> She started writing songs and found she had a natural country sound, and by age 15 she was playing gigs in pubs around Tamworth. While Simmonds still tours regularly, she is currently living on her parents' hundred-acre property outside of Tamworth, where she spends weekdays writing songs before hitting the road to tour on the weekends.<ref name=\"travelin1\"/>\n\nSimmonds is the host for [[BalconyTV]] Tamworth.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tamworth shines on the world|url=http://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/story/4058121/tamworth-shines-on-the-world-stage/|accessdate=30 November 2016}}</ref> An online music show that features bands, musicians and other variety acts on balconies around the world.<ref>{{cite news|title=BalconyTV Tamworth|url=https://www.balconytv.com/tamworth|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160718104934/http://www.balconytv.com/tamworth|url-status=usurped|archive-date=18 July 2016|accessdate=30 November 2016}}</ref> Tamworth is the only city in Australia that is not a Capital City that has BalconyTV. It is in association with the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Tamworth to join global TV network|url=http://www.tcmf.com.au/News/Tamworth-to-join-global-TV-network/|accessdate=30 November 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161130185203/http://www.tcmf.com.au/News/Tamworth-to-join-global-TV-network/|archive-date=30 November 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\" border=\"1\"\n|+ List of studio albums, with Australian positions \n! They have been held annually since 1973.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.country.com.au/awards/past-award-winners|title=Past Award Winners|accessdate=2 November 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"CMAA2021\">{{cite web|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-01-23/golden-guitars-awards-fanny-lumsden-sweeps-awards-in-tamworth/13081696|title=Fanny Lumsden wins five Golden Guitar Awards despite cancelled Tamworth Country Music Festival|website=ABC|date=23 January 2021|access-date=24 January 2021}}</ref>\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| 2018\n| ''More Than Meets the Eye''\n| Female Artist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2021\n| \"True Blue\" (with [[Amber Lawrence]], [[Kirsty Lee Akers]] and [[Dianna Corcoran]])\n| Vocal Collaboration of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n* Note: wins only\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Simmonds, Aleyce}}\n[[Category:1986 births]]\n[[Category:APRA Award winners]]\n[[Category:Australian country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Musicians from New South Wales]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:21st-century Australian singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century Australian women singers]]\n[[Category:Australian women singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:People from Port Macquarie]]\n[[Category:21st-century Australian singer-songwriters]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes.
