This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Shirley_Myers","to":"Shirley Myers"}],"pages":{"19785856":{"pageid":19785856,"ns":0,"title":"Shirley Myers","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name                = Shirley Myers\n| image                 = \n| image_size            = \n| background          = solo_singer\n| origin              = [[New Brunswick]], Canada\n| instrument          = \n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation          = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active        = 1997\u2013present\n| label               = [[Stony Plain Records|Stony Plain]]\n| website             = [http://www.shirleymyers.com/ www.shirleymyers.com]\n}}\n\n'''Shirley Myers''' is a Canadian [[country music]] singer-songwriter. Signed to [[Stony Plain Records]] in the 1990s, she released her debut album, ''[[Let It Rain (Shirley Myers album)|Let It Rain]]'', in 1997. The first single, the title track, reached the top five of the ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' Country Singles chart in Canada. Myers was nominated for a [[Juno Award]] for [[Juno Award for Country Recording of the Year|Best Country Female Vocalist]] in 1998.\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:14em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Details\n! Year\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Video\n|-\n| 1997\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Let It Rain\"\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1998\n! scope=\"row\"| \"One Last Step\"\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Fallin' Out of Love\"\n|-\n| 1999\n! scope=\"row\"| \"You Better Be Sure\"\n|-\n| 2000\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I'm Missin' You\"\n|-\n| 2002\n! scope=\"row\"| \"How Do I Get Out of This Dream\"\n|}\n\n==Notes==\n{{notelist}}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n{{Shirley Myers}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Myers, Shirley}}\n[[Category:Canadian women singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Canadian singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Canadian women country singers]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]\n\n\n{{Canada-singer-songwriter-stub}}"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Adam_Harvey","to":"Adam Harvey"}],"pages":{"20015373":{"pageid":20015373,"ns":0,"title":"Adam Harvey","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Australian country music singer (born 1974)}}\n{{for-multi|the English actor|Adam Paul Harvey|the American artist|Adam Harvey (artist)}}\n{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image           = Adam Harvey.jpg\n| name            = Adam Harvey\n| birth_name      =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1974|12|21}}\n| birth_place     = [[Geelong]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], Australia\n| death_date      =\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer, songwriter\n| years_active    = 1984\u2013present\n| label           = Open Road, Universal, [[ABC Music]], [[Sony Music]]\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = {{URL|http://adamharvey.com.au}}\n}}\n\n'''Adam Harvey''' (born 21 December 1974) is an Australian [[country music]] singer. Harvey has sold over half a million records, has been nominated five times for an [[ARIA Music Awards|ARIA Music Award]] and has won nine [[Country Music Awards of Australia|golden guitars at the Country Music Awards of Australia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cruisincountry.com.au/2019/performers/adam-harvey/|title=Adam Harvey|publisher=Cruis' Country|access-date=4 August 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180804110221/http://cruisincountry.com.au/2019/performers/adam-harvey/|archive-date=4 August 2018|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n==Biography==\nHarvey got his start musically learning country classics on the guitar as a small boy. His first gig came at the age of ten, and by his school years he was performing rock covers at a club when he was discovered and went off on tour as support for [[Tania Kernaghan]].<ref>{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p698129|pure_url=yes}}|title=Adam harvey|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|last=True|first=Chris|access-date=29 January 2010}}</ref> In 1998 Harvey won his first [[Country Music Awards of Australia|Country Music (CMAA) Award]] for 'Vocal Collaboration of the Year' with Tanya Self for \"Drive Away\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1134 |title=Country Music Awards of Australia 1990\u20131999 |publisher=[[Country Music Association of Australia|CMAA]] |access-date=29 January 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091017180321/http://www.country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1134 |archive-date=17 October 2009 }}</ref> In 2001 he won another CMAA Award for 'Vocal Collaboration of the Year' this time with [[Beccy Cole]], Darren Coggan and [[Felicity Urquhart|Felicity]], for \"Do I Ever Cross Your Mind\".<ref name=\"CMAA\">{{cite web|url=http://www.country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1135 |title=Country Music Awards of Australia 2000\u20132008 |publisher=[[Country Music Association of Australia|CMAA]] |access-date=29 January 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091017175108/http://www.country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1135 |archive-date=17 October 2009 }}</ref>\n\nIn 2002, Harvey won two CMAA Awards; 'Album of the Year' and 'Male Vocalist of the Year' for ''Workin' Overtime''.<ref name=\"CMAA\"/> ''Workin' Overtime'' was nominated for [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album]] at the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2002|2002 ARIA Awards]].<ref name=\"ARIA\">{{cite web|url=http://www.ariaawards.com.au/history-by-artist.php?letter=A&artist=Adam%20Harvey |title=ARIA Award History \u2013 Adam Harvey |publisher=[[Australian Recording Industry Association]] |access-date=29 January 2010 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>\n\nIn 2004, Harvey won a second CMAA Award for 'Male Vocalist of the Year' that year.<ref name=\"CMAA\"/> In 2005 he received his third [[ARIA Music Awards of 2005|ARIA award]] nomination for Best Country Album ''Can't Settle for Less''.<ref name=\"ARIA\"/> In 2008, he won Album of the Year ''I'm Doin' Alright''.<ref name=\"CMAA\"/>\n\nIn 2009, he sang the [[Australian national anthem]] before the Australia vs New Zealand [[rugby league]] test match.{{citation needed|date=December 2021}}\n\nHarvey has been nominated for a CMAA Award in 2010 for Collaboration of the Year with [[John Williamson (singer)|John Williamson]] for \"King of the Road\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1226 |title=Finalists \u2013 38th CMAA Country Music Awards of Australia |publisher=[[Country Music Association of Australia|CMAA]] |access-date=27 January 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100301214250/http://www.country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1226 |archive-date=1 March 2010 |url-status=dead |df=dmy }}</ref>\n\n{{externalvideo\n| float = right\n| width = 250px\n| video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J45LnaI3F9I Official Music Video ''Stuck in the Middle'']\n| \n}}\n\nIn 2013, Harvey collaborated with [[Troy Cassar-Daley]] to record ''[[The Great Country Songbook]]'', which debuted at number 2 on the [[ARIA Charts]].\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable Harvey has won nine awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://country.com.au/golden-guitars/|title=TOYOTA GOLDEN GUITAR AWARDS|publisher=COUNTRY|date=17 November 2014|access-date=21 August This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Lawrie_Minson","to":"Lawrie Minson"}],"pages":{"27171529":{"pageid":27171529,"ns":0,"title":"Lawrie Minson","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Australian musician}}\n{{EngvarB|date=December 2021}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2021}}\n{{Portal|Music|Australia}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image           =\n| caption         =\n| name            = Lawrie Minson\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1958|9|13}}\n| birth_place     = [[Paddington, New South Wales|Paddington]], NSW Australia\n| birth_name      = Lawrence Minson\n| instrument      = Accordion, banjo, [[didgeridoo]], guitar, harmonica, harp, mandolin, piano, vocals <ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/lawrie-minson-mn0001980170/credits | title=Lawrie Minson &#124; Credits | website=[[AllMusic]] }}</ref>\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]] / [[Rockabilly]]\n| occupation      = Musician, Songwriter\n| years_active    = 1979\u2013present\n| label           =\n| associated_acts = Buddy Williams <br /> Lee Kernaghan\n| website         = \n}}\n\n'''Lawrence (Lawrie) Minson''' (born 13 September 1958) is an Australian country musician, best known as a session player.<ref name=headlineact>{{cite web|url=https://www.examiner.com.au/story/430134/minson-goes-it-alone-for-the-first-time/|title=Minson goes it alone for the first time|publisher=The Examiner|date=5 February 2012|accessdate=14 December 2021}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nMinson is the son of former Australian radio personality [[John Minson]]. His country music career commenced in 1979 accompanying [[Buddy Williams (country musician)|Buddy Williams]] on tour as a guitarist. He went on to performing with Slim Dusty in 1981 and 1982. Since then, Minson has performed as part of the [[Lee Kernaghan]] touring band and accompanied various other Australian acts.<ref>https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1323682/ {{User-generated source|certain=yes|date=March 2022}}</ref> In 1989, Minson contributed \"[[When the Rain Tumbles Down in July]]\" and \"Murrumbidgee Jack\", as a tribute to [[Tex Morton]], on an instrumental record album of Australian classics. He married Shelley Watts in 2008. Together, they have performed as a rockabilly duo. In 2012, Minson's debut as a headline act was at an Australian Italian club in [[Launceston, Tasmania]].<ref name=headlineact />\n\nIn 2016, Tamworth Songwriters' Association presented Minson with the ''Tex Morton Award'' for his support and promotion of new songwriters.<ref>{{cite web |title=Tamworth Songwriters Association Past Winners History |url=https://www.tsaonline.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/2016-to-2017correction.pdf |website=TSA Online |access-date=20 December 2021}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\" border=\"1\"\n|+ List of Albums\n! scope=\"col\"| Title\n! scope=\"col\"| Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Memories Of Home - An Instrumental Tribute to Our Travelling Country Music Showmen''\n|\n* Released: 1989\n* Label: EMI (EMX 781815)\n|-\n! scope=\"row\" | ''Family Tree''\n|\n* Released: 1996\n* Label: ABC Music (724348984029)\n|-\n! scope=\"row\" | ''Milestones: The Ultimate Collection''\n|\n* Released: 2011\n* Note: Compilation album\n|}\n\n===Charting singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\" border=\"1\" \n|+ List of singles as featured artist, with selected chart positions\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:19em;\"| Title \n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:1em;\"| Year \n! scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" |Peak chart positions \n|- \n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:3em;font-size:90%;\"| [[ARIA Charts|AUS]]<br /><ref>{{cite book|last=Kent|first=David|authorlink=David Kent (historian)|title=Australian Chart Book 1970\u20131992|edition=Illustrated|publisher=Australian Chart Book|location=St Ives, N.S.W.|year=1993|pages=22|isbn=0-646-11917-6}} N.B. The Kent Report chart was licensed by [[Australian Recording Industry Association|ARIA]] between mid-1983 and 19 June 1988.</ref>\n|- \n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[The Garden (Australia Too song)|The Garden]]\"<br /><span style=\"font-size:85%;\">(as Australia Too)</span> \n| 1985\n| 22\n|}\n\n==Awards==\n===CMAA Awards===\nThese annual awards have been presented since 1973 and have been organised by [[Country Music Association of Australia]] (CMAA) from 1993,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1011 | title = About the CMAA Country Music Awards of Australia | publisher = Country Music Association of Australia (CMAA) | access-date = 25 October 2012 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080719040922/http://country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1011 | archive-date = 19 July 2008 }}</ref> to \"encourage, promote and recognise excellence in Australian country music recording\". From that time, the recipient's trophy has been a [[Country Music Awards of Australia#Golden Guitar trophy|Golden Guitar]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1019 | title = CMAA Country Music Awards of Australia Winners Archive | publisher = Country Music Association of Australia | access-date = 25 October 2012 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080719044338/http://country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1019 | archive-date = 19 July 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.country.com.au/awards/past-award-winners|title=Past Award Winners|accessdate=2 November 2020}}</ref>\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n|-\n| 1990\n| \"Wild River\"\n| Instrumental of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 1997\n| \"Action Jackson\"\n| Instrumental of the Year\n| {{won}}\n{{end}}\n\n===Tamworth Songwriters Awards===\nThe Tamworth Songwriters Association (TSA) is an annual songwriting contest for original country songs, awarded in January at the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]]. They commenced in 1986.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsaonline.com.au/song-competition/|title=Tamworth Songwriters Association|website=Tamworth Songwriters Association Online|access-date=23 March 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsaonline.com.au/past-winners/|title=Tamworth Songwriters Association Past Winners|website=Tamworth Songwriters Association Online|access-date=23 March 2022}}</ref>\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n|-\n| 2016\n| Lawrie Minson \n| Tex Morton Award\n| {{yes2|awarded}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Minson, Lawrie}}\n[[Category:1958 births]]\n[[Category:Australian musicians]]\n[[Category:Living people]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Melinda_Schneider","to":"Melinda Schneider"}],"pages":{"24110307":{"pageid":24110307,"ns":0,"title":"Melinda Schneider","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Australian country singer}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2020}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=September 2011}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name                = Melinda Schneider\n| background          = solo_singer\n| image               = Melinda Schneider & Son - March 2018.jpg\n| caption             = Schneider and her son in 2018 \n| birth_name          = Melinda-Jane Bean\n| birth_date          = {{birth date and age|df=y|1971|10|7}}\n| birth_place         = Sydney, Australia\n| instrument          = Guitar, vocals\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation          = Singer, songwriter, radio presenter\n| years_active        = 1979\u2013present\n| label               = {{hlist|Compass Bros|Be Music|[[Festival Records]]|[[Universal Music]]}}\n| associated_acts     = [[Mary Schneider]], [[Paul Kelly (Australian musician)|Paul Kelly]], [[Beccy Cole]]\n| website             = {{url|http://melindaschneider.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Melinda Schneider''' (born '''Melinda-Jane Bean'''; 7 October 1971) is an Australian [[country music]] singer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.debbiekruger.com/writer/aprap/tamworth2003.html|title=Old and new souls in country music|website=Debbie Kruger|date=2003|accessdate=18 May 2020}}</ref> She has been performing since she was three and sang with her mother, yodelling country artist [[Mary Schneider]], on the album ''The Magic of Yodelling'' at the age of eight.<ref name=\"Great Women of Country, Melinda Schneider\">{{Cite web|url=https://hercanberra.com.au/cpcity/great-women-of-country-melinda-schneider|title=Great Women of Country|date=26 February 2015 |accessdate = 27 February 2015 }}</ref> \n\nSchneider is a multi-[[Golden Guitar]] winner at the [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] winning her sixth with [[Paul Kelly (Australian musician)|Paul Kelly]] for 'Vocal Collaboration of the Year' for their duet \"Still Here\"  in 2009.<ref name=\"ABCSydney\">{{cite web | url = http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2009/03/01/2502131.htm | title = Performer \u2013 Melinda Schneider | publisher = [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] (ABC) | date = 1 March 2009 | accessdate = 17 September 2010 }}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nSchneider studied dance as a child and made her acting debut on the popular Australian drama ''[[A Country Practice]]'' when aged thirteen.<ref name=\"SMH2003\">{{cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/city-success-a-yodel-away-from-tamworth-20030403-gdgjdz.html|title= City success, a yodel away from Tamworth|website=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=2003|access-date=28 July 2022}}</ref> She also sang the theme music for the ABC TV series ''[[Something in the Air (TV series)|Something in the Air]]''. \n\nIn 1994, Schneider featuring on Audio Murphy Inc.'s dance track \"[[Tighten Up Your Pants]]\" which peaked at number 39 on the ARIA Chart.<ref name=\"Female\">{{cite web|url=https://www.female.com.au/melinda-schneider-life-begins-at-40-interview.htm|title= Melinda Schneider Life Begins at 40 Interview|website=Female|date=2011|access-date=25 July 2022}}</ref> The song mixed electronic beats and yodelling. The success of \"Tighten Up Your Pants\" earned her a three-album deal with [[Festival Records]]. Unsure of what kind of singer she wanted to be, Schneider foundered, eventually quitting Festival without making an album.<ref name=\"SMH2003\"/>\n\nIn 1999, Schneider performed the duet \"Love Away the Night\" with [[Adam Brand (musician)|Adam Brand]]. In January 2000, the song won Schneider her first [[Country Music Awards of Australia|CMAA Award]] for Vocal Collaboration of the Year.\n\nIn 2000, Schneider released her debut studio album, ''My Oxygen''.<ref name=\"SMH2003\"/> The album was recorded with the Nashville-based Australian producer Mark Moffatt.<ref name=\"SMH2003\"/>\n\nIn July 2002, Schneider released her second studio album, ''Happy Tears'', which peaked at number 94 on the ARIA charts and was certified gold. ''Happy Tears'' was produced by her husband of five years, Graham Thompson, and released on his Compass Bros label.<ref name=\"SMH2003\"/>\n\nIn 2003, Schneider won her the first solo Golden Guitar for Female Vocal of the Year.<ref name=\"Female\"/>\n\nIn May 2004, Schneider released ''Family Tree'', which peaked at number 64 on the ARIA charts and was certified gold. The album earner Schneider her first [[ARIA Music Award]] nomination.\n\nIn 2006, Schneider was invited by [[Deborah Conway]] to take part in the Broad Festival project with three other Australian female artists. They performed their own and each other's songs.<ref name=\"Elliott\">{{Cite news | url = http://www.smh.com.au/news/music/ladys-night-at-the-beckoning-microphone/2008/08/18/1218911561072.html?page=fullpage | title = Lady's Night at the Beckoning Microphone | last = Elliott | first = Tim | newspaper = The Sydney Morning Herald  | date = 19 August 2008 | accessdate = 5 June 2011 }}</ref> With Schneider and Conway were [[Mia Dyson]], [[Kate Miller-Heidke]] and [[Ella Hooper]].<ref name=\"Broad2006\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.broadfestival.com/broad_2006.html |title=Broad 2006 |publisher=Broad Festival |accessdate=5 June 2011 |url-status=usurped |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071008201951/http://www.broadfestival.com/broad_2006.html |archivedate=8 October 2007 }}</ref>\n\nIn 2010, Schneider was a participant on the [[ABC Television (Australian TV network)|ABC Television]] program ''Bush Slam'' and a celebrity contestant on the Channel 7 show ''[[Dancing with the Stars (Australian TV series)|Dancing with the Stars]]'' partnered by Serghei Bolgarschii in [[Dancing With The Stars (Australian Season 10)|Season 10]].<ref name=\"Rao\">{{cite news | url = http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/confidential/eliminated-singer-melinda-schneider-talks-about-sex-and-chemistry-on-dancing-with-the-stars/story-e6frf96o-1225897046975 | title = Eliminated singer Melinda Schneider talks about sex and chemistry on Dancing with the Stars | last1 = Rao | first1 = Shoba | newspaper = [[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]] | publisher = [[News Corporation (1980\u20132013)|News Corporation]] | date = 26 July 2010 | accessdate = 17 September 2010 }}</ref>\n\nIn 2011, Schneider starred in the theatre show ''Doris: So Much More Than the Girl Next Door'', written by Schneider and David Mitchell. The show told the story of [[Doris Day]]'s life and was first performed at the [[Twelfth Night Theatre]] in [[Brisbane]] in May 2011. \n\nIn November 2014, Schneider released ''[[Great Women of Country]]'', a collaboration with [[Beccy Cole]]. The album became her first to peak inside the ARIA top ten.\n\nIn 2022, Schneider performed a two-hour show titled ''Love Songs'', celebrating the love she has found with her long-time partner, Mark Gable. In May 2022, Schneider released a compilation album of the same name.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://entertainmentvenues.com.au/melinda-schneider---love-songs|title= MELINDA SCHNEIDER - LOVE SONGS |website=Entertainment Venues|date=April 2022|access-date=3 October 2022}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life ==\nSchneider is the daughter of singer-songwriter and yodeller Mary Schneider.\nShe attended St Joseph's Kogarah (now known as Bethany College) for her high school years.<ref>https://www.linkedin.com/in/melinda-schneider-19b15829/?originalSubdomain=au {{Bare URL inline|date=August 2024}}</ref>\nSchneider is married to [[Mark Gable]], the lead singer of [[The Choirboys (band)|the Choirboys]]. They were married in September 2022 on Killcare Beach, New South Wales, after 14 years together.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://newcastlelive.com.au/melinda-schneider-on-love-songs-and-marriage/|title=Melinda Schneider on love songs and marriage|website=Newcastle Live|date=August 2022|access-date=3 October 2022}}</ref>\n\n==Radio==\nSchneider was the host of her own radio progrsam, ''Love Songs with Melinda Schneider'', on [[Star 104.5]] FM. The program aired every weeknight in 2015 from 8&nbsp;pm. As the title indicates, the program was focused on songs of a romantic nature. This was Schneider's first radio program as host.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n!rowspan=\"2\"| Title\n!rowspan=\"2\"| Album details\n!colspan=\"1\"| Peak chart positions\n!rowspan=\"2\" width=\"150\"| [[Music recording sales certifications|Certifications]]<br /><small>[[List of music recording sales certifications|(sales thresholds)]]</small>\n|-\n!style=\"width:3em;font-size:85%\"|[[ARIA Charts|AUS]]<br /><ref name=\"AusCharts\">{{cite book|last=Ryan|first=Gavin|title=Australia's Music Charts 1988\u20132010|year=2011|publisher=Moonlight Publishing|location=Mt. Martha, VIC, Australia|edition=pdf}}\n* ''Melinda Does Doris...Again \u2013 The Movie Songs'': {{cite web|url=https://www.auspop.com.au/2016/10/aria-chart-watch-392/|title=ARIA Chart Watch #392|website=auspOp|date=29 October 2016|access-date=29 October 2016}}</ref>\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"|''My Oxygen''\n|\n*Released: 21 July 2000\n*Label: Compass Brothers / [[Festival Records]] <small>(002CDCB)</small>\n| \u2014\n|\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"|''Happy Tears''\n|\n*Released: July 2002\n*Label: Compass Brothers / Festival Records <small>(009CDCB)</small>\n| 94\n|\n* ARIA: Gold<ref name=\"AusCharts\"/>\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"|''Family Tree''\n|\n*Released: May 2004\n*Label: Compass Brothers / Festival Records <small>(016CDCB)</small>\n| 64\n|\n* ARIA: Gold<ref name=\"AusCharts\"/>\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"|''Stronger''\n|\n*Released: August 2006\n*Label: Compass Brothers / [[Sony Music Australia|Sony]] <small>(026CDCB)</small>\n| 74\n|\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"|''Be Yourself''\n|\n*Released: July 2008\n*Label: Be Music / Universal Music <small>(CDR1119)</small>\n| 83\n|\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"|''Melinda Does Doris''\n|\n*Released: August 2010\n*Label: Be Music / Universal Music <small>(2747553)</small>\n| 24\n|\n* ARIA: Gold<ref>{{cite certification|region=Australia|type=album|certyear=2022|access-date=4 April 2022}}</ref>\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"|''[[Great Women of Country]]'' <small>(with [[Beccy Cole]])</small>\n|\n*Released: 7 November 2014\n*Label: Universal Music <small>(4703930)</small>\n| 9\n|\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Melinda Does Doris...Again \u2013 The Movie Songs''\n|\n*Released: October 2016\n*Label: Be Music / Universal Music <small>(2747553)</small>\n| 97\n|\n|}\n\n===Live albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n! Title\n! EP details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"|''The Kitchen Table Tapes''\n|\n*Released: October 2003\n*Label: Compass Brothers / Festival <small>(011CDCB)</small>\n|-\n \n! scope=\"row\"|''Melinda Does Elvis''\n|\n*Released: 4 September 2020<ref>{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/au/album/melinda-does-elton-ep/1529843635|title=Melinda Does Elvis EP|website=[[Apple Music]]|date=4 September 2020|access-date=3 October 2022}}</ref>\n*Label: Melinda Schneider\n \n|-\n! scope=\"row\"|''Be Gentle On Yourself''\n|\n*Released: 7 October 2020<ref>{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/au/album/be-gentle-on-yourself-ep/1532848880|title=Be Gentle On Yourself EP|website=[[Apple Music]]|date=7 October 2020|access-date=3 October 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= https://flyctory.com/2020/10/10/melinda-schneider-be-gentle-on-yourself-ep/|title=Melinda Schneider - Be Gentle On Yourself EP |website= flyctory.com|date=10 October 2020 |access-date=3 October 2022}}</ref>\n*Label: Melinda Schneider\n|}\n\n===Charting singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|+List of singles, with selected chart positions\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\"| Title\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\"| Peak chart positions\n|-\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:3em;font-size:90%;\"| [[ARIA Charts|AUS]]<br /><ref name=aus>{{cite Ryan|page=21}}</ref> \n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[Tighten Up Your Pants]]\"<br />{{small|(Audio Murphy Inc. featuring Melinda)}}\n| 1994\n| 39\n|}\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n===ARIA Music Awards===\nThe [[ARIA Music Awards]] is an annual awards ceremony that recognises excellence, innovation, and achievement across all genres of [[Australian music]]. Schneider has been nominated for two awards.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.ariaawards.com.au/history/search/?text=Melinda%20Schneider|title = ARIA Awards Search Results - Melinda Schneider|work = ARIA Awards|accessdate = 18 May 2020}}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2004|2004]]\n| ''Family Tree''\n| [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]]\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2008|2008]]\n| ''Be Yourself''\n| Best Country Album\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Country Music Awards (CMAA)===\nThe [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] (CMAA) is an annual awards night held in January during the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]] and celebrates recording excellence in the Australian country music industry. Schneider has won six awards.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.country.com.au/awards/past-award-winners|title=Past Award Winners|website=Country|accessdate=18 May 2020 }}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}(wins only)\n|-\n| 2000 || \"Love Away the Night\" with [[Adam Brand (musician)|Adam Brand]] || Vocal Collaboration of the Year  || {{won}}\n|-\n| 2003 || \"The Story of My Life\" || Female Vocalist of the Year  || {{won}}\n|-\n| 2005 || ''Family Tree'' || Album of the Year  || {{won}}\n|-\n| 2005 || \"Real People\" || Song of the Year  || {{won}}\n|-\n| 2008 || ''Stronger'' || Top Selling Album of the Year  || {{won}}\n|-\n| 2009 || \"Still Here\" with [[Paul Kelly (Australian musician)|Paul Kelly]] || Vocal Collaboration of the Year  || {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Mo Awards===\nThe Australian Entertainment Mo Awards (commonly known informally as the [[Mo Awards]]), were annual Australian entertainment industry awards. They recognise achievements in live entertainment in Australia from 1975 to 2016. Melinda Schneider won eleven awards in that time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.moawards.com.au/awardwinners|title=MO Award Winners|website=Mo Awards|access-date=16 March 2022}}</ref>\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n|-\n| 1994\n| Melinda Schneider\n| Johnny O'Keefe Encouragement Award\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2000\n| Melinda Schneider\n| Female Country Entertainer of the Year \n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2002\n| Melinda Schneider\n| Female Country Entertainer of the Year \n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2003\n| Melinda Schneider\n| Female Country Entertainer of the Year \n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2004\n| Melinda Schneider\n| Female Country Entertainer of the Year \n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2006\n| Melinda Schneider\n| Slim Dusty Country Performer of the Year \n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2007\n| Melinda Schneider\n| Female Vocal Performer of the Year \n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2008\n| Melinda Schneider\n| Female Vocal Performer of the Year \n| {{won}}\n|-\n|rowspan=\"2\"| 2011\n| Melinda Schneider\n| Slim Dusty Country Act of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| Melinda Schneider\n| Female Vocal Performer of the Year \n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2014\n| Melinda Schneider\n| Slim Dusty Country Act of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.melindaschneider.com/ Official website]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Schneider, Melinda}}\n[[Category:1971 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Australian people of German descent]]\n[[Category:Australian country singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century Australian singers]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jesse_Mast","to":"Jesse Mast"}],"pages":{"50440193":{"pageid":50440193,"ns":0,"title":"Jesse Mast","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2019}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Jesse Mast\n| image           =\n| caption         =\n| image_size      =\n| birth_date      =\n| birth_name      =\n| birth_place     = [[Edmonton]], Alberta, Canada\n| origin          = [[Salmon Arm]], British Columbia, Canada\n| instrument      =\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 2014\u20132017\n| label           =\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = {{URL|jessemast.com/}}\n}}\n'''Jesse Mast''' is a Canadian [[country music]] singer-songwriter from [[Salmon Arm]], British Columbia.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jesse Mast Biography|url=http://www.cmt.ca/artist/jesse-mast|website=[[CMT (Canadian TV channel)|CMT]]|accessdate=May 5, 2016}}</ref> He has written with Larry Wayne Clark and toured with [[Gord Bamford]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Peebles|first1=Frank|title=Mast hoists his flag in P.G.|url=http://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/entertainment/local-a-e/mast-hoists-his-flag-in-p-g-1.2228853|accessdate=May 5, 2016|work=[[The Prince George Citizen]]|date=April 11, 2016}}</ref> He won three awards from the North American Country Music Association International in 2014: Songwriter of the Year, Male Vocalist of the Year and Male Entertainer of the Year.<ref>{{cite news|title=Coldstream is the place to be this Victoria Day weekend|url=http://www.vernonmorningstar.com/entertainment/258700091.html|accessdate=May 5, 2016|work=[[The Morning Star (Vernon, British Columbia)|The Morning Star]]|date=May 11, 2014}}</ref>\n\nMast is signed to Cache Entertainment/[[Sony Music Canada]] and released his debut single, \"Bad Blood\", in January 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bad Blood \u2013 Single|url=https://itunes.apple.com/ca/album/bad-blood-single/id1075413736|publisher=[[iTunes Store]]|accessdate=May 5, 2016}}</ref> It debuted on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Canada Country]] chart in March 2016.<ref name=\"Canada Country\" />\n\n==Discography==\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:8em;\"| Single\n! Peak<br />positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! [[Canada Country|CAN<br />Country]]<br /><ref name=\"Canada Country\">{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/search/charts?f%5B0%5D=ts_chart_artistname%3A%Jesse%20Mast%2A&f%5B1%5D=itm_field_chart_id%3A1240&f%5B2%5D=ss_bb_type%3Achart_item&type=2&artist=Jesse%20Mast|title=Jesse Mast Album & Song Chart History \u2013 Canada Country|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=May 5, 2016}}</ref>\n|-\n| 2016\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Bad Blood\"\n| 30\n| align=\"left\"| TBD\n|-\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:16em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| 2016\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Bad Blood\"<ref>{{cite news|title=News: Watch The Behind The Scenes Footage For Jesse Mast's New Video 'Bad Blood'|url=http://thefield.ca/news-watch-the-behind-the-scenes-footage-for-jesse-masts-new-video-bad-blood/|accessdate=May 5, 2016|work=The Field|date=February 18, 2016}}</ref>\n| [[Stephano Barberis]]\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2017\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Hold the Line\"\n|\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Somewhere South\"\n|\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*{{official website|http://www.jessemast.com/}}\n\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Mast, Jesse}}\n[[Category:Canadian country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Canadian male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Musicians from British Columbia]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Edmonton]]\n[[Category:People from Salmon Arm]]\n[[Category:21st-century Canadian male singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century Canadian singers]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]\n[[Category:21st-century Canadian singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Singers from Alberta]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jamie_Warren","to":"Jamie Warren"}],"pages":{"13241082":{"pageid":13241082,"ns":0,"title":"Jamie Warren","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image           = Jamie_Warren.jpg\n| name            = Jamie Warren\n| caption         = Jamie Warren, November 2005\n| birth_name      = Jamie Glenn Warren\n| alias           =\n| birth_place     =\n| birth_date      = April 8, 1961\n| death_date      =\n| origin          = [[Hanover, Ontario]], Canada\n| instrument      = Guitar, Piano\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 1984\u2013present\n| label           = TooHip Music\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = [http://www.jamiewarren.com/ www.jamiewarren.com]\n| current_members =\n| past_members    = \n}}\n\n'''Jamie Warren''' (born April 8, 1961) is a [[country music]] singer-songwriter, and the most awarded independent male artist in the Canadian country music industry.<ref name=\"bio\">{{Cite web |url=http://www.jamiewarren.com/bio.php |title=Jamie Warren<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=September 13, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120209110728/http://www.jamiewarren.com/bio.php |archive-date=February 9, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n==Biography==\nJamie Warren took piano lessons when he was 5 years old, and guitar lessons at 8. When he was 14, he wrote his first song. After high school, he did airshifts local radio stations, but maintained his interest in singing. He won the Youth Talent Search at [[London, Ontario|London]]'s [[Western Fair]], and was sent to [[Memphis, Tennessee]] to compete with other North American winners. This led Warren to a year performing at [[Libertyland]] amusement park in Memphis.<ref name=\"bio\">{{Cite web |url=http://www.jamiewarren.com/bio.php |title=Jamie Warren<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=September 13, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120209110728/http://www.jamiewarren.com/bio.php |archive-date=February 9, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nWhen Warren returned to Ontario, he began working with producer J. Richard \"Rick\" Hutt.<ref name=\"bio\">{{Cite web |url=http://www.jamiewarren.com/bio.php |title=Jamie Warren<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=September 13, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120209110728/http://www.jamiewarren.com/bio.php |archive-date=February 9, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref> His first single, \"World of a Child,\" was released in 1984. Independently, he released six more singles in the 1980s, including \"Take Me Home Mississippi,\" which peaked at No.&nbsp;10 in 1985. Later that year, Warren won the [[RPM (magazine)|RPM]] Big Country Award for Best New Artist.<ref name=\"awards\">[https://web.archive.org/web/20031219023234/http://www.jamiewarren.com/awards.html Jamie Warren's Official Website<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> When his career slowed down, he took time off to start a family, writing and playing in his spare time.<ref name=\"opry\">{{Cite web |url=http://www.oprynorth.com/indieartistprofiles/Iindienov2001.htm |title=New Page 1<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=September 13, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511172126/http://www.oprynorth.com/indieartistprofiles/Iindienov2001.htm |archive-date=May 11, 2008 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nIn 1993, Warren began work on his first album release on his own record label, TooHip Music.<ref name=\"jam1\">{{usurped|1=[https://archive.today/20130115162057/http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/W/Warren_Jamie/1996/05/02/751620.html CANOE \u2013 JAM! Music \u2013 Artists \u2013 Warren, Jamie: Jamie Warren has last laugh<!-- Bot generated title -->]}}</ref> The first single, \"Ready to Run,\" was released in 1995 and peaked at No.&nbsp;50 on the Canadian Country Singles chart. Warren wasn't originally planning to include the song on his album.<ref name=\"interview\">[http://thesongbridge.com/jamie.html Jamie Warren @ thesongbridge.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ''Fallen Angel'' was released in 1996 in both Canada and the United States.<ref name=\"cmt\">[https://web.archive.org/web/20071031103531/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/warren_jamie/bio.jhtml CMT.com : Jamie Warren : Biography<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> While the album didn't perform well in the US, it was a success in Canada. Singles released from the album include \"What Goes Around (Comes Around),\" \"Watching Her Sleep,\" and the 1996 top 5 hit \"One Step Back.\"\n\nWarren began work on his second album, ''Just Not the Same,'' in 1997.<ref name=\"jam2\">{{usurped|1=[https://archive.today/20130115070807/http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/W/Warren_Jamie/1997/02/06/751619.html CANOE \u2013 JAM! Music \u2013 Artists \u2013 Warren, Jamie: Not-so-young gun enjoys spotlight<!-- Bot generated title -->]}}</ref> The album was released the following year on the heels of his top 10 single, \"Cried All the Way Home.\" Four more singles from the album reached the Canadian top 20, including the top 10 singles \"The Way Love Goes\" and \"What a Woman Wants to Hear.\" ''Country Magazine'' named ''Just Not the Same'' the Best Album of 1999. When the [[Canadian Country Music Association]] (CCMA) awards were handed out in 1999, Warren was named Independent Male Vocalist of the Year, and \"Cried All the Way Home\" was named Independent Single of the Year. Warren swept the 1999 Ontario Country Music Awards (OCMA), winning every award he was nominated for, including Male Artist of the Year, Single Release of the Year (\"Cried All the Way Home\"), Video of the Year (\"Cried All the Way Home\"), CD Release of the Year (''Just Not the Same''), and Songwriter of the Year. He also received nominations at the 1999 RPM Big Country Awards (Male Vocalist of the Year) and the [[Juno Award]]s (Best Country Male Vocalist).<ref name=\"awards\">[https://web.archive.org/web/20031219023234/http://www.jamiewarren.com/awards.html Jamie Warren's Official Website<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>\n\n2000 was another big year for Warren, with the top 20 single \"Sunny Day in the Park.\" He was named Male Vocalist of the Year by the OCMA for the second year, and the Ontario Country Performer and Fan Association (OCPFA) awarded Warren Single of the Year for \"Cried All the Way Home\" and Songwriter of the Year for \"Words You Can't Take Back.\" He was also nominated for Male Vocalist of the Year by the CCMA, the Junos and RPM. Warren won two awards, Single of the Year (\"Sunny Day in the Park\") and Songwriter of the Year (\"Sunny Day in the Park\") at the 2002 OCPFA Awards.\n\nWarren's third album, ''Really'', was released in 2003. Four singles were released from the project, \"Without You,\" \"What More Can You Say,\" \"Reanne\" and \"Where's the Love,\" but they all missed the Canadian top 30. Warren released his [[greatest hits]] collection, ''Make Me Believe'', in October 2005. The album included 14 of Warren's most successful singles, along with five new tracks.<ref name=\"bio\">{{Cite web |url=http://www.jamiewarren.com/bio.php |title=Jamie Warren<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=September 13, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120209110728/http://www.jamiewarren.com/bio.php |archive-date=February 9, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Four of those songs received airplay on Canadian country radio, \"She Kissed Me,\" \"I Saw Her Standing There,\" \"You're My Everything\" and the title track.\n\nWarren's fourth studio album, ''Right Here Right Now'', was released in April 2008.\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! style=\"width:14em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Fallen Angel''\n| \n* Release date: September 9, 1996\n* Label: [[River North Records]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Just Not the Same''\n| \n* Release date: 1998\n* Label: TooHip Music\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Really''\n| \n* Release date: 2003\n* Label: TooHip Music\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Right Here Right Now''\n| \n* Release date: April 29, 2008\n* Label: TooHip Music\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Howl at the Moon''\n| \n* Release date: May 18, 2010\n* Label: TooHip Music\n|-\n! Year\n! style=\"width:20em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1995\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Ready to Run\"\n| \n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"What Goes Around (Comes Around)\"\n| \n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1996\n! scope=\"row\"| \"One Step Back\"\n| \n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Watching Her Sleep\"\n| \n|-\n| 1997\n! scope=\"row\"| \"The Secret\"\n| \n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1998\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Cried All the Way Home\"\n| \n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"The Way Love Goes\"\n| \n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 1999\n! scope=\"row\"| \"She'll Find Someone to Love Her\"\n| \n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"What a Woman Wants to Hear\"\n| Terrance Odette\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2000\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Words You Can't Take Back\"\n| \n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Sunny Day in the Park\"\n| Terrance Odette\n|-\n| 2008\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Right Here Right Now\"\n| \n|-\n| 2018\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Do You Think of Me (Dad's Song)\"\n|\n|}\n\n==References and footnotes==\n<references/>\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.jamiewarren.com Jamie Warren Official Site]\n*[http://thesongbridge.com/jamie.html Jamie Warren Interview]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Warren, Jamie}}\n[[Category:1961 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Canadian country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Canadian male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:River North Records artists]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Harmony_James","to":"Harmony James"}],"pages":{"37684047":{"pageid":37684047,"ns":0,"title":"Harmony James","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Australian singer-songwriter}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2020}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=March 2019}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Harmony James\n| image           = Harmony_%26_Shane_at_Lizotte%27s.jpg\n| alt             =\n| caption         = James performing live with [[Shane Nicholson (singer)|Shane Nicholson]]\n| landscape       = yes\n| birth_name      =\n| birth_place     = [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], Australia\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[alternative country]], [[folk music|folk]]\n| associated_acts =\n| occupation      = Singer, songwriter\n| years_active    = 2007\u2013present\n| label           = [[Warner Music|Warner]]\n| website         = {{URL|http://harmonyjames.com/}}\n}}\n\n'''Harmony James'''  is an Australian singer-songwriter. Although James is often classified as a country artist, her music draws on many genres, including [[folk music|folk]], pop, rock and [[blues music|blues]]. In 2006 Harmony first came to the attention of the music industry when she became the only Australian songwriter to have won the country category of the International Songwriting Competition, with her song \"Tailwind\".<ref name=\"update\" /> Her second single, \"Somebody Stole My Horse\",  became Australian radio's second most played country song in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|title=Herm Kovac Productions|url=http://www.ramrodstudio.com/Herm%20kovac.html|work=Ramrod Studio|accessdate=15 December 2012}}</ref> spawned \n\n==Early life==\nBorn in [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], Australia to a [[Baptist]] preacher as one of twelve children, Harmony went to a private school and says she had \"few friends\".<ref name=\"courier\" /> She read voraciously, eventually discovering the western novels of [[Louis L'Amour]].<ref name=update>{{cite journal|title=Tailwind or Tornado?|journal=Country Update|issue=54|url=http://www.countryupdate.com.au/images/stories/cu54/01_harmony_james.pdf|accessdate=1 December 2012}}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> James discovered traditional country music after a friend returned from [[Texas]] with records by [[Dolly Parton]] and [[The Judds]].<ref name=\"courier\" /> Soon after, James taught herself enough guitar to learn a few country songs and took to the streets singing to earn money.\n\nShe later ran a stock camp in the outback of [[Queensland]] and worked with cattle on the [[Northern Territory]]'s [[Barkly Tableland]]. She left home to work as a [[Jillaroo (trainee)|jillaroo]] at some of the most remote cattle stations in southwestern Queensland,<ref name=\"update\" /> \"covered in mud and blood, roughing it with the guys, working so hard I had biceps and thinking, 'This is not what my mother pictured for me'.\" A gig at a school fete in [[Goondiwindi]] led to an offer from the local publican and Harmony's songbook started filling, even as she continued her parallel life on the land, from the Cape to [[Tennant Creek]], studying agriculture at [[The University of Queensland]] at [[Gatton, Queensland|Gatton]]<ref name=\"courier\" /> and working as a welder \"in a shed of 80 blokes.\"<ref name=capital>{{cite news|last=Jarvis|first=Susan|title=Complete Harmony|url=http://www.capitalnews.com.au/editorial.asp?editorial_id=1614&issue=117|access-date=1 December 2012|newspaper=Capital News|date=July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130427073019/http://www.capitalnews.com.au/editorial.asp?editorial_id=1614&issue=117|archive-date=27 April 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref> \"My musical exposure was mostly church music until I got a job as a checkout chick and heard the radio,\" she says. \"Now when I hang out with other musos they'll drop names and I'll just look at them blankly 'cause my music history starts in '95.\"<ref name=alberts>{{cite web|title=Harmony James|url=http://albertmusic.com/musicians/harmony-james|work=Alberts|publisher=Alberts Pty Ltd.|accessdate=1 December 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905235752/http://albertmusic.com/musicians/harmony-james|archive-date=5 September 2015|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nIn 2007, James won the country category of the International Songwriting Competition, and began working with producer Herm Kovac on her debut EP, ''[[Harmony James (EP)|Harmony James]]''.  \n\nHer debut studio album, ''[[Tailwind (album)|Tailwind]]'',  was released in 2009.  In 2009, James went on tour with [[Sara Storer]] and [[Kasey Chambers]], performing \"Tailwind\" in major festivals. Chambers later recorded her own version of one of James' songs, \"Good Enough.\"<ref>{{Citation |title=Good Enough - Kasey Chambers, Shane Nicholson {{!}} Song Info {{!}} AllMusic |url=https://www.allmusic.com/song/mt0045623522 |language=en |access-date=2022-02-26}}</ref>\n\nJames was nominated for Best Female Artist and Best Album for the CMAA Golden Guitar Awards in 2010 and won Best Female artist at the Victorian and [[Mildura]] Country Awards.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Harmony James |url=https://www.female.com.au/harmony-james.htm |access-date=2022-02-26 |website=Female.com.au |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Eliezer |first=Christie |last2= |first2= |date=2009-11-12 |title=Keith Urban Snags 4 CMAA Nominations |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/keith-urban-snags-4-cmaa-nominations-1262999/ |access-date=2022-02-26 |website=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref>{{cn|date=April 2021}} and headlined her first [[Tamworth Country Music Festival|Tamworth]] show.<ref name=courier>{{cite news|last=Mengel|first=Noel|title=It's the sound of sweet Harmony|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/ipad/its-the-sound-of-sweet-harmony/story-fn6ck8la-1226249629574|accessdate=1 December 2012|newspaper=The Courier-Mail|date=21 January 2012}}</ref> \n\nAustralian country music trio The [[McClymonts]] signed James in 2011 as an opening act for their first major Australian tour. James' 2011 single \"Precious Little\" became the second most played single on Australian radio.{{citation needed|date=March 2019}}\n\nIn March 2011, James returned to the studio with Herm Kovac to work on her second album, ''[[Handfuls of Sky]]''. The following November, James signed a worldwide publishing deal with [[Albert Music]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Australian Country Songwriter Harmony James Signs World-wide Deal With Alberts|url=http://albertmusic.com/news/australian-country-songwriter-harmony-james-signs-world-wide-deal-with-albe|work=Alberts|publisher=Alberts Pty Ltd|accessdate=1 December 2012|date=11 October 2011}}</ref> and a major record deal with [[Warner Music Australia]] on the same day.<ref>{{Cite web |date=17 October 2011 |title=Australian Country Music News, October 2011 |url=https://www.countrymusicbulletin.com.au/newsarchive_Oct11.html |access-date=2022-02-26 |website=Country Music Bulletin}}</ref>\n\n''[[Handfuls of Sky]]'' was released on 20 January 2012, along with the ''Harmony James Songbook'', a portfolio of sheet music, lyrics, photos and stories. In 2012, James continued performing at festivals, tours, and shows with artists including [[Troy Cassar-Daley]]<ref name=\"courier\" /> and [[Tim Freedman]]. The first single from ''Handfuls of Sky'', \"Pride\", spent six weeks at number one,<ref name=\"courier\" /> and the third single, \"Emmylou's Guitar\" spend three weeks at number one. 2012 also brought more recognition for James, as she won the country category at the Queensland Music Awards<ref>{{cite web|title=QLD Music Awards 2012|url=http://www.qmusic.com.au/qldmusicawards/2012/index.cfm?contentID=704|work=Queensland Music Awards|access-date=1 December 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129014823/http://www.qmusic.com.au/qldmusicawards/2012/index.cfm?contentID=704|archive-date=29 November 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref> and was nominated for three 2013 Golden Guitar awards: Best Vocal Collaboration with [[Shane Nicholson (singer)|Shane Nicholson]] for \"Reach for You\", Best Female Artist, and APRA Song of the Year for \"Emmylou's Guitar\".<ref>{{cite web|title=41st Country Music Awards of Australia Finalists Announced|url=http://www.country.com.au/news/cmaa-news/856-41st-country-music-awards-of-australia-finalists-announced|work=CMAA|access-date=1 December 2012|date=12 November 2012|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121115091027/http://www.country.com.au/news/cmaa-news/856-41st-country-music-awards-of-australia-finalists-announced|archive-date=15 November 2012|df=}}</ref>\n\nIn 2014, James released her third studio album, ''[[Cautionary Tales (album)|Cautionary Tales]],'' for which James received CMAA 2015 nominations in the categories of Best Album, Best Female Artist, and Best Heritage Song for \"Coal Seam Gas\".<ref>{{Cite web |date=16 November 2014 |title=Golden Guitar Awards Unveil 2015 Finalists List |url=https://themusic.com.au/ |access-date=2022-02-26 |website=The Music |publisher=SGC Group |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Belt |first=Rebecca |date=2014-11-17 |title=Golden Guitar Awards: The finalists {{!}} SPECIAL COVERAGE |url=https://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/story/2700941/golden-guitar-awards-the-finalists-special-coverage/ |access-date=2022-02-26 |website=The Northern Daily Leader |language=en-AU}}</ref> Harmony toured extensively with Luke O'Shea and Pete Denahy and then later in the year with Lachlan Bryan.{{citation needed|date=March 2019}}<ref>{{Cite web |date=2016-12-30 |title=Lachlan Bryan & Harmony James at The Listening Room in Mobile, AL (Thur. Dec. 8, 2016) |url=https://thesouthlandmusicline.com/photos-and-music-art/photos/lachlan-bryan-harmony-james-at-the-listening-room-in-mobile-al-thur-dec-8-2016/ |access-date=2022-02-26 |website=The Southland Music Line |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nHarmony opened for and performed with Emmylou Harris and Rodney Crowell on their Australian tour in 2015. ''The Courier Mail''<nowiki/>'s Noel Mengel reviewed the show, saying about James' set, \"When someone shines while singing alongside Emmylou Harris, you know that's a truly great singer. If you love this kind of music, you really need to check her out.\"<ref>{{Cite web |last=Mengel |first=Noel |date=2 July 2015 |title=Emmylou Harris and Rodney Crowell shine at Jupiters gig |url=https://www.couriermail.com.au/entertainment/confidential/emmylou-harris-and-rodney-crowell-shine-at-jupiters-gig/news-story/0d574ce0f6d1fa5523e0da51f8e8f34a |website=The Courier Mail}}</ref> \n\nIn late 2018, James' official Facebook page announced a new independent album ''Resignation''. It was produced by Glen Hannah, music critic Bernard Zuel published a favourable review of the record, suggesting \"James might be earning the right to be counted among the likes of the more experienced Gretchen Peters and Rosanne Cash\".<ref>{{Cite web |last=Zuel |first=Bernard |date=2019-01-30 |title=Harmony James - Resignation: Review |url=https://www.bernardzuel.net/post/2019/01/31/harmony-james-resignation-review |access-date=2022-02-26 |website=Bernard Zuel |language=en}}</ref> The ''Sunburnt Country Music'' blog said \"despite its title, ''Resignation'' is not an album that sounds like defeat, retreat or weariness \u2013 it is a glorious manifestation of James's skills and talent, and it has been worth waiting for\".<ref>{{Cite web |date=2019-02-18 |title=Album review: Resignation by Harmony James |url=https://sunburntcountrymusic.com/2019/02/18/album-review-resignation-by-harmony-james/ |access-date=2022-02-26 |website=Sunburnt Country Music |language=en}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n=== Studio albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\" border=\"1\"\n! mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Lee_Kernaghan","to":"Lee Kernaghan"}],"pages":{"2193612":{"pageid":2193612,"ns":0,"title":"Lee Kernaghan","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2021}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name                = Lee Kernaghan\n| image               = Lee Kernaghan (cropped2).jpg\n| alt                 = Man in black hat sitting on ground\n| caption             = \n| birth_name          = Lee Raymond Kernaghan\n| alias               =\n| birth_date          = {{Birth date and age|1964|4|15|df=yes}}\n| birth_place         = [[Corryong]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], Australia\n| instrument          = Vocals, guitar\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]], [[Country Rock]], [[Rock music|Rock]], [[Pop music|Pop]], [[Country Pop]]\n| occupation          = Singer, songwriter, musician\n| years_active        = 1977\u2013present\n| label               = [[ABC Music]]\n| associated_acts     = {{hlist|The Blue Devils|Fiona Kernaghan|[[Ray Kernaghan]]|[[Tania Kernaghan]]}}\n| website             = {{URL|leekernaghan.com.au}}\n}}\n'''Lee Kernaghan''' [[Order of Australia|OAM]] (born 15 April 1964) is an Australian [[country music]] singer, songwriter and guitarist. Kernaghan has won four [[ARIA Awards]] and three [[APRA Awards (Australia)|APRA Awards]], and has sold over two million albums, and as of 2021,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jbhifi.com.au/products/cd-kernaghan-lee-backroad-nation-cd?queryID=1f79a7cabae927384ce0134b82f8b8e6&objectID=379435|title=Backroad Nation|website=[[JB HiFi]]|access-date=30 December 2021}}</ref> has won 38 [[Golden Guitar]]s at the Country Music Awards of Australia (second to [[Slim Dusty]]).\n\nHe was the 2008 [[Australian of the Year]], in recognition of his support for rural and regional Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.cs-ma-ANL%3AMA~Converted-ruth-5|title=Kernaghan. Lee|work=Music Australia|publisher=National Library of Australia|access-date=16 October 2009}}</ref><ref name=\"aoty\"/> Kernaghan was the recipient of the Outstanding Achievement Award at the 2015 ARIA Awards, for ''Spirit of the Anzacs''.<ref name=\":3\" />\n\n== Biography ==\n===1965\u20131990: Early years===\nLee Kernaghan was born on 15 April 1964 in [[Corryong]], Victoria and is the son of country music singer and truck driver [[Ray Kernaghan]]. Lee spent his formative years growing up in Albury [[New South Wales]]. His grandfather was a third generation drover of sheep and cattle.<ref name=\"abcbio\">{{cite web|url=https://www.abcmusic.com.au/lee-kernaghan|title=Lee Kernaghan|website=ABC Music|access-date=30 December 2021}}</ref>\n\nIn 1986, Kernaghan traveled to the United States to represent Australia at the [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] 'Fan Fair' country music festival.\n\n===1990s ===\nIn 1992, Kernaghan released \"Boys from the Bush\" which became his first number one on the country chart.<ref name=\"abcbio\"/> Kernaghan said \"When Garth (Porter) and I first wrote 'Boys from the Bush' I had no idea it would ever be a hit. It was just a song about me and my mates, working on the land, going to the pub and tearing around in utes. I didn't think anyone would be that interested in us... we were just kids from the bush but Garth said 'this record (''The Outback Club'') has to be about your life and where you come from so we wrote that song and several others and before long I had a band and we were out on the road performing them live.\"<ref name=\"abcbio\"/>\n\nIn May 1992, Kernaghan released ''[[The Outback Club]]''. The album debuted at number 94 on the [[ARIA Charts]].<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/> At the 1993 Country Music Awards of Australia (CMAA), the album won Album of the Year the [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album]].<ref name=\"CMAA\"/> The album re-entered the chart later peaking at number 58 in May 1994.<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/>\n\nIn August 1993, Kernaghan released his second studio album, ''[[Three Chain Road]]''. The album again won the CMAA Album of the Year and the ARIA Award for Best Country Album.<ref name=\"CMAA\"/>\n\nIn July 1995, Kernaghan released his third studio album, ''[[1959 (album)|1959]]'', which peaked at number 9 on the ARIA Chart, becoming Kernaghan's first top ten album.<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/> The album won Kernaghan his third Album of the Year at the CMAA of 1996.<ref name=\"CMAA\"/>\n\nIn February 1998, Kernaghan released his fourth studio album, ''[[Hat Town]]''. The album peaked at number 7 on the ARIA Chart<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/> and won his fourth Album of the Year at the CMAA of 1999.<ref name=\"CMAA\"/>\n\nKernaghan's fifth studio album was ''[[The Christmas Album (Lee Kernaghan album)|The Christmas Album]]'' in November 1998. The album peaked at number 31 on the ARIA chart.<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/>\n\n===2000s ===\nIn January 2000, Kernaghan released his sixth studio album, ''[[Rules of the Road (Lee Kernaghan album)|Rules of the Road]]''. This was followed by ''[[Electric Rodeo (Lee Kernaghan album)|Electric Rodeo]]'' in July 2002 which won Album of the Year and Top Selling Album of the Year at the 2003 CMAA.<ref name=\"CMAA\"/> ''Electric Rodeo'' peaked at number 5 on the ARIA chart.<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/>\n\nKernaghan was part of ''[[The Man from Snowy River: Arena Spectacular]]'' in 2002.\n\nIn October 2004, Kernaghan released his first greatest hits collection titled, ''[[The Big Ones: Greatest Hits Vol. 1]]''. The album peaked at number 16 on the ARIA charts and was certified platinum.<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/>\n\nIn April 2006, Kernaghan released his eighth studio album, ''[[The New Bush]]''. The album peaked at number 6 on the ARIA Charts and won Album of the Year and Top Selling Album of the Year at the 2007 CMAA.<ref name=\"CMAA\"/>\n\nIn July 2007, Kernaghan released his ninth studio album, ''[[Spirit of the Bush]]''. The album's title track peaked at number 11 on the ARIA singles chart, becoming Kernaghan's highest charting single. The song won three awards at the 2008 CMAA.<ref name=\"CMAA\"/>\n\nIn November 2009, Kernaghan released his tenth studio album, ''[[Planet Country]]''.\n\nIn 2009 Kernaghan was named the biggest hit-maker of the last twenty years on the Australian Country Tracks chart, beating musical greats from Australia and international.<ref name=\"abcbio\"/>\n\n===2010s ===\nIn September 2011, Kernaghan released his second greatest hits collection, ''[[Ultimate Hits (Lee Kernaghan album)|Ultimate Hits]]''. The album peaked at number 8 on the ARIA chart.<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/>\n\nIn October 2012, Kernaghan released his eleventh studio album, ''[[Beautiful Noise (Lee Kernaghan album)|Beautiful Noise]]''. The album peaked at number 9 on the ARIA chart.<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/>\n\nDuring a visit to the [[Australian War Memorial]] (AWM) in 2013, Kernaghan's friend and AWM Director [[Brendan Nelson|Dr. Brendan Nelson]] introduced Kernaghan to letters that were written by [[Australian Defence Force|Australian service men and women]] during various wars dating back to the landing at [[Gallipoli Campaign|Gallipoli]] during the [[World War I|First World War]]. These letters were held in the vaults at the AWM.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Lee Kernaghan \u2013 \"Outstanding Achievement Award\" for Spirit of the Anzacs {{!}} Australian War Memorial|url = https://www.awm.gov.au/blog/2015/12/10/lee-kernaghan-Spirit-of-the-Anzacs/|website = www.awm.gov.au|access-date = 14 December 2015}}</ref> The power of the letters affected Kernaghan deeply and the experience at the Australian War Memorial that day was the catalyst that saw these letters put to music in what would become the ''[[Spirit of the Anzacs (album)]]'' in March 2015. Upon release, the album peaked at number 1 on the ARIA charts, becoming Kernaghan's first chart topper. It was the highest selling Australian artist album for 2015.<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web|title = ARIAs: Lee Kernaghan wins achievement award|url = http://www.skynews.com.au/culture/showbiz/music/2015/11/26/arias--lee-kernaghan-wins-achievement-award.html|website = www.skynews.com.au|access-date =14 December 2015}}</ref>\n\n2015 also saw the release of Kernaghan's first book, ''The Boy from the Bush, These Are My Songs, These Are My Stories''.\n\nIn March 2017, Kernaghan released his fourteenth studio album, ''[[The 25th Anniversary Album (Lee Kernaghan album)|The 25th Anniversary Album]]''. The album peaked at number 2 on the ARIA chart.<ref name=\"AUS-Albums\"/>\n\nIn 2019 Kernaghan released his fifteenth studio album, ''[[Backroad Nation]]'' with the title track staying four weeks at #1 on the country singles charts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://countrytrackschart.com.au/index.php?chartid=273|title=Country Songs Top 40 Australian Airplay Chart|website=countrytrackschart.com.au|access-date=7 August 2019}}</ref>\n\n===2020s ===\nIn 2022 Kernaghan is set to celebrate his 30th anniversary as an artist. In January 2022, he released a 3-CD greatest hits collection titled ''[[The Very Best of Lee Kernaghan: Three Decades of Hits]]'' on 14 January 2022 which peaked at number 17 on the ARIA charts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jbhifi.com.au/products/cd-kernaghan-lee-very-best-of-lee-kernaghan-three-decades-of-hits-3cd?queryID=4099785a3b5dbca5b478be730a34c990&objectID=540243|title=Very Best Of Lee Kernaghan: Three Decades Of Hits|website=[[JB Hi-Fi]]|date=30 December 2021}}</ref>\n\n== Personal life ==\nDuring July 2015, Kernaghan's music was played at anti-Islam rallies in Australia, without his permission.<ref name=\"the Music\">{{cite news | url = http://themusic.com.au/news/all/2015/07/24/lee-kernaghan-sits-on-fence-over-reclaim-australia-use-of-song/ | title = Lee Kernaghan Sits on Fence Over Reclaim Australia Use of Song | last = (staff writer) | work = themusic.com.au | date = 24 July 2015 | access-date = 2 July 2016 }}</ref><ref name=\"Reclaim\">{{cite news | url = http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/as-midnight-oil-demands-reclaim-australia-stop-playing-songs-lee-kernaghan-refuses-20150724-gijkuu.html | title = As Midnight Oil Demands Reclaim Australia Stop Playing Songs, Lee Kernaghan Refuses | last = Vincent | first = Peter | work = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | date = 24 July 2015 | access-date = 2 July 2016 }}</ref> He responded that the use of his work should be \"consistent with \u2013 and respectful of, the memory of ... [soldiers who] laid down their lives for the freedoms we have today.\"<ref name=\"Reclaim\" /> Fellow local artists, [[Jimmy Barnes]], [[John Farnham]] and [[Mark Seymour]], objected to the use of their material at those rallies.\n\nKernaghan married musician Robyn McKelvie in 1999. They have two sons, Jet and Rock.<ref name=smh2013>{{cite web|url= https://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/what-i-know-about-women-20130528-2n9aw.html |title=What I know about women - Lee Kernaghan |website=Sydney Morning Herald |date=2 June 2013 |access-date=28 January 2023 }}</ref>\n\n=== Business ventures ===\nFor several years, Kernaghan owned the historic Great Western Hotel in [[Rockhampton, Queensland]], after buying the pub in 2003 when it was placed into receivership after a downturn in trade and public liability concerns.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/site-archive/rural/qld/stories/s828257.htm Kernaghan buys Great Western pub], Chris Lawson, ''[[The Country Hour|Queensland Country Hour]]'', [[ABC Rural]], 9 April 2003. Retrieved 23 March 2017.</ref><ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/site-archive/rural/news/stories/s828277.htm Boy from the bush buys QLD pub], ''National Rural News'', [[ABC Rural]], 9 April 2003. Retrieved 23 March 2017.</ref> Kernaghan has described the time during which he owned the Great Western Hotel as one of the greatest periods of his life.<ref>[https://www.themorningbulletin.com.au/news/lee-kernaghan-returns-to-second-home-country-music/2631007 Country music legend Lee Kernaghan returns to 'second home'], Michelle Gately, ''[[The Morning Bulletin]]'', 7 May 2015. Retrieved 23 March 2017.</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n=== Studio albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\" border=\"1\"\n|-\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:17em;\"| Title\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n! scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\"| Peak chart positions\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\"| [[List of music recording certifications|Certifications]]\n|-\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:3.7em;font-size:90%;\"| [[ARIA Charts|AUS]]<br /><ref name=\"AUS-Albums\">Peak chart positions in Australia:\n*Top 50 peaks: {{cite web|url=http://australian-charts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Lee+Kernaghan|title=australian-charts.com \u2013 Discography Lee Kernaghan|publisher=Hung Medien|access-date=25 August 2021}}\n*Top 100 peaks to December 2010: {{cite book|last=Ryan|first=Gavin|title=Australia's Music Charts 1988\u20132010|year=2011|publisher=Moonlight Publishing|location=Mt. Martha, VIC, Australia|edition=PDF|page=153}}</ref>\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Access All Areas''\n|\n* Release date: June 2004\n* Label: ABC Country (1391-9)\n| 8\n|\n* ARIA: Gold<ref name=ARIADVDCert04>{{cite certification|region=Australia|artist=Lee Kernaghan|type=video|certyear=2004|access-date=18 December 2021}}</ref>\n|}\n\n=== Charting singles ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\" border=\"1\"\n|-\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\"| Title\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\"| Peak chart positions\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:15em;\"| Album\n|-\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:3.7em;font-size:90%;\"| [[ARIA Charts|AUS]]<br /><ref name=\"AUS-Singles\">Peak chart positions in Australia:\n*Top 50 peaks: {{cite web|url=https://australian-charts.com/search.asp?search=lee+kernaghan&cat=s |title=australian-charts.com \u2013 Discography Lee Kernaghan|publisher=Hung Medien |access-date=25 August 2021}}\n*Top 100 peaks to December 2010: {{cite book|last=Ryan|first=Gavin|title=Australia's Music Charts 1988\u20132010|year=2011|publisher=Moonlight Publishing|location=Mt. 2007\n| 11\n| ''Spirit of the Bush''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[Spirit of the Anzacs]]\" <br />{{small|(featuring [[Guy Sebastian]], [[Sheppard (band)|Sheppard]], [[Jon Stevens]], [[Jessica Mauboy]], [[Shannon Noll]] and [[Megan Washington]])}}\n| 2015\n| 32\n| ''Spirit of the Anzacs''\n|}\n\n== Awards and nominations ==\nKernaghan received the [[Order of Australia]] Medal in 2004.<ref name=\"honour1\">{{cite web|url=https://honours.pmc.gov.au/honours/awards/1056303|title=KERNAGHAN, Lee Raymond OAM|work=It's an Honour|publisher=Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet|access-date=16 October 2009}}</ref>\n\nIn 2008, he was [[Australian of the Year]],<ref name=\"australian1\">{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,23108522-5018520,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091003235723/http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0%2C25197%2C23108522-5018520%2C00.html |url-status=dead |archive-date= 3 October 2009 |title=Lee Kernaghan named Australian of the Year |date=25 January 2008 |publisher=The Australian |access-date=16 October 2009 }}</ref> in recognition for his support of rural and regional Australia; his 'Pass the Hat Around' tours have raised more than a million dollars for rural communities during a challenging period of drought.<ref name=\"aoty\">{{Cite web|title = Australian of the Year Awards|url = https://www.australianoftheyear.org.au/recipients/lee-kernaghan/111/|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20200806013159/https://australianoftheyear.org.au/recipients/lee-kernaghan/111/|url-status = dead|archive-date = 6 August 2020|website = www.australianoftheyear.org.au|access-date = 9 February 2022}}</ref> He was presented with the award by [[Prime Minister of Australia|Prime Minister]] [[Kevin Rudd]].\n\n=== AIR Awards ===\nThe Australian Independent Record Awards (commonly known informally as [[AIR Awards]]) is an annual awards night to recognise, promote and celebrate the success of Australia's Independent Music sector.\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| [[AIR Awards of 2013|2013]]<ref name=\"13nom\">{{cite web|url=https://tonedeaf.thebrag.com/final-air-awards-2013-nominations-revealed-50000-prize-announced/|title=Final AIR Awards 2013 Nominations Revealed, $50,000 Prize Announced|website=tonedeaf|date=1 Album''\n| Best Independent Country Album\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[AIR Awards of 2020|2020]]<ref name=\"2020nom\">{{cite web|url=https://scenestr.com.au/music/2020-air-awards-nominees-20200707|title=2020
