a wrap: 2020 AIR Awards winners and celebrations|website=the industry observer|date=1 October 2020 |access-date=1 October 2020}}</ref>\n|''Backroad Nation''\n| Best Independent Country Album\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n=== ARIA Music Awards ===\nThe [[ARIA Music Awards]] is an annual awards ceremony that recognises excellence, innovation, and achievement across all genres of [[Australian music]]. Kernaghan has won two awards from 14 nominations.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.ariaawards.com.au/history/award/Best-Country-Album|title = ARIA Awards Search Results \u2013 Lee Kernaghan|work = ARIA Awards|publisher = www.ariaawards.com.au|date = 6 March 2015|access-date = 6 March 2015}}</ref> Plus, he received the Outstanding Achievement Award in 2015.\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 1993|1993]]\n| ''The Outback Club''\n| rowspan=\"10\"| [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]]\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 1994|1994]]\n| ''Three Chain Road''\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 1995|1995]]\n| ''Country Crowd''\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 1996|1996]]\n| ''1959''\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2000|2000]]\n| ''Rules of the Road''\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2002|2002]]\n| ''Electric Rodeo''\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2006|2006]]\n| ''The New Bush''\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2010|2010]]\n| ''Planet Country''\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2013|2013]]\n| ''Beautiful Noise''\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"4\"| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2015|2015]]\n| ''[[Spirit of the Anzacs (album)|Spirit of the Anzacs]]''\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| \"Spirit of the Anzacs\" (directed by [[Duncan Toombs]])\n| rowspan=\"1\"| [[ARIA Award for Best Video|Best Video]]\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Garth Porter for''Spirit of the Anzacs''\n| rowspan=\"1\"| [[ARIA Award for Producer of the Year|Producer of the Year]]\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| ''Spirit of the Anzacs''\n| rowspan=\"1\"| Outstanding Achievement Award\n| {{yes2|awarded}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2017|2017]]\n| ''The 25th Anniversary Album''\n| rowspan=\"2\"| Best Country Album\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2019|2019]]\n| ''Backroad Nation''\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n=== APRA Awards ===\nThe [[APRA Awards (Australia)|APRA Awards]] are held in Australia and New Zealand by the [[Australasian Performing Right Association]] to recognise songwriting skills, sales and airplay performance by its members annually. Kernaghan has won four awards from nine nominations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apraamcos.com.au/search|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210207235410/https://www.apraamcos.com.au/search|url-status=dead|archive-date=7 February 2021|title=Nine first-time winners in 12 APRA Music Award categories|work=APRA Awards|publisher=[[Australasian Performing Right Association]] (APRA) &#124; [[Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners Society]] (AMCOS)|date=6 March 2015}}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| [[APRA Music Awards of 1993|1993]]\n| \"Boys from the Bush\"\n| Country Song of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| [[APRA Music Awards of 1996|1996]]\n| \"1959\"\n| Most Performed Country Work\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| [[APRA Music Awards of 1999|1999]]\n| \"Hat Town\"\n| Most Performed Country Work\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| [[APRA Music Awards of 2004|2004]]\n| \"Way It Is\"\n| Most Performed Country Work\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[APRA Music Awards of 2007|2007]]\n| \"New Bush\"\n| Most Performed Country Work\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[APRA Music Awards of 2008|2008]]\n| \"Spirit of the Bush\" <small>(featuring Adam Brand and Steve Forde)</small>\n| Most Performed Country Work\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[APRA Music Awards of 2011|2011]]\n| \"Planet Country\"\n| Country Work of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[APRA Music Awards of 2014|2014]]\n| \"Flying with the King\"\n| Country Work of the Year<ref name=\"CWotYNom\">{{cite web | url = http://apraamcos.com.au/awards/2014-awards/apra-music-awards/country-work-of-the-year/ | title = Country Work of the Year | publisher = Australasian Performing Right Association (APRA) &#124; Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners Society (AMCOS) | year = 2014 | access-date = 5 March 2016 }}</ref>\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| [[APRA Music Awards of 2020|2020]]\n| \"Backroad Nation\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.noise11.com/news/tones-and-i-leads-nominations-for-2020-virtual-apra-awards-20200407|title= Tones and I Leads Nominations for 2020 Virtual APRA Awards|website=Noise11|date=7 April 2020|access-date=11 April 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://apraamcos.com.au/awards/2020-awards/apra-music-awards/|title=2020 Awards|website=APRA|date=7 April 2020|access-date=11 April 2020}}</ref>\n| Most Performed Country Work of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n=== Australian Roll of Renown ===\nThe [[Australian Roll of Renown]] honours Australian and New Zealander musicians who have shaped the music industry by making a significant and lasting contribution to Country Music. It was inaugurated in 1976 and the inductee is announced at the [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] in Tamworth in January.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tcmf.com.au/roll-of-renown |title=Roll of Renown |publisher=Tamworth Country Music Festival|access-date=29 October 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tcmf.com.au/What-s-On/Roll-of-Renown/ |title=Roll of Renown |publisher=TCMF |access-date=21 August 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180821093757/https://www.tcmf.com.au/What-s-On/Roll-of-Renown/ |archive-date=21 August 2018 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| 2015\n| Lee Kernaghan\n| Australian Roll of Renown\n| {{yes2|inductee}}\n{{end}}\n\n=== Country Music Awards (CMAA) ===\nThe [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] (CMAA) (also known as the Golden Guitar Awards) is an annual awards night held in January during the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]], celebrating recording excellence in the Australian country music industry. They have been held annually since 1973. Kernaghan has won thirty-eight [[Golden Guitar]] awards at the [[Tamworth, New South Wales|Tamworth]] [[Country Music Awards of Australia]].<ref name=\"CMAA\">{{Cite web |url=http://country.com.au/golden-guitars/award-winners/1990s |title=1990\u2032s :: Country Music Australia |access-date=21 February 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140125225402/http://country.com.au/golden-guitars/award-winners/1990s/ |archive-date=25 January 2014 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| Washington) </small> || Video clip of the Year || {{won}}\n|-\n| 2016 || ''[[Spirit of the Anzacs (album)|Spirit of the Anzacs]]'' || Top Selling Album of the Year || {{won}}\n|-\n| 2018 || ''The 25th Anniversary Album'' || Top Selling Album of the Year || {{won}}\n|-\n| 2020 || ''Backroad Nation'' || Top Selling Album of the Year || {{won}}\n{{end}}\n\n===Mo Awards===\nThe Australian Entertainment Mo Awards (commonly known informally as the [[Mo Awards]]), were annual Australian entertainment industry awards. They recognise achievements in live entertainment in Australia from 1975 to 2016. Lee Kernaghan won five awards in that time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.moawards.com.au/awardwinners|title=MO Award Winners|website=Mo Awards|access-date=16 March 2022}}</ref>\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n|-\n|rowspan=\"2\"| 1992 \n| Lee Kernaghan\n| Country Performer of the Year \n| {{won}}\n|-\n| Lee Kernaghan\n| Male Country Entertainer of the Year \n| {{won}}\n|-\n|rowspan=\"2\"| 1993\n| Lee Kernaghan\n| Country Performer of the Year \n| {{won}}\n|-\n| Lee Kernaghan\n| Male Country Entertainer of the Year \n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 1994 \n| Lee Kernaghan\n| Male Country Entertainer of the Year \n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n=== Music for a New Generation Awards===\nThe Music For A New Generation Awards are run by the [[Planet Country with Big Stu & MJ]] radio program and celebrate crossover country artist efforts each year. The awards have featured fan voting since 2016.\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| 2015\n| Himself\n| Australian Male Artist of The Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| 2017\n| Himself\n| Australian Male Artist of The Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Tamworth Songwriters Awards===\nThe Tamworth Songwriters Association (TSA) is an annual songwriting contest for original country songs, awarded in January at the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]]. They commenced in 1986.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsaonline.com.au/song-competition/|title=Tamworth Songwriters Association|website=Tamworth Songwriters Association Online|access-date=23 March 2022}}</ref> Lee Kernaghan has won three awards in that time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsaonline.com.au/past-winners/|title=Tamworth Songwriters Association Past Winners|website=Tamworth Songwriters Association Online|access-date=23 March 2022}}</ref>\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n|-\n|rowspan=\"2\"| 1993\n|rowspan=\"2\"| \"Boys from the Bush\" by Lee Kernaghan and [[Garth Porter]]\n| Contemporary Country Song of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|- \n| Country Song of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 1996\n| \"1959\" by Lee Kernaghan\n| Contemporary Country Song of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|- \n{{end}}\n\n== References ==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n{{sister project links|wikt=no|b=no|q=Lee Kernaghan|s=no|commons=Category:Lee Kernaghan|n=no|v=no|species=no}}\n{{Australians of the Year}}\n{{Lee Kernaghan}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Kernaghan, Lee}}\n[[Category:1964 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:People from Corryong]]\n[[Category:APRA Award winners]]\n[[Category:ARIA Award winners]]\n[[Category:Australian country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Australian male musical theatre actors]]\n[[Category:Australian of the Year Award winners]]\n[[Category:Recipients of the Medal of the Order of Australia]]\n[[Category:Australian country guitarists]]\n[[Category:Australian male guitarists]]\n[[Category:Australian male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Australian singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Australian republicans]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Colin_Amey","to":"Colin Amey"}],"pages":{"28841602":{"pageid":28841602,"ns":0,"title":"Colin Amey","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Canadian country music artist}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Colin Amey\n| image           = Colin_Amey.jpg\n| caption         = Colin Amey, November 2005\n| birth_name      =\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} -->\n| birth_place     = [[Dunnville, Ontario]], Canada\n| death_date      = <!-- {{death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} (death date 1st) -->\n| death_place     =\n| origin          = Dunnville, Ontario, Canada\n| instrument      = Vocals\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer\n| years_active    = 1990\u2013present\n| label           = Makin' Tracks<br />[[Royalty Records|Royalty]]\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = \n}}\n'''Colin Amey''' (born [[Dunnville, Ontario]]) is a Canadian [[country music]] artist.<ref name=\"jam.canoe.ca\"/> Amey has released three studio albums which include 1998's ''Colin Amey'', 2000's ''What My Heart Don't Know'' and 2006's ''Getaway''. Two of Amey's singles reached the Top 20 on the ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' Country Tracks chart in Canada, \"I Wish She Was Mine\"<ref name=\"avtrust.ca_RPM(Country Singles)_1\"/> and \"What My Heart Don't Know.\"<ref name=\"avtrust.ca_RPM(Country Singles)_4\"/>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Michelle_Wright","to":"Michelle Wright"}],"pages":{"1269740":{"pageid":1269740,"ns":0,"title":"Michelle Wright","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{distinguish|Chely Wright|Michelle Elizabeth Benson Keegan Wright|Michelle Keegan}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image           = Michelle_Wright.jpg\n| caption         = Michelle Wright in December 2004\n| name            = Michelle Wright\n| birth_name      =\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1961|07|1}}\n| birth_place     = [[Chatham, Ontario]], Canada\n| origin          = [[Merlin, Ontario]], Canada\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 1980\u2013present\n| label           = [[Savannah Records|Savannah]], [[Arista Nashville]], [[RCA Records|RCA]]/[[ViK. Recordings]], Icon, Navigator Records\n| website         = [http://www.michelle-wright.com/ michelle-wright.com]\n}}\n'''Michelle Wright''' (born July 1, 1961) is a Canadian [[country music]] artist. She won the [[Canadian Country Music Association]]'s Fans' Choice Award twice (1993 and 1995). In 2011, Wright was inducted into the [[Canadian Country Music Hall of Fame]].\n\nWright's primary success has been in her native Canada, where she has charted more than twenty-five singles, including six Number One hits: \"[[Take It Like a Man (Michelle Wright song)|Take It Like a Man]]\", \"[[One Time Around]]\", \"[[Guitar Talk]]\", \"[[One Good Man]]\", \"[[Nobody's Girl (song)|Nobody's Girl]]\" and \"[[Crank My Tractor]]\". She also had chart success in the United States in the 1990s, landing in the Top 40 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts with \"Take It Like a Man\" at No.&nbsp;10, \"He Would Be Sixteen\" at No.&nbsp;31 and \"New Kind of Love\" at No.&nbsp;32.\n\n==Career==\n\n===Early life===\nMichelle Wright was born on July 1, 1961, in [[Chatham, Ontario]]. Wright grew up in the small nearby town of [[Merlin, Ontario|Merlin]] where her parents were both local music performers. By 1980, when Wright was in college studying counseling for the mentally disadvantaged, she joined a local band with whom she performed until 1983.\n\nThat year Wright started her own band.<ref name=mw>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/wright_michelle/bio.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040110053306/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/wright_michelle/bio.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 10, 2004|title=Michelle Wright \u2013 Biography|access-date=September 20, 2009|publisher=[[Country Music Television|CMT.com]]}}</ref> She performed with her own band until 1988.<ref name=mw/> In 1985, while performing with her band, Wright signed a record deal with [[Savannah Records]]. The next year she released her debut single, \"I Want to Count on You\", which peaked at No.&nbsp;48 on the Canadian ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' Country Tracks chart.\n\nWright's debut album, ''[[Do Right by Me]]'', was issued in 1988 and produced seven more singles, including Wright's cover of the 1974 [[Andy Kim (singer)|Andy Kim]] hit, \"[[Rock Me Gently (Andy Kim song)|Rock Me Gently]]\", which reached No.&nbsp;7 on the Canadian ''RPM'' Country Tracks chart. The album's success in Canada led to a record contract with [[Arista Nashville]]. Wright became one of the label's flagship artists.<ref name=mw2>{{cite web |url=http://www.michelle-wright.com/about/|title=Michelle Wright: Biography|access-date=January 15, 2015|publisher=Michelle Wright}}</ref>\n\n===1990\u20131993: Breakthrough success===\nIn April 1990, Wright's first American single, \"New Kind of Love\", was issued and became her first \"Top Five\" hit in Canada, in addition to peaking at No.&nbsp;32 on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs|Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] chart in the United States. Her second album, ''[[Michelle Wright (album)|Michelle Wright]]'', was released in July 1990. To support the album, Wright was added as an opening act to [[Kenny Rogers]] 1991 tour.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/465696871.html?dids=465696871:465696871&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+18%2C+1991&author=Mira+Friedlander+SPECIAL+TO+THE+STAR&pub=Toronto+Star&desc=Kenny%27s+opening+act&pqatl=google|title=Kenny's opening act|access-date=September 20, 2009|publisher=[[Toronto Star]]|first=Mira|last=Friedlander|date=August 18, 1991|archive-date=March 3, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303200407/http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/465696871.html?dids=465696871%3A465696871&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS%3AFT&type=current&date=Aug+18%2C+1991&author=Mira+Friedlander+SPECIAL+TO+THE+STAR&pub=Toronto+Star&desc=Kenny%27s+opening+act&pqatl=google|url-status=dead}}</ref> The album became a success in Canada.\n\nThat year, 1990, Wright was awarded Female Artist of the Year by the [[Canadian Country Music Association]]. The following year she was awarded Album of the Year for ''Michelle Wright'', Single of the Year for \"New Kind of Love\", and Female Artist of the Year again by the Canadian Country Music Association.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/513957251.html?dids=513957251:513957251&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Sep+16%2C+1991&author=Wendy+Cox%2C+The+Canadian+Press&pub=The+Record&desc=Michelle+Wright+sweeps+Country+Music+Awards&pqatl=google|title=Michelle Wright sweeps Country Music Awards|access-date=September 20, 2009|publisher=[[Toronto Star]]|first=Wendy|last=Cox|date=September 16, 1991|archive-date=October 22, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022181803/http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/513957251.html?dids=513957251:513957251&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Sep+16,+1991&author=Wendy+Cox,+The+Canadian+Press&pub=The+Record&desc=Michelle+Wright+sweeps+Country+Music+Awards&pqatl=google|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nDue to the success of her album ''[[Michelle Wright (album)|Michelle Wright]]'' and single \"New Kind of Love,\" Wright relocated to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in 1991 to spend more time advancing her career.<ref name=mw2/> When in Nashville, Wright began to record her third album, ''[[Now and Then (Michelle Wright album)|Now and Then]]'', released in May 1992. The album's first single, \"[[Take It Like a Man (Michelle Wright song)|Take It Like a Man]]\", became an instant hit, reaching No.&nbsp;1 in Canada on the ''RPM'' Country Tracks chart and No.&nbsp;10 in the United States on the ''Billboard'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart. In Canada, the song also crossed over to the adult contemporary charts, peaking at No.&nbsp;18. The song received the Single of the Year award from the Canadian Country Music Association in late 1992.\n\nIn 1993, the album earned Wright the award for Top New Female Vocalist from the [[Academy of Country Music]]. She appeared on the [[CBS]] television special, ''Women of Country'', where she performed \"Take It Like a Man\" and the [[Mary Chapin Carpenter]] song, \"[[The Hard Way (Mary Chapin Carpenter song)|The Hard Way]],\" with several other artists including Carpenter. ''Now and Then'' went on to produce six more singles, including the Canadian number one hits \"[[One Time Around]]\" and \"[[Guitar Talk]]\". The album also contained the single, \"He Would Be Sixteen\", which reached No.&nbsp;31 on the U.S. ''Billboard'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart and No.&nbsp;3 on the Canadian ''RPM'' Country Tracks chart. It was awarded Single of the Year by the Canadian Country Music Association in 1993. Also in 1993, Wright won the Fans' Choice Award from Canadian Country Music Association, which she would also win in 1995.\n\n===1994\u20131999: Further success===\nIn 1994, Wright released the first single from her upcoming album, \"[[One Good Man]]\", which became her fourth number one single in Canada; but it didn't reach the top 40 in the United States. Wright's fourth album, ''[[The Reasons Why (Michelle Wright album)|The Reasons Why]]'', was released in September 1994 in Canada. Plans for the album to be released in the United States were delayed and eventually cancelled.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ogkEAAAAMBAJ|title=The Time Is Wright for Arista Singer|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=July 13, 1996|access-date=November 17, 2013}}</ref> The album was also released in Europe after a Wright completed a successful tour in mid-1994.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/497020981.html?dids=497020981:497020981&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jul+07%2C+1994&author=Harry+Currie&pub=The+Record&desc=Going+places+Wright%27s+career+gets+further+boost+with+European+tour&pqatl=google|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130131214908/http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/497020981.html?dids=497020981:497020981&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jul+07,+1994&author=Harry+Currie&pub=The+Record&desc=Going+places+Wright's+career+gets+further+boost+with+European+tour&pqatl=google|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 31, 2013|title=Going places Wright's career gets further boost with European tour|access-date=September 20, 2009|publisher=[[Toronto Star]]|first=Harry|last=Currie|date=July 7, 1994}}</ref> In early 1995, Wright embarked on a 40-city tour in Canada, which at that time was the most extensive tour in the history of country music in Canada.<ref name=mw2/>\n\nIn August 1996, Wright released her fifth album, ''[[For Me It's You]]'', following the release of the first single, \"[[Nobody's Girl (song)|Nobody's Girl]]\", which reached No.&nbsp;1 on the Canadian ''RPM'' Country Tracks and No.&nbsp;57 on the U.S. ''Billboard'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart. The album marked Wright's first album to be released in the American market in four years.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=DM&p_theme=dm&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0ED3D6CD39887AA3&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=Country COMEBACKS: Michelle Wright finds the going rough|access-date=September 20, 2009|publisher=[[The Dallas Morning News]] | first=Mario | last=Tarradell}}</ref> The album went on to be successful in Canada, producing three Top Five singles in \"[[Crank My Tractor]]\", \"The Answer Is Yes\", and \"What Love Looks Like\". The album was not a success in the United States. In a 1997 interview with ''[[Jam!]],'' Wright admitted that she was \"very disappointed\" and \"not happy with what [U.S. radio] did with this album\".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/W/Wright_Michelle/1997/04/16/751951.html|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120713010329/http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/W/Wright_Michelle/1997/04/16/751951.html|url-status=usurped|archive-date=July 13, 2012|title=Michelle Wright gets in the act|access-date=September 20, 2009|publisher=[[Jam!]]}}</ref>\n\nDuring 1997, Wright was awarded the C.F. Martin Humanitarian Award by the Canadian Country Music Association for her international work with the [[Special Olympics]]; her successful fundraising efforts for St. Joseph's Hospital in Chatham, Ontario, the hospital where she was born; and her support for the [[Manitoba]] flood relief fund.<ref name=mw2/>\n\nIn 1999, U.S. radio welcomed Wright back when her 1997 duet with pianist [[Jim Brickman]] was released to radio. The song, \"Your Love\", failed at country radio, but gave Wright her only American adult contemporary hit when the song peaked at No.&nbsp;19 on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Adult Contemporary Tracks]] chart.<ref name=mw2/> Despite the song's success at AC radio, it would be Wright's last charting single in the United States.\n\nIn October 1999, Wright's first greatest hits album, ''[[The Greatest Hits Collection (Michelle Wright album)|The Greatest Hits Collection]]'', was released in Canada. The album included two new songs, \"I Surrender\" and \"When I Found You\", both of which were Top Ten hits on the Canadian ''RPM'' Country Tracks chart. In 2000, Arista Nashville released the [[Greatest Hits (Michelle Wright album)|American version]] of her 1999 greatest hits album in the United States. The album contained a different track list than the Canadian version. The album was Wright's final release with Arista Nashville.\n\n===2000\u2013present: Success today===\nIn 2002, Wright was transferred to [[RCA Records]]/[[ViK. Recordings]]. That year she released her sixth studio album, ''[[Shut Up and Kiss Me (Michelle Wright album)|Shut Up and Kiss Me]]'', in June 2002. The album showed Wright in a more pop-driven styled than her previous work.<ref name=mw3>{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/430200801.html?dids=430200801:430200801&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jun+27%2C+2002&author=&pub=The+Record&desc=Country%27s+Wright+couldn%27t+resist+the+pull+of+pop&pqatl=google|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130131170437/http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/430200801.html?dids=430200801:430200801&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jun+27,+2002&author=&pub=The+Record&desc=Country's+Wright+couldn't+resist+the+pull+of+pop&pqatl=google|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 31, 2013|title=Country's Wright couldn't resist the pull of pop|access-date=September 20, 2009|publisher=[[Toronto Star]]|date=June 27, 2002}}</ref> Wright co-wrote eight of the album's twelve songs, and recorded songs by successful songwriters such as [[Shelly Peiken]], who wrote pop singer [[Christina Aguilera]]'s 1999 hit, \"[[What a Girl Wants (Christina Aguilera song)|What a Girl Wants]]\".<ref name=mw3/> ''Shut Up and Kiss Me'' also contained a more pop-oriented version of her 2000 single, \"I Surrender.\" This version had been used for the song's music video and pop radio release.\n\nIn 2004, Wright started her annual Christmas tour, ''Dreaming of a Wright Christmas''. A year later Wright signed with Icon Records and in October 2005, she released her first Christmas album, ''[[A Wright Christmas]]'' in Canada. The album featured covers of eleven Christmas song and one new song, \"I Know Santa's Been Here\", written by Canadian country singer [[Patricia Conroy]]. The song was issued as the album's first single in December 2005. ''A Wright Christmas'' was released digitally in the United States 2007 and Europe in 2008.\n\nIn June 2006, Wright returned to country music by releasing her first new album in four years, ''[[Everything and More (Michelle Wright album)|Everything and More]]'' in Canada. In 2007, ''Everything and More'' was made available digitally in United States.\n\nIn 2011, Savannah Music Canada released Wright's first live album, ''The Wright Songs: An Acoustic Evening with Michelle Wright''. The album features seventeen tracks, including singles and unreleased album cuts.\n\nWright released a new single, \"Another Good Day,\" to Canadian country radio on April 24, 2012. She released a new single entitled \"Strong\" to radio in April 2013. Wright's first album of original material in seven years, ''[[Strong (Michelle Wright album)|Strong]]'', was released on July 9, 2013.\n\nIn 2015, Wright signed with Chuck Thompson, President of the Nashville-based Thompson Entertainment Group, for management.\n\nIn 2018, she signed with Navigator Records and the label released her first brand new music since the release of ''Strong''. \"Lovin' This Day\" and \"Attitude Is Everything\" were released as singles with an \"old-school\" A side song and a B side song configuration across all digital platforms on the Navigator Records label.\n\nFor 2019, Navigator released Wright's recording of the holiday classic \"Silver Bells,\" produced by fellow Canadian Bob Funk, to launch the ''A Wright Christmas: 2019'' with concert dates across Alberta and Ontario.\n\nMichelle's newest album, titled \"Milestone\" will be released on August 26, 2022.The album features nine new tracks, followed by a new recording of her 1992 hit, \"Take it Like A Man\"\n\n===Canadian Country Music Hall of Fame Induction===\n\nIn 2011, Wright was inducted into the [[Canadian Country Music Hall of Fame]] at a special gala dinner and award ceremony in [[Hamilton, Ontario]]. Wright, the year's artist inductee, was recognized for her outstanding contributions to Canada's country music landscape. Wright has been acknowledged within the collections of the National Music Centre in [[Calgary|Calgary, Alberta]] since 2014.\n\n===Other work===\nWright appeared as a country music star in an episode in Season 4 of the Canadian TV series ''[[Due South]].''  The episode, entitled \"Mountie Sings the Blues,\" deals with the Mountie's efforts to protect Wright's character, Tracy Jenkins, from a stalker.  She sings \"Nobody's Girl\" at the conclusion of the episode.\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Michelle Wright discography}}\n\n==References==\n\n{{Reflist|30em}}\n\n==External links==\n* [http://www.michelle-wright.com Michelle Wright's official web site]\n* {{IMDb name|1790976}}\n{{Michelle Wright}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Wright, Michelle}}\n[[Category:1961 births]]\n[[Category:Canadian women country singers]]\n[[Category:Canadian country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Canadian country guitarists]]\n[[Category:Canadian women guitarists]]\n[[Category:Juno Award winners]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Singers from Ontario]]\n[[Category:People from Chatham-Kent]]\n[[Category:Arista Nashville artists]]\n[[Category:Canadian Country Music Association Fans' Choice Award winners]]\n[[Category:Canadian Country Music Association Female Artist of the Year winners]]\n[[Category:Canadian Country Music Association Single of the Year winners]]\n[[Category:20th-century Canadian women singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century Canadian women singers]]\n[[Category:Canadian Country Music Association Album of the Year winners]]\n[[Category:20th-century Canadian singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century Canadian singer-songwriters]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Adam_Brand_(musician)","to":"Adam Brand (musician)"}],"pages":{"13919379":{"pageid":13919379,"ns":0,"title":"Adam Brand (musician)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Australian country musician|bot=PearBOT 5}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2020}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=January 2012}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Adam Brand\n| image           = Adam Brand in Melbourne.jpg\n| birth_name      = Adamo Alberto Brun\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1970|01|27|df=yes}}\n| birth_place     = [[Perth, Western Australia]], Australia\n| death_date      =\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer, songwriter\n| years_active    = 1997\u2013present\n| label           = {{hlist|[[ABC Music]]|[[Flying Nun Records|Flying Nun]]|Compass Brothers|[[Arista Nashville]]}}\n| associated_acts = Hodad City, [[Melinda Schneider]], [[Lee Kernaghan]]\n}}\n\n'''Adam Brand''' (born 27 January 1970) is an Australian country singer-songwriter. Brand released his debut album in 1997. He has since released 14 studio albums and has won 12 [[Country Music Awards of Australia]]. Adam Brand has been voted ''CMC Oz Artist of the Year'' five consecutive years between 2007 \u2013 2011.<ref name=McGee>{{cite web|url=https://mcgeeentertainment.com.au/adam-brand|title=Adam Brand |website=mcgeeentertainment.com.au|date=2013|access-date=8 August 2022}}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nAdam Brand was born on 27 January 1970 in [[Perth, Western Australia]].<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.driverdb.com/drivers/adam-brand/|title=Adam Brand {{!}} Racing career profile {{!}} Driver Database|website=www.driverdb.com|access-date=2016-05-23}}</ref> Brand's first stage appearance was at age 3 singing \"[[(How Much Is) That Doggie in the Window?]]\" with his father Mick at a pub in Perth.<ref name =\"Saucer\">{{cite web|url=https://www.flyingsaucerclub.com.au/gig/adam-brand/|title=Adam Brand \u2013 Up Close & Personal |publisher=Flying Saucer|access-date=24 July 2018}}</ref>\n\nHis love for music was heavily influenced by his father who was a singer and a fan of [[Elvis Presley]].<ref name=McGee/> His mother exposed him to [[Kris Kristofferson]], [[Roy Orbison]] and [[the Everly Brothers]].<ref name=McGee/>\n\nAt age 10, Adam picked up the drum sticks. In his teens, Brand began playing the drums in church bands around [[Colac, Victoria|Colac]] and [[Geelong]] where he was introduced to gospel and developed his lifelong love of rhythm.<ref name=McGee/>\n\n==Career==\n===1997-1999: Career beginnings===\nIn January 1997, Brand began busking on Peel Street, [[Tamworth, New South Wales|Tamworth]] which led to his first record deal with [[Festival Mushroom Records]] which he signed in September 1997.<ref name =\"Saucer\"/> In July 1998, Brand released his debut [[Adam Brand (album)|self-titled studio album]], which peaked at number 44 on the Australian [[Australian Recording Industry Association|ARIA]] album charts<ref name=\"Charts\">{{cite web|url=http://australian-charts.com/search.asp?cat=a&artist=adam+brand&artist_search=starts&title=&title_search=starts| title=Adam Brand|publisher=Australian-charts.com|access-date=27 January 2010}}</ref> and was certified [[List of music recording certifications|platinum]].<ref name=\"Accred\">{{cite web|url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/ARIACharts-Accreditations-2006Albums.htm |title=ARIA Charts \u2013 Accreditations \u2013 2006 Albums |publisher=[[Australian Recording Industry Association|ARIA]] |access-date=27 January 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100204044318/http://www.aria.com.au/pages/ARIACharts-Accreditations-2006Albums.htm |archive-date=4 February 2010 |url-status=dead}}</ref> At the 1999 [[Country Music Awards of Australia|CMAA awards]], Brand won three [[Golden Guitars]]; Song of the Year, New Talent of the Year and Video of the Year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1134 |title=Country Music Awards of Australia 1990\u20131999 |publisher=[[Country Music Association of Australia|CMAA]] |access-date=27 January 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091017180321/http://www.country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1134 |archive-date=17 October 2009 }}</ref> The album was nominated for [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album]] at the [[ARIA Music Awards of 1999|1999 ARIA Music Awards]].<ref name=\"ARIA\">{{cite web|url=http://www.ariaawards.com.au/history-by-artist.php?letter=A&artist=Adam%20Brand|title=ARIA Award History \u2013 Adam Brand|publisher=[[Australian Recording Industry Association]]|access-date=29 January 2010}}{{Dead link|date=September 2019 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Brand won the '[[Johnny O'Keefe]] Encouragement Award' at the [[Mo Awards]] in July 1999.\n\n===2000\u20132005: Career Establishment===\nIn January 2000, Brand won his fourth CMAA Award for Vocal Collaboration of the Year with [[Melinda Schneider]] for \"Love Away the Night\".<ref name=\"CMAA\">{{cite web|url=http://www.country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1135 |title=Country Music Awards of Australia 2000\u20132008 |publisher=[[Country Music Association of Australia|CMAA]] |access-date=27 January 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091017175108/http://www.country.com.au/index.cfm?page_id=1135 |archive-date=17 October 2009}}</ref> In March 2000, Brand released his second studio album ''[[Good Friends (Adam Brand album)|Good Friends]]'' which peaked at number 26 on the ARIA charts.<ref name=\"Charts\"/> The album was nominated for Best Country Album at the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2000|2000 ARIA Awards]].<ref name=\"ARIA\"/> In January 2001, Brand won three more CMAA Awards; Album of the Year, Male Vocalist of the Year and Song of the Year.<ref name=\"CMAA\"/> He also won a Mo Award for Male Country Performer of the Year.\n\nIn January 2002, Brand released his third studio album ''[[Built for Speed (Adam Brand album)|Built for Speed]]'' which peaked at number 24 ARIA charts<ref name=\"Charts\"/> and was certified platinum in Australia.<ref name=\"Accred\"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/httpwww.aria.com.aupagesARIACharts-Accreditations-2009Albums.htm|title=ARIA Charts \u2013 Accreditations \u2013 2009 Albums|publisher=[[Australian Recording Industry Association|ARIA]] |access-date=27 January 2010| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20100204015724/http://aria.com.au/pages/httpwww.aria.com.aupagesARIACharts-Accreditations-2009Albums.htm| archive-date= 4 February 2010 | url-status= live}}</ref> Brand won a further Mo Award for Male Country Performer of the Year. In January 2003, \"The Anzac\" won the CMAA Award for Heritage Song of the Year, Brand's eighth CMA Award overall.<ref name =\"Saucer\"/> In 2003, Brand contributed the tracks \"Sicilian Born\" and \"Menindee\" to the compilation album ''Australian Storytellers''. Both songs received CMA Awards nominations.\n\nIn August 2004, Brand released his fourth studio album ''[[Get Loud]]'', which debuted at number 16 on the ARIA charts,<ref name=\"Charts\"/> was certified Gold and earned Brand's third ARIA Award nomination for Best Country Album.<ref name=\"ARIA\"/> In October 2005 Brand released a [[Christmas music|Christmas album]] titled ''[[Christmas in Australia (album)|Christmas in Australia]]''.\n\n===2006\u20132009: Continued Success and ''Dancing with the Stars''===\nIn July 2006, Brand released his sixth studio album ''[[What a Life (Adam Brand album)|What a Life]]'' which peaked at number 28 on the ARIA charts<ref name=\"Charts\"/> and was certified Gold.<ref name=\"Accred\"/> Brand received another ARIA nomination for 'Best Country Album' at the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2006]].<ref name=\"ARIA\"/> In January 2007 Brand is awarded the inaugural [[Country Music Channel]] Oz Artist of the Year Award.<ref name=\"auto\">{{cite web | url = https://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/cmc-music-awards-2011 | title = CMC Music Awards 2011 | publisher = [[Country Music Channel]] (CMC) | access-date = 1 April 2018 }}</ref> In January 2008, Brand won three more CMA Awards for his song \"[[Spirit of the Bush (song)|Spirit of the Bush]]\" with [[Lee Kernaghan]] and [[Steve Forde]].<ref name=\"CMAA\"/> In January 2008, Brand released his seventh studio album ''[[Blame It on Eve]]'' which became Brand's first ARIA top ten album.<ref name=\"Charts\"/> In September 2008, Brand's first [[compilation album]] ''[[Greatest Hits 1998\u20132008]]'' was released. In January 2009 Brand wins his third consecutive CMC Oz Artist of the Year Award and his twelfth CMA Award when he won Male Artist of the Year.<ref name =\"Saucer\"/> In March 2009 Brand released his eighth studio album ''[[Hell of a Ride]]'', which peaked at number 19 on ARIA charts.<ref name=\"Charts\"/> In March 2009, Brand was the lead act at the [[Black Saturday bushfires|Victorian Bushfire Appeal]] concert in [[Traralgon]].\n\nFrom July to September 2009, Brand competed the [[Dancing with the Stars (Australian season 9)|ninth season]] of [[Dancing with the Stars (Australian TV series)|Dancing with the Stars (Australia)]] and was declared the winner on 6 September 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/adam-brand-wins-dancing-with-the-stars-finale-20090907-fdcw.html|title=Adam Brand wins Dancing with the Stars finale |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=7 September 2009 |access-date=24 July 2018}}</ref> Brand partnered professional dancer [[Jade Hatcher]], whom he married on 31 May 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.adelaidenow.com.au/entertainment/celebrity/country-singer-adam-brands-18-months-marriage-to-dancing-with-the-stars-dancer-jade-hatcher-in-break-up/story-e6fredq3-1226227888098?sv=4c98efefd65aeb0e3d13554389f60b85&nk=548c9950a8edaa17540736c41e58fa0e-1532414957|title=Country singer Adam Brand's 18-months marriage to Dancing With the Stars dancer Jade Hatcher in break-up |work=The Advertiser|location=Adelaide|date=21 December 2011 |access-date=24 July 2018}}</ref>\n\nIn September 2009 Brand signed a recording contract with Arista Records, the [[Nashville]]-based division of [[Sony Music Entertainment]] for the distribution of his recordings in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/adam-brand-signs-us-recording-deal-will-compete-in-dancing-with-the-stars-final/news-story/3e409ccec2f2b6a38360f4d6fed98e30|title=Adam Brand signs US recording deal; will compete in Dancing with the Stars final |publisher=[[news.com.au]]|date=5 September 2009|access-date=24 July 2018}}</ref><ref name=McGee/>\n\n===2010\u2013present: Adam Brand label ===\nIn January 2010 Brand won his fourth consecutive CMC Oz Artist of the Year Award. In August 2010, Brand released his ninth studio album ''[[It's Gonna Be OK (album)|It's Gonna Be OK]]'' which peaked at number 11 on the ARIA charts.<ref name=\"Charts\"/> The Track \"Ready for Loving\" was released in the United States and reached the Top 40 in the US Country charts.<ref name =\"Saucer\"/> In January 2011, Brand won CMC Oz Artist of the Year Award for the fifth consecutive year. In May 2011, Brand released a compilation album titled ''[[You're a Revhead]]'' before supporting [[Taylor Swift]] on her North American tour.<ref name =\"Saucer\"/>\n\nIn August 2012, Brand released his tenth studio album ''[[There Will Be Love]]'' on [[Arista Nashville]]/[[Sony Music Australia]], which peaked at number 4 on the ARIA charts; Brand's highest-charting album.<ref name=\"Charts\"/> This was followed by ''[[My Acoustic Diary]]'' which was the first album recorded by Brand's own label. It was distributed by [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC Music]]. The album saw Brand re-record 13 of his own tracks in an acoustic setting. Upon release, Brand said \"I have decided to re-record some of these diary entries acoustically, the way they were first written\u2026 I've chosen songs that represent pivotal points in my life, and my growth as a songwriter and as an artist trying to find my own voice.\"<ref name=McGee/>\n\nBrand's twelfth studio album ''[[My Side of the Street]]'' was released in August 2014, became his second top 5 album. It was nominated for an ARIA Award and two CMA Awards. In January 2015, Brand won CMC Oz Artist of the Year Award for a fifth year.\n\nIn January 2016, Brand released his thirteenth studio album ''[[Adam Brand and the Outlaws]]'', featuring fellow Australian country musicians [[Travis Collins]], [[Drew McAlister]], [[Baby Animals|Matt Cornell]] and Mike Carr.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Introducing the new Aussie supergroup: Adam Brand and the Outlaws {{!}} CMC|url = http://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/news/introducing-the-new-aussie-supergroup-adam-brand-and-the-outlaws.aspx|website = www.countrymusicchannel.com.au|access-date = 2016-01-13|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160122043842/http://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/news/introducing-the-new-aussie-supergroup-adam-brand-and-the-outlaws.aspx|archive-date = 22 January 2016|url-status = dead|df = dmy-all}}</ref> The album peaked at number 6 on the ARIA charts<ref name=\"Charts\"/> and was nominated for an ARIA Award. The album won a CMC Award for Highest Selling Album. In February 2017, Brand released ''[[Get On Your Feet (album)|Get On Your Feet]]'' which peaked at number 7 on the ARIA charts.<ref name=\"Charts\"/>\n\nIn July 2018, Brand celebrated 20 years since the release of his debut album releasing a compilation album titled ''[[Milestones... 20 Years]]''. The album debuted at number 6 on the ARIA charts, becoming his highest charting compilation album.<ref name=\"Charts\"/> In September 2018 Brand joined [[Scott Darlow]], [[Sarah McLeod (musician)|Sarah McLeod]], [[Irwin Thomas|Jack Jones]] and [[Todd Hunter]] to re-record the [[Dragon (band)|Dragon]] song \"[[Rain (Dragon song)|Rain]]\" with all net proceeds from the sale to go towards to the Buy-a-bale program in support of Australian farmers suffering from the [[2018 in Australia#August|Australian drought]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.triplem.com.au/music/news/welcome-to-the-drought-breakers-australia-s-newest-band-raising-money-for-the-farmers|title=Welcome to the Drought Breakers- Australia's Newest Band Raising Money for the Farmers |publisher=Triple M|date=14 September 2018 |access-date=14 September 2018}}</ref>\n\nIn late 2019, Brand appeared in the first season of [[The Masked Singer (Australian TV series)|The Masked Singer Australia]] as the 'Dragon' and was the sixth contestant voted out.<ref>{{cite web|last=Morgan|first=Michaela|title='I Don't Believe It': Only Dannii Guessed The Dragon's Real Identity|url=https://10daily.com.au/entertainment/tv/a191008lbfwy/i-dont-believe-it-only-dannii-guessed-the-dragons-real-identity-20191008|website=10 Daily|date=8 October 2019|access-date=8 October 2019}}</ref>\n\nIn August 2019 Brand released a new single \"Life's Been Good to Me\" after taking 12 months off to start a family with the birth of his first child, a baby girl named Pepper.<ref>{{cite web |title=Adam Brand releases new single Life's Been Good to Me and talks about being a new father 30 August 2019 |url=https://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/story/6337556/adam-brand-rejigs-the-priority-list-as-he-settles-into-fatherhood/ |website=The Northern Daily Leader |date=30 August 2019 |access-date=19 October 2019}}</ref> Adam will be hitting the road with his Speed of Life Tour March 2020 when he will release his new album.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Masked Singer: Country music star Adam Brand revealed as the face behind the dragon head. The Daily Telegraph Confidential 09 October 2019 |url=https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/sydney-confidential/the-masked-singer-country-music-star-adam-brand-revealed-as-the-face-behind-the-dragon-head/news-story/0086d9fb3a3f764d4f3abbc9038c54dc |website=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref> Special guests on the tour will be new country duo \"Cornell & Carr\". Matt Cornell and Mike Carr were previously members of [[Adam Brand and the Outlaws]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Speed of Life Tour |url=https://www.bandsintown.com/e/101606578?affil_code=js_www.adambrandmusic.com&app_id=js_www.adambrandmusic.com&came_from=242 |website=Bandsintown |access-date=19 October 2019 |ref=\"Brand is back and he's bringing the good times with him\"}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Kix Country Music. Country Confidential CORNELL & CARR interview\u2013 12th September 2019 |url=https://www.kixcountry.com.au/country-confidential/394-shows/luke-crossy-cross/interviews/47675-cornell-carr-12th-september-2019 |website=Kixcountry.com.au |date=13 September 2019 |access-date=19 October 2019}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nBrand is a fan of motor sport.<ref name=\":0\" /> His song \"Dirt Track Cowboys\" is themed around speedway racing and features speedway commentator Wade Aunger. Brand has also raced, spending several years racing in the [[V8 Utes]] category racing Ford Falcon V8s in the early 2000s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.v8utes.com.au/index.php?page_id=1398|title=Brand to perform V8 Ute backing track at Deni Ute Muster|last=Bain|first=Erin|website=v8utes.com.au|publisher=V8 Utes Racing Series|access-date=2011-12-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fords.com.au/article/Adam-Brand-Joins-Ford-Credit-Racing |title=Adam Brand Joins Ford Credit Racing |date=1 June 2002 |publisher=Fords Online Magazine |access-date=2011-12-26 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20120731035237/http://www.fords.com.au/article/Adam-Brand-Joins-Ford-Credit-Racing |archive-date=31 July 2012 |url-status=dead}}</ref> Brand made a return to racing in 2011, competing in the [[2011 Eastern Creek Six Hour]]. Brand and his co-drivers won their class racing a Suzuki Swift.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.transtasmanmotorsport.com/#/news1-101211/4558500616 |title=Simpson shines as the stars rock the Swift field at Eastern Creek |date=10 December 2011 |work=Australian Swift Racing Series |publisher=Trans Tasman Motorsport |access-date=2011-12-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426072159/http://www.transtasmanmotorsport.com/#/news1-101211/4558500616 |archive-date=26 April 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nHe has been married and divorced three times. At the age of 39 he met [[Jade Hatcher]], then 19, on the set of ''[[Dancing with the Stars]]'' in 2009. They went on to win the competition despite a lower score compared to their competitor, ''[[Today Tonight]]'' presenter [[Matthew White (journalist)|Matt White]]. Brand and Hatcher married in May 2010,<ref>{{cite web|title=Country singer Adam Brand's 18-months marriage to Dancing With the Stars dancer Jade Hatcher in break-up|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/sydney-confidential/country-singer-adam-brands-18-months-marriage-to-dancing-with-the-stars-dancer-jade-hatcher-in-break-up/story-e6frewz0-1226227888098|work=The Daily Telegraph|access-date=28 December 2011}}</ref> but in late 2011 it was announced that they had separated.<ref>{{cite web|title=Adam Brand and Jade Hatcher part after two years|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/television/adam-brand-and-jade-hatcher-part-after-two-years/story-e6frfmyi-1226228153701|work=Herald Sun|access-date=28 December 2011}}</ref> They later divorced.{{citation needed|date=April 2020}}\n\nIn 2019, Brand became a father for the first time, after his partner gave birth to daughter Pepper.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nowtolove.com.au/reality-tv/the-masked-singer/the-masked-singer-adam-brand-baby-59664|title=The Masked Singer: Adam Brand fatherhood |website= Now To Love|date=October 2019|access-date=8 August 2022}}</ref>\n\nBrand's partner gave birth to a second baby in August 2022.<ref name=Iwantedtofeelfreedom>{{cite web|url=https://liveatyourlocal.com.au/2022/08/05/adam-brand-i-wanted-to-feel-freedom/|title= Adam Brand: \"I Wanted to Feel Freedom\"|website=Live at Your Local|date=5 August 2022|access-date=8 August 2022}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Adam Brand discography}}\n\n* ''[[Adam Brand (album)|Adam Brand]]'' (1998)\n* ''[[Good Friends (Adam Brand album)|Good Friends]]'' (2000)\n* ''[[Built for Speed (Adam Brand album)|Built for Speed]]'' (2002)\n* ''[[Get Loud]]'' (2004)\n* ''[[Christmas in Australia (album)|Christmas in Australia]]'' <small> (credited to Adam Brand and Friends) </small> (2005)\n* ''[[What a Life (Adam Brand album)|What a Life]]'' (2006)\n* ''[[Blame It on Eve]]'' (2008)\n* ''[[Hell of a Ride]]'' (2009)\n* ''[[It's Gonna Be OK (album)|It's Gonna Be OK]]'' (2010)\n* ''[[There Will Be Love]]'' (2012)\n* ''[[My Acoustic Diary]]'' (2013) \n* ''[[My Side of the Street]]'' (2014)\n* ''[[Adam Brand and the Outlaws]]'' <small> (as Adam Brand and the Outlaws) </small> (2016)\n* ''[[Get On Your Feet (album)|Get On Your Feet]]'' (2017) \n* ''[[Speed of Life (Adam Brand album)|Speed of Life]]'' (2020)\n* ''All or Nothing'' (2022)\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n===AIR Awards===\nThe Australian Independent Record Awards (commonly known informally as [[AIR Awards]]) is an annual awards night to recognise, promote and celebrate the success of Australia's Independent Music sector.\n{{awards table}}\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| [[AIR Awards of 2009|2009]]\n|''Hell of a Ride'' \n| Best Independent Country Album\n| {{won}}\n|<ref name=\"09noms\">{{cite web|url=https://www.auspop.com.au/2009/10/air-nominees/|title=AIR Nominees|date=19 October 2009|access-date=19 August 2020|archive-date=18 September 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200918230557/https://www.auspop.com.au/2009/10/air-nominees/|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=\"AIRwins\">{{cite web|url=https://www.air.org.au/awards/history|title=History Wins|website=[[Australian Independent Record Labels Association]]|access-date=18 August 2020}}</ref>\n|-\n| [[AIR Awards of 2023|2023]]\n| ''All or Nothing''\n| Best Independent Country Album or EP\n| {{nom}}\n| <ref name=\"AIRnoms2023\">{{cite web|url= https://musicfeeds.com.au/news/nominees-announced-for-the-australian-independent-music-awards-2023/|title= Nominees Announced for the Australian Independent Music Awards 2023 |website=[[Music Feeds]]|date=31 May 2023|access-date=31 May 2023}}</ref><ref name=\"AIRwins2023\">{{cite web|url=https://musicfeeds.com.au/news/air-awards-2023-winners/|title=King Stingray and Genesis Owusu Win Big at 2023 AIR Awards |website=[[Music Feeds]]|date= 4 August 2023|access-date=5 August 2023}}</ref>\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===APRA Awards===\nThe [[APRA Awards (Australia)|APRA Awards]] are held in Australia and New Zealand by the [[Australasian Performing Right Association]] to recognise songwriting skills, sales and airplay performance by its members annually. Brand has been nominated nine times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apraamcos.com.au/search?searchtype=site&keywords=adam+brand|title=Search Results Adam Brand|publisher=APRA AMCOS|access-date=24 July 2018}}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| 1999\n| \"Last Man Standing\" \n| rowspan=\"5\"| Most Performed Country Work \n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| 2000\n| \"Dirt Track Cowboys\" \n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| 2001\n| \"Beating Around the Bush\" \n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[APRA Awards of 2002|2002]]\n| \"Good Things in Life\" \n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[APRA Awards of 2003|2003]]\n| \"New England Highway\" \n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[APRA Awards of 2008|2008]]\n| \"[[Spirit of the Bush (song)|Spirit of the Bush]]\" <small>([[Lee Kernaghan]] featuring Adam Brand and [[Steve Forde]])</small> \n| rowspan=\"4\"| Country Work of the Year \n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[APRA Awards of 2009|2009]]\n| \"Coming From / [[Khe Sanh]]\"\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[APRA Awards of 2010|2010]]\n| \"Hell of a Ride\" \n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| 2015\n| \"Freedom Rebels\" \n| {{nom}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===ARIA Music Awards===\nThe [[ARIA Music Awards]] is an annual awards ceremony that recognises excellence, innovation, and achievement across all genres of [[Australian music]]. Brand has been nominated seven times.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ariaawards.com.au/search?term=adam%20brand|title= Adam Brand ARIA Awards search|publisher=ARIA Awards|access-date=24 July 2018}}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 1999|1999]]\n| ''Adam Brand''\n| rowspan=\"7\"| [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]]\n| {{nominated}} \n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2000|2000]]\n| ''Good Friends''\n| {{nominated}} \n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2004|2004]]\n| ''Get Loud''\n| {{nominated}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2006|2006]]\n| ''What a Life''\n| {{nominated}} \n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2014|2014]]\n| ''My Side of the Street''\n| {{nominated}} \n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2016|2016]]\n| ''Adam Brand and the Outlaws''\n| {{nominated}} \n|-\n| [[2022 ARIA Music Awards|2022]]<ref name=\"2022ARIAnoms\">{{cite web|url=https://themusicnetwork.com/2022-aria-awards-nominees/|title=R\u00fcf\u00fcs Du Sol Leads 2022 ARIA Awards Nominees (Full List)|website=The Music Network|date=12 October 2022|access-date=12 October 2022|author=Lars Brandle}}</ref>\n| ''All Or Nothing''\n| {{nominated}} \n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===CMC Awards===\nThe [[Country Music Channel]] (CMC Awards) are an annual fan voted award ceremony. From 2007 to 2010, The CMC awarded only one category, The Oz Artist of the Year, which Brand won four years in a row. The CMC Awards officially commenced in 2011, with four categories in total.<ref name=\"auto\"/> Brand has won 11 awards in total.\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| 2007\n| rowspan=\"6\"| Adam Brand\n| rowspan=\"6\"| Oz Artist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2008\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2009\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2010\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2011\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2015\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| Adam Brand \u2013 \"What Your Love Looks Like\"\n| Video of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2016\n| Adam Brand\n| Oz Artist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2017\n| Adam Brand and the Outlaws \u2013 ''Adam Brand and the Outlaws''\n| ARIA Highest Selling Album\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 2018\n| rowspan=\"2\"| Adam Brand\n| Oz Artist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| Male Artist of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Adam Brand \u2013 \"Drunk\"\n| Video of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===CMA Awards===\nThe [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] is an annual awards night held in January during the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]], celebrating recording excellence in the [[Australian country music]] industry. Brand has won 12 awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.flyingsaucerclub.com.au/gig/adam-brand/|title= Adam Brand \u2013 Up Close & Personal|publisher=Flying Saucer Club|access-date=24 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://country.com.au/finalists-for-the-2015-country-music-awards/|title=FINALISTS FOR THE 2015 COUNTRY MUSIC AWARDS|publisher=COUNTRY|date=17 November 2014|access-date=24 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150111090836/http://country.com.au/finalists-for-the-2015-country-music-awards/|archive-date=11 January 2015|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n|rowspan=\"3\"| 1999\n| Adam Brand \u2013 \"Last Man Standing\"\n| APRA Song of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| Adam Brand\n| New Talent of the Year\n| January 2023}}</ref>\n| rowspan=\"2\"| \"All Or Nothing\"\n| Single of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Song of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''All Or Nothing''\n| Contemporary Country Album of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Album of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Adam Brand\n| Male Artist of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| 2024<ref name=\"CMAA23noms1\">{{cite web|url=https://www.tcmf.com.au/gga-nominees|title=Toyota 52nd Golden Guitar Awards|website=TCMF|date=20 November 2023|access-date=23 November 2023}}</ref><ref name=\"CMAA23noms2\">{{cite the Year\n| {{pending}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===MO Awards===\nThe [[Mo Awards]] is an annual award ceremony recognising achievements in live entertainment in Australia. Brand has won three awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.countrymusichalloffame.com.au/Hands/Brand_Adam.html|title=Adam BRAND (2001)|publisher=country Music Hall of Fame|access-date=24 July 2018}}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| 1999\n| rowspan=\"3\"| Adam Brand\n| Johnny O'Keefe Encouragement Award\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2001\n| Male Country Performer of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2002\n|Male Country Performer of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Queensland Music Awards===\nThe [[Queensland Music Awards]] (previously known as the Q Song Awards) are an annual awards ceremony celebrating [[Queensland]]'s brightest emerging artists and established legends. They commenced in 2006.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.queenslandmusicawards.com.au/about/ |title=About the Queensland Music Awards |publisher=[[Queensland Music Awards]] |access-date=21 March 2021}}</ref>\n\n{{Awards table}}\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| 2023\n| ''All Or Nothing''\n| Highest Selling Album of the Year\n| {{Won}}\n| <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2023-03-29/queensland-music-awards-thelma-plum-ball-park-music/102155630|title= Thelma Plum, Ball Park Music win top gongs at 2023 Queensland Music Awards|website=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=29 March 2023|access-date=30 March 2023}}</ref>\n|}\n\n===Tamworth Songwriters Awards===\nThe Tamworth Songwriters Association (TSA) is an annual songwriting contest for original country songs, awarded in January at the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]]. They commenced in 1986.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsaonline.com.au/song-competition/|title=Tamworth Songwriters Association|website=Tamworth Songwriters Association Online|access-date=23 March 2022}}</ref> Adam Brand has won one award.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsaonline.com.au/past-winners/|title=Tamworth Songwriters Association Past Winners|website=Tamworth Songwriters Association Online|access-date=23 March 2022}}</ref>\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n|-\n| 1999\n| \"Uncle Pete\" by Adam Brand \n| New Songwriter Award\n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[https://web.archive.org/web/20100901115442/http://www.adambrandofficial.com/ Official Website]\n*[{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p337658|pure_url=yes}} Adam Brand] at Allmusic.com\n*{{DriverDB driver|adam-brand}}\n\n{{Adam Brand (musician)}}\n{{Dancing with the Stars (Australia)}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Brand, Adam}}\n[[Category:1970 births]]\n[[Category:Arista Nashville artists]]\n[[Category:Australian country singers]]\n[[Category:Australian male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Dancing with the Stars (Australian TV series) winners]]\n[[Category:Racing drivers from Western Australia]]\n[[Category:20th-century Australian male singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century Australian male singers]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Perth, Western Australia]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Racing drivers from Perth, Western Australia]]\n[[Category:20th-century Australian singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century Australian singer-songwriters]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"The_Sunny_Cowgirls","to":"The Sunny Cowgirls"}],"pages":{"20950298":{"pageid":20950298,"ns":0,"title":"The Sunny Cowgirls","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Australian country music group}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = The Sunny Cowgirls\n| image            = \n| caption          = \n| image_size       = \n| background       = group_or_band\n| origin           = [[Hamilton, Victoria]], [[Australia]]\n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]]\n| years_active     = 2005\u2013present\n| label            = Compass Bros.<br />MSI<br />Phantom Sound and Vision\n| associated_acts  = \n| website          = www.sunnycowgirls.com.au\n| current_members  = Sophie Clabburn<br />Celeste Clabburn\n}}\n\n'''The Sunny Cowgirls''' is an Australian [[country music]] group formed in 2005. They have released a total of seven studio albums since 2005. Their debut album, ''Little Bit Rusty'', was released in 2005. Their latest album, ''Here We Go'', was released in September 2016.\n\n==Biography==\nThe Sunny Cowgirls, Sophie and Celeste Clabburn, grew up on a farm in [[Hamilton, Victoria]]. The Clabburn sisters were raised on \"Sunninghill\", the family farm at [[Dunkeld]] near Hamilton, Victoria, before the whole family moved to [[Perth]], [[Western Australia]] when they were primary school kids. Their farm was in their father's family a long while, and that's where they came up with the name \"Sunny\".<ref>[http://www.sunnycowgirls.com.au/ Sunny Cowgirls official site]</ref> After four years of working around the country and doing the occasional gig, they raised enough cash to approach well-known Perth record producer Mark Donohoe to showcase their writing and music.\n\nThe Cowgirls lives and careers changed in early 2005 when they secured places as aspiring artists in the CMAA College of Country Music, held before the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]] each year. They then signed with Compass Bros Records and their first album, ''Little Bit Rusty'', reached No.&nbsp;4 on the [[Australian Recording Industry Association|ARIA]] country charts.\n \nThe Sunny Cowgirls have also collaborated with [[Adam Brand (musician)|Adam Brand]] on \"Someday\".{{when|date=November 2020}}\n\nOn 1 September 2012 The Sunny Cowgirls performed at the 25th [[Trundle, New South Wales|Trundle]] Bush Tucker Day.\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\" \n|+ List of studio albums, with selected details chart positions\n! They have been held annually since 1973.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.country.com.au/awards/past-award-winners|title=Past Award Winners|accessdate=2 November 2020}}</ref>\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| 2011\n| The Sunny Cowgirls\n| Horizon Award\n| {{won}}\n{{end}}\n* Note: wins only\n\n==References==\n{{reflist|2}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Sunny Cowgirls}}\n[[Category:Australian country music groups]]\n[[Category:Country music duos]]\n[[Category:Sibling musical duos]]\n[[Category:Musical groups established in 2005]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Boys"}],"pages":{"43803166":{"pageid":43803166,"ns":0,"title":"The Boom Chucka Boys","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Canadian country/rockabilly band}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = The Boom Chucka Boys\n| image           =\n| caption         =\n| image_size      =\n| alias           =\n| origin          = [[Sylvan Lake, Alberta]], [[Canada]]\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]], [[rockabilly]]\n| years_active    = 2010\u2013present\n| label           = Cache Entertainment, [[Royalty Records|Royalty]]\n| associated_acts = [[Gord Bamford]], [[Byron Hill]]\n| website         = {{URL|http://www.theboomchuckaboys.com/|theboomchuckaboys.com}}\n| current_members = Ryan Langlois<br />Joel Rathjen<br />Teddy Roy Michaylow<br />Ben Shillabeer<br />Neil MacDonald\n| past_members    = Dave Grobe\n}}\n'''The Boom Chucka Boys''' is a Canadian [[country music|country]] and [[rockabilly]] band<ref name=\"express\"/> from [[Sylvan Lake, Alberta]] composed of Ryan Langlois, Joel Rathjen, Teddy Roy Michaylow, Ben Shillabeer and Neil MacDonald.<ref name=\"cbc\">{{cite web|title=The Boom Chucka Boys on CBC Music|url=http://music.cbc.ca/#/artists/The-Boom-Chucka-Boys|website=[[CBC Music]]|accessdate=September 11, 2014}}</ref> The band was formed in July 2010.<ref name=\"cbc\" /><ref name=\"express\">{{cite news|last1=Weber|first1=Mark|title=Boom Chucka Boys unleash 'rockabilly and classic country'|url=http://www.reddeerexpress.com/entertainment/Boom_Chucka_Boys_unleash_rockabilly_and_classic_country_211255751.html|accessdate=September 11, 2014|work=Red Deer Express|date=June 12, 2013}}</ref> They were discovered by [[Gord Bamford]] in January 2011 and signed a record deal with his company, Cache Entertainment.<ref name=\"express\" /><ref name=\"college\">{{cite news|last1=Ledingham|first1=Lani|title=The Boom Chucka Boys will make you shake your boogie woogie|url=http://rdc.ab.ca/about/alumni-foundation/alumni/blog/boom-chucka-boys-will-make-you-shake-your-boogie-woogie|accessdate=September 11, 2014|work=[[Red Deer College]]|date=February 14, 2014}}</ref>\n\nTheir self-titled debut album was released in April 2013 and distributed by [[Sony Music Canada]].<ref name=\"college\" /> It was produced by [[Byron Hill]] and recorded in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref name=\"cbc\" /> The first single, \"Find My Peace of Mind\", was released in March 2013 and peaked at number 43 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Canada Country]] chart.<ref name=\"Canada Country\" /> In 2014, The Boom Chucka Boys were nominated for the [[Canadian Country Music Association]] Award for Group or Duo of the Year.<ref name=\"advocate\">{{cite news|last1=Michelin|first1=Lana|title=Boom Chucka Boys have shot at country music group of year|url=http://www.reddeeradvocate.com/entertainment/Boom_Chucka_Boys_have_shot__at_country_music_group_of_year_268335022.html|accessdate=September 11, 2014|work=[[Red Deer Advocate]]|date=July 23, 2014}}</ref> The band signed with [[Royalty Records]] in 2014 and released their second album, ''Ramble'', on February 10, 2015.<ref name=\"advocate\" /> The album features three singles: \"Turn This Car Around\" released in October 2014, \"Rebel Wings\" released in February 2015 and \"Can't Take My Lips Off You\" released in August 2015.\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"65\"| [[Canada Country|CAN Country]]<br /><ref name=\"Canada Country\">{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/search/charts?f%5B0%5D=ts_chart_artistname%3A%2ABoom%20Chucka%20Boys%2A&f%5B1%5D=itm_field_chart_id%3A1240&f%5B2%5D=ss_bb_type%3Achart_item&type=2&artist=Boom%20Chucka%20Boys|title=Boom Chucka Boys Album & Song Chart History - Canada Country|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=September 11, 2014}}</ref>\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2013\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Find My Peace of Mind\"\n| 43\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"2\"| ''The Boom Chucka Boys''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Caffeine\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2014\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Turn This Car Around\"\n| 42\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"3\"| ''Ramble''\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2015\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Rebel Wings\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Can't Take My Lips Off You\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"4\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n!
