Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Deana_Carter","to":"Deana Carter"}],"pages":{"1745378":{"pageid":1745378,"ns":0,"title":"Deana Carter","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country singer-songwriter (born 1966)}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Deana Carter\n| image            = Deana Carter 2014.JPG\n| birth_name       = Deana Kay Carter\n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1966|01|04}}\n| birth_place      = [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], Tennessee, U.S.\n| instrument       = Vocals, guitar\n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation       = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active     = 1994\u2013present\n| label            = {{hlist|[[Capitol Records Nashville|Capitol Nashville]]|[[Rounder Records|Rounder]]|[[Arista Nashville]]|[[Vanguard Records|Vanguard]]|[[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros. Nashville]]/Chappel Music}}\n| spouse           =\n* {{marriage|Brandon Malone|October 3, 2009|November 2012|reason=divorced}}\n* {{marriage|Jim McPhail|July 6, 2018}}\n| website          = {{URL|deana.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Deana Kay Carter''' (born January 4, 1966) is an American [[country music]] singer-songwriter who broke through in 1996 with the release of her debut album ''[[Did I Shave My Legs for This?]]'', which was certified 5\u00d7 Multi-Platinum in the United States for sales of over 5 million. It was followed by 1998's ''[[Everything's Gonna Be Alright (Deana Carter album)|Everything's Gonna Be Alright]]'', 2003's ''[[I'm Just a Girl]]'', 2005's ''[[The Story of My Life (Deana Carter album)|The Story of My Life]]'', and 2007's ''[[The Chain (Deana Carter album)|The Chain]]''. Overall, Carter's albums have accounted for 14 singles, including three which reached Number One on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts: \"[[Strawberry Wine (Deana Carter song)|Strawberry Wine]]\", \"[[We Danced Anyway]]\", and \"[[How Do I Get There]]\".\n\n==Biography==\nCarter was born in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], the daughter of singer [[Fred Carter, Jr.]] Despite her famous father, she did not have a smooth path to a recording deal.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.radio.com/2013/12/19/qa-strawberry-wine-singer-deana-carter-on-her-new-album-writing-with-kacey-musgraves-watching-nashville/|title=Q&A: 'Strawberry Wine' Singer Deana Carter on Her New Album, Writing with Kacey Musgraves & Watching 'Nashville'|date=December 1, 2013|access-date=March 23, 2018|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180323154955/http://news.radio.com/2013/12/19/qa-strawberry-wine-singer-deana-carter-on-her-new-album-writing-with-kacey-musgraves-watching-nashville/|archive-date=March 23, 2018|url-status=dead}}</ref> After an initial lack of success at age 17, she entered the [[University of Tennessee]], majoring in rehabilitation therapy and becoming a member of [[Alpha Delta Pi]] sorority.  During college, she sang at various campus locations, performing for the enjoyment of singing, rather than with the intent of pursuing a musical career.  She was also a local bartender at the Back Door Tavern (BDT) on Kingston Pike. After she graduated, she worked with recovering stroke and head injury patients. Although she found the work rewarding and worthwhile, she eventually realized that her first love was music, and decided to pursue the music career she had left.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2016/09/04/deana-carter-once-worked-stroke-patients/89593534/|title=Deana Carter once worked with stroke patients|work=The Tennessean|access-date=March 23, 2018|language=en}}</ref>\n\nCarter dated music video director [[Chris Hicky]] and had a son during their relationship; Gray Hayes Hicky was born in September 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/carter_deana/bio.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031223021004/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/carter_deana/bio.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 23, 2003|title=Country Music \u2013 Music News, New Songs, Videos, Music Shows and Playlists from CMT|website=Cmt.com|access-date=April 19, 2018}}</ref> On October 3, 2009, Carter married boyfriend Brandon Malone in Malibu.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countryschatter.com/2009/10/deana-carter-brandon-malone-marry-on-malibu-beach/|title=Deana Carter & Brandon Malone marry on Malibu Beach|date=October 11, 2009|website=Countryschatter.com|access-date=April 19, 2018}}</ref> In November 2012, Carter filed for legal separation from Malone, citing [[irreconcilable differences]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Country Singer Deana Carter Files for Separation |url=http://www.allvoices.com/news/13417866-country-singer-deana-carter-files-for-separation |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130116144922/http://www.allvoices.com/news/13417866-country-singer-deana-carter-files-for-separation |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 16, 2013 |publisher=All Voices |access-date=November 17, 2012 }}</ref> On July 6, 2018, Carter married Jim McPhail in a ceremony at the Pearl Hotel in Rosemary Beach, Fla.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://people.com/country/deana-carter-marries-jim-mcphail-wedding-exclusive/|title=Country \u2013 'Strawberry Wine' Singer Deana Carter Marries Jim McPhail in Sweet Wedding \u2014 See the Pics|website=people.com|access-date=March 14, 2020}}</ref>\n\nCarter has been a national spokeswoman for the [[National Kidney Foundation]]; her late father was a kidney transplant recipient. Carter also was the author of a book, ''Songs From the Heart.''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000NNES4S |title=Songs From the Heart: Deana Carter: Music |website=Amazon.com |date=September 9, 2009 |access-date=April 4, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1643927/fred-carter-jr-nashville-session-musician-dies-at-76/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150411044434/http://www.cmt.com/news/1643927/fred-carter-jr-nashville-session-musician-dies-at-76/|url-status=dead|archive-date=April 11, 2015|title=Fred Carter Jr., Nashville Session Musician, Dies at 76|work=CMT News|access-date=March 23, 2018}}</ref>\n\n===Breakthrough success: ''Did I Shave My Legs for This?''===\nCarter's first big break came when one of her demo tapes caught the attention of [[Willie Nelson]], who invited her to take part in the 1994 [[Farm Aid]] VII concert as the show's only female soloist. That same tape led to a contract with Capitol Records that year.\n\nIn early 1995, she released her debut album, ''[[Did I Shave My Legs for This?]],'' in the UK on [[Patriot Records]]. However, the label folded shortly after the album's release. In 1996, Carter released her debut country single, \"[[Strawberry Wine (Deana Carter song)|Strawberry Wine]]\", which reached No. 1 on the U.S. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Singles & Tracks]]. ''Did I Shave My Legs for This?'' was released in North America (keeping only three of the original tracks) to great success. The album debuted at No.&nbsp;2 on the U.S. Top Country Albums chart and sold well over 5 million copies, and produced two further No. 1 hits in \"[[We Danced Anyway]]\" and \"[[How Do I Get There]]\".\n\nCarter was featured on the soundtrack to the 1997 animated film ''[[Anastasia (1997 film)|Anastasia]]'' for her rendition of \"[[Once Upon a December]]\". The track was made into a music video and received rotation on [[Country Music Television|CMT]] at the time \"How Do I Get There\" was charting as a radio single (since the single had no music video).\n\nAlso in 1997, she was nominated for Top New Female Vocalist at the [[Academy of Country Music Awards]], along with [[Mindy McCready]] and [[LeAnn Rimes]], but lost to Rimes.\n\n===Second album and departure from Capitol: ''Everything's Gonna Be Alright''===\nIn September 1998, Carter released her sixth single, \"[[Absence of the Heart]],\" as the lead-off single to her second album, ''[[Everything's Gonna Be Alright (Deana Carter album)|Everything's Gonna Be Alright]],'' which was released on October 20, 1998. The album peaked at No.&nbsp;6 and sold just enough to receive a [[gold single|Gold]] certification, far less than the sales of her debut album. The album produced a Top 20 in its lead single and three further singles, two of which were minor Top 40 hits (\"You Still Shake Me\" and \"[[Angels Working Overtime]]\").\n\nAfter her second album failed to follow up on the success of her debut, she attempted for several years to get new material out. But after dealing with a total of four label presidents and a failed attempt to push out a third album in 2001, she chose to end her relationship with Capitol Records over differences on creative direction.<ref>[http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1459786/20030131/carter_deana.jhtml]{{dead link|date=July 2024|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>\n\n===Return to the studio: ''Father Christmas'' and ''I'm Just a Girl''===\nAfter releasing her third studio album, ''Father Christmas,'' on [[Rounder Records]] in November 2001, and a divorce from husband Chris DiCroce, she relocated to Los Angeles.\n\nIn 2002, Carter signed with [[Arista Records|Arista Nashville]] and released her first single in three years. \"[[There's No Limit]],\" which became her sixth Top 20 hit with a peak of No.&nbsp;14 in early 2003, served as the lead-off single to her fourth studio album, ''[[I'm Just a Girl]],'' which was released on March 18, 2003. The title track was released as the album's second single, and was a minor Top 40 hit. No further singles were released from the album, and Carter once again parted ways with her record label.\n\n===Turning to independent labels: ''The Story of My Life'' and ''The Chain''===\nIn 2004, Carter signed with independent record label [[Vanguard Records]]. She released the song \"(Bleep) Texas\" in March 2005, but it failed to chart and was shortly replaced with \"One Day at a Time,\" which served as the lead single to her fifth studio album, ''[[The Story of My Life (Deana Carter album)|The Story of My Life]].'' It only remained on the chart for five weeks and peaked at No.&nbsp;55. ''The Story of My Life'' peaked at No.&nbsp;26 on the U.S. Country Albums chart, and all further singles (\"The Girl You Left Me For,\" \"Sunny Day,\" and \"In a Heartbeat\") failed to chart. Despite having less success, Carter had more artistic freedom with this album and was able to write (or co-write) and produce all 11 tracks.\n\n''Live in Concert,'' Carter's first live album, was released in early 2007 through Big Band Concert Series. The album includes one previously-unreleased song, \"Angels of the Heart,\" as well as other concert favorites. Although released in 2007, all of the live performances on the album were recorded in 1998.\n\nCarter's sixth studio album, ''[[The Chain (Deana Carter album)|The Chain]],'' was released on October 9, 2007. ''The Chain'' was a cover album, that she recorded as a tribute to her father (who performed guitar on many of the original versions of the covers found on the album). Many of the tracks also featured the original artists as duet partners, such as [[Dolly Parton]] (on \"Love Is Like a Butterfly\") and [[Willie Nelson]] (on \"[[On the Road Again (Willie Nelson song)|On the Road Again]]\"). The album was unsuccessful; it debuted and peaked at No.&nbsp;60, and its only single (the duet version of \"On the Road Again\" with Nelson) failed to chart.\n\nCarter was ranked No.&nbsp;81 on the ''100 Greatest Women'' (of Country Music) by Country Universe in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countryuniverse.net/2008/04/13/100-greatest-women-81-deana-carter/|title=100 Greatest Women, #81: Deana Carter|date=April 14, 2008|website=Countryuniverse.net|access-date=April 19, 2018}}</ref>\n\n===Return to music and career today: ''Southern Way of Life''===\nAfter releasing ''The Chain'', Carter took some time off from recording music to spend at home with her son.\n\nIn an interview with Jay Cooper of Slither Productions, Carter reported that she had been writing music for her next album, with hopes of releasing the record sometime in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deana.com/|title=Deana Carter|website=Deana Carter|access-date=April 19, 2018}}</ref> It was announced in March 2010 that Deana Carter had signed a record deal with Warner Bros. Nashville/Chappel Music.\n\nIn 2010, [[Kenny Chesney]] covered \"[[You and Tequila]],\" a song co-written by Carter with [[Matraca Berg]] for the album ''I'm Just a Girl'', and included it on his album ''[[Hemingway's Whiskey]]''. Chesney's version was later released as the album's fourth single in May 2011 and features guest vocals from [[Grace Potter]]. It peaked at number 3 in September 2011, and was nominated for Song of the Year at the 2011 CMA Awards.\n\nDeana Carter's third studio and holiday album, ''Father Christmas'', was re-released on December 13, 2011, via Adamant Records, ten years after its initial release.\n\nIn 2013, Carter formed her own record label, Little Nugget Records.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Morris|first1=Edward|title=Deana Carter Out With Southern Way of Life in December|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1719477/deana-carter-out-with-southern-way-of-life-in-december/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141213002515/http://www.cmt.com/news/1719477/deana-carter-out-with-southern-way-of-life-in-december/|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 13, 2014|access-date=December 11, 2014|publisher=Country Music Television|date=December 2, 2013}}</ref> ''Southern Way of Life'', Carter's seventh studio album, released on December 2, 2013. In 2013, Carter re-released ''Father Christmas'' with her own record label, Little Nugget Records.\n\n== Discography ==\n{{Main|Deana Carter discography}}\n*1996: ''[[Did I Shave My Legs for This?]]''\n*1998: ''[[Everything's Gonna Be Alright (Deana Carter album)|Everything's Gonna Be Alright]]''\n*2001: ''Father Christmas''\n*2003: ''[[I'm Just a Girl]]''\n*2005: ''[[The Story of My Life (Deana Carter album)|The Story of My Life]]''\n*2007: ''[[The Chain (Deana Carter album)|The Chain]]''\n* 2013: ''Southern Way of Life''\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n=== Grammy Awards ===\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n|[[39th Grammy Awards|1997]]\n|\"[[Strawberry Wine (Deana Carter song)|Strawberry Wine]]\"\n|rowspan=2| [[Grammy Award for Best Female Country Vocal Performance|Best Female Country Vocal Performance]]\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n|[[40th Grammy Awards|1998]]\n|\"[[Did I Shave My Legs for This? (song)|Did I Shave My Legs for This]]\"\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n|[[2012 Country Music Association Awards|2012]]\n|\"[[You and Tequila]]\"{{Ref|1|[A]}}\n|[[Country Music Association Award for Song of the Year|Song of the Year]]\n|{{nom}}\n|}\n\n{{Note|1|[A]}}<small>Nominated alongside co-writer [[Matraca Berg]]</small><br>{{Note|2|[B]}}<small>Nominated alongside songwriters [[Matraca Berg]] and [[Gary Harrison]]</small><br />{{Note|3|[C]}}<small>Nominated alongside co-writer [[Matraca Berg]], along with [[Kenny Chesney]] and [[Grace Potter]]</small><br />\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n{{commons category}}\n* {{Official website|http://www.deana.com/}}\n* {{IMDb name|id=0004811|name=Deana Carter}}\n\n{{Deana Carter}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Carter, Deana}}\n[[Category:1966 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Singers from Nashville, Tennessee]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:Vanguard Records artists]]\n[[Category:Capitol Records artists]]\n[[Category:Arista Nashville artists]]\n[[Category:20th-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Tennessee]]\n[[Category:20th-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:20th-century American singers]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women singers]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Sean_Hogan","to":"Sean Hogan"}],"pages":{"4373982":{"pageid":4373982,"ns":0,"title":"Sean Hogan","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|Canadian country music singer-songwriter}}\n{{about|the Canadian singer-songwriter|the American businessman|Shawn Hogan|the Irish republican|Se\u00e1n Hogan}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| image = Sean_Hogan.jpg\n| name            = Sean Hogan |\n| caption         = Sean Hogan, November 2005\n| background      = solo_singer |\n| origin          = [[Sarnia]], Ontario, Canada |\n| instrument     = Guitar |\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]] |\n| occupation      = singer-songwriter |\n| years_active    = 1996&ndash;present |\n| label           = Barnstorm<br>Raving Rooster |\n| associated_acts = |\n| website             = [http://www.seanhogan.net/ www.seanhogan.net] |\n}}\n\n'''Sean Hogan''' is a Canadian [[country music]] singer-songwriter.\n\n==Biography==\nBorn in [[Sarnia]], Ontario, Hogan attended [[Fanshawe College]] in [[London, Ontario]], studying music.<ref>{{cite news|author = The Observer|title = Sean Hogan to play the Imperial Centre|publisher = Sarnia Observer |date = June 1, 2002}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author = The Observer|title = Sean Hogan offers his take on Junos|publisher = Sarnia Observer|date = March 11, 2000}}</ref> In 2003 he won the Roots Artist of the Year at the Canadian Country Music Awards and he has also won the Independent Male Artist of the Year award in 1997.<ref>{{cite news|author = Mike Bell|title = SUN RISES ON SEAN HOGAN|publisher = Calgary Sun|date = May 26, 2004}}</ref> Hogan engages in charity work and in 2005 the Saskatchewan Country Music Association named him Humanitarian of the Year.<ref>{{cite news|author = John P. McLaughlin|title = 'Help out and give back': Sean Hogan brings cavalcade of Canadian talent to town|publisher = The Vancouver Province|date = December 19, 2005}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! style=\"width:14em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Sean Hogan''\n| \n* Release date: April 1996\n* Label: Barnstorm\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Hijacked''\n| \n* Release date: June 1999\n* Label: Barnstorm\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Late Last Night''\n| \n* Release date: November 20, 2001\n* Label: Barnstorm\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Ruled by Mercury''<br /><small>(U.S. release)</small>\n| \n* Release date: 2002\n* Label: Barnstorm\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Catalina Sunrise''\n| \n* Release date: April 2005\n* Label: Raving Rooster\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''The Southern Sessions'' \n| \n* Release date: June 2007\n* Label: Raving Rooster\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Conspiracy Radio''\n| \n* Release date: July 2008\n* Label: Northbuck Records\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''The Southern Sessions''<br /><small>(U.S. release)</small>\n| \n* Release date: September 15, 2009\n* Label: Lakeland Heart\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Phoenix''\n| \n* Release date: March 20, 2012\n* Label: Lakeland Heart\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n\n====1996\u20132000====\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:26em;\"| Single\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"The_Johner_Brothers","to":"The Johner Brothers"}],"pages":{"11569018":{"pageid":11569018,"ns":0,"title":"The Johner Brothers","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Infobox musical artist | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name            = The Johner Brothers\n| image           = \n| caption         = \n| image_size      = <!-- Only for images smaller than 220 pixels -->\n| background      = group_or_band\n| origin          = [[Midale, Saskatchewan|Midale]], [[Saskatchewan]], Canada\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| years_active    = 1988&ndash;2001\n| label           = [[Warner Music Canada|Warner]]\n| associated_acts = \n| website         = \n| current_members = Ken Johner<br />[[Brad Johner]]<br />Bart McKay<br />Kevin Churko<br />Shaun Beavis\n| past_members    = \n}}\n\n'''The Johner Brothers''' were a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[country music]] duo from [[Midale, Saskatchewan|Midale]]. They won more than 40 awards from the Saskatchewan Country Music Association, including Entertainer of the Decade in 1999.<ref>[http://www.weyburnreview.com/News/1999/9912/johner.html Johner Brothers named Entertainer of the Decade<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>\n\n==History==\nBrothers Ken Johner and [[Brad Johner]] grew up in Saskatchewan playing music in their family band. In 1988, they teamed up together to form '''The Johner Brothers'''.<ref>[http://www.techmgt.ca/BJconcerts/artists/brad_johner.htm Brad Johner<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In 2000 the pair took home a Prairie Music Award for their video and production skills.<ref>[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/singer-jann-arden-tops-music-awards/article1042761/ \"Singer Jann Arden tops music awards\"]. SASKATOON \u2014 ''Globe and Mail'', Oct. 02, 2000</ref>\n\nThe duo signed with [[Warner Music Canada]] and released their first album, ''Some Kind of Magic'', in 1991. Two singles from the album reached the Canadian country singles chart, including the top 40 \"Right On Time.\" That same year, the Johner's won four awards at the Saskatchewan Country Music Awards (SCMA), including Group of the Year, Single of the Year, Song of the Year, and Most Promising. They were also named Group or Duo of the Year by the [[Canadian Country Music Association]].\n\nIn 1992, The Johner Brothers won seven awards from the SCMA, including Entertainer, Group, Duo, Song, Single and Album of the Year. They released their second studio album, ''My Brother and Me'', in 1993. Seven singles from the album found their way to the Canadian country singles chart, including the top 20 hit \"Starting Right Now\", and their duet with [[Lisa Brokop]], \"Light In My Life.\" The duo won another four awards at the 1993 SCMA Awards, including Entertainer, Group and Single of the Year.\n\nThe Johner Brothers became one of only a few Canadian country music acts to release a Christmas album with the release of 1993's ''One Winter's Night''. 1994 proved to be a banner year for the Johner's, when they won no less than 11 awards from SCMA. Among their wins were Entertainer, Group, Song, Single, Video and Album of the Year, along with Vocal Collaboration of the Year for their duet with [[Lisa Brokop]].\n\nTheir success continued in 1995 with the release of their third album, ''Ten More Miles''. The album charted 5 singles, including the Top 25 songs \"Hillbilly Country Boy\" and the title track. They racked up another 7 awards at the SCMA Awards the same year, including their fourth straight win as Entertainer of the Year, and their fifth as Group of the Year. Their television special '''One Winter's Night''' also won an SCMA Award for TV Show of the Year.\n\nThe Johner Brothers took some time off before the release of their fourth studio album, ''The Perfect Life'', in 1999. That same year, they were named Entertainer of the Decade by SCMA. As a condition of their win, that was their only honour from the SCMA for the year. They continued to rack up hits on the Canadian country singles chart, including the top 25 \"Maybe She'll Change Her Mind\", and their duet with [[Suzanne Gitzi]], \"I Don't Wanna Know.\"\n\nIn 2002, Ken decided to retire from the music business to pursue other interests. Before the duo disbanded in 2001, [[Warner Music Canada]] released The Johner Brothers' ''Greatest Hits''.<ref>[http://www.countrymusicnews.ca/news.ihtml?step=2&article_id=151 Country Music News Canadian country Music Artists CD's CDs CD Nashville report<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The album included 16 of the Johner's biggest hits from their 11-year career, along with one new track, \"Good Ol' Days.\" Brad continues to maintain a successful solo career in Canada.\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{|class=\"wikitable\"\n!Year\n!Album\n!<small>CAN Country</small>\n|-\n|1991\n|''Some Kind of Magic''\n|\n|-\n|rowspan=\"2\"| 1993\n|''My Brother and Me''\n|\n|-\n|''One Winter's Night''\n|\n|-\n|1995\n|''Ten More Miles''\n|align=\"center\"|26\n|-\n|1999\n|''The Perfect Life''\n|\n|-\n|2002\n|''Greatest Hits''\n|\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=text-align:center;\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"John_Landry","to":"John Landry"}],"pages":{"19786512":{"pageid":19786512,"ns":0,"title":"John Landry","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{about||the British actor|John Landry (actor)|other people with similar names|Jon Landry (disambiguation)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = John Landry\n| image           =\n| image_size      =\n| birth_name      = John Mark Landry\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1969|12|22}}\n| origin          = [[Montreal]], Quebec, Canada\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 1999\u2013present\n| label           = Spin Records/EMI Canada, Icon Records/Universal Canada, Tangents North\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = {{URL|jlandry.com}}\n}}\n'''John Landry''' (born December 22, 1969)<ref name=\"opry\">[http://www.oprynorth.com/oprynorth2/independ%20july%20artist.htm John Landry] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030303164542/http://www.oprynorth.com/oprynorth2/independ%20july%20artist.htm |date=March 3, 2003 }} at Opry North</ref> is a Canadian [[country music]] artist. Landry's debut album, ''Forever Took Too Long'', was released in 1999 by Spin Records. Its first two singles, \"There You Were\" and \"Bit by Bit,\" both reached the Top 10 of the Canadian Country Singles chart. Landry was nominated for a 2000 [[Juno Award]] for [[Juno Award for Country Recording of the Year|Best Country Male Artist]].\n\nLandry entertained on the country stage at the 2003 Palmer Rapids Twin Festival in Ontario.<ref>Palmer Rapids Twin Festival Souvenir Program, July 2003</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! style=\"width:14em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Forever Took Too Long''\n| \n* Release date: August 23, 1999\n* Label: Spin Records\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Bottom of the Ninth''\n| \n* Release date: June 10, 2002\n* Label: Spin Records\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Someday''\n| \n* Release date: June 21, 2005\n* Label: Icon Records\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Changing Man''\n| \n* Release date: November 2, 2010\n* Label: Tangents North Music\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Don't Look Back''\n| \n* Release date: May 20, 2014\n* Label: Jlanpro\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:20em;\"| Single\n! Year\n! style=\"width:20em;\"| Single\n! Director\n|-\n| rowspan=\"4\"| 1999\n! scope=\"row\"| \"There You Were\"\n| \n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Bit by Bit\"\n| \n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Which Way Is Love\" <small>(with [[Beverley Mahood]])</small>\n| \n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Long Gone and Forgotten\"\n| \n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2000\n! scope=\"row\"| \"My Heart Says Yes<br />(But the Hurt Says No)\" <small>(with Stacey Lee)</small>\n| \n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Fantasy Island\"\n| \n|-\n| 2001\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Same Old Love\"\n| \n|-\n| 2002\n! scope=\"row\"| \"When Will Your Memory Let Me Go\"\n| \n|-\n| 2003\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Everybody Rides\"\n| \n|-\n| 2011\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Changing Man\"\n| Zac Whyte\n|-\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*[http://www.jlandry.com Official Site]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Landry, John}}\n[[Category:1969 births]]\n[[Category:Canadian male singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Canadian country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Montreal]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Beccy_Cole","to":"Beccy Cole"}],"pages":{"7688846":{"pageid":7688846,"ns":0,"title":"Beccy Cole","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{for|the American musician|Rebecca Cole (musician)}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2023}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=June 2023}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Beccy Cole\n| honorific_suffix = {{Post-nominals|country=AUS|OAM|size=100}}\n| image            = BeccyCole19072013a.jpg\n| image_size       = \n| landscape        = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank -->\n| alt              = Close-up shot of a woman's face as she sings into a microphone. Her slightly, wavy, blonde hair falls to her shoulders.\n| caption          = Cole at The Abbey, Canberra, in July 2013\n| birth_name       = Rebecca Diane Thompson\n| alias            = Beccy Sturtzel, Rebecca Diane Albeck\n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|df=y|1972|10|27}}\n| birth_place      = [[Glenelg, South Australia]], Australia\n| origin           = \n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation       = Singer, songwriter\n| instrument       = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar|fiddle|drums|bass guitar}}\n| years_active     = 1986\u2013present\n| label            = {{hlist|[[ABC Music]]|[[Columbia Records|Columbia]]|[[Universal Music Australia|Universal]]|[[Warner Music Group|Warner]]|[[EMI]]|[[Sony Music Australia|Sony BMG Australia]]}}\n| associated_acts  = {{hlist|Wild Oats|[[Dead Ringer Band]]|Young Stars|[[Songbirds (group)|Songbirds]]|[[Melinda Schneider]]|[[Adam Harvey]]|[[Kasey Chambers]]}}\n| website          = {{URL|beccycole.com/}}\n}}\n\n'''Beccy Cole''' {{Post-nominals|country=AUS|OAM}} (born '''Rebecca Diane Thompson''', 27 October 1972), also known as '''Beccy Sturtzel''', '''Rebecca Diane Albeck''' and '''Bec O'Donovan''', is an Australian [[country music]] [[singer-songwriter]] and [[multi-instrumentalist]]. She has released ten studio albums, with six reaching the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Albums Chart]] top&nbsp;40, ''[[Little Victories (Beccy Cole album)|Little Victories]]'' (January 2003), ''[[Preloved (album)|Preloved]]'' (September 2010), ''[[Songs & Pictures]]'' (September 2011), ''[[Great Women of Country]]'' (with [[Melinda Schneider]], November 2014), ''[[Sweet Rebecca]]'' (April 2015) and ''[[The Great Country Songbook Volume 2]]'' (with [[Adam Harvey]], April 2017). Her video album, ''Just a Girl Singer'' (August 2004), peaked at No.&nbsp;6 on the ARIA Top&nbsp;40 DVD Chart. Cole has received nine Golden Guitar trophies at the [[Country Music Awards of Australia|CMAA Country Music Awards of Australia]]. During December 2005 to January 2006 she performed for [[Australian Defence Force]] personnel in Iraq. Her related single, \"[[Poster Girl (Wrong Side of the World)]]\" (May 2016), expresses her support for the troops. It won the 2007 Song of the Year at CMAA awards, and its music video was listed at No.&nbsp;1 on Australia's [[Country Music Channel]]. In March 2015 she published her autobiography, ''Poster Girl''.\n\n==Life and career==\n===Early life: 1972\u20131992===\nBeccy Cole was born as Rebecca Diane Thompson on 27 October 1972 in [[Glenelg, South Australia|Glenelg]].<ref name=\"Autobio\"/><ref name=\"APRA Bad Hair\"/><ref name=\"APRA Bass Solo\"/> Her mother is a country music singer, Carole Sturtzel, and her father, Jeff Thompson, was saxophonist for the Strangers<!-- Adelaide group -->.<ref name=\"Autobio\"/><ref name=\"Aus Story\"/><ref name=\"Leo\"/> Cole attended [[Blackwood, South Australia|Blackwood]] Primary School.<ref name=\"Leo\"/> At the age of 14 years she started performing in her mother's group, Wild Oats, as Beccy Sturtzel.<ref name=\"Aus Story\"/><ref name=\"Nutting\"/> She also performed solo on the South Australian festival circuit.<ref name=\"Nutting\"/> Aside from her mother, Cole's inspirations are [[Dolly Parton]] and [[The Eagles]].<ref name=\"Negus\"/> In 1991, Cole joined a country music group, Dead Ringer Band, led by Bill Chambers; she had met his daughter, [[Kasey Chambers]], in Adelaide in mid-1989.<ref name=\"Aus Story\"/><ref name=\"Nutting\"/> Cole and Chambers performed as a duo at the [[Port Pirie]] Country Music Festival,<ref name=\"Mengel\"/> and by 1991 they had busked together on the streets of [[Tamworth, New South Wales|Tamworth]].<ref name=\"Aus Story\"/> As a member of Dead Ringer Band, Cole provided rhythm guitar, lead and backing vocals and occasional drums.\n\n===Career beginnings and first album: 1993\u20132000===\nOn the advice of her manager she changed her performance name to \"Beccy Cole\".<ref name=\"Nutting\"/> In January 1993 at the [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] she won the Star Maker award, singing [[Reba McEntire]]'s \"[[Just a Little Love (Reba McEntire song)|Just a Little Love]]\" and [[Slim Dusty]]'s \"Bushland Boogie\".<ref name=\"Woodbridge\"/> As a result of winning the Star Maker award, she had to perform at a special concert opening for [[Gina Jeffreys]]. This was the commencement of a lifelong friendship. Cole moved to Sydney in 1993 to pursue her music career and to record a single. She was advised by studio owners Deniese and Martin Cass that her self-penned tracks were not good enough, so she recorded \"Fooling' Around\", which was written by Perth songwriter Mark Donahoe. The single spent two weeks at number&nbsp;2 on the country charts.<ref name=\"Autobio\">{{cite book | last = Cole| first = Beccy | date = 24 March 2015 | title = Poster Girl | publisher = Hachette Australia | location = Sydney | isbn = 978-0-7336-3258-7| pages = 89, 105 }}</ref> At the 1994 Country Music Awards of Australia, Cole won the [[Golden Guitar]] trophy for Best New Talent.<ref name=\"NLA 1\"/><ref name=\"ACM HoF Bio\"/><ref name=\"CMAA Awards\"/> and signed her first record deal in 1994. Later that year, she spent four months touring remote Aboriginal communities in northern Australia.<ref name=\"Negus\"/> In 1995 Cole toured with [[Slim Dusty]]. Cole featured on the [[ABC TV (Australian TV channel)|ABC TV]] documentary ''Doesn't Everyone Want a Golden Guitar?'' and her song \"Take Me Home the Long Way\" appeared on the associated soundtrack album of the same name.<ref name=\"Doesn't Everyone\"/> Cole supplied backing vocals for an album, ''The Circle Game'', by country music duo [[Rod McCormack]] and Mick Albeck; another guest vocalist was [[Gina Jeffreys]].<ref name=\"Gleeson\"/>\n\nIn 1996, Cole signed a new record deal with Harvestone Records on the Sony label and began working on her debut album. The album was produced by [[Rod McCormack]]. Cole issued two singles, \"Hearts Changing Hands\" and \"Rest in Pieces\". The latter single's B-side, \"Big Girls\", was co-written with Chambers;<ref name=\"APRA Big Girls\"/> it was promoted by a music video which featured Albeck as Cole's love interest. On 11 July 1997 her debut album, ''Beccy Cole'', was released<ref name=\"iTunes Beccy\"/> and peaked at number 122 on the [[ARIA Charts]] in November.<ref>{{cite journal|archive-url=https://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20020220130000/http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/23790/20020221-0000/www.aria.com.au/issue572.pdf |url=http://www.ariacharts.com.au/about/faq#q6 |title=Chartifacts!, ARIA Top 100 Albums, ARIA Hitseekers: Albums, ARIA Country Albums |journal=The ARIA Report |publisher=[[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA) |issue=572 |pages=1, 5, 15, 19 |archive-date=20 February 2002 |date=12 February 2001 |access-date=13 January 2014 }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> The album generated lukewarm responses and Sony decided not to record a second album.\nCole married Mick Albeck late in 1997 and gave birth to a son on 2 March 1999. Cole and Albeck divorced in 1999. Later in 1999, Cole began touring with Darren Coggan, [[Felicity Urquhart|Felicity]], and [[Adam Harvey]] as the 'Young Stars of Country'.<ref name=\"Adsett\"/> In 2000 at the [[Gympie Muster|Gympie Music Muster]] the four artists recorded their live cover version of Dolly Parton's \"[[Do I Ever Cross Your Mind]]\".<ref name=\"Adsett\"/>\n\n===Commercial success: 2001\u20132005===\n{{Main|Wild at Heart (album)|Little Victories (Beccy Cole album)|Feel This Free}}\nCole's second album, ''[[Wild at Heart (album)|Wild at Heart]]'', was issued on 15 January 2001 by [[ABC Music|ABC Country]] and distributed by [[Universal Music Australia]], which peaked at No.&nbsp;4 on the ARIA Country Albums Chart.<ref name=\"NLA Wild\"/><ref name=\"AusCharts\"/> It included contributions by Chambers and Jeffreys on vocals, and McCormack on guitars, keyboards, piano, Hammond organ, mandolin, banjo and backing vocals, as well as producing the album.<ref name=\"Adsett\"/><ref name=\"NLA Wild\"/> Rosie Adsett at ''Country Update'' felt \"[she's] never been in finer voice, and the enjoyment of finally recording just shines through this one\".<ref name=\"Adsett\"/> While ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]''{{'}}s Katrina Lobley noted that Cole \"unashamedly examines every corner of a recently broken heart. The album's not entirely miserable \u2013 her sense of fun bursts out in wild ditties\".<ref name=\"Lobley\"/> At the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2001]] ''[[Wild at Heart (album)|Wild at Heart]]'' was nominated for Best Country Album.<ref name=\"ARIA List\"/> By November 2002 it was re-issued with a five-track bonus disc, including her single, \"Life Goes On\".<ref name=\"Lobley\"/> For her gigs she also performs on lead guitar, drums, bass guitar, fiddle or piano.<ref name=\"Nutting\"/><ref name=\"Lobley\"/> In December 2003 ''[[Wild at Heart (album)|Wild at Heart]]'' was accredited with a gold certificate for shipment of 35,000 copies.<ref name=\"ARIA Accred 2003\"/>\n\nOn 20 January 2003, Cole released her third studio album, ''[[Little Victories (Beccy Cole album)|Little Victories]]'', which reached the top&nbsp;30 on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Albums Chart]] and No.&nbsp;4 on the Country Albums Chart.<ref name=\"AusCharts\"/> It was again produced by McCormack, who also provided banjo, dobro, guitars (acoustic and electric), [[mandola]], mandolin and percussion as well as mixing and engineering.<ref name=\"NLA Little\"/><ref name=\"AMG Little\"/> On the End of Year Charts \u2013 Country 2003, the album reached No.&nbsp;18.<ref name=\"EoY Country 2003\"/> Cole co-wrote eight of its tracks with Tamara Stewart (aka Tamara Sloper).<ref name=\"Capital News\"/><ref name=\"Daves Diary\"/> ''Capital News'' described the work as by \"a more mature, more reflective and more confident\" artist.<ref name=\"Capital News\"/> At the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2003|ARIA Music Awards that year]] it was nominated for Best Country Album.<ref name=\"ARIA List\"/> In December 2005 it was accredited with a gold certificate.<ref name=\"ARIA Accred 2005\"/>\n\nOn 2 August 2004, Cole issued a video album, ''Just a Girl Singer'', which included interviews, live concert footage, music videos and archival footage. The album was written, produced and directed by Lindsay Frazer;<ref name=\"NLA Just\"/><ref name=\"ABC Just\"/> which peaked at No.&nbsp;6 on the ARIA Top&nbsp;40 DVD Chart.<ref name=\"AusCharts\"/> It provided Cole's next single, \"Sorry I Asked\".<ref name=\"NLA Just\"/><ref name=\"ABC Just\"/> In the following year, on 11 April, Cole released her next studio album, ''[[Feel This Free]]'',<ref name=\"NLA Free\"/><ref name=\"iTunes Free\"/> which reached the ARIA Albums Chart Top&nbsp;100 and No.&nbsp;3 on the ARIA Country Albums Chart.<ref name=\"AusCharts\"/> It includes Albeck on violin and fiddle; McCormack on multiple instruments and producing; and Jeffreys and McCormack co-writing tracks with Cole.<ref name=\"AMG Feel\"/>\n\n===\"Poster Girl\" and Songbirds: 2006\u20132009===\n{{Main|Poster Girl (Wrong Side of the World)|Songbirds (group)}}\n[[File:Beccy Cole.jpg|thumb|Cole, October 2008, Armidale]]\nDuring the festive season of December 2005 and January 2006, Cole joined the Tour de Force series of concerts in Iraq and \"across the Middle East\" for [[Australian Defence Force]] \"personnel serving in Operation Catalyst\".<ref name=\"DoD Media\"/> Also performing at the concerts were [[Little Pattie]] (patron of Forces Advisory Council on Entertainment, which organised the tour's entertainers), [[Angry Anderson]], [[Bessie Bardot]], Hayley Jenson and comedian [[Lehmo]].<ref name=\"DoD Media\"/><ref name=\"Catalyst 06\"/> They were backed by the Royal Australian Navy Band.<ref name=\"Catalyst 06\"/> Anderson later recalled that \"[Cole] struck me from the beginning, I mean she's a born entertainer, and I thought, this chick is as funny as hell. The songs that she was singing, original tunes, and just funny and witty\".<ref name=\"Aus Story\"/>\nUpon her return to Australia, Cole received a letter from a disgruntled former fan who objected to her Tour de Force appearances and declared \"I've taken your poster off of my wall and I won't be listening to your music any more.\"<ref name=\"Shedden\"/> In May 2006 she issued a single, \"[[Poster Girl (Wrong Side of the World)]]\" in response, she declared her support for the Australian [[Digger (soldier)|diggers]] but not the [[Iraq War]].<ref name=\"Aus Story\"/><ref name=\"Shedden\"/> Also that month she re-released ''[[Feel This Free]]'', with bonus tracks, on [[Warner Music Group|Warner Records]].<ref name=\"AMG Feel\"/> In January the following year, at the 35th Country Music Awards of Australia, she received three Golden Guitar trophies for Female Artist of the Year, Single of the Year, and Song of the Year for \"[[Poster Girl (Wrong Side of the World)]]\".<ref name=\"CMAA Awards\"/> On 17 March 2007, Cole appeared on celebrity music quiz show ''[[RocKwiz]]'', performing \"Rockabilly Fever\" and a duet with [[Diesel (artist)|Mark Lizotte]] on \"A Good Year for the Roses\".<ref name=\"SBS RocKwiz\"/>\n\nOn 12 October 2007, Cole issued her debut live album, ''[[Live @ Lizotte's]]'', with guest appearances by Chambers, Jeffreys and [[Sara Storer]].<ref name=\"NLA Live\"/> The deluxe version included a DVD of seven live performances and a behind the scenes documentary.<ref name=\"NLA Live\"/> In 2007, Cole, Jeffreys and Storer combined to form [[Songbirds (group)|Songbirds]]. A live concert film, ''Songbirds: You've Got a Friend'', was recorded at the Tamworth Country Music Festival on 22 January 2009<ref name=\"Cashmere Songbirds\"/><ref name=\"Songbirds Film\"/><ref name=\"NLA Youve Got\"/> and the related DVD was released in May by [[EMI]] Music Australia.<ref name=\"NLA Youve Got\"/><ref name=\"Jarvis\"/> The DVD went gold in 2009.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://httpwww.aria.com.aupageshttpwww.aria.com.aupageshttpwww.aria.com.aupagesARIACharts-_000.htm|archive-url=https://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20150211130100/http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/56172/20150212-0001/www.aria.com.au/pages/httpwww.aria.com.aupageshttpwww.aria.com.aupageshttpwww.aria.com.aupagesARIACharts-_000.htm|url-status=dead|archive-date=11 February 2015|title= ARIA Charts \u2013 Accreditations \u2013 2009 DVDs|publisher=ARIA Charts|date=31 December 2009|access-date=30 August 2016}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Susan Jarvis of ''Capital News'' noted that the \"friendship between the three girls is very much in evidence\" where each \"performs some of their songs solo, but the three come and go in a wonderfully fluid and organic way, providing a feeling of warmth and spontaneity\".<ref name=\"Jarvis\"/>\n\n===Continued success: 2010\u2013present===\n{{Main|Preloved (album)|Songs & Pictures|Beccy's Big Hits|Sweet Rebecca}}\n[[File:Beccy Cole The Abbey July 2013.jpg|thumb|Cole (second from left) on guitar and singing, with her backing band, performing at The Abbey, Canberra, in July 2013.]]\nOn 3 September 2010 Cole issued a covers album, ''[[Preloved (album)|Preloved]]'', on [[Sony Music Australia|Sony BMG Australia]] which peaked in the top&nbsp;40 on the ARIA Albums Chart.<ref name=\"AusCharts\"/> Included are her renditions of Neil Young's \"[[Only Love Can Break Your Heart]]\", [[Deborah Conway]]'s \"It's Only the Beginning\" and [[Leiber and Stoller]]'s \"(You're So Square) Baby I Don't Care\".<ref name=\"AusCharts\"/> Cole's version of Parton's \"[[Here You Come Again (song)|Here You Come Again]]\" was released as the lead single, she told Anita Beaumont of ''[[The Newcastle Herald]]'' that \"[it] is the least covered song of Dolly's, and I believed the lyrics stand the test of time\".<ref name=\"Beaumont\"/> Beaumont felt the album showed \"quite a bit of country influence ... but some of these songs weren't originally intended for a country audience. They sound pretty rootsy\".<ref name=\"Beaumont\"/>\n\nCole's sixth studio album, ''[[Songs & Pictures]]'', appeared on 30 September 2011 and reached No.&nbsp;24 on the ARIA Albums Chart \u2013&nbsp;her highest position.<ref name=\"AusCharts\"/> It was produced by [[Shane Nicholson (singer)|Shane Nicholson]] (Angie Hart, Catherine Britt).<ref name=\"AusCharts\"/> The album includes a duet with Chambers, \"Millionaires\", which they had co-written; Chambers later recalled \"It's really the story of our friendship\".<ref name=\"Aus Story\"/> At the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2012]] ''Songs & Pictures'' was nominated for Best Country Album.<ref name=\"ARIA List\"/> In May 2013 Cole released her first compilation album, ''[[Beccy's Big Hits]]''.<ref name=\"NLA Beccy's Big Hits\"/><ref name=\"Aquilina\"/> She promoted the album with an Australian tour and invited aspiring artists to perform a song on stage, via the Beccy's Search for a Shiny Star competition.<ref name=\"Aquilina\"/> In 2014, Cole released ''[[Great Women of Country]]'' a duet album with [[Melinda Schneider]] was released, a tribute and covers album of Beccy's idols and legendary female country singers and songwriters. She and Schneider performed one of the tracks, [[Dolly Parton]]'s \"[[9 to 5 (Dolly Parton song)|9 to 5]]\", on ''[[The Morning Show (TV program)|The Morning Show]]''. In 2015, Cole released ''[[Sweet Rebecca]]'' through [[ABC Music]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Beccy Cole|url = https://www.abcmusic.com.au/beccy-cole|website = ABC Music|access-date = 14 December 2015}}</ref>\n\nThe [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] announced on 22 January 2021 that Cole would become the new host of ''[[Saturday Night Country]]'', its long-running national country music radio program, heard on [[ABC Local Radio|regional ABC stations]] and on [[ABC Country]]. On 13 February 2021, Cole commenced presenting the program from studios at [[ABC Radio Adelaide]]. The show has a history of retaining its hosts for long time periods with Cole having only two predecessors, [[John Nutting (radio presenter)|John Nutting]] and Felicity Urquhart.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Beccy Cole joins ABC Radio| url =https://www.abc.net.au/radio/country/beccy-cole-joins-abc-radio/13079204 |website = ABC Radio| date =21 January 2021 |access-date = 24 January 2021}}</ref>\n\nIn 2022, Cole was inducted into the [[Australian Roll of Renown]].<ref name=\"CMAA2022\"/>\n\n==Personal life==\nDuring the mid-1990s, Cole and Gina Jeffreys were flatmates, while Mick Albeck and Rod McCormack were also flatmates.<ref name=\"Aus Story\"/><ref name=\"Lobley\"/> Cole was married to Albeck for one-and-a-half years (1998\u201399), writing songs as Rebecca Diane Albeck.<ref name=\"APRA Bass Solo\"/><ref name=\"Aus Story\"/> The couple have a son.<ref name=\"Aus Story\"/> Not long after he was born, Jeffreys and McCormack married each other.<ref name=\"Lobley\"/> Cole's second album, ''[[Wild at Heart (album)|Wild at Heart]]'', dealt with her divorce;<ref name=\"Negus\"/> the track \"Lazy Bones\" was written about Albeck and their short marriage.<ref name=\"Borrelli\"/> According to Albeck, \"it was tough sometimes when we were touring together, living together, bringing up the baby together and having to be on stage together at night. I guess I decided I didn't want the relationship anymore. That was pretty tough for Bec at the time\".<ref name=\"Aus Story\"/>\n\nBy August 2004, Cole was living in the [[Central Coast (New South Wales)|Central Coast]] region with other country musicians nearby including Kasey Chambers, Jeffreys and McCormack, [[Lyn Bowtell]] and Adam Harvey: the artists call the local area, Hillbilly Heaven.<ref name=\"ABC Just\"/><ref name=\"Focus Mag\"/><ref name=\"Chesterton\"/> Albeck, Bowtell, Jeffreys and McCormack have assisted Cole on her albums. As of April 2012, Cole lived in [[Copacabana, New South Wales]].<ref name=\"Zwan\"/> In July of that year, she revealed that she is a lesbian on the ABC-TV series ''[[Australian Story]]''.<ref name=\"Aus Story\"/><ref name=\"Leo\"/> In October 2013, Cole was the inaugural ambassador for the Adelaide-based [[Feast Festival]], and in the following month, she presented her show ''The Queer of Country''.<ref name=\"Keen\"/> She explained to Suzie Keen of ''InDaily'' that \"I was concerned that there may be a lack of understanding towards my sexuality. How wrong I was. What Australians appreciate more than anything is honesty.\"<ref name=\"Keen\"/>\n\nBy April 2015, Cole was living in Adelaide with her domestic partner, Libby O'Donovan, a cabaret singer.<ref name=\"Gilbertson\">{{cite news | url = http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/entertainment/beccy-coles-back-in-adelaide-with-her-partner-their-children-and-a-new-book-detailing-her-life/news-story/4c245e8a25807808990b69e378a781bc | title = Beccy Cole back in Adelaide with her partner their children and a new book detailing her life | last = Gilbertson | first = Matt | work = The Advertiser|location=Adelaide | date = 10 April 2015 | access-date = 19 August 2018 }}</ref> She published her autobiography, ''Poster Girl'', in the previous month.<ref name=\"Autobio\"/><ref name=\"Hardy\">{{cite web | url = http://www.dailylife.com.au/dl-people/what-beccy-cole-knows-about-women-20150505-gguq3f.html | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20180819082829/http://www.dailylife.com.au/dl-people/what-beccy-cole-knows-about-women-20150505-gguq3f.html | url-status = dead | archive-date = 19 August 2018 | title = What Beccy Cole knows about women | last = Hardy | first = Karen | work = Daily Life | date = 10 May 2015 | access-date = 19 August 2018 }}</ref> Cole and O'Donovan were married on 2 February 2018 with fellow country musician [[Tania Kernaghan]] officiating. The civil ceremony was attended by Adam Harvey, Gina Jeffreys, Kasey Chambers, Lyn Bowtell, Chris E. Thomas, Bec Willis, Kym Warner, Trev Warner and Gina Timms. It was announced on Cole's Facebook page on 5 February 2022 that her marriage to O'Donovan had ended.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cairnspost.com.au/news/south-australia/sa-country-music-queen-beccy-cole-reveals-how-she-survived-one-of-the-darkest-periods-of-her-life/news-story/57c19338509b4c48f5d0db640c0b6648?amp |newspaper=Sunday Mail |via=Cairns Post |title=SA country music queen Beccy Cole reveals how she survived one of the darkest periods of her life |first=Jason |last=Katsaras |date=29 April 2022 |access-date=1 May 2022}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Beccy Cole discography}}\n\n===Studio albums===\n* ''Beccy Cole'' (1997)\n* ''[[Wild at Heart (album)|Wild at Heart]]'' (2001)\n* ''[[Little Victories (Beccy Cole album)|Little Victories]]'' (2003)\n* ''[[Feel This Free]]'' (2005)\n* ''[[Preloved (album)|Preloved]]'' (2010)\n* ''[[Songs & Pictures]]'' (2011)\n* ''[[Great Women of Country]]'' (with [[Melinda Schneider]]) (2014)\n* ''[[Sweet Rebecca]]'' (2015)\n* ''[[The Great Country Songbook Volume 2]]'' (with [[Adam Harvey]]) (2017)\n* ''[[Lioness (Beccy Cole album)|Lioness]]'' (2018)\n* ''The Great Country Songbook Volume III'' (with Adam Harvey) (2022)\n\n==Awards and nominations==\nCole was awarded the Centenary Medal in 2001<ref>{{Cite web |title=Ms Beccy Cole |url=https://honours.pmc.gov.au/honours/awards/1118335 |access-date=2022-06-12 |website=It's an Honour}}</ref> and the Medal of the [[Order of Australia]] in the [[2022 Queen's Birthday Honours (Australia)|2022 Queen's Birthday Honours]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Ms Beccy Cole |url=https://honours.pmc.gov.au/honours/awards/2010976 |access-date=2022-06-12 |website=It's an Honour}}</ref>\n\n===APRA Awards===\nThe [[APRA Awards (Australia)|APRA Awards]] are presented annually from 1982 by the [[Australasian Performing Right Association]] (APRA), \"honouring composers and songwriters\". They commenced in 1982.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.apra-amcos.com.au/APRAAwards/MusicAwards/History.aspx |title=APRA History |publisher=[[Australasian Performing Right Association]] (APRA) {{pipe}} [[Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners Society]] (AMCOS) |access-date=25 April 2022 |archive-date=20 September 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100920230857/http://www.apra-amcos.com.au/APRAAwards/MusicAwards/History.aspx |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| [[APRA Music Awards of 2013|2013]] \n| \"Waitress\"\n| Country Work of the Year\n| {{nominated}}\n| <ref name=\"CWotYNom\">{{cite web | url = http://www.apraamcos.com.au/awards/2013-awards/apra-music-awards/country-work-of-the-year/ | title = Country Work of the Year | publisher = Australasian Performing Right Association (APRA) {{pipe}} Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners Society (AMCOS) | year = 2013 | accessdate = 19 March 2015 | archive-date = 1 April 2015 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150401040047/http://apraamcos.com.au/awards/2013-awards/apra-music-awards/country-work-of-the-year/ | url-status = dead }}</ref>\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===ARIA Awards===\nThe [[ARIA Music Awards]] is an annual awards ceremony that recognises excellence, innovation, and achievement across all genres of [[Australian music]]. They commenced in 1987.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ariaawards.com.au/history/award/Best-Country-Album|title=ARIA Awards for Best Country Album|publisher=ARIA Awards|access-date=18 June 2016}}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2001|2001]]\n| ''Wild at Heart''\n| [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]]\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2003|2003]]\n| ''Little Victories''\n| Best Country Album\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2012|2012]]\n| ''Songs and Pictures''\n| Best Country Album\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===AIR Awards===\nThe Australian Independent Record Awards (commonly known informally as [[AIR Awards]]) is an annual awards night to recognise, promote and celebrate the success of Australia's independent music sector.\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| [[AIR Awards of 2019|2019]]<ref name=\"2019nom\">{{cite web|url=https://scenestr.com.au/music/2019-air-awards-nominees-20190328|title=2019 AIR Awards Nominees|date=28 March 2019 |access-date=20 August 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"AIRwins\">{{cite web|url=https://www.air.org.au/awards/history|title=History Wins|website=[[Australian Independent Record Labels Association]]|access-date=18 August 2020|archive-date=10 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310102536/https://www.air.org.au/awards/history|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n|''Lioness''\n| Best Independent Country Album\n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Australian Women in Music Awards===\nThe [[Australian Women in Music Awards]] is an annual event that celebrates outstanding women in the [[Music of Australia|Australian Music Industry]] who have made significant and lasting contributions in their chosen field. They commenced in 2018.\n\n{{awards table}}\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| [[2023 Australian Women in Music Awards|2023]]\n| Beccy Cole\n| Artistic Excellence Award\n| {{nominated}}\n| <ref name=\"finalists\">{{cite web|url=https://musicfeeds.com.au/news/2023-australian-women-in-music-awards-finalists/|title=Finalists Announced for the 2023 Australian Women in Music Awards|website=[[Music Feeds]]|date=18 July 2023|access-date=18 July 2023}}</ref><ref name=\"2023AWMA wins\">{{cite web|url=https://musicfeeds.com.au/news/australian-women-in-music-awards-2023-winners-announced/#:~:text=Among%20the%20highlights%20of%20the,scooped%20the%20big%20Songwriter%20Award.|title=Australian Women In Music Awards 2023 Winners Announced |website=[[Music Feeds]]|date= 28 September 2023|access-date=1 October 2023}}</ref>\n{{end}}\n\n===Country Music Awards of Australia===\nThe [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] (CMAA) (also known as the Golden Guitar Awards) is an annual awards night held in January during the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]], celebrating recording excellence in the Australian country music industry. They have been held annually since 1973.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.country.com.au/awards/past-award-winners|title=Past Award Winners|access-date=2 November 2020|archive-date=25 October 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201025171148/https://country.com.au/awards/past-award-winners|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n|-\n| 1994\n| Beccy Cole for \"Foolin' Around\"\n| New Talent of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n|rowspan=2|2001\n| ''This Heart''\n| Female Vocalist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| \"Do I Ever Cross Your Mind\" with Darren Coggan, Felicity and Adam Harvey\n| Vocal Collaboration of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2002\n| \"Too Strong To Break \"\n| Female Vocalist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n|rowspan=3| 2007\n|rowspan=3| \"[[Poster Girl (Wrong Side of the World)]]\"\n| Female Vocalist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| Song of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| Single of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n|rowspan=2| 2012\n| \"Waitress\"\n| Female Vocalist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| \"Millionaires\" (with Kasey Chambers)\n| Vocal Collaboration of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2017\n| \"FU Cancer\" (with Catherine Britt)\n| Vocal Collaboration of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2019<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2019-01-27/golden-guitars-wolfe-brothers-win-top-country-music-awards/10753724|title= Wolfe Brothers, Andrew Swift, Beccy Cole and Travis Collins win Golden Guitars|publisher=ABC|date=27 January 2019|access-date=27 January 2019 }}</ref>\n| ''Lioness''\n| Female Vocalist of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 2022<ref name=\"CMAA2022\">{{cite web|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2022-04-20/golden-guitar-winners-2022-country-music-tamworth/101002818|title=2022 Golden Guitar Awards see Cassar-Daley take out Slim Dusty record, Shane Nicholson and Ashleigh Dallas collect top gongs|website=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=20 April 2022|access-date=21 April 2022|author= Maguire, Kemii}}</ref>\n| Beccy Cole\n| [[Australian Roll of Renown]]\n| {{yes2|inducted}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Helpmann Awards===\nThe [[Helpmann Awards]] is an awards show, celebrating live entertainment and performing arts in Australia, presented by industry group ''Live Performance Australia'' since 2001.<ref name=lpa>{{cite web | title=Events & Programs| website=Live Performance Australia | url=https://liveperformance.com.au/events-programs/ | access-date=4 October 2022}}</ref> Note: 2020 and 2021 were cancelled due to the [[COVID-19 pandemic]].\n \n{{awards table}}\n! {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}}\n|-\n| [[15th Helpmann Awards|2015]]\n| Beccy Cole and Libby O'Donovan \u2013 ''The Cowgirl and the Showgirl''\n| [[Helpmann Award for Best Cabaret Performer|Best Cabaret Performer]]\n| {{nom}}\n|<ref>{{Cite web|url= http://www.helpmannawards.com.au/2016/past-nominees-and-winners/ | title= 2016 Helpmann Awards Nominees & Winners|publisher=Australian Entertainment Industry Association (AEIA)|website=Helpmann Awards|access-date=8 October 2022}}</ref>\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Tamworth Songwriters Awards===\nThe Tamworth Songwriters Association (TSA) is an annual songwriting contest for original country songs, awarded in January at the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]]. They commenced in 1986.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsaonline.com.au/song-competition/|title=Tamworth Songwriters Association|website=Tamworth Songwriters Association Online|access-date=23 March 2022}}</ref> Beccy Cole has won three awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tsaonline.com.au/past-winners/|title=Tamworth Songwriters Association Past Winners|website=Tamworth Songwriters Association Online|access-date=23 March 2022}}</ref>\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n|-\n| 2002\n| \"Too Strong to Break\" by Beccy Cole, [[Rod McCormack]] and [[Rick Price]]\n| Contemporary Song of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n|rowspan=\"2\"| 2007\n|rowspan=\"2\"| \"Poster Girl\" by Beccy Cole\n| Contemporary Song of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| Country Song of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n==References==\n{{reflist|25em|refs=\n\n<ref name=\"APRA Bad Hair\">{{cite web|publisher=[[Australasian Performing Right Association]] (APRA) |title='Bad Hair Day' at APRA }}</ref>\n\n<ref name=\"ARIA Accred 2003\">{{Cite certification|region=Australia|type=album|certyear=2003}}</ref>\n\n<ref name=\"NLA Little\">{{Citation | author1 = Cole, Beccy | author2 = McCormack, Rod | title = Little Victories | publication-date = 2003 | publisher = ABC Country : Warner Music Australia [distributor]. National Library of Australia | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/14167162 | access-date = 13 January 2014 }}</ref>\n\n<ref name=\"AMG Little\">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=album|tag=credits|id=r804370|pure_url=yes}} | title = ''Little Victories'' \u2013 Beccy Cole {{pipe}} Credits | publisher = [[AllMusic]] | access-date = 13 January 2014 }}</ref>\n\n<ref name=\"EoY Country 2003\">{{cite web|url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/aria-charts-end-of-year-charts-country-2003.htm |title=ARIA Charts \u2013 End of Year Charts \u2013 Country 2003 |access-date=14 January 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140204041641/http://www.aria.com.au/pages/aria-charts-end-of-year-charts-country-2003.htm |archive-date=4 February 2014 }}</ref>\n\n<ref name=\"Capital News\">{{cite news | url = http://www.capitalnews.com.au/editorial.asp?editorial_id=198&issue=36 | title = Beccy Cole \u2013 ''Little Victories'' | work = Capital News | publisher = Rural Press Limited | volume = 28 | issue = 1 | date = January 2003 | access-date = 13 January 2014 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140114023713/http://www.capitalnews.com.au/editorial.asp?editorial_id=198&issue=36 | archive-date = 14 January 2014 | url-status = dead }}</ref>\n\n<ref name=\"Daves Diary\">{{cite web | url = http://www.nucountry.com.au/articles/diary/february2008/260208_tamara_stewart.htm | title = Dave's Diary \u2013 Tamara Stewart | last =Dawson | first = Dave | work = Nu Country | date = 26 February 2008 | access-date = 13 January 2014 }}</ref>\n\n<ref name=\"ARIA Accred 2005\">{{Cite certification|region=Australia|type=album|certyear=2005}}</ref>\n\n<ref name=\"NLA Just\">{{Citation | author1 = Cole, Beccy | author2 = Australian Broadcasting Corporation | title = Just a Girl Singer | publication-date = 2004 | publisher = Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Credits: Written, produced and directed by Lindsay Frazer}}.</ref>\n\n<ref name=\"ABC Just\">{{cite web|url=https://shop.abc.net.au/products/just-a-girl-singer |title=''Just a Girl Singer'' Beccy Cole |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) |date=2 August 2004 |access-date=13 January 2014 |quote=''Just a Girl Singer'' contains rare interviews with Beccy and her 'hillbilly heaven' mates, live concert footage, plus video clips from her highly successful albums that have seen her win Female Vocalist of the Year twice. It also includes archival footage from Star Maker, ''Good Morning Australia'' and a sneak preview of a brand new song |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140113112913/https://shop.abc.net.au/products/just-a-girl-singer |archive-date=13 January 2014 }}.</ref>\n\n<ref name=\"Focus Mag\">{{cite news | url = http://focusmag.com.au/mgl/interviews/adam-harvey-and-troy-cassar-daley | title = Adam Harvey and Troy Cassar-Daley | work = Focus Mag | publisher = Creative House | date = 10 November 2010 | access-date = 14 January 2014 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140114193508/http://focusmag.com.au/mgl/interviews/adam-harvey-and-troy-cassar-daley | archive-date = 14 January 2014 | url-status = dead }}</ref>\n\n<ref name=\"Chesterton\">{{cite journal | title = Lunch at Hillbilly Heaven | last = Chesterton | first = Ray | journal = [[Woman's Day (Australian magazine)|Woman's Day]] | publisher = Athena Information Solutions | date = 1 March 2010 | page = 41 | issn = 0043-7328 }}</ref>\n\n<ref name=\"NLA Free\">{{Citation | author1=Cole, Beccy | title=Feel This Free | publication-date=2005 | publisher=ABC Country.
