National Library of Australia | url = http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/78557317 | access-date = 15 January 2014 }}</ref>\n\n<ref name=\"Jarvis\">{{cite web | url = http://www.capitalnews.com.au/editorial.asp?editorial_id=1576&issue=115 | title = True Friendship | last = Jarvis | first = Susan | date = May 2009 | work = Capital News | publisher = Rural Press Limited | volume = 34 | issue = 5 | access-date = 15 January 2014 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140116102447/http://www.capitalnews.com.au/editorial.asp?editorial_id=1576&issue=115 | archive-date = 16 January 2014 | url-status = dead}}</ref>\n\n<ref name=\"Beaumont\">{{cite news | url = http://newsstore.fairfax.com.au/apps/viewDocument.ac;jsessionid=33FC18652D03EE06A9F19F85D35B01FA?sy=afr&pb=all_ffx&dt=selectRange&dr=1month&so=relevance&sf=text&sf=headline&rc=10&rm=200&sp=brs&cls=18880&clsPage=1&docID=NCH101223ML76O6IGIOA | title = Recycling Refreshes Top Songs | last = Beaumont | first = Anita | work = [[The Newcastle Herald]] | date = 23 December 2010 | page = 25 | access-date = 15 January 2014 }}</ref>\n\n<ref name=\"Zwan\">{{cite journal|url=http://womansday.ninemsn.com.au/entertainment/tvfilmsbooks/8449133/beccy-cole-how-i-stayed-friends-with-my-ex |title=How I Stayed Friends with My Ex |last=van der Zwan |first=Sebastian |journal=Woman's Day |publisher=Athena Information Solutions |date=9 April 2012 |issn=0043-7328 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116083153/http://womansday.ninemsn.com.au/entertainment/tvfilmsbooks/8449133/beccy-cole-how-i-stayed-friends-with-my-ex |archive-date=16 January 2014 }}</ref>\n\n<ref name=\"Keen\">{{cite news | url = http://indaily.com.au/arts-and-culture/2013/10/01/beccy-cole-on-the-queer-of-country/ | title = Beccy Cole and the 'Queer of Country' | last = Keen | first = Suzie | work = InDaily. Adelaide Independent News | date = 1 October 2013 | access-date = 15 January 2014 }}</ref>\n\n<ref name=\"NLA Beccy's Big Hits\">{{Citation | author1 = Cole, Beccy | title = Beccy's Big Hits | publication-date = 2013 | publisher = Australia Beccy Cole Music Ambition Entertainment PTY LTD Distributed by EMI Music Australia. National Library of Australia | url = http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/180799409 | access-date = 15 January 2014 }}</ref>\n\n<ref name=\"Aquilina\">{{cite news | url = http://www.hillsnews.com.au/story/1592563/beccys-big-hits-on-the-road-with-her-best-country-tracks/ | title = Beccy's Big Hits on the Road with Her Best Country Tracks | last = Aquilina | first = Jessica | work = Hills News | date = 24 June 2013 | access-date = 15 January 2014 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140116142958/http://www.hillsnews.com.au/story/1592563/beccys-big-hits-on-the-road-with-her-best-country-tracks/ | archive-date = 16 January 2014 | url-status = dead }}</ref>\n\n}}\n\n==External links==\n* {{Official website|http://beccycole.com/}}\n* {{MusicBrainz artist|id=077f78ec-54db-4487-b572-e8b555a5b241|name=Beccy Cole}}\n\n{{Beccy Cole}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Cole, Beccy}}\n[[Category:1972 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Australian country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Australian women singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Australian lesbian musicians]]\n[[Category:Australian LGBTQ singers]]\n[[Category:Australian LGBTQ songwriters]]\n[[Category:Lesbian singers]]\n[[Category:Lesbian songwriters]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Adelaide]]\n[[Category:Songbirds (group) members]]\n[[Category:Dead Ringer Band members]]\n[[Category:21st-century Australian women singers]]\n[[Category:20th-century Australian LGBTQ people]]\n[[Category:21st-century Australian LGBTQ people]]\n[[Category:21st-century Australian singer-songwriters]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Shane_Nicholson_(singer)","to":"Shane Nicholson (singer)"}],"pages":{"12064551":{"pageid":12064551,"ns":0,"title":"Shane Nicholson (singer)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use Australian English|date=July 2011}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name                = Shane Nicholson\n| image               = Shane Nicholson (October 3, 2015).jpg\n| caption             = Nicholson performing at the Dashville Skyline in October 2015\n| image_size          =\n| landscape           = \n| background          = solo_singer\n| birth_place         = [[Brisbane]], Australia\n| instrument          =\n| genre               = [[Country music|Country]], [[Americana (music)|Americana]]\n| occupation          = Musician\n| years_active        = 1998\u2013present\n| label               = [[Virt Records]], [[Liberation Records]], [[EMI Records]], [[Warner Bros. Records]], [[Warner Music Group|WEA]]\n| associated_acts     = [[Pretty Violet Stain]], [[Kasey Chambers]], [[Alex Lloyd]]\n| website             ={{url|shanenicholson.com}}\n}}\n'''Shane Nicholson''' is an Australian singer-songwriter from [[Brisbane]]. He has released 11 albums, both in Australia and internationally, and has won 3 ARIA Awards, 15 Golden Guitars, and 2 APRA Awards. He's twice been named Producer of the Year at the [[Country Music Awards of Australia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/archived/liveset/shane-nicholson/5830818|title=Shane Nicholson live at Port Fairy |website=ABC |date=24 October 2014 |accessdate=25 April 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\n===1990s\u20132001: Freak and Pretty Violet Stain===\nDuring his final year of high school, Nicholson was part of a band called '''Freak''', which won an early round of [[Triple J]] [[Unearthed (talent contest)|Unearthed]] competition in the Sunshine Coast division.<ref name=\"Sunshine\">{{cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/little-ray-of-sunshine-20110331-1cgki.html|title=Little Ray of Sunshine |website=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=31 March 2011|accessdate=25 April 2020}}</ref> Shortly after this, the band name changed to '''Pretty Violet Stain''' and released an [[extended play]] in 1997 called ''Blush''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.temeritydigital.com.au/retro/oz-sounds/prettyviolet.html|title=pretty violet stain Blush|website=OZsounds|accessdate=25 April 2020}}</ref> This was followed by singles \"If the Money's Right\", \"Never Come Down\" and \"Talk\" and album ''Parachutes and Gravity'', which was released in 2000. The band split shortly after.\n\n===2002\u20132007: ''It's a Movie'' and ''Faith and Science''===\nNicholson signed with [[EastWest]] and released his debut studio album ''It's a Movie'' in 2002. It was during the recording of this album with [[Nash Chambers]] that Nicholson met [[Kasey Chambers]]. The two dueted on the lead single, \"Designed to Fade\".\n\nHe toured in Australia and made his United States debut at the [[South by Southwest Festival]], which prompted his signing with [[Virt Records]] and a more extensive American tour.<ref name=\"Knoxville\">{{cite news| last =Bledsoe| first =Wayne| title =\"Just one person\": Songwriter seeks stray successes in shine of solitary spotlight| page =5| newspaper =[[Knoxville News Sentinel]]| date =23 July 2004}}</ref> ''[[USA Today]]'' named ''It's a Movie'' one of the top pop albums of 2004.<ref>{{cite news| last =Gundersen| first =Edna|author2=Steve Jones |author3=Elysa Gardner |author4=Brian Mansfield |author5=Ken Barnes | title =Critics gang up on the world of music| page =D6| newspaper =[[USA Today]]| date =28 December 2004}}</ref>\n\nA second solo album, ''Faith and Science'', was released in 2006 and included the single \"I Know What You Need\", which became his first charting single, peaking at number 54.\n\n===2008\u20132013: Albums with Kasey Chambers, ''Familiar Ghosts'' and ''Bad Machines''===\n{{main|Rattlin' Bones|Bad Machines|Wreck & Ruin}}\nNicholson joined with wife Kasey Chambers for the album ''[[Rattlin' Bones]]'', which was released in April 2008 and debuted at number 1 on the [[ARIA charts]]. At the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2008]], it won [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album]]. The album won five Golden Guitar Awards at the [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] (CMAA) in January 2009.\n\nBetween tours he recorded a third solo album, ''Familiar Ghosts'', which was released in November 2008 and was nominated for an Best Country Album at the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2009]]. This coincided with Nicholson moving into music production. \n \nIn March 2011, Nicholson released his sixth solo album, ''[[Bad Machines]]'', which peaked at number 29. Nicholson and his wife welcomed a baby girl on 6 October 2011, named Poet Poppin Nicholson.\n\nAt the January 2012 CMAA, Nicholson won the Song of the Year for his song, \"Bad Machines\". Also in 2012, Nicholson won the [[APRA Music Awards of 2012|APRA]] Country Work of the Year award for \"Famous Last Words\".\n\nIn September 2012, Nicholson and Chambers released a second collaborative album, ''[[Wreck & Ruin]]'' was peaked at number 6 on the ARIA Charts. The album was nominated for 5 awards at the 2013 CMAA awards, ultimately winning the couple the award for \"Group/Duo of the Year\". At the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2013]], the album won Best Country Album. Nicholson was named Producer of the Year at the 2013 Country Music Awards of Australia.\n\nOn 23 April 2013, it was announced that Nicholson and Kasey Chambers had separated, with the collision of work and family life said to have forced their split.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/shane-nicholson-and-kasey-chambers-separate-after-eight-years-of-marriage/news-story/240f7c7dc6fa67ac7c78b6ba8a508cbb?sv=7674704dcfb1d17ffd9293047dec897a|title=Shane Nicholson and Kasey Chambers separate after eight years of marriage |website=[[news.com.au]]|date= 23 April 2013|accessdate=30 April 2020}}</ref>\n\n===2014\u20132020: ''Hell Breaks Loose'' and ''Love and Blood''===\n{{main|Hell Breaks Loose (album)|Love and Blood (album)}}\nIn 2014, Nicholson signed a new recording deal with Lost Highway Australia/Universal Music, and released his first live album, ''Pitch, Roll & Yaw \u2013 Live and Solo''.\n\nJune 2015 saw the release of \"Secondhand Man\", the first single from Nicholson's album ''[[Hell Breaks Loose (album)|Hell Breaks Loose]]''. The album was written amongst the break up of this married to Chambers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thewest.com.au/entertainment/music/love-and-blood-on-the-dance-floor-ng-b88534130z|title=Love and Blood on the dance floor |website=The West|date=25 July 2017 |accessdate=30 April 2020}}</ref> Released in August 2015, it debuted at No. 16 on the ARIA chart.\n\n''Hell Breaks Loose'' won the ARIA award for Best Country Album at the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2015]] and received 7 CMAA nominations at the 2016 CMAA awards. The album won Alternative Country Album of the Year Award.<ref name=\"CMAA2016noms\"/>\n\n''[[Love and Blood (album)|Love and Blood]]'' was released in July 2017 and debuted at No. 28 on the ARIA chart. It was nominated for Best Country Album at the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2017]]. At the CMAA in January 2018, Nicholson won Male Artist of the Year.<ref name=\"CMAA2018noms\"/>\n\nNicholson appeared as an on-camera music producer in [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] television production of ''[[The Recording Studio]]'', a 10-part series that ran in April 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/ShaneNicholsonMusic/posts/we-can-finally-tell-the-world-what-we-did-late-last-yearwe-made-a-tv-show-this-n/2358883000811877/|title=We can finally tell the world what we did late last year...we made a tv show!|website=Facebook|date=4 April 2019 |accessdate=28 April 2020}}</ref> The music from the series won the 2019 [[ARIA Music Awards of 2019|ARIA Award]] for [[ARIA Award for Best Original Soundtrack, Cast or Show Album|Best Original Soundtrack, Cast or Show Album]].<ref name=\"ARIA Fine Arts & Artisan winners 2019\">{{cite web | url = https://ariaawards.com.au/News/2019/2019-Fine-Arts-Artisan-ARIA-winners-announced | title = ARIA Awards: 2019 Fine Arts & Artisan Winners Announced | publisher = Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA) | date = 10 October 2019 | accessdate = 28 April 2020 }}</ref>\n\nIn May 2019, Nicholson was signed a publishing deal with [[Cooking Vinyl]] Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://themusicnetwork.com/shane-nicholson-sings-publishing-with-cooking-vinyl-exclusive/|title=Shane Nicholson signs publishing with Cooking Vinyl |website=TMN|date=14 May 2019 |accessdate=28 April 2020}}</ref>\n\nOn 3 April 2020, Nicholson confirmed the digital reissued of his back-catalogue.<ref>{{Cite tweet |user=shanenicholson |number=1245897653151358977 |date=3 April 2020 |url=https://twitter.com/shanenicholson/status/1245897653151358977 |title=We've quietly reissued the entire back-catalogue today on all DSP's.|accessdate=28 April 2020}}</ref>\n\n===2021: ''Living in Colour''===\n{{main|Living in Colour}}\nIn July 2021, Nicholson announced the release of his forthcoming studio album, ''[[Living in Colour]]''. The album was released on 20 August 2021.<ref name=\"LiC\">{{cite web|url=http://www.noise11.com/news/shane-nicholson-reveals-living-in-colour-album-20210709|title=Shane Nicholson Reveals ''Living In Colour'' Album|website=noise11|date=9 July 2021|access-date=10 July 2021}}</ref> August also saw the release of [[Camille Trail]]'s album ''River of Sin'' which Nicholson had produced.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hui |first=Jin |date=2022-03-12 |title=Hauntingly beautiful sounds echo in Camille's voice |url=https://bundabergtoday.com.au/news/2022/03/12/hauntingly-beautiful-sounds-echo-in-camilles-voice/ |access-date=2022-03-21 |website=Bundaberg Today |language=en-US}}</ref> It debuted at #34 on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Country Music Charts]], and #5 on the ARIA Australian Country Music Charts.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2021 |title=ARIA Top 40 Country Albums Chart - Week of 16 August 2021 |url=https://www.aria.com.au/charts/country-albums-chart |access-date=2022-03-21 |website=ARIA |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2021 |title=ARIA Top 20 Australian Country Albums Chart - Week of 16 August 2021 |url=https://www.aria.com.au/charts/australia-artist-country-albums-chart |access-date=2022-03-21 |website=ARIA |language=en}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nOn 17 December 2005 Nicholson married fellow country music singer-songwriter, [[Kasey Chambers]].<ref name=\"SMH Feb06\">{{cite news | url = https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/celebrity/hopper-almost-quit-over-split-20060202-gdmvzp.html | title = Hopper almost quit over split | agency = [[Australian Associated Press]] (AAP) | work = The Sydney Morning Herald | date = 2 February 2006 | accessdate =25 April 2020}}</ref> In 2002, Chambers sung on Nicholson's debut solo album \"Designed to Fade\", which was produced by Kasey's brother, [[Nash Chambers|Nash]].<ref name=\"SMH Dec02\">{{cite web | url = https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/in-like-finn-20021206-gdfx8i.html | title = In Like Finn | work = The Sydney Morning Herald | publisher = Fairfax Media | date = 6 December 2002 | accessdate = 25 April 2020}}</ref> Subsequently, they co-released two albums, ''Rattlin' Bones'' (2008) and ''Wreck & Ruin'' (2012). Chambers and Nicholson have two children: son Arlo Ray (2007) and daughter Poet Poppin (2011). In April 2013 the couple announced their separation.<ref name=\"AutoRI-2\">{{cite news | url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/shane-nicholson-and-kasey-chambers-separate-after-eight-years-of-marriage/story-e6frfn09-1226627018835 | work=The Daily Telegraph | title=Shane Nicholson and Kasey Chambers separate after eight years of marriage | date=25 April 2020 | access-date=25 April 2020 | archive-date=9 May 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160509022448/http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/shane-nicholson-and-kasey-chambers-separate-after-eight-years-of-marriage/story-e6frfn09-1226627018835 | url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n====Studio albums====\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center\"\n|+ List of studio albums, with selected chart positions and certifications\n! Nicholson has been nominated twice.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://americanamusic.org/awards?page=7 |title=Honors & Awards: Year: 2010 |website=AmericanaMusic.org |accessdate=30 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tcmf.com.au/What-s-On/Roll-of-Renown/ |title=Roll of Renown |website=TCMF |accessdate=21 August 2018 |archive-date=4 September 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180904141436/https://tcmf.com.au/What-s-On/Roll-of-Renown/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| 2009\n| Nicholson and Kasey Chambers\n| Best Duo/ Group of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| 2010\n| \"Rattlin' Bones\" {{small|(with Kasey Chambers)}}\n| Song of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===APRA Music Awards===\nThe [[APRA Awards (Australia)|APRA Music Awards]] is annual awards ceremony that celebrate excellence in contemporary music, which honour the skills of member composers, songwriters and publishers who have achieved outstanding success in sales and airplay performance. Nicholson has won two awards from five nominations.\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| [[APRA Music Awards of 2009|2009]]\n| rowspan=\"2\"| \"Rattlin Bones\" {{small|(with Kasey Chambers)}}\n| Song of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Country Work of the Year\n| {{won}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| [[APRA Music Awards of 2012|2012]]\n| rowspan=\"2\"| \"Bad Machines\"\n| Country Work of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Song of the Year<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.noise11.com/news/apra-announce-star-studded-song-of-the-year-top-30-20120322|title=APRA Announce Star-Studded Song of the Year Top 30|website=Noise11|date=22 March 2012|access-date=28 April 2022}}</ref>\n| {{shortlisted}}\n|-\n| Country Work of the Year\n| \"Famous Last Words\"\n| {{won}}\n|-\n|rowspan=\"2\"| [[APRA Music Awards of 2013|2013]] || \"Adam and Eve\" (Kasey Chambers and Shane Nicholson) ||rowspan=\"2\"| Song of the Year<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tonedeaf.thebrag.com/apra-song-year-shortlist-revealed/|title=APRA Song Of The Year 2013 Shortlist Revealed|website=Tone Deaf|date=11 April 2013|access-date=28 April 2022}}</ref> || {{shortlisted}}\n|-\n| \"The Quiet Life\" (Kasey Chambers and Shane Nicholson) || {{shortlisted}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| [[APRA Music Awards of 2016|2016]]\n| rowspan=\"2\"| \"Secondhand Man\"\n| Country Work of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Song of the Year<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.auspop.com.au/2016/01/2016-apra-awards-date-confirmed/| title = 2016 APRA AWARDS : Date Confirmed|website=auspOp|date=April 2016|access-date=14 April 2022 }}</ref> \n| {{shortlisted}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===ARIA Music Awards===\nThe [[ARIA Music Awards]] is an annual awards ceremony that recognises excellence, innovation, and achievement across all genres of [[Australian music]]. Nicholson has won three awards from eleven nominations.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.ariaawards.com.au/history/search/?text=Shane%20nicholson|title = ARIA Awards Search Results \u2013 Shane Nicholson|website =ARIA|accessdate = 26 April 2020}}</ref>\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 2008\n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''Rattlin' Bones'' {{small|(with Kasey Chambers)}}\n| [[ARIA Award for Best year's awards the Hip Hop and R'n'B ARIAs|publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|date=24 November 2021|first=Mawunyo|last=Gbogbo|access-date=25 November 2021}}</ref>\n| ''Living in Colour''\n| Best Country Album\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Country Music Awards of Australia===\nThe [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] (CMAA) (also known as the Golden Guitar Awards) is an annual awards night held in January during the Tamworth Country Music Festival, in [[Tamworth, New South Wales]], celebrating recording excellence in the Australian country music industry. Nicholson has won fifteen awards.<ref name=\"CMAAwins\">{{cite web|url=https://www.country.com.au/awards/past-award-winners|title=Past Award Winners|website=Country|accessdate=26 April 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"CMAA2009nom\">{{cite web|url=https://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2008/12/12/2444724.htm|title=Golden Guitar Nominations for 2009 |website=ABC|date=12 December 2008|accessdate=26 April 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"CMAA2012nom\">{{cite web|url=https://countryroutesnews.blogspot.com/2012/02/country-music-awards-of-australia-2012.html|title=Country Music Awards of Australia 2012 |website=Country Route News|date=4 February 2012|accessdate=26 April 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"CMAA2013nom\">{{cite web|url=https://countryroutesnews.blogspot.com/2013/02/country-music-awards-of-australia-2013.html|title=Country Music Awards of Australia 2013|website=Country Route News|date=6 February 2013|accessdate=26 April 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"CMAA2016noms\">{{cite web|url=https://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/story/3496067/golden-guitar-finalists-revealed-photos/|title= CMAA Country Music Awards of Australia 2016 finalists announced at Sydney Opera House|website=Northern Daily Leader|date=November 2015|accessdate=26 April 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"CMAA2018noms\">{{cite web|url=https://themusicnetwork.com/new-album-categories-announced-for-the-golden-guitar-country-music-awards/|title= I'm over the moon to be nominated for Alt Country Album of the Year|website=The Music Network|date=21 November 2017 |accessdate=26 April 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"CMAA2021\">{{cite web|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-01-23/golden-guitars-awards-fanny-lumsden-sweeps-awards-in-tamworth/13081696|title=Fanny Lumsden wins five Golden Guitar Awards despite cancelled Tamworth Country Music Festival|website=ABC|date=23 January 2021|access-date=24 January 2021}}</ref><ref name=\"CMAA2022\"/>\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"6\"| 2009\n| rowspan=\"2\"| ''Rattlin' Bones'' Artist\n! Album\n! Notes\n|-\n| 2009\n| [[Lou Bradley]]\n| ''La La La Not Listening''\n|\n|-\n| 2010\n| [[Catherine Britt]]\n| ''[[Catherine Britt (album)|Catherine Britt]]''\n| [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album]], nominated (2010)\n|-\n| 2011\n| [[Beccy Cole]]\n| ''[[Songs & Pictures]]''\n| [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album]], nominated (2012)\n|-\n| 2012\n| Quarry Mountain Dead Rats\n| ''Bloodhound Killed My Squeezebox''\n| \n|-\n| 2013\n| [[Alex Lloyd]]\n| ''Urban Wilderness''\n| \n|-\n| 2014\n| [[Lyn Bowtell]]\n| ''Heart of Sorrow''\n| \n|-\n| 2014\n| [[Jodi Martin]]\n| ''Saltwater''\n| \n|-\n| 2015\n| Beccy Cole\n| ''[[Sweet Rebecca]]''\n| \n|-\n| 2015\n| [[Suze DeMarchi]]\n| ''[[Home (Suze DeMarchi album)|Home]]''\n| \n|-\n| 2016\n| [[Katie Brianna]]\n| ''The Victim or The Heroine''\n| \n|-\n| 2016\n| [[Jason Walker (musician)|Jason Walker]]\n| ''All-Night Ghost Town''\n|\n|-\n| 2016\n| [[Amber Lawrence]]\n| ''Happy Ever After''\n| \n|-\n| 2016\n| Tori Forsyth\n| ''Dawn of the Dark''\n| CMAA Alternative Country Album of the Year, nominated (2017)\n|-\n| 2018\n| Ben Leece\n| ''No Wonder The World Is Exhausted''\n|\n|-\n|2021\n|[[Camille Trail]]\n|''River of Sins'' \n|\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n{{commons category|Shane Nicholson (vocalist)}}\n*[http://www.shanenicholson.com Official site]\n*[{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p542391|pure_url=yes}} Entry] at [[Allmusic]]\n\n{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2020}}\n{{Shane Nicholson (singer)}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Nicholson, Shane}}\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:APRA Award winners]]\n[[Category:ARIA Award winners]]\n[[Category:Australian country singers]]\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Lace_(band)","to":"Lace (band)"}],"pages":{"16688350":{"pageid":16688350,"ns":0,"title":"Lace (band)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Canadian musical group}}\n{{Infobox musical artist | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name            = Lace |\n| image             = |\n| caption        = |\n| image_size        = <!-- Only for images smaller than 220 pixels --> |\n|\n| background      = group_or_band |\n| origin          = [[Canada]] |\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]] |\n| years_active    = 1998\u20132001, 2006 |\n| label           = [[143 Records|143]]/[[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros. Nashville]] |\n| associated_acts = [[David Foster]]|\n| past_members    = [[Beverley Mahood]]<br>Giselle<br>Corbi Dyann<br>Stacey Lee |\n}}\n\n'''Lace''' was a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[country music]] group who formed in 1998 with the backing of music producer [[David Foster]].<ref>{{cite news| last =Strauss| first =Neil| title =The pop life: Seeking models who can sing | page =E3| newspaper =[[The New York Times]]| date =1998-12-24| url =https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CE5DD113CF937A15751C1A96E958260| accessdate =2008-03-31 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last =Mclaughlin| first =John P| title =She's plucky in Lace: Beverley Mahood and mates trying for breakthrough album| page =B4| newspaper =[[The Province]]| date =2001-07-20}}</ref> Active between 1998 and 2001, the band charted four singles on national country music charts, in addition to releasing a self-titled studio album on [[143 Records]] (in association with [[Warner Bros. Records]] Nashville).\n\n== Biography ==\nFoster's plan to put together an all-female country trio began to take shape after seeing a music video of [[Beverley Mahood]] on [[CMT (Canada)|CMT Canada]] while he was visiting his mother in [[Victoria, British Columbia]]; he requested to meet with Mahood, and soon after signed her to a recording contract on his label, [[143 Records]].<ref>{{cite news| last =Mclaughlin| first =John P| title =Singin' Dixie: They're like the Chicks, only two-thirds Canadian. Lace is the latest country girl band| page =B1| newspaper =[[The Province]]| date =1999-11-16}}</ref> Mahood later suggested her friend Giselle, a fellow singer-songwriter in [[Ontario]], prior to David Foster introducing them to the group's third member, [[Austin, Texas]] native Corbi Dyann. The trio received a [[Juno Award]] nomination in 2000 for [[Juno Awards of 2000#Best Country Group or Duo|Best Country Group or Duo]].<ref name=\"Canoe1\">{{cite magazine| last =Ross| first =Mike| title =Three cheers! Lace's Beverley Mahood loves trio harmonies| magazine =[[Jam!]]| date =2000-07-22| url =http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/L/Lace/2000/07/22/746782.html| archive-url =https://archive.today/20130115060151/http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/L/Lace/2000/07/22/746782.html| url-status =usurped| archive-date =January 15, 2013| accessdate =2008-03-31 }}</ref> They also received nominations for Group of the Year and Video of the Year (\"I Want a Man\") at the 2000 [[Canadian Country Music Association|Canadian Country Music Awards]].<ref>{{cite news| last =Fuller| first =Cam| title =Touring a treat for Lace| page =D1| publisher =[[Saskatoon StarPhoenix]]| date =2000-08-11}}</ref>\n\nTheir 1999 self-titled album includes record producing credits of Foster, [[Chris Farren (country musician)|Chris Farren]], [[Humberto Gatica]], and J. Richard Hutt. Songwriting credits on the album include [[Linda Thompson (actress)|Linda Thompson]], [[Deana Carter]], [[Sarah McLachlan]] and [[John Scott Sherrill]].<ref>{{cite news| last =North| first =Peter| title =Time for Canada to try on some country Lace| page =C3| newspaper =[[Edmonton Journal]]| date =1999-11-25}}</ref> The group's best-known song was \"I Want a Man\".<ref>{{cite magazine| last =Van Wyk| first =Anika| title =Mahood gets 'Moody' on new album| magazine =[[Jam!]]| date =2004-03-10| url =http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/M/Mahood_Beverley/2004/03/10/747339.html| archive-url =https://archive.today/20120711201531/http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/M/Mahood_Beverley/2004/03/10/747339.html| url-status =usurped| archive-date =July 11, 2012| accessdate =2008-03-31 }}</ref>\n\nIn 2000, Corbi Dyann left the group and Canadian Stacey Lee replaced her.<ref name=\"Canoe1\" /><ref>{{cite news| last =Sweetland| first =Phil| title =Mahood merges beauty, talent| page =G3| newspaper =[[Calgary Herald]]| date =2000-04-01}}</ref>\n\nThe trio often was seen as attempting to capitalize on the success of girl groups [[Dixie Chicks]] and [[SHeDAISY]].<ref>{{cite news| last =Flynn| first =Andrew| title =Lace takes on country girl groups with Foster's help| page =1| publisher =[[Canadian Press]]| date =1999-11-27}}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n=== Albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:8em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"65\"| [[RPM (magazine)|CAN Country]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[Lace (album)|Lace]]''\n| \n* Release date: October 5, 1999\n* Label: [[143 Records]]\n| 17\n|-\n|}\n\n=== Singles ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"2\"| Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"45\"| [[RPM (magazine)|CAN Country]]<br><ref>{{cite magazine|title=Lace - RPM Country Tracks|url=http://www.bac-lac.gc.ca/eng/discover/films-videos-sound-recordings/rpm/Pages/list.aspx?OCRText=Lace&ChartEn=Country+Singles&|magazine=RPM|accessdate=August 11, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|title=Lace - Canada Country|url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/lace/chart-history/ccw/|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=August 11, 2019}}</ref>\n! width=\"45\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]<br><ref>{{cite magazine|title=Lace - Hot Country Songs|url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/lace/chart-history/csi/|magazine=Billboard|accessdate=August 11, 2019}}</ref>\n|-\n| 1999\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[I Want a Man]]\"\n| 7\n| 65\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"6\"| ''Lace''\n|- \n| rowspan=\"4\"| 2000\n! scope=\"row\"| \"You Could've Had Me\"\n| \u2014\n| 71\n|- \n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[Kiss 'Em All]]\"\n| 6\n| \u2014\n|- \n! scope=\"row\"| \"True Love (Never Goes Out of Style)\"\n| 15\n| \u2014\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I Cry Real Tears\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2001\n! scope=\"row\"| \"[[Angel (Sarah McLachlan song)|Angel]]\"\n| \u2014\n| \u2014\n|-\n| 2006\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Can You Handle It\"\n| 48\n| \u2014\n| {{n/a}}\n|- \n| colspan=\"5\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! Year\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Video\n! Director\n|-\n| 1999\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I Want a Man\"\n| Roger Pistole\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2000\n! scope=\"row\"| \"True Love (Never Goes Out of Style)\"\n| rowspan=\"2\"| Terrance Odette \n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"I Cry Real Tears\"\n|-\n|}\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! Year\n! Association\n! Category\n! Result\n|-\n| rowspan=\"3\"| 2000\n| [[Juno Awards of 2000]]\n| [[Juno Award for Country Album of the Year|Best Country Group or Duo]]\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| [[Canadian Country Music Association]]\n| Group or Duo of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Video of the Year \u2013 \"I Want a Man\"\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2001\n| [[Juno Awards of 2001]]\n| Best Country Group or Duo\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n| Canadian Country Music Association\n| Group or Duo of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n|}\n\n== References ==\n{{reflist}}\n\n== External links ==\n* [https://myspace.com/beverleymahood Beverley Mahood] on [[Myspace]]\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Lace}}\n[[Category:Canadian country music groups]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Sara_Storer","to":"Sara Storer"}],"pages":{"512526":{"pageid":512526,"ns":0,"title":"Sara Storer","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2021}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=April 2012}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Sara Storer\n| image            = Sara Storer.png\n| image_upright    = 1.0\n| image_size       = \n| landscape        = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank -->\n| alt              = \n| caption          = \n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = Sara Bettine Storer\n| alias            = \n| birth_date       = {{Birth date and age|df=y|1973|10|6}}\n| birth_place      = [[Wemen, Victoria]]\n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation       = {{flatlist|\n* Singer-songwriter\n* teacher\n}}\n| instrument       = {{flatlist|\n* Vocals\n* acoustic guitar\n}}\n| years_active     = 1996\u2013present\n| label            = {{flatlist|\n* [[ABC Music|ABC]]\n* [[Universal Music Australia|Universal]]\n* [[EMI Records|EMI]]\n}}\n| associated_acts  = \n* [[Greg Storer]]\n* [[Songbirds (group)|Songbirds]]\n| website          = {{URL|sarastorer.com.au}}\n}}\n\n'''Sara Bettine Storer''' (born 6 October 1973) is an Australian [[country music]] singer-songwriter and former teacher. She won a record breaking seven [[Golden Guitar]] awards in the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]] in January 2004, and as of 2017, she has won 21 in total.<ref name=\"storer by storer\">{{cite web|url=https://www.jbhifi.com.au/products/cd-storer-storer-cd|title=Storer by Storer|website=[[JB Hi-Fi]]|access-date=17 December 2022}}</ref> Three of her six studio albums have reached the top&nbsp;30 on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Albums Chart]], ''[[Firefly (Sara Storer album)|Firefly]]'' (July 2005), ''[[Lovegrass (album)|Lovegrass]]'' (August 2013) and ''[[Silos (album)|Silos]]'' (March 2016). ''Silos'' also won [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]] at the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2016]]. Storer has been a member of a country music trio, [[Songbirds (group)|Songbirds]] (2007\u201309) alongside [[Beccy Cole]] and [[Gina Jeffries]]. Her older brother, [[Greg Storer]], is also a country music singer-songwriter and the siblings have recorded and performed together.\n\n==Early career==\nSara Bettine Storer was born in October 1973 in [[Wemen, Victoria|Wemen]] where her parents, Lindsay and Fay<!-- maiden name not seen in sources --> Storer, farmed wheat and cattle on a {{convert|5000|acre|ha}} property.<ref name=\"APRA Buffalo\"/><ref name=\"Dawson\"/> Her three brothers, including Doug and [[Greg Storer]], became farmers, she also has two older sisters.<ref name=\"Dawson\"/><ref name=\"Fidler inter\"/> She attended school in nearby, [[Robinvale]].<ref name=\"Thorburn\"/>\n\nStorer later recalled, \"I wasn't much of a farmer's daughter. Three brothers \u2013 they did everything and they enjoyed it. I would rather sit at home and help out with mum really. I was scared of cattle. I always got yelled at cos I was in the wrong spot you know, didn't really know what I was doing. I was never very good.\"<ref name=\"Fidler inter\"/> She completed her tertiary studies in Melbourne, becoming a teacher and then headed north in the mid-1990s. Living in [[Camooweal, Queensland|Camooweal]], she met a retired [[domestic buffalo|water buffalo]] shooter, Harry Chandler, whose stories inspired her to write, \"Buffalo Bill\", her first song.<ref name=\"APRA Buffalo\"/><ref name=\"Dawson\"/>\n\nNine months later, Storer moved to [[Katherine, Northern Territory]], where she taught kindergarten level at Casuarina Street Primary School.<ref name=\"ABC Bio\"/> After a year there she taught at [[Kalkarindji]] ({{convert|466|km|mi}} southwest of Katherine), for four years.<ref name=\"ABC Bio\"/><ref name=\"AMO Bio\"/> Later she co-wrote and recorded a track, \"Children of the Gurindji\", with [[Kev Carmody]], for her compilation album, ''[[Calling Me Home \u2013 The Best of Sara Storer]]'' (April 2010).\n\nCarmody told [[Rhoda Roberts]] of ''Deadly Vibe'', \"[Storer] came up here about 12 months ago and we did a song about the Gurindji kids together. The whole basis of the song was, when she went to teach at Kalkarindji \u2013 she taught there for a number of years \u2013 she said that she came away with the kids teaching her more than she taught them, and that was the chorus of the song.\"<ref name=\"Roberts\"/>\n\nWhen not teaching she started playing at parties across the territory. She won a talent quest at [[Adelaide River, Northern Territory|Adelaide River]] which provided a scholarship to the College of Country Music, held two weeks before the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]], in January 2000. There she met [[Garth Porter]], former keyboard player with [[Sherbet (band)|Sherbet]], and a record producer of fellow singers, [[Lee Kernaghan]] and [[Gina Jeffreys]]. Porter worked with Storer to record six tracks which he showcased to [[ABC Music]]'s owners, who agreed to sign her to their label.\n\n==Recording career==\n===2000\u20132009===\nSara Storer released her debut studio album, ''[[Chasing Buffalo]]'', in August 2000 via ABC Music/[[Universal Music Australia]] with Porter producing. It peaked in the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Albums Chart]] top&nbsp;100, No.&nbsp;20 on the Australasian Artists, No.&nbsp;8 on the Hitseekers and No.&nbsp;6 on the Country albums charts.<ref name=\"ARIA Report 626\"/> She won the Best New Talent category at the 2001 [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] for her debut single, \"Buffalo Bill\", in January of that year.<ref name=\"CMAoA 2000s\"/>\n\nHer second album, ''[[Beautiful Circle]]'', was released in November 2002, which was produced by Porter again. In January 2004 at the Country Music Awards of Australia she was nominated for eight Golden Guitars, and won seven of them \u2013 a then-record number of trophies at one ceremony:<ref name=\"ARIA Report 804\"/><ref name=\"Morris 1\"/> Vocal Collaboration, Single of the Year and Song of the Year all for \"Raining on the Plains\" (with [[John Williamson (singer)|John Williamson]]); Female Vocalist of the Year and Album of the Year for ''Beautiful Circle'', Songwriter of the Year for \"Raining on the Plains\" (co-written with Porter and Greg Storer); Bush Ballad of the Year for \"Boss Drovers Pride\" and Heritage Song of the Year for \"Drover's Call\".<ref name=\"CMAoA 2000s\"/>\n\nThe album reached No.&nbsp;50 on the ARIA Albums Chart in March 2004.<ref name=\"AUS Charts\"/> It also peaked at No.&nbsp;11 on the Australasian Artists, No.&nbsp;1 on the Hitseekers and No.&nbsp;2 on the Country albums charts.<ref name=\"ARIA Report 732\"/> She promoted it by touring with Australian country singer, [[Troy Cassar-Daley]],<ref name=\"Morris 1\"/> and United Kingdom singer, [[Charlie Landsborough]], including playing to an audience of over 40,000 people at the [[Gympie Muster]], Queensland. On 6 October 2004 she issued her first DVD, ''Stories to Tell'', which included music videos, interview footage, acoustic performances and new tracks.<ref name=\"Morris 1\"/>\n\n''[[Firefly (Sara Storer album)|Firefly]]'', was Storer's third album, was released in July 2005, which peaked at No.&nbsp;24 on the ARIA Albums Chart.<ref name=\"ARIA Report 804\"/><ref name=\"AUS Charts\"/> Porter produced the work and it became her first number-one on the ARIA Country Albums Chart.<ref name=\"ARIA Report 804\"/> She co-wrote and recorded duets on three tracks: with Greg (\"Chiller's Bend\"), [[Josh Cunningham]] (\"Important Things\") and [[Paul Kelly (Australian musician)|Paul Kelly]] (\"Must've Been a Hell of a Party\").\n\nKelly described Storer, \"You know she's paid attention, heard the bush waking up in the morning, listened to the worries thrashed out at the kitchen table, smelt dry summer wheat up close, dreamed of far away places in a bedroom with a window on a big sky, driven miles on dirt and bitumen and fallen in and out of love. She's found her own way to sing the stories that are all around her and then inside her bubbling out. She doesn't copy over-emotive, fake sincere twangy country singers from overseas. She's found her own restraint and steel and lets her songs do their sweet, sly work.\"<ref name=\"ABC Bio\"/>\n\nIn December 2005 [[Deborah Conway]] established the Broad Festival project, \"the idea that I would pull these different women performers together from different genres and call it Broad\".<ref name=\"Elliott\"/> Storer joined Conway, [[Katie Noonan]], [[Ruby Hunter]] and [[Clare Bowditch]] where they performed their own and each other's songs on an Australian tour.<ref name=\"Elliott\"/><ref name=\"Broad2005\"/> Conway observed, \"Sara you're a gorgeous surprise package, quiet and unassuming offstage; onstage, you had us pissing ourselves every night. I love that simple yet deceptive guitar playing and those haunting songs, which have such a piercing truth to them.\"<ref name=\"Broad2005\"/>\n\nIn March 2006 Storer played at the Queens' Lunch during the [[2006 Commonwealth Games|Melbourne Commonwealth Games]]. In February and March 2007 she performed a double-headlining tour with fellow country musician, [[Felicity Urquhart]].<ref name=\"Morris 1\"/> In November of that year she released her fourth studio album, ''[[Silver Skies]]'', which reached the ARIA Albums Chart top&nbsp;100 and No.&nbsp;3 on the Country Albums Chart.<ref name=\"AUS Charts\"/> It was co-produced by Cunningham and Matt Fell for her new label, [[EMI Records]].<ref name=\"AUS Charts\"/><ref name=\"Dawson 3\"/>\n\nIts lead single, \"Land Cries Out\", was released in September 2007, which Andrew Tijs of ''Undercover News'' described, \"an achingly beautiful rumination on the bitterness of being forced to leave the land you love \u2013 an all too common scenario during the recent drought. With this heartfelt subject matter, Storer has branched away from traditional country sounds... [she] uses electric guitar and drums to complement the lament.\"<ref name=\"Tijs 2\"/> From late January to early February 2008 she supported a tour by American singer-songwriter, [[Suzanne Vega]].<ref name=\"Tijs\"/>\n\nFrom 2007 to 2009 she joined [[Beccy Cole]] and [[Gina Jeffreys]] to form a country music trio, [[Songbirds (group)|Songbirds]].<ref name=\"Morris 1\"/> The group released a live DVD, ''You've Got a Friend: Live in Concert'', on 1 May 2009, which was accredited by [[Australian Recording Industry Association|ARIA]] as a gold album by the end of that year.<ref name=\"ARIA Acred 09\"/> It was recorded at Tamworth in January 2009.<ref name=\"Dawson 2\"/> It was shown at cinemas from 29 April of that year, Storer opined, \"I'm really proud of the Songbirds: You've Got a Friend live filming but am worried how pregnant I will look shown on a big screen.\"<ref name=\"Cashmere 1\"/>\n\nStorer had encouraged her brother Greg, a cropping farmer from \"Strawin\" {{convert|60|km|mi}} north-west of [[Warren, New South Wales]], to write music, she has performed his work, including duets with him and she is recorded on his debut single, \"When I Was a Boy\" (December 2009).<ref name=\"Land Warren\"/> He recalled, \"Sara started off telling me to write some lyrics and then every now and then she said I should get up and have a sing at one of her shows. It was absolutely terrifying to get up and sing in front of some great artists... [its] a bit addictive. The trick is to never put the guitar away \u2013 in between wrestling with the kids or doing something else, I can just pick up the guitar.\"<ref name=\"Land Warren\"/>\n\n===2010\u20132020===\nIn April 2010, Storer released her first compilation album, ''Calling Me Home \u2013 The Best of Sara Storer'', which reached No.&nbsp;28 on the ARIA Albums Chart and No.&nbsp;1 on the Country Albums Chart.<ref name=\"AUS Charts\"/> She had recorded three new tracks, \"Calling Me Home\", \"Children of the Gurundi\" (with Kev Carmody) and \"Tears\". At the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2010]] John Williamson was inducted into their [[ARIA Hall of Fame|Hall of Fame]] in October, where Storer performed his tune, \"Mallee Boy\", in his honour.<ref name=\"Ferris\"/>\n\nThe singer-songwriter launched her fifth album, ''[[Lovegrass (album)|Lovegrass]]'', at the [[Gympie Music Muster]] in August 2013.<ref name=\"Hamley\"/> She explained her preparation, \"I'm getting there early and we're all going to catch up prior to the Muster for a rehearsal, which is a must especially when I'm releasing a new album and playing the songs with the band for the first time, really. We need a little practice run otherwise we could end up a train smash.\"<ref name=\"Hamley\"/> ''Lovegrass'', which was produced by Matt Fell, peaked at No.&nbsp;25 on the ARIA Albums Chart and No.&nbsp;5 on the Country Albums Chart.<ref name=\"AUS Charts\"/> In 2015 Storer recorded \"Song for Grace\", a duet with Lee Kernaghan for his album, ''[[Spirit of the Anzacs (album)|Spirit of the Anzacs]]'' (March 2015).\n\nIn March 2016 Storer released her sixth studio album, ''[[Silos (album)|Silos]]'', also produced by Fell, which peaked at No.&nbsp;30 on the ARIA Albums Chart and No.&nbsp;3 on the Country Music Albums Chart.<ref name=\"AUS Charts\"/> It earned the musician her sixth nomination for [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album]] and her first win in the category, at [[ARIA Music Awards of 2016|that year's]] ceremony.<ref name=\"ARIA List\"/> At the Country Music Awards of Australia in January 2017 she received her 21st Golden Guitar \u2013 the most by any female artist.<ref name=\"CMAoA 2010s\"/><ref name=\"Young\"/>\n\nIn April 2019, Storer released her 7th studio album, ''[[Raindance (Sara Storer album)|Raindance]]''.\n\n===2020\u2013present===\nIn January 2023, Sara will feature on the self-titled album by Storer, alongside her brother Greg and Greg's daughters Bonnie & Pip.<ref name=\"storer by storer\"/>\n\n== Personal life==\nWhen Sara Storer was 18, her parents moved from Wemen, Victoria to a farming property near Warren, New South Wales.<ref name=\"Dawson 2\"/><ref name=\"OSullivan\"/> Storer had lived in Melbourne, moved to Camooweal, North Queensland and then to Katherine and Kalkarindji, Northern Territory in the mid-1990s. By June 2009 Storer was living in Darwin.<ref name=\"Dawson 2\"/><ref name=\"NT News\"/> There she married David O'Hare, a cattle buyer, in April 2012 and the couple have four children.<ref name=\"Johnstone\"/><ref name=\"Belt\"/><ref name=\"Felicity\"/> Storer took a break from song writing while focussing on parenting.<ref name=\"Hamley\"/><ref name=\"NT News\"/> O'Hare left Austrex in February 2014 after being their cattle export manager in Darwin for ten years.<ref name=\"Beef Central\"/>\n\nAs of May 2017 the family has a farm near [[Bowna]] {{convert|33|km|mi}} from [[Albury]], they also have a home in Albury.<ref name=\"Young\"/><ref name=\"Byram\"/><ref name=\"Torenbeek\"/> In January of that year she acknowledged her family when receiving her Golden Guitars at the Country Music Awards, \"Dave has been a great support when I've gotten down about still doing this with four little boys. I have to thank my boys as well, for giving me a little moment every now and then to get a few lines down on paper.\"<ref name=\"Young\"/>\n\n==Discography==\n\n=== Studio albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|+ List of studio albums, with selected chart positions and certifications\n! Storer has won one award.<ref name=\"ARIA List\"/>\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2001|2001]] || ''Chasing Buffalo'' || [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]] || {{nom}} \n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2003|2003]] || ''Beautiful Circle'' ||Best Country Album || {{nom}} \n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2005|2005]] || ''Firefly'' ||Best Country Album || {{nom}} \n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2008|2008]] || ''Silver Skies'' || Best Country Album || {{nom}} \n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2013|2013]] || ''Lovegrass'' || Best Country Album || {{nom}} \n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2016|2016]] || ''Silos'' || Best Country Album || {{won}} \n|-\n| [[ARIA Music Awards of 2019|2019]] || ''Raindance'' || Best Country Album || {{nom}} \n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Country Music Awards (CMAA)===\nThe [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] (CMAA) (also known as the Golden Guitar Awards) is an annual awards night held in January during the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]], celebrating recording excellence in the Australian country music industry. They have been held annually since 1973. Sara Storer has won 22 awards.<ref name=\"CMAoA 2000s\"/><ref name=\"CMAoA 2010s\"/><ref name=\"Storer Silos\"/><ref name=\"storer by storer\"/><ref name=GGwins2024>{{cite web|url=https://www.kixcountry.com.au/hottest-country-news/brad-cox-the-wolfe-brothers-win-big-at-the-2024-golden-guitar-awards/ |title= Brad Cox, The Wolfe Brothers Win Big At The 2024 Golden Guitar Awards|website=Kix Country|date= 27 January 2024|access-date=29 January 2024}}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| 2001 || \"Buffalo Bill\" || New Talent of the Year || {{won}}\n|-\n|rowspan=\"7\"| 2004 SToReR) (written by Sara Storer, Greg Storer) || Bush Ballad of the Year || {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n==See also==\n* [[Songbirds (group)|Songbirds]]\n\n==References==\n\n{{Refbegin}}\n;General\n* singers]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Brad_Johner","to":"Brad Johner"}],"pages":{"11570005":{"pageid":11570005,"ns":0,"title":"Brad Johner","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Canadian singer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}}\n{{BLP primary sources|date=June 2009}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Brad Johner\n| image           =\n| birth_name      =\n| alias           =\n| birth_place     = [[Estevan, Saskatchewan]], Canada \n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1969|02|04|mf=y}}\n| origin          = [[Midale, Saskatchewan]], Canada\n| instrument      = Acoustic guitar, electric guitar, vocals\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter, musician\n| years_active    = 1988\u2013present\n| label           = [[Royalty Records|Royalty]], 306, On Ramp\n| associated_acts = [[The Johner Brothers]], Ken Johner, [[Donny Parenteau]], The Johner Boys\n| website         = [http://www.bradjohner.com/ www.bradjohner.com]\n}}\n\n'''Bradley Robert Johner''' (born February 4, 1969) is a Canadian [[country music]] singer.\n\n==Biography==\nJohner was born in [[Estevan, Saskatchewan]] and grew up on a farm near [[Midale, Saskatchewan]] playing music in his family band. When he was 16, Brad won a National Talent Contest during Country Music Week in [[Hamilton, Ontario|Hamilton]] in 1982.<ref>[https://esask.uregina.ca/entry/johner_brad_1969-.html Brad Johner (1969- )]</ref><ref name=autogenerated>[http://www.countrymusicnews.ca/news.ihtml?step=2&article_id=333 Country Music News Canadian country Music Artists CD's CDs CD Nashville report<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He spent six years maintaining his solo career before teaming up with his brother Ken to form [[The Johner Brothers]] in 1988. After 14 years, six albums (including their ''Greatest Hits''), 26 singles, one [[Canadian Country Music Association]] (CCMA) award and more than 40 awards from the Saskatchewan Country Music Association (SCMA), including Entertainer of the Decade, Ken decided to retire from the music business to pursue other interests in 2002.\n\nAfter the Johner Brothers dissolved, Brad returned to his solo career. He moved to [[Saskatoon]] with his wife Rhea and their five sons to begin work on his first solo album with producer Bart McKay.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.countrymusicnews.ca/news.ihtml?step=2&article_id=333 Country Music News Canadian country Music Artists CD's CDs CD Nashville report<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The album, ''[[Free (Brad Johner album)|Free]]'', was released by [[Royalty Records]] in 2003. The album was nominated for Album of the Year by the CCMA and the [[Juno Award]]s, and won Outstanding Country Album at the 2003 Western Country Music Awards. In 2004, the Canadian Independent Music Awards named Johner Favourite Country Artist/Group of the Year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.livetourartists.com/brad-johner/index.htm |title=LiveTourArtists - Brad Johner |accessdate=June 3, 2007 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070518233337/http://www.livetourartists.com/brad-johner/index.htm |archivedate=May 18, 2007 }}</ref> Brad won Male Vocalist of the Year at the 2003 SCMA, along with Single and Song of the Year for \"Hello.\" He cleaned up the following year at the SCMA ceremonies, winning Entertainer and Male Vocalist of the Year. \"Free\" was named Song, Single and Video of the Year, and ''Free'' won Album of the Year. His backup band, the '''Brad Johner Band''', won Backup Band of the Year.\n\nAn American record label (Infinity Records Nashville) took notice of Brad, and re-released his debut album in the United States in 2004. The label folded before \"Free,\" the first single, took off at radio. Brad signed with Canadian label 306 Records for the release of his second album, ''[[Summertown Road]]'', in 2005. The first four singles from the album reached the Canadian country top 25, including \"She Moved,\" \"I'd Rather Be Lucky,\" \"Your Love Is My Luck,\" and the top 10 \"I've Got It Good.\" At the 2005 SCMA Award ceremony in March, Brad won 10 awards, including Fans' Choice Entertainer of the Year, Male Vocalist of the Year and the National Achievement Award. On July 17, 2005, Brad received a star on the [[Merritt, British Columbia|Merritt]] Walk of Stars.<ref>[http://www.bradjohner.com/topten.cfm?JournalID=931 The Official Brad Johner Website/Le Site Officiel de Brad Johner<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070708150737/http://www.bradjohner.com/topten.cfm?JournalID=931 |date=July 8, 2007 }}</ref> Brad released his first solo Christmas album, ''Now That's Christmas'' in November 2005.\n\n''Summertown Road'' was nominated for Album of the Year by the CCMA in 2006, and Brad picked up a nod for Male Vocalist of the Year. Once again, Brad was named Fans' Choice Entertainer and Male Vocalist of the Year at the 2006 SCMA Awards on March 19, 2006. One month later, he was presented the Saskatchewan Centennial Medal in recognition of his outstanding musical achievements and contributions to the province.<ref>[http://www.bradjohner.com/topten.cfm?JournalID=2054 The Official Brad Johner Website/Le Site Officiel de Brad Johner<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070709012252/http://www.bradjohner.com/topten.cfm?JournalID=2054 |date=July 9, 2007 }}</ref> At the [[CMA Music Festival]] in 2006, Brad was chosen to represent Canada at the Global Artist Party.<ref>[http://www.bradjohner.com/topten.cfm?JournalID=2208 The Official Brad Johner Website/Le Site Officiel de Brad Johner<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070607182157/http://www.bradjohner.com/topten.cfm?JournalID=2208 |date=June 7, 2007 }}</ref> When the 2007 SCMA Awards were handed out on April 15, Brad was named Entertainer of the Year for the fourth year in a row, and Male Vocalist for the sixth straight year. Brad was also named Male Vocalist of the Year at the 2007 CCMA Awards.\n\n==Charity work==\nJohner has made appearances on [[Telemiracle]], a yearly telethon. Johner co-wrote the current Telemiracle opening theme song with Donny Parenteau entitled \"You are the Miracle\". It became the theme in 2011.\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[Free (Brad Johner album)|Free]]''\n| \n* Release date: February 11, 2003\n* Label: [[Royalty Records]]\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[Summertown Road]]''\n| \n* Release date: October 18, 2005\n* Label: 306 Records\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Lookin' at You''\n| \n* Release date: July 7, 2009\n* Label: On Ramp Records\n|-\n|}\n\n===Compilation albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''The Classics''\n| \n* Release date: November 12, 2015\n* Label: On Ramp Records\n|-\n|}\n\n===Christmas albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Now That's Christmas''\n| \n* Release date: November 28, 2005\n* Label: 306 Records\n|-\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! Between his solo work and the Johner Brothers, Brad he has won 67 Saskatchewan Country Music Awards which makes him one of the all-time winningest nominees in award history.\n\n{{Infobox musician This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jake_Mathews","to":"Jake Mathews"}],"pages":{"4741417":{"pageid":4741417,"ns":0,"title":"Jake Mathews","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Distinguish|Jake Matthews (disambiguation){{!}}Jake Matthews}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| image           = Jake Mathews 1.JPG\n| name            = Jake Mathews\n| background      = solo_singer\n| caption         = \n| birth_name      = Jacques Lagrandeur\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1971|03|14}}\n| origin          = [[Greater Sudbury|Sudbury]], Ontario, Canada\n| Instruments     = \n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer, songwriter\n| years_active    = 2001\u2013present\n| label           = [[Royalty Records|Royalty]], [[Open Road Recordings|Open Road]]\n| website         = [http://www.jakemathews.com/ www.jakemathews.com]\n}}\n\n'''Jake Mathews''' (born '''Jacques Lagrandeur''' born March 14, 1971, in [[Greater Sudbury|Sudbury]], Ontario, Canada) is a Canadian [[country music]] singer, songwriter and performer.\n\n==Career==\nJake's self-titled debut CD (''Jake Mathews'') garnered six nationally charted hits: \"I\u2019ll Do You One Better,\" \"Try Again Tomorrow,\" \"That's How Long,\" \"Rush,\" \"I\u2019m Gone\" and \"There Ain't No Such Thing.\"\n\nHis second CD, ''Time After Time'', released in 2004, was voted Best Album by [[Country Music News]]. Singles released from the album include the title track, \"Signs of You Everywhere,\" \"Kings for a Day\" and \"Arizona on My Mind.\"\n\nAlthough he is the younger brother of [[Gil Grand]], he has established a music career in his own right. In 2006, Mathews and Grand joined forces for \"Raise the Roof,\" a tour that took them across Canada, raising awareness of [[Ronald McDonald House Charities]].\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Duane_Steele","to":"Duane Steele"}],"pages":{"11606567":{"pageid":11606567,"ns":0,"title":"Duane Steele","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image           =\n| name            = Duane Steele\n| origin          = [[Hines Creek, Alberta]], Canada\n| instrument      = Vocals, Guitar\n| genre           = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 1984\u2013present\n| label           = [[Mercury Records|Mercury]]<br>[[Royalty Records|Royalty]]<br>Icon\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = [http://www.duanesteele.com/ www.duanesteele.com]\n}}\n\n'''Duane Bj\u00f6rklund'''<ref>https://m.facebook.com/story.php/?id=100003601632379&story_fbid=3033860183410673 {{Bare URL inline|date=August 2024}}</ref> (born 1968) known professionally as '''Duane Steele''',  is a Canadian [[country music]] artist. He has released five studio albums and one greatest hits album, and has charted multiple singles on the Canadian country singles charts, including the Number One hit \"[[Anita Got Married]]\" in 1996. A new album entitled \"Drive On\" was released in 2019.\n\n==Biography==\nDuane Steele's career began when he became the lead singer of the band '''Rock 'N' Horse''' in 1984 under his real name of Duane Bj\u00f6rklund.<ref>[http://www.duanesteele.com/pages/press_kit.htm Press Kit<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The band released one album, ''Highways'', in 1991, and the song \"Real Good Love\" reached No.&nbsp;69 on the Canadian country singles chart. However, members of the band went their separate ways in 1993.\n\nSteele moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] and signed a publishing contract with [[Warner Music Group|Warner-Chappell]].<ref>{{usurped|1=[https://archive.today/20120709201714/http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/S/Steele_Duane/1997/08/01/749948.html CANOE \u2013 JAM! Music \u2013 Artists \u2013 Steele, Duane: Steele's lifetime devotion rewarded<!-- Bot generated title -->]}}</ref> He scored a record deal with [[Mercury Records]] in 1995 after a performance during Canadian Country Music Week. The following year, he released his debut solo album, ''[[P.O. Box 423]]''. The first four singles from the project all reached the top 10 on the Canadian country chart, including \"[[Anita Got Married]],\" which became Steele's first No.&nbsp;1 song. He was nominated for the Vista Rising Star Award by the [[Canadian Country Music Association]] (CCMA) in 1996, but lost to [[Terri Clark]]. He also received a nomination for Male Vocalist of the Year. In 1997, the [[Juno Award]]s nominated Steele for Best Country Male Vocalist, and also the all-genre Best New Solo Artist. He won his first award, Vocal Event of the Year, at the 1997 CCMA Awards for his duet with [[Lisa Brokop]], \"Two Names On An Overpass.\"\n\nSteele's second album, ''[[This Is the Life (Duane Steele album)|This Is the Life]]'', was released in September 1997. The disc included a cover of [[Gordon Lightfoot]]'s \"[[If You Could Read My Mind (song)|If You Could Read My Mind]].\" The first two singles, \"Tell The Girl\" and \"If I Could Just Get To You,\" both reached the Canadian top 10. Steele was again nominated for Male Vocalist of the Year in 1998 at both the CCMA Awards and the Juno Awards. When subsequent singles failed to reach the top 30, Steele and Mercury parted ways.<ref>{{usurped|1=[https://archive.today/20120711074656/http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/S/Steele_Duane/1998/10/06/749944.html CANOE \u2013 JAM! Music \u2013 Artists \u2013 Steele, Duane: Steele swears he'll survive loss of recording contract<!-- Bot generated title -->]}}</ref>\n\nSteele moved back to Canada in 1999 and began writing for his third album. ''[[I'll Be Alright (album)|I'll Be Alright]]'' was released in August 2000 on Steele's own Jolt Records and distributed by [[Royalty Records]]. Seven singles were released from the project, including \"The Good Side Of Your Goodbye,\" \"This Is Love,\" \"I-65\" and \"The Heart Of The It Don't Matter.\" In 2001, the CCMA named Steele Independent Male Artist of the Year.\n\nSteele released a [[greatest hits]] album, ''[[Set List (Duane Steele album)|Set List]]'', in 2004. The album collected seventeen of Steele's biggest hits, along with three new songs. Steele's fourth studio album, ''[[Ghost Town (Duane Steele album)|Ghost Town]]'', was released in 2006 on Icon Records. It was followed by ''[[Gas and Time]]'', released in 2010 on Jolt. A new album entitled \"Drive On\" was released in 2019.\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:14em;\"| Title\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak positions\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"65\"| [[RPM (magazine)|CAN Country]]<br><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-110.01-e.php?PHPSESSID=ibdcu4ks3e9c43vbmja9b5cl12&q1=Duane+Steele&q2=Country+Albums%2FCDs&interval=20|title=Results \u2013 RPM \u2013 Library and Archives Canada \u2013 Country Albums/CDs|work=[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]|accessdate=6 September 2011}}</ref>\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''[[P.O.
