This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Tommy_Emmanuel","to":"Tommy Emmanuel"}],"pages":{"1900005":{"pageid":1900005,"ns":0,"title":"Tommy Emmanuel","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Australian guitarist (born 1955)}}\n{{Use Australian English|date=July 2013}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2021}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name               = Tommy Emmanuel \n| image              = 2024-09-18 Concert of Tommy Emmanuel and Mike Dawes at UdK Berlin Konzertsaal (Martin Rulsch) 096.jpg\n| caption            = Emmanuel in Berlin, September 2024\n| background         = non_vocal_instrumentalist\n| birth_name         = William Thomas Emmanuel\n| birth_date         = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1955|05|31}}\n| birth_place        = [[Muswellbrook, New South Wales]], Australia\n| genre              = [[Jazz]], [[Pop music|pop]], [[Rock music|rock]], [[Country music|country]]\n| occupation         = Musician\n| instrument         = Guitar, vocals\n| years_active       = 1962\u2013present\n| label              = [[Sony Music|Sony]], [[Columbia Records|Columbia]], [[Favored Nations Records|Favored Nations]]\n| associated_acts = Southern Star Band, [[John Farnham]], [[Dragon (band)|Dragon]], [[Jerry Reed]], [[Chet Atkins]], [[Martin Taylor (guitarist)|Martin Taylor]], [[Hank Marvin]], [[Gabriella Quevedo]]\n| website            = {{URL|tommyemmanuel.com}}\n{{Infobox person|embed=yes\n| signature          = Tommy Emmanuel signature 2013.svg\n}}\n}}\n\n'''William Thomas Emmanuel''' {{post-nominals|country=AUS|AM}} (born 31 May 1955) is an Australian guitarist. Originally a session player in many bands, he has released many award-winning recordings as a solo artist. In June 2010, Emmanuel was appointed a Member of the [[Order of Australia]] (AM);<ref name=\"It's an Honour: AM\">{{cite web|url=https://honours.pmc.gov.au/honours/awards/1142663 |title=It's an Honour \u2013 Honours \u2013 Search Australian Honours |publisher=Itsanhonour.gov.au |date=14 June 2010 |access-date=17 March 2013}}</ref> in 2011, he was inducted into the [[Australian Roll of Renown]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tcmf.com.au/What-s-On/Roll-of-Renown/ |title=Roll of Renown|publisher=TCMF |access-date=21 August 2018}}</ref> In 2019, he was listed by MusicRadar as the best [[acoustic guitar]]ist in the world.<ref>{{Cite web|date=12 December 2019|first=Matt |last=Parker |title=The 10 best acoustic guitarists in the world today|url=https://www.musicradar.com/news/the-10-best-acoustic-guitarists-in-the-world-today|access-date=2021-08-03|website=MusicRadar|language=en}}</ref>\n\n==Life and career==\nOne of six children, Emmanuel was born in [[Muswellbrook, New South Wales]], Australia, in 1955. He received his first guitar in 1959 at age four and was taught by his mother to accompany her playing [[lap steel guitar]]. In 1961, at the age of six, he heard [[Chet Atkins]] playing on the radio. He vividly remembers that moment and said it greatly inspired him as a musician.<ref name=\"pritcher\">{{cite web |url=http://users.adam.com.au/donald/markinter.htm |title=The Official Tommy Emmanuel Web Site \u2013 Interview |publisher=Users.adam.com.au |date=19 April 1997 |access-date=17 March 2013 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131010192609/http://users.adam.com.au/donald/markinter.htm |archive-date=10 October 2013 }}</ref>\n\nBy the age of six, he was a working professional musician. Recognizing the musical talents of Emmanuel and his older brother, [[Phil Emmanuel|Phil]], their father created a family band, sold their home, and took his family on the road. With the family living in two station wagons, much of Emmanuel's childhood was spent touring Australia, playing rhythm guitar, and rarely going to school. After their father died in 1966, Australian Country Music star [[Buddy Williams (country musician)|Buddy Williams]] approached the family and asked permission to take the Emmanuel brothers on the road with his touring show travelling around Australia. Tommy Emmanuel would go on to record a number of Buddy Williams albums in the early 1970s. The family settled in Parkes after the [[New South Wales Department of Education]] insisted that the Emmanuel children had to go to school regularly. <ref name=\"cmonline\">{{cite web|url=http://www.countrymusiconline.net/tommyemmanuel.html |title=Tommy Emmanuel: c.g.p |publisher=Countrymusiconline.net|access-date=17 March 2013}}</ref>\n\nIn his teen years, Tommy Emmanuel moved to Sydney, and was noticed nationally when he won a string of talent contests. <ref name=\"pritcher\" /><ref name=\"musicfrisk\">{{cite web|url=http://www.musicfrisk.com/picture/interview/tommy.emmanuel.fingerstyle.02.14.2003.php |title=Tommy Emmanuel Interview |publisher=Music Frisk |date=14 February 2003 |access-date=17 March 2013}}</ref> By the late 1970s, he was playing drums with his brother Phil in the group Goldrush as well as doing session work on numerous albums and jingles. He gained further prominence in the late 1970s as the lead guitarist in the Southern Star Band, the backing group for vocalist [[Doug Parkinson]]. During 1986\u20131988 and 1995, he joined the lineup of the leading New Zealand/Australian 1970s rock group [[Dragon (band)|Dragon]] that had reformed in 1982, touring widely with them, including a 1987 tour with [[Tina Turner]]; he left the group to embark on a solo career.\n\nIn 1994, Australian music veteran [[John Farnham]] invited him to play the guitar next to Stuart Fraser from [[Noiseworks]] for the ''Concert for Rwanda''. Emmanuel had previously been a member of Farnham's band during the early 1980s and featured on the album ''[[Uncovered (John Farnham album)|Uncovered]]'' and rejoined after the 1994 concert.\n\nIn July 1999, [[Chet Atkins]] commented that Emmanuel was a \"fearless\" [[fingerpicking]] guitar player and awarded Tommy and four others ([[John Knowles (guitarist)|John Knowles]], [[Marcel Dadi]], [[Jerry Reed]], and [[Steve Wariner]]) the \"Certified Guitar Player\" title.<ref name=Certified>{{cite news|last1=St. James|first1=Adam|title=Tommy Emmanuel: Certified Guitar Player|url=https://www.guitar.com/articles/tommy-emmanuel-certified-guitar-player|access-date=3 June 2019|publisher=Guitar.com|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160111083823/https://guitar.com/articles/tommy-emmanuel-certified-guitar-player|archive-date=11 January 2016}}</ref><ref name=\"Certified Wariner\">{{cite magazine|last1=Thompson|first1=Art|title=Steve Wariner|url=http://www.guitarplayer.com/artists/1013/steve-wariner/11636|magazine=[[Guitar Player]]|access-date=25 October 2015|date=1 September 2009}}</ref>\n\nEmmanuel and his brother Phil performed live in Sydney at the closing ceremony of the [[Summer Olympics]] in 2000. The event was televised worldwide with an estimated 2.85&nbsp;billion viewers.<ref name=\"musicfrisk\" />\n\nIn December 2007, he was diagnosed with heart problems<ref>{{cite web |url=http://break-hollywood.blogspot.com/2007/12/oz-music-legend-tommy-emmanuel-falls.html |title= Oz music legend Tommy Emmanuel falls ill|website=break-hollywood.blogspot.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100316231641/http://break-hollywood.blogspot.com/2007/12/oz-music-legend-tommy-emmanuel-falls.html |archive-date=16 March 2010}}</ref> and was forced to take a break from his hectic touring schedule due to exhaustion but returned to full-time touring in early 2008.\n\nIn June 2010, Emmanuel was appointed a Member of the [[Order of Australia]] (AM).<ref name=\"It's an Honour: AM\"/>\n\nAt the 2011 \u2018TommyFest\u2019, Tommy took the chance to talk to the audience about his strong Christian faith.\n\u201cThe Lord is my shepherd, so I lack nothing\u2014it\u2019s true!\u201d he told the gathered crowds.\n<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.warcry.org.au/single-post/2018/02/10/Tommy-Emmanuel-Guitar-star-takes-his-cue-from-God | title=Salvos Magazine &#124; the Salvation Army Australia }}</ref>\n\nIn 2012, Governor [[Steve Beshear]] awarded Emmanuel the state of Kentucky's honorific title of [[Kentucky Colonel]].<ref name=\"BroadwayWorld.com Kentucky Colonel\">{{cite web|author1=Music News Desk|title=Tommy Emmanuel to Tour United States Alongside Martin Taylor in Early 2014|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwmusic/article/Tommy-Emmanuel-to-Tour-United-States-Alongside-Martin-Taylor-in-Early-2014-20140114|access-date=25 October 2015|website=BroadwayWorld.com|date=14 January 2014}}</ref>\n\nIn 2009 he worked with fellow local artists [[Ray Burgess]], [[Marty Rhone]], [[John St Peeters]] and [[Swanee (singer)|John \"Swanee\" Swan]] to release a single, \"Legends of the Southern Land\".<ref name=\"Pascuzzi\">{{cite news | archive-url = https://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20131018132000/http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/63544/20131019-0020/www.mediasearch.com.au/music/wrap/legendsofthesouthernland.html | url = http://www.mediasearch.com.au/music/wrap/legendsofthesouthernland.html | title = 'Legends of the Southern Land' \u2013 a new Australian anthem | last = Pascuzzi | first = Carmine | work = MediaSearch | archive-date = 18 October 2013 | access-date = 13 May 2017 }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>\n\nDuring a July 2019 concert he mentioned recently receiving American citizenship.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.theday.com/article/20190719/ENT10/190719396 |title=Review: Acoustic guitarists Tommy Emmanuel, Mike Dawes dazzle Garde crowd |date=19 July 2019 |website=The Day |language=en-US |access-date=26 July 2019}}</ref>\n\n==Guitar style==\n[[File:Tommy Emmanuel flickr.jpg|thumb|220px|right|Emmanuel's fingerstyle technique was featured at a June 2006 performance at [[City Stages]] in Birmingham, Alabama]]\nEmmanuel had said that even at a young age he was fascinated by [[Chet Atkins|Chet Atkins's]] musical style (sometimes referred to as [[Travis picking]]) of playing bass lines, chords, melodies, and harmonies simultaneously using the thumb and fingers of the right hand, achieving a dynamic range of sound from the instrument. Although Emmanuel's playing incorporates a multitude of musical influences and styles, including [[jazz]], [[blues]], [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[folk music|folk]] and rock, this type of [[country music|country]] finger-style playing is at the core of his technique. While Emmanuel has never had formal music training and does not read or write music, his natural musical ability, intrinsic sense of rhythm, and charisma gained him fans from all over the world. As a solo performer, he never plays to a setlist and uses a minimum of effects onstage.<ref name=\"musicfrisk\" /> He usually completes studio recordings in one take.\n\n[[File:2024-09-18 Concert of Tommy Emmanuel and Mike Dawes at UdK Berlin Konzertsaal (Martin Rulsch) 163.jpg|thumb|Emmanuel uses a snare-drum brush to emulate the sound of a percussion kit]]\nIn his solo shows, he mainly plays guitars made by [[Maton]], an Australian guitar manufacturer. He usually travels with two custom Maton EBG808 TE models and one TE1 model, both of which are Tommy Emmanuel artist signature models.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://maton.com.au/product/te-series|title=The Maton TE Series - Maton Guitars Australia|access-date=19 September 2016}}</ref> He has played Maton guitars for most of his career and is somewhat of an ambassador for the company due to his long-standing association with the brand.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maton.com.au/artists/tommy-emmanuel|title=Tommy Emmanuel - Maton Guitars Australia|access-date=19 September 2016}}</ref> Emmanuel is known for the battered and worn-down appearances of his guitars; a result of his dynamic, energetic playing and percussive techniques. One of his signature performances, for example, involves striking the whole body of the guitar in various places with his hands or a drummer's [[Drum brush#Brushes|snare-drum brush]] to emulate the sound of a percussion kit.\n\nEmmanuel usually keeps one Maton EBG808 in standard guitar tuning (E-A-D-G-B-E), while he tunes his second Maton EBG808 to D-G-D-G-B-E (G6 tuning) and his TE1 to C{{music|sharp}}-F{{music|sharp}}-B-E-G{{music|sharp}}-C{{music|sharp}}. He generally uses 0.12 gauge (light) strings on one EBG808 and 0.13 gauge (medium) strings on the second Maton EBG808 and on the TE1. This allows him to quickly change tuning by swapping between guitars during a show if needed, rather than spending time onstage re-tuning one guitar.{{Cn|date=December 2023}}\n\nEmmanuel often curls his left thumb around the neck of the guitar onto the [[fretboard]] to play some notes, rather than using only his fingers to play \u2014 contrary to how classical guitarists play, but not unusual for jazz and country guitarists. He frequently plays common three-finger chord shapes with just two fingers. He commonly uses a [[thumbpick]], a flat pick ([[plectrum]]), his fingers, or a combination of these in his playing, a style known as [[hybrid picking]]. Amongst his trademark rapid virtuoso licks and cascading harmonic progressions, he often uses a technique that imitated an electric guitar's tremolo system on acoustic guitar \u2014 by pressing the palm of his right hand against the [[Sound board (music)|sound board]] of the guitar near the neck joint, while maintaining forward pressure with his left hand on the top of the [[headstock]]. The guitar neck slightly bends away from the body and consequently affects the pitch of the strings to achieve the desired sound.{{Cn|date=December 2023}}\n\n==Influences==\nAs a young man in Australia, Emmanuel wrote to his hero [[Chet Atkins]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. Eventually, Atkins replied with words of encouragement and a long-standing invitation to drop by to visit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://justjazzguitar.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=329&Itemid=52 |title=Just Jazz Guitar Online \u2013 Tommy Emmanuel Interview |publisher=Justjazzguitar.com |access-date=17 March 2013}}</ref>\n\nIn 1997, Emmanuel and Atkins recorded as a duo, releasing the album ''[[The Day Finger Pickers Took Over the World]]''. It would be Atkins's last album, with the exception of \"Solo Sessions\" which Atkins' estate released posthumously.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Chet Atkins: Solo Sessions|url=https://www.misterguitar.us/news/solorelease.html|access-date=2021-04-25|website=www.misterguitar.us}}</ref> Emmanuel and Atkins appeared together on [[The Nashville Network]]'s 'Country Christmas' in late 1997, and on that occasion, Atkins stated about him: \"He is one of the greatest guitar players I've ever seen.\" Atkins gave Emmanuel the guitar on which [[Arthur \"Guitar Boogie\" Smith]] recorded \"Guitar Boogie\", one of the foundation performances of the blues guitar world and a regular feature of Emmanuel's shows.\n\nIn July 1999, at the 15th Annual Chet Atkins Appreciation Society Convention,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.misterguitar.com/caas/index.html |title=The Chet Atkins Appreciation Society |publisher=Misterguitar.com |date=21 December 1997 |access-date=17 March 2013}}</ref> Atkins presented Emmanuel with a Certified Guitar Player award, an honour Chet personally bestowed to only four guitarists.<ref name=\"pritcher\" /> This award gains its fame from being bestowed by Atkins himself, a widely recognised leader in guitar music. The award states: \"In Recognition of His Contributions to the Art of Fingerpicking.\" Tommy performed at the Chet Atkins Appreciation Society (CAAS) in July each year in Nashville.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.modernguitars.com/archives/002881.html |title= Tommy Emmanuel Interview|website=www.modernguitars.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509135648/http://www.modernguitars.com/archives/002881.html |archive-date=9 May 2008}}</ref>\n\nIn addition to being influenced by Chet Atkins, Emmanuel has stated that he and his brother [[Phil Emmanuel]] were inspired by and modelled themselves on [[Hank Marvin]] and [[Bruce Welch]] of [[the Shadows]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Zollo |first1=Paul |title=Tommy Emmanuel: On Becoming \"The World's Greatest Living Guitarist\" |url=https://americansongwriter.com/tommy-emmanuel-on-becoming-the-worlds-greatest-living-guitarist/ |access-date=17 February 2022 |work=American Songwriter |date=20 August 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Tommy Emmanuel discography}}\n\n{{Div col|colwidth=20em}}\n* ''[[From Out of Nowhere (Tommy Emmanuel (2023)\n{{Div col end}}\n\n==Awards==\n===APRA Awards===\nThe [[APRA Awards (Australia)]] are annual awards to recognise composing and songwriting skills, sales, and airplay performance by its members annually.\n\n{|class=\"wikitable\"\n|- style=\"background:#ccc;\"\n!Year\n!Category\n!Nominated work\n!Result\n|-\n||[[APRA Music Awards of 1992|1992]]\n|Jazz Composition of the Year\n||\"[[Stevie's Blues]]\"\n|{{won}}\n|}\n\n===ARIA Awards===\nThe Australian Recording Industry Association Music Awards, commonly known as [[ARIA Music Awards]], are held to recognise excellence and innovation and achievement across all genres of Australian music. Award nominees and winners, excluding for sales and public voted categories, are selected by the ARIA Academy comprising \"judges from all sectors of the music industry\u2013retail, radio and tv, journalists and critics, television presenters, concert promoters, agents, ARIA member record companies and past ARIA winners\".<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120126003459/http://www.ariaawards.com.au/faqs/ ARIA Awards - FAQs]. ARIA Awards. Archived from [http://www.ariaawards.com.au/faqs/ the original] on 25 January 2012.</ref> The inaugural ARIA Awards took place in 1987.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120126020142/http://www.ariaawards.com.au/about/ Aria Awards overview]. Australian Recording Industry Association. Archived from [http://www.ariaawards.com.au/about/ the original] on 24 January 2012.</ref>\n\n{|class=\"wikitable\"\n|- style=\"background:#ccc;\"\n!Year\n!Category\n!Nominated work\n!Result\n|-\n||[[ARIA Music Awards of 1989|1989]]\n|[[ARIA Award for Best Cover Art|Best Cover Art]]\n||\"[[Up from Down Under]]\"\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n||[[ARIA Music Awards of 1991|1991]]\n|[[ARIA Award for Best Adult Contemporary Album|Best Adult Contemporary Album]]\n|''[[Dare to Be Different (album)|Dare to Be Different]]''\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n|rowspan=\"2\"|[[ARIA Music Awards of 1992|1992]]\n|Best Adult Contemporary Album\n|rowspan=\"2\"|''[[Determination (Tommy Emmanuel album)|Determination]]''\n|{{won}}\n|-\n|[[ARIA Award for Best Male Artist|Best Male Artist]]\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n||[[ARIA Music Awards of 1994|1994]]\n|Best Adult Contemporary Album\n|''[[The Journey (Tommy Emmanuel album)|The Journey]]''\n|{{won}}\n|-\n||[[ARIA Music Awards of 1995|1995]]\n|Best Adult Contemporary Album\n|''[[Terra Firma (Tommy Emmanuel album)|Terra Firma]]''\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n||[[ARIA Music Awards of 1996|1996]]\n|Best Adult Contemporary Album\n|''[[Classical Gas (Tommy Emmanuel album)|Classical Gas]]''\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n||[[ARIA Music Awards of 1997|1997]]\n|Best Adult Contemporary Album\n|''[[Can't Get Enough (Tommy Emmanuel album)|Can't Get Enough]]''\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n||[[ARIA Music Awards of 2013|2013]]\n|Best Jazz Album\n|''The Colonel & The Governor''\n|{{nom}}\n|}\n\n===Australian Roll of Renown===\nThe [[Australian Roll of Renown]] honours Australian and New Zealand musicians who have shaped the music industry by making a significant and lasting contribution to Country Music. It was inaugurated in 1976 and the inductee is announced at the [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] in Tamworth in January.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tcmf.com.au/roll-of-renown |title=Roll of Renown |publisher=Tamworth Country Music Festival|access-date=29 October 2020}}</ref>\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| 2011\n| Tommy Emmanuel\n| Australian Country Music Roll of Renown\n| {{yes2|inductee}}\n{{end}}\n\n===Country Music Awards of Australia===\nThe [[Country Music Awards of Australia]] (CMAA) (also known as the Golden Guitar Awards) is an annual awards night held in January during the [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]], celebrating recording excellence in the Australian country music industry. They have been held annually since 1973.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.country.com.au/awards/past-award-winners|title=Past Award Winners|access-date=2 November 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"CMAA2021\">{{cite web|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-01-23/golden-guitars-awards-fanny-lumsden-sweeps-awards-in-tamworth/13081696|title=Fanny Lumsden wins five Golden Guitar Awards despite cancelled Tamworth Country Music Festival|website=ABC|date=23 January 2021|access-date=24 January 2021}}</ref>\n\n{|class=\"wikitable\"\n|- style=\"background:#ccc;\"\n!Year\n!Category\n!Nominated work\n!Result\n|-\n||2005\n|Instrumental of the Year\n|\"Tall Fiddler\"\n|{{won}}\n|-\n||2007\n|Instrumental of the Year\n|\"Gameshow Rag/Cannonball Rag\"\n|{{won}}\n|-\n||2019\n|Instrumental of the Year\n|\"Wheelin' and Dealin'\"\n|{{won}}\n|-\n||2021\n|Bluegrass Recording of the Year\n|\"Finger Picking Good\" ([[Kristy Cox]] feat Tommy Emmanuel)\n|{{won}}\n|}\n\n===Grammy Awards===\nThe [[Grammy Awards]] is an annual award presentation by [[The Recording Academy]] to recognise achievement in the mainly English-language [[music industry]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/tommy-emmanuel|title=Grammy Awards Artist Tommy Emmanuel|publisher=Grammy|access-date=22 January 2018}}</ref>\n{|class=\"wikitable\"\n|- style=\"background:#ccc;\"\n!Year\n!Category\n!Nominated work\n!Result\n|-\n||[[40th Annual Grammy Awards|1998]]\n|[[Grammy Award for Best Country Instrumental Performance|Best Country Instrumental Performance]]\n|\"Smokey Mountain Lullaby\"\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n||[[49th Annual Grammy Awards|2006]]\n|[[Grammy Award for Best Country Instrumental Performance|Best Country Instrumental Performance]]\n|\"Gameshow Rag/Cannonball Rag\"\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n||[[66th Annual Grammy Awards|2024]]\n|[[Grammy Award for Best Arrangement, Instrumental or A Cappella|Best Arrangement, Instrumental or A Cappella]]\n|\"Folsom Prison Blues\"\n|{{won}}\n|}\n\n===Mo Awards===\nThe Australian Entertainment Mo Awards (commonly known informally as the [[Mo Awards]]), were annual Australian entertainment industry awards. They recognise achievements in live entertainment in Australia from 1975 to 2016. Tommy Emmanuel won two awards in that time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.moawards.com.au/awardwinners|title=MO Award Winners|website=Mo Awards|access-date=16 March 2022}}</ref>\n{{awards table}} (wins only)\n|-\n| 1994\n| Tommy Emmanuel\n| Australian Performer of the Year \n| {{won}}\n|-\n| 1996\n| Tommy Emmanuel\n| Australian Performer of the Year \n| {{won}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===National Live Music Awards===\nThe [[National Live Music Awards]] (NLMAs) are a broad recognition of Australia's diverse live industry, celebrating the success of the Australian live scene. The awards commenced in 2016.\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n| [[National Live Music Awards of 2019|2019]]<ref name=\"2019noms\">{{cite web|url=https://www.nlmas.com.au/2019/10/22/here-are-your-2019-national-live-music-awards-nominees/|title=HERE ARE YOUR 2019 NATIONAL LIVE MUSIC AWARDS NOMINEES!|website=NLMA|date=22 October 2020|access-date=5 September 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"2019wins\">{{cite web|url=https://www.nlmas.com.au/2019/12/05/and-the-winners-of-the-2019-national-live-music-awards-are/|title=AND THE WINNERS OF THE 2019 NATIONAL LIVE MUSIC AWARDS ARE\u2026\n|website=NLMA|date=5 December 2020|access-date=5 September 2020}}</ref>\n| Rosie Fitzgerald (I Know Leopard)\n| Live Guitarist of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n{{end}}\n\n===Lifetime Achievement Award===\nThe National Guitar Museum nominated Emmanuel for its annual \u201cLifetime Achievement\u201d Award in 2023.\n<ref>{{cite web | url=https://guitarinternational.com/2023/12/18/the-national-guitar-museum-announces-presentation-of-lifetime-achievement-award-to-tommy-emmanuel/ | title=The National GUITAR Museum Announces Presentation of \"Lifetime Achievement\" Award to Tommy Emmanuel }}</ref>\n\n==Bibliography==\n===Contributor===\n* {{cite book|year=2007|title=Laugh Even Louder!|author=Camp Quality|author-link=Camp Quality|publisher=[[Scholastic Corporation|Scholastic Australia Pty Limited]]|location=Gosford, New South Wales|contributor-last=Emmanuel|contributor-first=Tommy|contribution=Contributor|isbn=978-1-74169-022-4}}<ref>{{Cite book|title=Laugh Even Louder!|author=Camp Quality|author-link=Camp Quality|page=4|publisher=[[Scholastic Corporation|Scholastic Australia Pty Limited]]|location=Gosford, New South Wales|isbn=978-1-74169-022-4|date=2007}}</ref>\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n{{commons category|Tommy Emmanuel}}\n* [http://www.TommyEmmanuel.com Official site] \n* Wales]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Shane_Yellowbird","to":"Shane Yellowbird"}],"pages":{"11327291":{"pageid":11327291,"ns":0,"title":"Shane Yellowbird","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|Canadian country music singer-songwriter (1979\u20132022)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist|<!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name             = Shane Yellowbird\n| image            = Shane_Yellowbird.jpg\n| caption          = Yellowbird in 2009\n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = \n| alias            = \n| birth_date       = {{birth date|1979|07|07}}\n| birth_place      = [[Maskwacis|Maskwacis, Alberta]], Canada<br>(now [[Maskwacis]], Alberta)\n| death_date       = {{death date and age|2022|04|25|1979|07|07}}\n| death_place      = [[Calgary, Alberta]], Canada\n| Instruments      = \n| genre            = [[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation       = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active     = 2005&ndash;2022\n| label            = 306 Records, On Ramp\n| associated_acts  = \n| website          = \n| current_members  = \n| past_members     = \n}}\n'''Shane Yellowbird''' (July 7, 1979{{spnd}}April 25, 2022) was a Canadian [[country music]] singer-songwriter from [[Maskwacis|Maskwacis, Alberta]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.shaneyellowbird.com/bio.cfm |title=Shane Yellowbird Official Website :: Bio |accessdate=June 25, 2010 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100131080508/http://www.shaneyellowbird.com/bio.cfm |archivedate=January 31, 2010 }}</ref> A [[Cree]], in 2007, he was named the Aboriginal Entertainer of the Year at the Aboriginal People's Choice Music Awards, [[Chevrolet|Chevy Trucks]]' Rising Star of the Year at the [[Canadian Country Music Association|Canadian Country Music Awards]] and his song \"Pickup Truck\" was one of the year's ten most played country songs.\n\n==Early life==\nYellowbird was born in [[Maskwacis|Hobbema, Alberta]],<ref name=\"AllMusic bio\">{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/shane-yellowbird-mn0001044131/biography|title=Shane Yellowbird \u2013 Biography|first=Chris|last=True|work=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=April 27, 2022|archive-date=April 27, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220427205158/https://www.allmusic.com/artist/shane-yellowbird-mn0001044131/biography|url-status=live}}</ref> on 7 July 1979.<ref name=Banks>{{cite news|title=42-year-old Country music singer Shane Yellowbird passes away|url=https://www.wsmv.com/2022/04/27/42-year-old-country-music-singer-shane-yellowbird-passes-away/|first=Torrence|last=Banks|date=April 27, 2022|access-date=April 27, 2022|publisher=[[WSMV-TV]]|archive-date=April 27, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220427041532/https://www.wsmv.com/2022/04/27/42-year-old-country-music-singer-shane-yellowbird-passes-away/|url-status=live}}</ref> He attended Ponoka Composite High School.<ref name=Banks/> He suffered a severe [[stuttering]] problem as a child, for which he attended a [[speech therapy|speech therapist]] who suggested he sing his sentences. This method proved successful in treating him, and led to an interest in music.<ref name=\"CBC obit\">{{cite news|title='Trailblazer' Cree country artist Shane Yellowbird dead at 42|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/trailblazer-cree-country-artist-shane-yellowbird-dead-at-42-1.6431650|date=April 26, 2022|access-date=April 27, 2022|publisher=CBC News|archive-date=April 26, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220426230753/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/trailblazer-cree-country-artist-shane-yellowbird-dead-at-42-1.6431650|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=Mertz>{{cite news|title=Alberta country music singer-songwriter Shane Yellowbird passes away|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/8788997/alberta-country-singer-shane-yellowbird-dead-cree/|first=Emily|last=Mertz|date=April 26, 2022|access-date=April 27, 2022|publisher=Global News|archive-date=April 27, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220427205219/https://globalnews.ca/news/8788997/alberta-country-singer-shane-yellowbird-dead-cree/|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nYellowbird was signed by O'Reilly International in 2003.<ref name=Banks/>  Three years later, he released his debut album titled ''Life Is Calling My Name''.<ref>[http://www.shaneyellowbird.com/news.cfm?JournalID=6338 Yellowbird Releases Debut Album] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070209183218/http://www.shaneyellowbird.com/news.cfm?JournalID=6338 |date=February 9, 2007 }}</ref> The album includes the singles \"Beautiful Concept,\" \"They're All About You,\" \"Pickup Truck\" and \"I Remember the Music.\" In November 2006, Yellowbird won three awards at the Aboriginal People's Choice Music Awards ceremony, including Best New Artist, Single of the Year (\"Beautiful Concept\") and Best Video (\"Beautiful Concept\").<ref>[http://www.shaneyellowbird.com/news.cfm?JournalID=6337 Yellowbird Ropes 3 APCMA Awards] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070210011236/http://www.shaneyellowbird.com/news.cfm?JournalID=6337 |date=February 10, 2007 }}</ref>\n\nYellowbird opened for [[Emerson Drive]] on their cross-Canada tour,<ref>[http://www.shaneyellowbird.com/news.cfm?JournalID=10440 Shane Yellowbird to Tour with Emerson Drive] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070210011450/http://www.shaneyellowbird.com/news.cfm?JournalID=10440 |date=February 10, 2007 }}</ref> and was chosen to represent his native Canada by performing at the Fourth Annual Global Artist Party at the [[CMA Music Festival]] in June 2007.<ref>[http://www.shaneyellowbird.com/news.cfm?JournalID=14751 Yellowbird to Perform at CMA Music Festival in June] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928100559/http://www.shaneyellowbird.com/news.cfm?JournalID=14751 |date=September 28, 2007 }}</ref> Yellowbird was named the [[Chevrolet|Chevy Trucks]] Rising Star of the Year at the 2007 [[Canadian Country Music Association|Canadian Country Music Awards]].<ref name=\"CBC obit\"/><ref name=Amato>{{cite news|title='A truly beautiful soul': Alberta country artist Shane Yellowbird dies at age 42|url=https://edmonton.ctvnews.ca/a-truly-beautiful-soul-alberta-country-artist-shane-yellowbird-dies-at-age-42-1.5877193|first=Sean|last=Amato|date=April 26, 2022|access-date=April 27, 2022|publisher=CTV News|archive-date=April 26, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220426220642/https://edmonton.ctvnews.ca/a-truly-beautiful-soul-alberta-country-artist-shane-yellowbird-dies-at-age-42-1.5877193|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\n\"Pickup Truck,\" Yellowbird's third single, also became his first Top 5 song on the Canadian Country Singles chart in the summer of 2007. The song also peaked at No.&nbsp;64 on the all-genre [[Canadian Hot 100]], while the video topped the [[CMT (Canada)|CMT]] Chevy Top 20 in July.<ref>[http://www.thatscountry.com/am2/publish/Country_News_2/003753.shtml Shane Yellowbird's \"Pickup Truck\" No.&nbsp;1 Video in Canada] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071212222849/http://www.thatscountry.com/am2/publish/Country_News_2/003753.shtml |date=December 12, 2007 }}</ref> It was one of the ten most played country music songs of the year in Canada.<ref>[http://www.radioandrecords.com/Formats/Charts/YearEnd/07/Canada_Country_songs.asp R&R Top Canada Country Songs] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080305023257/http://www.radioandrecords.com/Formats/Charts/YearEnd/07/Canada_Country_songs.asp |date=March 5, 2008 }}</ref> Yellowbird opened the 2007 Aboriginal People's Choice Music Awards, starring with [[Lorne Cardinal]] and [[Gabrielle Miller]] of ''[[Corner Gas]]''.<ref>[http://www.shaneyellowbird.com/news.cfm?JournalID=15516 Shane Yellowbird to Open the Aboriginal Peoples Choice Music Awards with the \"Corner Gas\" crew] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080115164553/http://www.shaneyellowbird.com/news.cfm?JournalID=15516 |date=January 15, 2008 }}</ref> Later that evening, he was named the Aboriginal Entertainer of the Year.<ref>[http://www.shaneyellowbird.com/news.cfm?JournalID=15629 Shane Yellowbird Grabs \"Aboriginal Entertainer of the Year\" and More at the 2007 APCMA's] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071206044254/http://www.shaneyellowbird.com/news.cfm?JournalID=15629 |date=December 6, 2007 }}</ref> He also won awards for Best Country CD (''Life Is Calling My Name'') and Best Music Video (\"Pickup Truck\").<ref>{{cite news|title=Dion, LaBelle honoured|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/2007/11/05/dion_labelle_honoured.html|date=November 5, 2007|accessdate=April 27, 2022|newspaper=Toronto Star|archive-date=April 27, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220427205235/https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/2007/11/05/dion_labelle_honoured.html|url-status=live}}</ref>  Yellowbird later won three trophies at the 2007 Canadian Aboriginal Music Awards, including Best Male Artist, Best Country Album and Best Album of the Year (''Life Is Calling My Name'').<ref>[http://www.shaneyellowbird.com/news.cfm?JournalID=15667 Shane Yellowbird Big Winner at Canadian Aboriginal Music Awards] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071206000049/http://www.shaneyellowbird.com/news.cfm?JournalID=15667 |date=December 6, 2007 }}</ref>  He was also nominated for the 2008 [[Juno Award]] for Country Recording of the Year, for ''Life Is Calling My Name''.<ref name=Germano>{{cite news|title='Trailblazer' Cree country singer Shane Yellowbird dead at age 42|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/music/2022/04/26/trailblazer-cree-country-singer-shane-yellowbird-dead-at-age-42.html|first=Daniela|last=Germano|date=April 26, 2022|accessdate=April 27, 2022|newspaper=Toronto Star|agency=The Canadian Press|archive-date=April 27, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220427005755/https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/music/2022/04/26/trailblazer-cree-country-singer-shane-yellowbird-dead-at-age-42.html|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nYellowbird's second album, ''It's About Time'' was released on November 17, 2009, featuring the single, \"Bare Feet on the Blacktop\".<ref name=Mertz/>  In the United States, the video received a nomination from the Native American Music Association.  Yellowbird won two Native American Music Awards for Best Country Recording for \"Life Is Calling My Name\" in 2011 and won Best Country Recording for \"It's About Time\" in 2012.<ref name=NAMA11>{{cite web|title=Eleventh Annual Award Winners|url=https://nativeamericanmusicawards.com/nama-11|accessdate=April 27, 2022|publisher=Native American Music Awards|archive-date=August 13, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210813182639/https://nativeamericanmusicawards.com/nama-11|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=NAMA12>{{cite web|title=The 12th Annual Native American Music Awards|url=https://nativeamericanmusicawards.com/nama-12|accessdate=April 27, 2022|publisher=Native American Music Awards|archive-date=November 25, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211125014413/https://nativeamericanmusicawards.com/nama-12|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nAt the time of his death, Yellowbird was in a [[domestic partnership]] with fianc\u00e9e Sarah Garrow.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Tributes and candlelight vigils for Cree country singer Shane Yellowbird |url=https://edmontonjournal.com/entertainment/local-arts/tributes-and-candlelight-vigils-for-cree-country-singer-shane-yellowbird |access-date=2022-05-03 |website=edmontonjournal |language=en-CA}}</ref> The couple announced their engagement hours before his death was announced. He had four children.<ref name=Mertz/> He suffered from [[epilepsy]] and had occasional [[seizure]]s.<ref name=Mertz/><ref name=\"CBC obit\"/><ref name=Amato/>\n\nYellowbird died on April 25, 2022, in [[Calgary]].  He was 42 years old.<ref name=Mertz/><ref name=\"CBC obit\"/>\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:14em;\"| Title\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Dianna_Corcoran","to":"Dianna Corcoran"}],"pages":{"30939848":{"pageid":30939848,"ns":0,"title":"Dianna Corcoran","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name         = Dianna Corcoran\n| image        = Dianna Corcoran.jpg\n| alt          =\n| caption      = Corcoran performing in 2010\n| image_size   =\n| birth_name   = Dianna Elizabeth Corcoran\n| birth_date   = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1979|6|20}}\n| birth_place  = [[Parkes, New South Wales]], Australia\n| instrument   = Vocals, guitar\n| genre        = Country music\n| occupation   = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active = 2003\u2013present\n| label        =\n| website      = [http://diannacorcoran.com/ diannacorcoran.com]\n}}\n\n'''Dianna Elizabeth Corcoran''' (born 20 June 1979 in [[Parkes, New South Wales]])<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/diannacorcoran/4171288376/|title=Mum (Jann) and baby Dianna in Hospital|date=8 December 2009|work=flickr.com|accessdate=20 May 2011}}</ref> is an Australian country music singer-songwriter. Among numerous awards, she is a three-time [[Country Music Awards of Australia|Golden Guitar]] winner\n\n==History==\nCorcoran's initial interest in country music involved [[yodelling]]. After finishing high school, Corcoran moved to Adelaide where she worked in three jobs (recruitment, dog food factory and car parts plant)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.country.com.au/links-contacts/country-contacts/127-corcoran-dianna|title=Dianna Corcoran|date=6 July 2010|work=country.com.au|accessdate=21 February 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110315165722/http://country.com.au/links-contacts/country-contacts/127-corcoran-dianna|archive-date=15 March 2011|url-status=dead}}</ref> to save enough money to make her first record (''Little Bit Crazy''). She became a professional musician in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/tv/programs/landline/old-site/content/2004/s1189932.htm|title=Gympie Muster goes from strength to strength|last=Lee|first=Tim|date=5 September 2004|work=abc.net.au|accessdate=28 December 2018}}</ref> In that year, she toured with [[Adam Brand (musician)|Adam Brand]] as an [[opening act]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/tasmania/stories/s1202879.htm|title=Adam Brand gets louder|last=Cox|first=Tim|date=20 September 2004|work=abc.net.au|accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref> It was also in that year that she won her first Golden Guitar Award for New Talent of the Year.\n\nCorcoran has been deployed on three occasions to perform for Australian troops on active duty in war zones around the world, including a tour of Afghanistan with [[Jenny Morris (musician)|Jenny Morris]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jennymorris.com/?p=353|title=The FACE tour: Images|last=Morris|first=Jenny|date=29 September 2009|work=jennymorris.com|accessdate=20 February 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713101857/http://www.jennymorris.com/?p=353|archive-date=13 July 2011|url-status=dead}}</ref> During one such tour to the [[Solomon Islands]] in March 2007 she met Tom Hinds, an Australian soldier. Corcoran wrote the song \"Come Back Home\" on the album ''Keep Breathing'' for him. She has written other songs about family and childhood experiences, including her father (\"If You Hear Angels\"), her mother (\"You'll Always Love Me More\") and her hometown Parkes (\"Rocky Hill\").<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.capitalnews.com.au/editorial.asp?editorial_id=1747|title=Twists and Turns|last=Jarvis|first=Susan|year=2011|work=capitalnews.com.au|accessdate=20 February 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706102524/http://www.capitalnews.com.au/editorial.asp?editorial_id=1747|archive-date=6 July 2011|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nIn 2008, Corcoran won Female Artist of the Year.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/news/local/news/general/awards-ceremony-a-singing-spectacular/287367.aspx|title=Awards ceremony a singing spectacular|last=Belt|first=Rebecca|date=28 January 2008|work=northerndailyleader.com.au|accessdate=20 February 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706110607/http://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/news/local/news/general/awards-ceremony-a-singing-spectacular/287367.aspx|archive-date=6 July 2011|url-status=dead}}</ref> In August, Corcoran was invited by [[Deborah Conway]] to take part in the Broad Festival project, which toured major Australian cities including performing at the Sydney Opera House.<ref name=\"Elliott\">{{Cite news | url = http://www.smh.com.au/news/music/ladys-night-at-the-beckoning-microphone/2008/08/18/1218911561072.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap1 | title = Lady's Night at the Beckoning Microphone | last = Elliott | first = Tim | newspaper = The Sydney Morning Herald | publisher = Fairfax Media | date = 19 August 2008 | accessdate = 5 June 2011 }}</ref> With Corcoran and Conway were [[Laura Jean]], [[Liz Stringer]] and [[Elana Stone]] \u2013 they performed their own and each other's songs.<ref name=\"Broad2008\">{{Cite web | url = http://www.broadfestival.com/ | title = Broad 2008 | publisher = Broad Festival | accessdate = 5 June 2011 | url-status = usurped | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110511080719/http://www.broadfestival.com/ | archivedate = 11 May 2011 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>\n\n==Discography ==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\" border=\"1\"\n|+ List of studio albums, with Australian positions \n! scope=\"col\" | Title\n! scope=\"col\" | Details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\" | ''Little Bit Crazy''\n|\n* Released: 2004\n* Label: Compass Brothers\n|-\n! scope=\"row\" | ''Then There's Me''\n|\n* Released: January 2007\n* Label: Compass Brothers (031CDCB)\n|-\n! scope=\"row\" | ''Keep Breathing''\n|\n* Released: 16 January 2010\n* Label: Dianna Corcoran  (DC10003)\n|-\n! scope=\"row\" | ''In America''\n|\n* Released: 29 January 2016\n* Label: Compass Brothers\n|}\n\n==Awards and web|url=http://www.rivetingriffs.com/Dianna%20Corcoran%20Interview%20page%20one.html|title=Dianna Corcoran Says \u2013 Wrong
